  • Copyright Page 版权页
  • Acknowledgements 致谢
  • Epigraph 题词
  • Foreword 前言
  • PART I - My Standard of Performance: An Environment of Excellence 第一部分——我的绩效标准：追求卓越的环境
    • How to Know if You’re Doing the Job 如何判断你是否胜任这份工作
    • Coaches Aren’t Supposed to Cry: Survive One Minute at a Time 教练不该哭：一分钟一分钟地熬过去
    • My Standard of Performance: High Requirements for Actions and Attitudes 我的工作标准：对行为和态度有很高的要求
    • An Organization Has a Conscience 一个组织是有良知的。
    • Specifics of My New Standards 我的新标准的具体细节
    • The Prime Directive Was Not Victory 最高指令并非胜利
    • The Top Priority Is Teaching 教学是重中之重。
    • Winners Act Like Winners (Before They’re Winners) 成功者在成为成功者之前就展现出成功者的行为。
    • Seek to Be Near the Summit 力争靠近山顶
    • Establishing Your Standard of Performance 确立你的绩效标准
    • How I Avoid Becoming a Victim of Myself 我如何避免成为自己的受害者
    • THE WALSH WAY - The Organization Man 沃尔什之道——组织人
  • PART II - Success Is Not Spelled G-E-N-I-U-S: Innovation, Planning, and Common Sense 第二部分——成功并非靠天才：创新、规划和常识
    • Opportunity Is in the Eye of the Beholder 机会在于观察者的眼中。
    • The West Coast Offense: From Checkers to Chess 西海岸进攻体系：从跳棋到国际象棋
    • Lessons of the Bill Walsh Offense 比尔·沃尔什进攻体系的经验教训
    • Welcome Skeptics to Your Team 欢迎怀疑论者加入您的团队
    • Share the Glory 分享荣耀
    • Write Your Own Script for Success: Flying by the Seat of Your Pants (Is No Way ... 书写你自己的成功剧本：凭感觉行事（绝对行不通……）
    • Control What You Can Control: Let the Score Take Care of Itself 掌控你能掌控的：让分数自然而然地变化。
    • Protect Your Blind Side: The Leadership Two-Step: Move/Countermove 保护你的盲点：领导力两步法：行动/反击
    • The Archaeology of Leadership: Seek Reward in the Ruins 领导力考古学：在废墟中寻找回报
    • THE WALSH WAY - The Problem Solver 华尔街之道——问题解决者
  • PART III - Fundamentals of Leadership: Concepts, Conceits, and Conclusions 第三部分——领导力基础：概念、假设和结论
    • “I Am the Leader!” “我是领导者！”
    • The Common Denominator of Leadership: Strength of Will 领导力的共同要素：意志力
    • Be Wrong for the Right Reasons 为正确的理由而犯错
    • Protect Your Turf 保护你的草坪
    • Be a Leader—Twelve Habits Plus One 成为领导者——十二个习惯加一个
    • Sweat the Right Small Stuff: Sharp Pencils Do Not Translate into Sharp Performance 注重细节：削尖的铅笔并不等同于出色的表现
    • Good Leadership Percolates Down 优秀的领导力自下而上地发挥作用。
    • Nameless, Faceless Objects 无名无面物体
    • The Rules May Change, But the Game Goes On: I Strike Out the First Time, Not ... 规则或许会变，但游戏仍在继续：我第一次出局，并非……
    • You Must Have a Hard Edge 你必须有棱角
    • The Inner Voice vs. the Outer Voice 内心的声音与外在的声音
    • Montana’s Leadership by Example: Cool, Calm, and Collected 蒙大拿州的领导力以身作则：冷静沉着
    • Don’t Let Anybody Call You a Genius 别让任何人称你为天才
    • The Leverage of Language 语言的杠杆作用
    • Don’t Beat Around the Bush (When Describing a Bush) （描述灌木丛时）不要拐弯抹角
    • Don’t Mistake Grabbin’ for Tackling 不要把抓取误认为是擒抱
    • Communication Creates Collaboration: Big Ears Are Better Than Big Egos 沟通促进合作：倾听胜于自负
    • Be a King Without a Crown 做一位没有王冠的国王
    • Create Uncertainty 制造不确定性
    • Play with Poise 沉着冷静地比赛
    • Teaching Defines Your Leadership 教学塑造你的领导力
    • The Thrill of Teaching 教学的乐趣
    • THE WALSH WAY - The House Cleaner 沃尔什之道——家政清洁工
  • PART IV - Essentials of a Winning Team: People, Priorities, and Performance 第四部分——制胜团队的要素：人员、优先事项和绩效
    • Money Talks. Treating People Right Talks Louder. 金钱固然重要，但善待他人更有说服力。
    • You’re as Good as Your Good People 你的好人越多，你的好人就越多。
    • The Over and Under: The Art of Managing Confidence 自信的艺术：高低起伏
    • The Under: Strive to Be a One-Point Underdog 看好小分：力争成为一分劣势方
    • Seek Character. Beware Characters. 寻找品格，警惕人品。
    • A Big Cheer for a Big Ego 为自大狂欢呼
    • The Bottom 20 Percent May Determine Your Success 最终决定你成败的，可能是那20%的人群。
    • Avoid the Dance of the Doomed 避免跳那注定失败的舞蹈
    • Use the Four Most Powerful Words 运用四个最有力量的词语
    • Extreme Effort Requires Extreme Prudence 极致的努力需要极致的谨慎
    • The Bubba Diet: You Can’t Transplant Willpower 布巴减肥法：意志力无法移植
    • “Conventional Wisdom” Is an Oxymoron “传统智慧”本身就是一个自相矛盾的说法。
    • Make Friends, Not Enemies: Al Davis, Howard Cosell, and Monday Night Football 广交朋友，而非树敌：艾尔·戴维斯、霍华德·科塞尔和周一晚间橄榄球赛
    • Hold on Until Help Arrives: Keep Your Boss in the Loop 坚持到救援到来：随时向你的老板汇报情况
    • Keep Your Eye on the Ball 盯紧球
    • Make Your Own Mentors: A PhD from the University of Paul Brown, et al. 打造你自己的导师：保罗·布朗等人的博士论文
    • THE WALSH WAY - The Fog Cutter 沃尔什路——雾之切割者
  • PART V - Thin Skin, Baloney, and “The Star-Spangled Banner”: Looking for ... 第五部分——薄皮、胡说八道和《星条旗永不落》：寻找……
    • How You Get Good: No Mystery to Mastery 如何变得优秀：精通之道并不神秘
    • Sine Qua Non: Your Work Ethic—What William Archibald Walsh Taught His Son 必要条件：你的职业道德——威廉·阿奇博尔德·沃尔什教给他的儿子
    • The Perfection of the Puzzle 拼图的完美之处
    • The Gladiator Mentality: Get Your Mind Right 角斗士心态：调整好你的心态
    • I Never Sang “The Star-Spangled Banner” 我从未唱过《星条旗永不落》
    • My Strengths? 我的优势？
    • Unleash Mentors: Tell Your Team to Teach 释放导师潜能：让你的团队去教导
    • Don’t Do unto Others (What Paul Brown Did unto Me) 不要以牙还牙（就像保罗·布朗对我做的那样）
    • Nine Steps for a Healthy Heart 九个步骤，助您拥有健康的心脏
    • Seriously, Don’t Be Too Serious 说真的，别太严肃
    • The Last Word on Getting in the Last Word 关于如何发表最后发言的最后意见
    • Thinly Sliced Baloney (Can Make a Good Sandwich) 薄切博洛尼亚香肠（可以做成美味的三明治）
    • Surprising News Re: The Element of Surprise 关于“出其不意”元素的惊人消息
    • Don’t Delay Delegating (Famous Last Words: “I’ll Do It Myself”) 不要拖延授权（临终遗言：“我自己来做”）
    • Cut Your Losses Before They Cut You 趁他们还没把你甩掉，赶紧止损。
    • Look Below the Surface: There’s More Than Meets the Eye 透过表象看本质：远不止表面所见
    • A Pretty Package Can’t Sell a Poor Product 精美的包装卖不出去劣质产品。
    • Zero Points for Winning (Means You’re Losing) 赢了得零分（意味着你输了）
    • What Do I Miss Least? 我最不怀念的是什么？
    • What Do I Miss Most? 我最怀念的是什么？
    • Quick Results Come Slowly: The Score Takes Care of Itself 快速见效需要时间：分数会慢慢提升。
    • THE WALSH WAY - A Complex Man. A Simple Goal. 沃尔什之道——一个复杂的人，一个简单的目标。
  • Index 指数

What Do I Miss Most? 我最怀念的是什么？

THE WALSH WAY - A Complex Man. A Simple Goal. 沃尔什之道——一个复杂的人，一个简单的目标。

在不限制上述版权保留权利的前提下，未经本书版权所有者和上述出版商事先书面许可，不得以任何形式或任何方式（电子、机械、影印、录音或其他方式）复制、存储于检索系统或传播本出版物的任何部分。

Acknowledgments 致谢

Craig Walsh

克雷格·沃尔什

My father would want to acknowledge and thank Eddie DeBartolo Jr., the only owner who had the foresight and courage to give Bill Walsh a chance to be a head coach in the NFL.
我的父亲会感谢小埃迪·德巴托罗，他是唯一一位有远见和勇气的老板，给了比尔·沃尔什一个在 NFL 担任主教练的机会。
He would also want to express his deep dedication and appreciation to all the people who wore the San Francisco 49er uniform both on the field or off—the entire organization who helped make a dream come true.
他还想向所有身穿旧金山49人队队服的人，无论是在场上还是场下，表达他深深的敬意和感激之情——感谢整个组织帮助他实现了梦想。
I would also like to dedicate our book to my children, Nate and Saman tha. I know their grandfather is very proud of them just as they are proud of him. This book is also dedicated to my mother, Geri, my sister, Elizabeth, and the memory of my brother, Steve.
我还要将这本书献给我的孩子们，内特和萨曼塔。我知道他们的祖父会为他们感到非常骄傲，就像他们也为祖父感到骄傲一样。这本书也献给我的母亲格里、我的妹妹伊丽莎白，以及我已故的哥哥史蒂夫。

Steve Jamison

史蒂夫·贾米森

The Score Takes Care of Itself is dedicated with a lot of love to my mother, Mary Jean Edstrom. And, to my father, Everett, his brother, Harold, and their friend Roger Busdicker who created magic when they created Hal Leonard Publishing—my introduction to the world of publishing. Also, to Bill Walsh, Coach John Wooden, Uncle Roy Stark, David Varner, Aunt Jo Edstrom. And, lest we forget, the great publishing mind of Jeffrey Krames made it all happen.
谨以此书献给我挚爱的母亲玛丽·简·埃德斯特罗姆。同时，也献给我的父亲埃弗雷特、他的兄弟哈罗德，以及他们的朋友罗杰·布斯迪克，他们共同创立了哈尔·伦纳德出版社，创造了奇迹——正是这家出版社引领我进入了出版界。此外，还要感谢比尔·沃尔什、约翰·伍登教练、罗伊·斯塔克叔叔、大卫·瓦纳、乔·埃德斯特罗姆阿姨。当然，我们也不能忘记杰弗里·克雷姆斯这位伟大的出版家，是他成就了这一切。

Running a football franchise is not unlike running any other business: You start first with a structural format and basic philosophy and then find the people who can implement it. 经营一家足球俱乐部与经营其他任何企业并无二致：首先要制定结构模式和基本理念，然后找到能够执行这些理念的人。
—BILL WALSH
——比尔·沃尔什

A Leader’s Book for Leaders 领导者的指南
Craig Walsh
克雷格·沃尔什







My father, Bill Walsh, was one of the NFL’s pivotal figures, a leader, head coach, and general manager whose innovations changed the way football is played and whose San Francisco 49er dynasty—five Super Bowl championships in fourteen years—ranks among the great achievements in sports history. The Score Takes Care of Itself is his very personal and, at times, painful account of the leadership lessons he learned during his life as well as his conclusions on how they might be useful in overcoming your own challenges as a leader.
我的父亲比尔·沃尔什是美国国家橄榄球联盟（NFL）的关键人物之一，他是一位领袖、主教练和总经理，他的创新改变了橄榄球的比赛方式，他带领旧金山49人队在14年内五次夺得超级碗冠军，这一王朝成就堪称体育史上的伟大成就之一。《比分自有分晓》是他非常个人化，有时甚至略带痛苦地讲述他一生中汲取的领导经验，以及他总结出的这些经验如何能帮助其他领导者克服自身挑战的感悟。
Obviously, every profession has many elements unique unto itself. Nevertheless, when it comes to the fundamentals of effective leadership in the context of human nature and managing people, there are great parallels among the NFL, corporate America, or a grocery store with twelve employees. At least, Bill Walsh thought so.
显然，每个行业都有许多其独特的要素。然而，就有效领导力的基本要素而言，尤其是在人性层面和人员管理方面，NFL（美国国家橄榄球联盟）、美国企业界，甚至一家只有十二名员工的杂货店之间，都存在着许多共通之处。至少，比尔·沃尔什是这么认为的。
The applicability of what he did in the NFL to the world of business is attested to by the fact that many CEOs in Silicon Valley and elsewhere not only were among his friends but also sought his advice and invited him to speak about leadership to their executive teams. After his retirement as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, he did the same at Stanford University, where he gave lectures on leadership to graduate students at the business school. The Harvard Business Review, Forbes, and other magazines and business publications regularly came to him for ideas on team building and leadership beyond the context of football.
他在NFL的经验同样适用于商业领域，这一点可以从以下事实得到印证：硅谷及其他地区的许多CEO不仅是他的朋友，还经常向他寻求建议，并邀请他为他们的管理团队讲授领导力课程。从旧金山49人队主教练的职位上退休后，他又在斯坦福大学商学院为研究生讲授领导力课程。《哈佛商业评论》、《福布斯》以及其他杂志和商业出版物也经常向他请教关于团队建设和领导力方面的见解，而不仅仅局限于橄榄球领域。
You might wonder about the origins of the title. The Score Takes Care of Itself was one of my dad’s oft-told sayings. Do all the right things to precision and “the score will take care of itself” sums up my father’s philosophy, which is why we thought it the perfect title for his book.
你或许会好奇书名的由来。“乐谱自会水到渠成”是我父亲常说的一句话。把所有该做的事情都做到精准到位，“乐谱自会水到渠成”概括了我父亲的人生哲学，所以我们觉得这句话非常适合作为他这本书的书名。
It is the ultimate guidebook to the Bill Walsh philosophy and methodology of leadership and is drawn from my father’s revealing and extensive conversations on the subject with best-selling author Steve Jamison. We have also utilized my father’s private notes, including those for his lectures at the Stanford Graduate School of Business and video- and audiotapes of talks that he gave to the 49ers, as well as intimate conversations I had with him over his years as head coach about how he was doing it—and what it was doing to him.
本书是比尔·沃尔什领导理念和方法论的终极指南，取材于我父亲与畅销书作家史蒂夫·贾米森就此主题进行的深入而富有启发性的对话。此外，我们还参考了我父亲的私人笔记，包括他在斯坦福商学院的讲稿、他为旧金山49人队所做的演讲的录像和录音，以及在他担任主教练期间，我与他进行的关于他如何执教以及这种执教方式对他自身影响的私密谈话。
Additionally, we’ve included concise but revealing and frank opinions about my father from five key “players” in his professional life, each chosen for a specific reason:
1. Joe Montana was the quarterback whom my father drafted in his first year as head coach at San Francisco. Joe was at the helm for all of the Super Bowl championships coached by my father, and his comments on how Bill Walsh could make dreams come true, “His Standard of Performance,” is a master’s analysis of a master and the foreword for the book.
2. John McVay, vice president and director of football operations for my father, offers insights into the great skills Bill Walsh exhibited when it came to getting the right people on the same page of the same book—a book written by Bill Walsh. “The Organization Man” is John’s overview of the superb organization he saw put in place very quickly by the new coach, who could see a connection between wearing a tie and winning a Super Bowl.
3. Mike White was one of my father’s true pals, a fellow assistant coach at the University of California-Berkeley who later worked for him in the beginning at San Francisco. Mike labored with Bill Walsh professionally at those two crucial points in his career and understood him inside and out. “The Problem Solver” is his description of the “spectacular” creative and analytical skills he saw demonstrated right from the beginning. Bill Walsh had very few intimate friends, but Mike White was one of those guys.
4. Bill McPherson was a defensive assistant coach through the entire decade that Bill Walsh was at the helm of the 49ers, an insider who saw firsthand how my father came in and cleaned house. If you didn’t “get with the program,” as defined by Bill Walsh, you were gone. “The House Cleaner” is Bill McPherson’s description of those rough early months when Bill Walsh started building a dynasty by dismantling a disaster.
5. Randy Cross, a great offensive lineman and now a top CBS football analyst, was a member of the San Francisco 49ers for thirteen years, including his first three, which were pre -Bill Walsh seasons. He was chosen because he experienced, as a player, what life was like on the worst team in the NFL and how Bill Walsh transformed it into the best. “The Fog Cutter” is Randy’s keen perspective on the tumultuous events that were part of the creation of a dynasty by his new head coach and general manager.
此外，我们还收录了五位在我父亲职业生涯中扮演关键角色的人物对我父亲的简洁而深刻的评价，每位人物的入选都有其特定原因：1. 乔·蒙塔纳是我父亲在旧金山担任主教练的第一年选中的四分卫。乔带领球队赢得了我父亲执教期间的所有超级碗冠军，他对比尔·沃尔什如何实现梦想的评价——《他的绩效标准》——堪称大师对大师的精辟分析，也是本书的前言。2. 约翰·麦克维，我父亲的副总裁兼足球运营总监，他深入剖析了比尔·沃尔什在让合适的人齐心协力方面所展现的卓越才能——而这本“书”正是由比尔·沃尔什自己撰写的。《组织大师》是约翰对这位新教练迅速建立起来的卓越组织的概述，这位教练似乎看到了领带与赢得超级碗之间的联系。3.迈克·怀特是我父亲的挚友之一，他曾是加州大学伯克利分校的助理教练，后来在旧金山49人队初期也曾为我父亲效力。在比尔·沃尔什职业生涯的两个关键时期，迈克都曾与他并肩作战，对他了如指掌。“问题解决者”是他对沃尔什从一开始就展现出的“卓越”创造力和分析能力的评价。比尔·沃尔什的知己好友寥寥无几，但迈克·怀特就是其中之一。4. 比尔·麦克弗森在比尔·沃尔什执教49人队的整个十年里都是球队的防守助理教练，他亲眼目睹了我父亲是如何接手并彻底整顿球队的。如果你不“融入球队”（用比尔·沃尔什的话来说），你就得走人。“大扫除者”是比尔·麦克弗森对沃尔什执教初期那段艰难岁月的描述，当时他通过拆解一个烂摊子来建立王朝。5.兰迪·克罗斯曾是一名出色的进攻锋线球员，如今是哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）的顶级橄榄球评论员。他曾在旧金山49人队效力十三年，其中包括他职业生涯的前三年，也就是比尔·沃尔什执教之前的那三年。之所以选择他，是因为他作为球员亲身经历了NFL垫底球队的艰辛，以及比尔·沃尔什如何将这支球队打造成联盟最佳。在《拨开迷雾》一书中，兰迪以敏锐的视角，讲述了这位新任主教练兼总经理如何打造王朝的种种动荡历程。
These five, all important figures in my father’s life, were asked to contribute their analyses of the leadership philosophy of Bill Walsh to complement and expand on the comprehensive lessons my father offers in The Score Takes Care of Itself. Others certainly were well qualified, but these five were asked and kindly accepted the invitation to more fully explain the “genius” of Bill Walsh.
这五位都是我父亲生命中的重要人物，我们邀请他们分析比尔·沃尔什的领导理念，以补充和拓展我父亲在《得分自有分晓》（The Score Takes Care of Itself）一书中提出的全面见解。当然，其他人也完全有资格，但我们邀请了这五位，他们欣然接受了邀请，更深入地阐释比尔·沃尔什的“天才之处”。
Nevertheless, there is only one person who can fully articulate what he did, why it worked, and how it may benefit you as a leader; namely, Bill Walsh. In his own words, this book is his explanation.
然而，只有一个人能够完整地阐述他所做的一切、其成功的原因以及它如何使你作为一名领导者受益；这个人就是比尔·沃尔什。本书正是他用自己的语言所作的解释。
My father’s journey was arduous, but his dream was big: Bill Walsh wanted to be a successful head coach in the NFL more than anything else in the world. As he moved his family back and forth across the country, he chased his dream, from the Oakland Raiders and the San Jose Apaches to the Cincinnati Bengals, San Diego Chargers, and Stanford University. Ultimately, the dream came true: head coach of the San Francisco 49ers. The lessons he learned he wanted to share. My father is no longer with us, but I know he would be proud that his hard-earned lessons are now available in his book, The Score Takes Care of Itself.
我父亲的人生旅程艰辛无比，但他怀揣着远大的梦想：比尔·沃尔什最大的愿望就是成为一名成功的NFL主教练。为了追逐梦想，他带着家人辗转于美国各地，从奥克兰突袭者队、圣何塞阿帕奇队到辛辛那提猛虎队、圣地亚哥闪电队，再到斯坦福大学，他始终不渝。最终，梦想成真：他成为了旧金山49人队的主教练。他渴望分享自己一路走来的经验教训。父亲已经离世，但我知道，如果他还在世，他一定会为他毕生积累的经验如今汇集成书《比分自有分晓》（The Score Takes Care of Itself）而感到骄傲。

FOREWORD 前言
His Standard of Performance 他的表现标准
Joe Montana
乔·蒙塔纳







I never saw a regular-season NFL game in person until I was a player in the NFL—watching from the sidelines as a rookie backup quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers during a game against the Minnesota Vikings. It was my first game as a pro. Bill Walsh was my coach.
在我成为NFL球员之前，我从未现场观看过NFL常规赛——当时我作为旧金山49人队的新秀替补四分卫，在场边观看了一场对阵明尼苏达维京人队的比赛。那是我职业生涯的第一场比赛。我的教练是比尔·沃尔什。
We lost that game to the Vikings (28-22) as well as thirteen of our next fifteen games; fans were unhappy, and critics were howling and having a field day at our expense because all they could see was our 2-14 won-lost record. But I had my own opinion: Bill Walsh was special.
我们输给了维京人队（22比28），接下来的十五场比赛也输了十三场；球迷们很不高兴，评论家们更是对我们大加挞伐，因为他们看到的只是我们2胜14负的战绩。但我有自己的看法：比尔·沃尔什很特别。
His mind for technical football was extraordinary, but beyond that was his ability to organize and manage his staff, players, everybody—to get the whole organization on exactly the same page. On that page he set the standard for how he wanted things done, and his standard was simple: perfection. That’s what he taught us individually and as a group—to believe it could be achieved and then achieve it (or come close). He had in his mind this ideal—an image of perfect football—coupled with the nuts-and-bolts details of how to accomplish it, which he then taught.
他对足球技术的理解非同凡响，但更重要的是他卓越的组织和管理能力，他能够带领团队、球员以及所有人朝着同一个方向前进。在这个方向上，他设定了自己期望的行事标准，而他的标准很简单：完美。他教导我们每个人，也教导我们整个团队——相信完美可以实现，然后去实现它（或者至少接近完美）。他心中有一个理想——一个完美的足球蓝图——并结合了实现它的具体细节，然后将这些细节传授给我们。
That, in my opinion, was his primary leadership asset: his ability to teach people how to think and play at a different and much higher, and, at times, perfect level. He accomplished this in three ways: (1) he had a tremendous knowledge of all aspects of the game and a visionary approach to offense; (2) he brought in a great staff and coaches who knew how to coach, how to complement his own teaching of what we needed to know to rise to his standard of performance; and (3) he taught us to hate mistakes.
在我看来，他最主要的领导才能在于：他能够教会人们如何以更高、更卓越的方式思考和比赛，有时甚至达到完美境界。他通过三种方式实现了这一点：(1) 他对比赛的各个方面都拥有渊博的知识，并且对进攻有着极具远见的构想；(2) 他组建了一支优秀的教练团队，这些教练不仅懂得如何执教，还能与他相辅相成，帮助我们达到他设定的竞技标准；(3) 他教会我们痛恨错误。
Bill got all of us striving to be perfect in games and practice. (You didn’t want to see any balls on the ground, no fumbles, no mistakes, no turnovers.) Without all the screaming that coaches usually do, he was very focused and demanding because he was making you test yourself, take yourself to different limits. He said that if you aim for perfection and miss, you’re still pretty good, but if you aim for mediocre and miss? Well, he didn’t allow us to think like that.
比尔让我们所有人都在比赛和训练中力求完美。（你不想看到任何球掉在地上、任何掉球、任何失误、任何失误。）他不像其他教练那样大吼大叫，而是非常专注且要求严格，因为他要我们挑战自我，突破极限。他说，如果你追求完美却没能做到，你仍然很优秀；但如果你追求平庸却没能做到呢？他不允许我们这样想。
That was the thing about his perspective: Being really good wasn’t good enough. He taught us to want to be perfect and instilled in the team a hunger for improvement, a drive to get better and better. We saw his own hunger for perfection, and it was contagious.
这就是他的独特视角：仅仅优秀还不够。他教会我们追求完美，并在团队中灌输了对进步的渴望，一种不断提升自我的动力。我们看到了他自己对完美的执着，这种执着也感染了我们。
In fact, that was the biggest challenge in playing for Bill—trying to be perfect. It applied to everyone on the team, everyone in the organization, but it seemed like it especially applied to his quarterback. He expected a lot from his quarterback.
事实上，为比尔效力最大的挑战就是力求完美。这适用于球队里的每一个人，整个俱乐部的每一个人，但似乎对他的四分卫要求尤其高。他对四分卫寄予厚望。
Bill just assumed I was supposed to be great and didn’t praise me routinely. The quarterback didn’t get the game ball, didn’t get a load of compliments. Win a Super Bowl? Yes, then you’d get praise from Bill, but otherwise he didn’t believe his starting quarterback needed a lot of praise for doing what he was being paid to do.
比尔理所当然地认为我应该很出色，所以并没有经常表扬我。四分卫没拿到比赛用球，也没得到多少赞扬。赢了超级碗？那当然会得到比尔的表扬，但除此之外，他觉得他的首发四分卫不需要太多赞扬，因为他已经尽职尽责地完成了自己的工作。
You might think that trying to meet his extremely high expectations would tighten you up, but Bill didn’t jump on you for a mistake; he came right in with the correction: “Here’s what was wrong; this is how to do it right.” Over and over, without getting all upset, he taught the smallest details of perfecting performance.
你或许会觉得，要达到他极高的期望会让你变得紧张，但比尔并没有因为你的错误而责备你；他会直接指出错误：“这里错了；正确的做法是这样的。”他一遍又一遍地，从不生气，耐心地教你如何把表演做到尽善尽美，哪怕是最细微的细节。
He had this little way of taking the pressure off with a comment or, on occasion, some sarcasm. Humor was one of his assets. One time, to emphasize the dress code, he had all the assistant coaches come into a meeting wearing outfits that were ridiculous. One was dressed like a bum, another like a hippie, and somebody was wearing tights, a dress, and falsies—that may have been Bill. He said something like, “Now, we don’t want to look like this on the road, do we?” He made a serious point with humor.
他总有办法用一句玩笑话，或者偶尔带点讽刺，来缓解大家的压力。幽默是他的强项之一。有一次，为了强调着装要求，他让所有助理教练都穿着奇装异服来开会。一个打扮得像个流浪汉，一个像个嬉皮士，还有一个穿着紧身裤、裙子，还戴了假胸——那可能就是比尔。他说道：“我们可不想在客场比赛时也这样打扮，对吧？”他用幽默的方式表达了严肃的观点。
He was extremely demanding without a lot of noise. He was supportive. Bill and I both knew what we were trying to achieve, and his approach with me was simply to teach what was necessary to get there. He was great at making people great students.
他要求极高，但为人低调。他很支持学生。我和比尔都清楚我们想要达成的目标，而他教我的方法很简单，就是教我实现目标所需的知识。他很擅长培养优秀的学生。
The first time Bill ever saw me throw a football in person was across from Los Angeles International Airport at a little public park. He and his assistant coach, Sam Wyche, had flown down from San Francisco to work out James Owens, a receiver, and me. It wasn’t even a football field, just a little park with a playground for kids.
比尔第一次亲眼看到我扔橄榄球，是在洛杉矶国际机场对面的一个小公园里。他和他的助理教练萨姆·怀奇从旧金山飞过来，是为了指导我和接球手詹姆斯·欧文斯训练。那甚至算不上一个橄榄球场，只是一个带儿童游乐场的小公园。
Bill and Sam had me throw to Owens for about thirty minutes. I was struck by Bill’s easy manner. He was friendly, but there was another air about him too. I could sense he was very knowledgeable, and later, when he drafted me, it was apparent that he wanted things a very specific way and that he had logical reasons for it. He had this self-assurance—not cocky, just very confident. And that didn’t change, even when we went 2-14 that first season.
比尔和萨姆让我跟欧文斯练习传球，大概持续了三十分钟。比尔轻松自在的态度给我留下了深刻的印象。他很友善，但身上还有一种特别的气质。我能感觉到他知识渊博，后来他选中我的时候，很明显他希望一切都按他设想的方式进行，而且他这么做是有充分理由的。他有一种自信——不是傲慢，而是非常自信。即使在我们第一个赛季只赢了2胜14负的情况下，这种自信也没有改变。
Bill ran a pretty tight ship, but he knew when to let up. He didn’t beat up players mentally or physically in practice. In fact, his approach was unique because often we didn’t even wear pads in practice—there was no contact—especially as the season went on. Word got around the league, and other players wanted to be 49ers because Bill had this enlightened approach: He wanted us healthy on Sunday, so he didn’t work us to death on Wednesday like most other coaches. And that was just the start of his advanced way of thinking. Everything he did was well thought out and ahead of the curve.
比尔管理严格，但他懂得何时放松。他不会在训练中对球员进行精神或身体上的折磨。事实上，他的方法非常独特，因为我们经常在训练中甚至不穿护具——没有任何身体接触——尤其是在赛季后期。消息很快传遍了联盟，其他球员都想加入49人队，因为比尔的这种理念非常开明：他希望我们周日能保持健康，所以不像其他教练那样在周三让我们拼命训练。而这仅仅是他先进思维的开始。他所做的一切都经过深思熟虑，并且具有前瞻性。
Bill raised everybody’s standard, what we defined as acceptable. Perfection was his acceptable norm, and he got us thinking we could achieve it by teaching us what perfection was and how to reach it—not just how to locate a receiver, but every other aspect of doing your job at the top level, whatever that job was in the organization. It was something special, teaching a person, a whole team, an entire organization, to want to be perfect, to want to get to the next level, and the next one. And then do it.
比尔提高了所有人的标准，也就是我们对“可接受”的定义。完美是他眼中可接受的准则，他教会我们什么是完美以及如何达到完美，从而让我们意识到我们可以实现完美——不仅仅是如何找到接球手，而是做好工作的方方面面，无论你在组织中担任什么职位。这很特别，他教会了一个人、一个团队、一个组织去追求完美，去渴望达到更高的层次，再更高。然后，他真的做到了。
The place you dreamed of but didn’t know you could reach? Bill Walsh taught me how to reach it. He taught all of us how to reach it.
你梦寐以求却不知能否抵达的地方？比尔·沃尔什教会了我如何抵达它。他教会了我们所有人如何抵达它。

Bill’s Final Lecture on Leadership 比尔关于领导力的最后一次演讲
Steve Jamison
史蒂夫·贾米森







The phone rang four times before somebody picked it up: “This is Bill Walsh,” a voice announced. I was startled. After my calling and leaving messages on his answering machine or with secretaries many times over many months, the creator of one of the NFL’s legendary dynasties, the San Francisco 49ers (five Super Bowl championships!), the man who is perhaps the greatest coach in football history, had picked up the phone himself .
电话响了四声才有人接：“我是比尔·沃尔什，”一个声音说道。我吓了一跳。几个月来，我多次打电话，在他的答录机或秘书那里留言，而现在，这位缔造了NFL传奇王朝之一——旧金山49人队（五次超级碗冠军！）的缔造者，这位或许是橄榄球历史上最伟大的教练，竟然亲自接了电话。
“This is Bill Walsh. Hello. Hello?” he repeated.
“我是比尔·沃尔什。你好。你好？”他重复道。
Briefly, I was thrown off; fortunately, he didn’t hang up.
简而言之，我被他的话弄糊涂了；幸运的是，他没有挂断电话。
And that’s how this book began. It was that sudden and that simple.
这本书就是这样开始的。一切都发生得如此突然，如此简单。
I started talking, explaining to him my idea for a book about his philosophy of leadership as it applied beyond football—to management, business, and corporate life. And that I would like to collaborate with him in writing it. “I think I saw one of your letters,” he said. “Sounds okay.” (Yes, I had written several letters to him over the course of those many months.) “Can you meet me here at 9 A.M. tomorrow?” he continued. I got there at eight.
我开始和他交谈，向他解释了我的想法：写一本关于他领导哲学的书，探讨其在足球之外的领域——管理、商业和企业生活中的应用。我还表示，我希望与他合作撰写这本书。“我想我看过你的一封信，”他说，“听起来不错。”（是的，在那几个月里，我给他写过好几封信。）“你明天早上九点能在这里见我吗？”他接着问道。我八点就到了。
His office was located on the second floor of an expansive and expensive office complex right next to the exclusive Sharon Heights Golf and Country Club, just two minutes from Stanford University on Sand Hill Road. The complex, forty minutes south of San Francisco in Silicon Valley, was populated by a host of technology-related companies and some of the most successful venture capitalists in the world, including the most famous, Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers (friends of Bill’s).
他的办公室位于一座规模庞大、造价昂贵的办公大楼二楼，紧邻高档的沙龙高地高尔夫乡村俱乐部，距离斯坦福大学仅两分钟路程，位于沙丘路 (Sand Hill Road) 上。这座办公大楼位于旧金山以南四十分钟车程的硅谷，聚集了众多科技公司和一些世界上最成功的风险投资家，其中包括最著名的凯鹏华盈 (Kleiner Perkins Caufield) 和拜尔斯 (Byers)（比尔的朋友）。
The parking areas—beautifully designed and landscaped—looked like the crowded showroom of a Lexus or Mercedes-Benz dealer. I found an open space and parked, eager to meet Bill—nervous, in fact.
停车场设计精美，绿化优美，看起来就像雷克萨斯或奔驰经销商拥挤的展厅。我找到一个空位停好车，迫不及待地想见到比尔——事实上，我还有些紧张。
At 8:30 A.M. I walked up to his second floor office and knocked. No answer. I began staring directly down at the staircase I had just climbed, in anticipation of his grand arrival. Bill’s arrival wasn’t so grand. At exactly 9 A.M. I saw the top of a head—white hair, neatly trimmed and combed. Bill was walking up the stairs rather deliberately. Sandals (no socks), freshly pressed khaki Bermudas, a red and gold golf shirt (49ers colors). In his left hand a cup of Dunkin’ Donuts coffee; in his right, a bag of Dunkin’ Donuts.
早上八点半，我走到他二楼的办公室门口，敲了敲门。没人应。我开始盯着刚才爬上来的楼梯，期待着他隆重登场。比尔的到来却并不隆重。九点整，我看到一个脑袋——一头白发，修剪得整整齐齐，梳理得一丝不苟。比尔正慢悠悠地走上楼梯。他穿着凉鞋（没穿袜子），一条熨烫笔挺的卡其色百慕大短裤，一件红金相间的球衣（旧金山49人队的配色）。左手拿着一杯唐恩都乐咖啡，右手拿着一袋唐恩都乐甜甜圈。
“Steve? C’mon in. I got some doughnuts on the way over,” he said as an introduction. He opened up the bag of doughnuts, and we started talking. Here’s exactly what he told me in the first minute: “I came to the San Francisco 49ers with a specific goal—to implement what I call the Standard of Performance. It was a way of doing things, a leadership philosophy, that has as much to do with core values, principles, and ideals as with blocking, tackling, and passing; more to do with the mental than with the physical.”
“史蒂夫？进来吧。我路上顺便买了些甜甜圈。”他这样自我介绍道。他打开甜甜圈袋，我们便开始聊天。以下是他第一分钟告诉我的内容：“我来到旧金山49人队时有一个明确的目标——推行我所谓的‘绩效标准’。这是一种做事方式，一种领导理念，它不仅关乎阻挡、擒抱和传球等技术动作，更关乎核心价值观、原则和理想；它更多地关乎精神层面，而非身体层面。”
Bill talked about the need for character as a component of leadership (as well as the elements of character as he saw it); the evolution of the NFL’s most significant change in fifty years—the pass-oriented offense he created—and the lesson it offers beyond football; how he taught the intricacies of high performance to players such as Joe Montana and how they apply to high performance elsewhere.
比尔谈到了品格作为领导力组成部分的重要性（以及他眼中的品格要素）；他创造了NFL五十年来最重大的变革——以传球为主的进攻——以及它对足球之外的启示；他如何将高水平表现的精髓传授给像乔·蒙塔纳这样的球员，以及这些精髓如何应用于其他领域的高水平表现。
“Hey, wait a minute,” he said at one point. “I’ve got some old videotapes in the closet that might help you get the idea of what we did in practice to get all the moving parts moving in the right direction. I’ll get some for you.” Bill put his coffee down, walked to the closet behind his desk, and after a couple of minutes came out with an armful of videotapes. “Here. Take these home. They might help you get the idea. When I put all the pieces together, it looked complicated, but each piece is simple. Most big things are simple in the specific, much less so in the general.” Bill was a genius at making the complex comprehensible, the comprehensible achievable.
“嘿，等一下，”他突然说道，“我壁橱里有一些旧录像带，或许能帮你理解我们当初是如何让所有环节都朝着正确方向运转的。我去拿一些给你。”比尔放下咖啡，走到办公桌后面的壁橱，几分钟后抱着一大堆录像带走了出来。“给你，带回家吧。它们或许能帮你理解。我把所有环节整合起来的时候，看起来很复杂，但其实每个环节都很简单。大多数大事，具体起来都很简单，但整体起来就没那么简单了。”比尔是个天才，他能把复杂的事情变得通俗易懂，把容易理解的事情变成现实。
I asked him about the years with the Cincinnati Bengals when he began to emerge as a quarterback coach and offensive strategist whom others around the league started to take notice of. “I got fooled at Cincinnati,” he chuckled. “Taken right down the primrose path by Paul Brown. But here’s the lesson I learned.” And he told me the lesson. He talked about winning his first Super Bowl and how it destroyed the next season: “But here’s the lesson I learned.” And he told me the lesson. Bill talked about his final game as an assistant coach with the Bengals, when he became flummoxed in the last moments of a game against the Oakland Raiders: “But here’s the lesson I learned.” All those lessons, all that accumulating leadership expertise.
我问起他在辛辛那提猛虎队的那几年，那时他开始崭露头角，成为一名优秀的四分卫教练和进攻策略师，并逐渐引起联盟其他球队的关注。“我在辛辛那提被骗了，”他笑着说，“被保罗·布朗带入了歧途。但我从中吸取了教训。”然后他把教训告诉了我。他谈到赢得第一个超级碗冠军，以及这如何摧毁了接下来的赛季：“但我从中吸取了教训。”然后他把教训告诉了我。比尔谈到了他作为猛虎队助理教练的最后一场比赛，在对阵奥克兰突袭者的比赛最后时刻，他陷入了困境：“但我从中吸取了教训。”所有这些教训，所有这些积累的领导经验。
This went on for three hours until he called our conversation—a lecture on leadership—to a halt because of a scheduled lunch with friends at the Sundeck Restaurant across the parking lot. Our discussions in that office continued for several months as he expanded on his core concepts of leadership—with accompanying anecdotes—for this book. Along the way there were more videotapes, notes, lessons of all sorts that he had learned along the way.
这样的谈话持续了三个小时，直到他因为要和朋友们在停车场对面的Sundeck餐厅吃午饭而结束了我们的对话——一场关于领导力的讲座。之后几个月，我们在他的办公室里继续讨论，他详细阐述了他关于领导力的核心理念，并穿插了一些轶事，最终汇集成这本书。在此期间，他还提供了更多的录像带、笔记以及他一路走来积累的各种经验教训。
We would talk. I would write. He would review. We would talk some more. That’s how we worked. Quickly, this book developed. Along the way I came to better understand Bill and how and why he did things as a leader, who he was as a person. Let me share a few observations.
我们会交谈，我写作，他审阅，然后再继续讨论。我们就是这样工作的。这本书很快就成型了。在这个过程中，我对比尔有了更深的了解，明白了他作为领导者的行事方式和原因，也了解了他作为一个人是怎样的人。下面我想分享一些我的观察。
Bill Walsh was brilliant almost beyond comprehension. His ability to analyze an intractable problem and come up with a solution (the West Coast Offense, for example) was stunning. It applied not only to touchdowns but also to managing and organizing individuals. Of course, how he did the latter facilitated the former. He was a master at it. Bill’s analytical intelligence was coupled with an immense creativity that allowed him to see things differently. The result moved NFL football, in many ways, from the Stone Age to the twenty-first century. If there is such a thing as a Renaissance coach, he was it: truly enlightened when it came to directing an organization’s attention and best effort to achieving goals he defined.
比尔·沃尔什的才华几乎令人难以置信。他分析棘手问题并提出解决方案的能力（例如西海岸进攻体系）令人叹为观止。这种能力不仅体现在达阵得分上，也体现在管理和组织球员方面。当然，他管理球员的方式也促进了达阵得分。他在这方面堪称大师。比尔的分析能力与他惊人的创造力相结合，使他能够以独特的视角看待事物。在许多方面，这都推动了NFL橄榄球从石器时代迈向了21世纪。如果说真有文艺复兴式的教练，那他就是：他真正具有远见卓识，能够引导整个团队的注意力和全力以赴地朝着他设定的目标前进。
Bill Walsh held the need to treat individuals within his organization fairly almost sacrosanct (in return, those individuals were expected to consistently work at their most productive level). It stemmed from his own professional experience of being treated unfairly, which he describes here in detail. This did not preclude harsh—at times, seemingly ruthless—action when someone in the organization behaved in a manner contrary to the team’s best interests.
比尔·沃尔什认为，公平对待组织内的每一位成员几乎是神圣不可侵犯的（作为回报，他期望这些成员能够始终保持最佳工作状态）。这源于他自身曾遭受不公平待遇的职业经历，他在此书中对此进行了详细描述。但这并不妨碍他采取严厉——有时甚至是看似冷酷无情——的措施，以应对组织内任何损害团队利益的行为。
He did not view the organization and the individuals within it as two separate entities, but as one and the same: “People are the heart of your organization,” he instructed me. This perspective affected his leadership profoundly.
他并不把组织和组织中的个人视为两个独立的实体，而是视之为一体：“人才是组织的核心，”他曾这样教导我。这种观点深刻地影响了他的领导风格。
Bill Walsh loved lists, viewed them as a road map to results. That may sound simplistic, but I believe it was an important part of his astounding deductive-reasoning ability. When confronted with a “problem”—for example, how do we score touchdowns without a good running game or a strong passer? what is our communication process on the sidelines during a game when crowd noise becomes overwhelming? what are the specific duties of my executive vice president for football operations? and hundreds and hundreds more—Bill Walsh dissected the issue into its relevant parts, found a solution, and then taught the solution to the appropriate individuals. His creative and commonsense brilliance as a problem solver was unsurpassed and a major component in the installation of what he called the Standard of Performance.
比尔·沃尔什酷爱清单，他把清单视为通往成功的路线图。这听起来或许有些简单，但我相信这是他惊人的演绎推理能力的重要组成部分。当面对“问题”时——例如，如何在没有出色跑动进攻或强力传球手的情况下得分？比赛期间，当观众的喧嚣声震耳欲聋时，我们在场边的沟通流程是什么？我的足球运营执行副总裁的具体职责是什么？等等等等——比尔·沃尔什会将问题分解成各个相关部分，找到解决方案，然后将解决方案传授给相关人员。他作为问题解决者的创造力和常识天赋无人能及，也是他所谓的“绩效标准”建立的关键组成部分。
I kidded him once that he was so obsessive about lists that he probably had lists of the lists in his file cabinet. He didn’t deny it. I found a list of directives for his speech to receptionists at 49er headquarters that was two pages long with bullet point after bullet point. Here’s bullet point number seventeen: “Your job is not civil service or even big corporate business. We exist to support and field a football team. In other words, we don’t ‘exist for the sake of existing.’ We are not maintaining .” He told me this addressed his concern that most people simply go through the motions at their jobs, just putting in time—existing—with a “business as usual” attitude. Not if you’re on his team.
我曾经开玩笑说他痴迷于清单，说不定他的文件柜里都堆满了清单的清单。他也没否认。我找到了一份长达两页的清单，上面列满了他在49人队总部对前台接待员的讲话要点。这是第十七条：“你们的工作不是公务员，甚至不是大公司。我们的存在是为了支持和运营一支橄榄球队。换句话说，我们不是‘为了存在而存在’。我们不是在维持现状。”他告诉我，这正是为了回应他的担忧：大多数人只是例行公事地工作，只是为了混日子——存在——抱着一种“一切照旧”的态度。但如果你在他的团队里，情况就完全不同了。
The meticulous manner in which he detailed specific actions and attitudes of his Standard of Performance as applied to secretaries and receptionists was true throughout the organization but in increasingly exponential quantities.
他一丝不苟地详细规定了秘书和接待员的绩效标准中具体的行为和态度，这种规定在整个组织中都适用，而且数量呈指数级增长。
Bill Walsh was cautious in part because he was savvy. One day I started asking him about the leadership characteristics of other outstanding coaches—first Tom Landry, then Mike Holmgren, next Jimmy Johnson. Initially, he was open and insightful (as you’ll read later). But then, suddenly, he decided this was a subject he did not like, namely, talking about his peers—that I was taking him down a path that could cause problems for him. And that was the end of that discussion. The atmosphere in his small office chilled: “I’ve got to make some calls,” he said brusquely as he broke off his description of Bill Parcells and picked up the phone. And without his saying so, I knew he had dismissed me for the day. (I noticed as I was leaving that he put the phone down, never made a call.)
比尔·沃尔什之所以谨慎，部分原因是他很精明。有一天，我开始向他请教其他杰出教练的领导特质——先是汤姆·兰德里，然后是迈克·霍尔姆格伦，接着是吉米·约翰逊。起初，他很坦诚，也很有见地（稍后你会读到）。但突然间，他觉得这是个他不喜欢的话题，也就是谈论同行——他认为我把他引向了一条可能给他带来麻烦的道路。于是，那次谈话就此结束。他那间小办公室里的气氛顿时冷了下来：“我得打几个电话，”他一边说着，一边生硬地中断了对比尔·帕塞尔斯的描述，拿起电话。虽然他没有明说，但我知道他已经把我打发走了。（我离开时注意到，他把电话挂断了，并没有打出去。）
Bill had sensed, incorrectly, that I was looking for some dirt or critical comments on other coaches. He was a very careful man.
比尔错误地察觉到我是在打探其他教练的丑闻或批评之词。他是个非常谨慎的人。
Bill Walsh was an educator—a teacher. He accumulated great knowledge because he was a Grade A student of leadership, paying close attention along the way to some of football’s most outstanding and forward-thinking coaches, most of all Paul Brown (of the Cincinnati Bengals). Bill absorbed their good ideas, learned from their bad ones, applied his own even more advanced concepts, and then reveled in the process of teaching what he knew to his teams. I came to believe that the part of football he enjoyed best was teaching, or more accurately, identifying outstanding talent and teaching that player, assistant coach, or staff member how to be great. He loved it.
比尔·沃尔什是一位教育家——一位教师。他积累了丰富的知识，因为他是一位杰出的领导力学习者，一路走来，他密切关注着一些橄榄球界最杰出、最具前瞻性的教练，尤其是辛辛那提猛虎队的保罗·布朗。比尔吸收了他们的好想法，从他们的坏事中吸取了教训，并运用自己更为先进的理念，然后乐于将所学传授给他的球队。我逐渐相信，他最享受的橄榄球运动部分是教学，或者更准确地说，是发现杰出人才，并指导这些球员、助理教练或工作人员如何成为伟大的人。他热爱这项工作。
Bill Walsh was without pretense, almost soft-spoken. While his comportment was never chummy—there was a reserve to his manner—he was easy to talk to and be with unless I hit a nerve. For all the attention and glory that had been heaped on him during and especially after the dynasty years, he was normal—coffee-and-doughnuts normal; although not laid-back or casual, he was unaffected. You’d think you were talking to a very successful and focused midlevel corporate executive unless you noticed the picture on the wall of Bill standing next to Joe Montana holding a Super Bowl trophy, or the picture on the other wall of Bill standing next to Joe Montana holding a different Super Bowl trophy.
比尔·沃尔什为人谦逊，说话轻声细语。虽然他举止并不亲切——他总是带着一丝矜持——但只要我不触及他的痛处，和他交谈、相处都很容易。尽管在王朝时期，尤其是在王朝之后，他获得了无数的关注和荣耀，但他依然保持着普通人的本色——那种喝咖啡吃甜甜圈的普通人；虽然他并不慵懒随意，但也毫不做作。你会以为自己是在和一位非常成功、专注的中层企业高管交谈，除非你注意到墙上挂着一张比尔和乔·蒙塔纳并肩站立、手捧超级碗奖杯的照片，或者另一面墙上比尔和乔·蒙塔纳并肩站立、手捧另一座超级碗奖杯的照片。
All of the above became apparent to me as we proceeded to write this book revealing Bill’s leadership philosophy. Along the way, I secured a generous offer from a publisher eager to share the “wisdom of Walsh”—when it came to building a top team in business or elsewhere. And then, boom! Just as simply and suddenly as it had begun, it stopped. No book.
在我们着手撰写这本揭示比尔领导理念的书的过程中，以上所有情况都变得显而易见。在此过程中，我获得了一家出版社的慷慨邀约，他们渴望分享“沃尔什的智慧”——无论是在商业领域还是其他领域，如何打造一支顶尖团队。然而，突然之间，一切都戛然而止！就像它开始时那样简单而突然。书稿最终未能面世。
Bill—retired from the NFL for ten years—had accepted an offer to return in an executive capacity to the San Francisco 49ers. On the same day that I received a lengthy contract from a publisher, he called with the news that he was going back to the NFL. I knew what that meant, because in our earliest conversations he had laid out only one stipulation: “If I go back to the NFL, I don’t want this book coming out. I don’t need the headache.” It was a handshake deal. And so, no book.
比尔——从NFL退役十年后——接受了旧金山49人队的邀请，以高管身份重返球队。就在我收到出版社的长篇合同的同一天，他打电话告诉我他要重返NFL。我知道这意味着什么，因为在我们最初的几次谈话中，他只提出了一个条件：“如果我重返NFL，这本书就不出版了。我可不想给自己添麻烦。” 这完全是口头协议。所以，这本书最终没能出版。
As writers do, I put my writing and notes and tapes and collected articles and interviews and research material into boxes, put the boxes into storage, and then forgot about it—or tried to. It was great stuff on leadership that Bill had shared in our conversations, and it seemed a shame to pack it up and move on. But that’s what happened.
像很多作家一样，我把写好的文章、笔记、录音带、收集的文章、访谈记录和研究资料装进箱子，放进储藏室，然后就忘了这回事——或者说，我试图忘掉它。比尔在我们谈话中分享的那些关于领导力的见解非常精彩，把它们打包带走似乎有点可惜。但事情就是这样发生了。
Bill lent a hand to resuscitating the moribund 49ers for several years (his towering San Francisco 49er dynasty had fallen into disrepair and he was called back to duty) and I continued work with UCLA’s legendary basketball coach, John Wooden. A book we had written earlier was becoming a best seller, and it led us to a productive professional association and friendship, including more books, television presentations, seminars, and even a best-selling publication for children.
比尔曾出手相助，帮助当时奄奄一息的旧金山49人队重振旗鼓，长达数年之久（他曾经辉煌的旧金山49人王朝已然衰落，他被召回重任），而我则继续与加州大学洛杉矶分校的传奇篮球教练约翰·伍登合作。我们之前合著的一本书逐渐成为畅销书，这促成了我们富有成效的专业合作和友谊，包括更多的书籍、电视节目、研讨会，甚至还有一本畅销的儿童读物。
My boxes marked “Bill Walsh Leadership” were collecting dust. And then one day my phone rang. “Hello, this is Bill Walsh,” the voice said. “I’m very interested in getting that book finished up, Steve.” As with our first phone call, I was almost at a loss for words. He was no longer working for the 49ers and, in fact, was lecturing on a regular basis to corporate groups and students at Stanford University about leadership. It was time, he said, to get his book on leadership published. Ten years had gone by.
我那些标着“比尔·沃尔什领导力”的箱子都积满了灰尘。有一天，我的电话响了。“你好，我是比尔·沃尔什，”电话那头传来一个声音。“史蒂夫，我很想尽快完成那本书。” 和我们第一次通话时一样，我几乎说不出话来。他已经不再为旧金山49人队工作了，事实上，他经常在斯坦福大学为企业团体和学生讲授领导力课程。他说，是时候出版他的领导力著作了。十年过去了。
I was delighted: “If you’ve got some time next week, I’ll meet you at Stanford and you can review the manuscript again before I go back to publishers.” That sounded good to him: “Fine! Oops, wait a minute. I’m going into the hospital for some tests next week. But if you want, it’s probably okay to meet me there.”
我欣喜若狂：“如果你下周有空，我可以去斯坦福见你，你可以在我把稿件寄回出版社之前再审阅一遍。”他觉得这主意不错：“好啊！哎呀，等等。我下周要去医院做一些检查。不过如果你愿意的话，在医院见我应该没问题。”
I don’t like hospitals and didn’t particularly want to impose on Bill while he was wearing a gown: “No, no. Let’s wait a week. Is it anything to be worried about, the tests?” I asked. He assured me that it was routine, nothing serious, just a series of tests to check on something that had been going on for a while. I said, “Okay, I’ll talk to you after you finish up at the hospital. Good luck.” He replied, “I’ll see you then.”
我不喜欢医院，也不想打扰穿着病号服的比尔：“不，不。我们等一周吧。那些检查有什么好担心的吗？”我问。他向我保证说只是例行检查，没什么大碍，只是为了查一下我之前一直有的毛病。我说：“好的，等你从医院出来我再跟你聊。祝你好运。”他回答说：“到时候见。”
Not long after that, Bill was dead—leukemia. The greatest coach in football’s history was seventy-five.
不久之后，比尔就去世了——死于白血病。这位足球史上最伟大的教练享年75岁。
I had come to feel close to him over the years, first as a fan watching Bill lead the 49ers to multiple Super Bowl championships; later working with him on this book; and still later watching him from afar as he wrestled once again with the problems of a struggling team. Through it all he had exhibited poise, intelligence, and a basic decency.
这些年来，我和他逐渐建立起了亲近的感情。最初，我作为一名球迷，看着比尔带领旧金山49人队多次夺得超级碗冠军；后来，我与他合作撰写了这本书；再后来，我又远远地关注着他，看着他再次与一支陷入困境的球队作斗争。在这一切过程中，他始终展现出沉着冷静、智慧过人以及基本的正直品格。
Bill and I certainly were not buddies, but from the start he treated me right. (I learned recently that Bill had plenty of friends, associates, and a ton of great working relationships but almost no buddies, intimates with whom he could bare his soul.) He was unpretentious, forthright, no BS; his composure and presence were so unique and appealing. As Joe Montana told me, “You knew immediately there was something special about him.”
我和比尔当然算不上铁哥们，但他从一开始就待我很好。（我最近才知道，比尔有很多朋友、同事，也建立了许多良好的工作关系，但几乎没有可以敞开心扉的知己。）他为人谦逊，直率坦诚，从不虚伪；他的沉着冷静和个人魅力都非常独特，令人着迷。正如乔·蒙塔纳告诉我的那样：“你一眼就能看出他与众不同。”
And I had grown to appreciate—be astonished by—his incredible story of overcoming impossible odds in the NFL with the singularity of his leadership brilliance, management acumen, and football creativity and the force of his will.
我逐渐开始欣赏——并为之惊叹——他在 NFL 中凭借其卓越的领导才能、管理才能、足球创造力和强大的意志力，克服了看似不可能的困难，取得了令人瞩目的成就。
There also was his willingness to talk about the personal issues, his emotional meltdown in the second season, the toll of not just getting to the top, but staying there, triumph and burnout, and, of course, all the insights into leadership—“but here’s the lesson I learned.”
此外，他还愿意谈论个人问题，他在第二季中的情绪崩溃，不仅要登上顶峰，还要保持顶峰所付出的代价，胜利和倦怠，当然还有他对领导力的所有见解——“但我学到的教训是这样的。”
I had, in my own small way, gotten to know and greatly respect Bill, and his death hurt; it knocked the wind out of my sails for the book; I’m not sure why. He was a good guy, a real guy. So, sadly, once again I put our manuscript back in boxes. This time for good. Or so I thought.
我以自己的方式认识了比尔，并且非常尊敬他，他的去世让我很痛苦；它让我对这本书的创作热情骤然消退；我也不知道为什么。他是个好人，一个真诚的人。所以，很遗憾，我又一次把手稿放回了箱子里。这一次，是真的要永远地放回去了。至少我是这么想的。
Several months after the public tributes and a big memorial service at Candlestick Park (where Bill had worked his leadership genius) had been concluded, a friend of mine, Peter Fatooh, a successful local executive and big-time fan of the 49ers, started telling me how much he respected Bill Walsh as a leader, how far ahead of everybody he had been in his thinking. I mentioned casually that I had been working on a book with Bill at the time of his death but wasn’t going to publish it now—that I had kind of lost heart, gotten the wind knocked out of me by his death. “Would you mind if I read it?” Peter asked. “I’d like to know what Bill says about leadership.”
在公众悼念和烛台公园（比尔展现其卓越领导才能的地方）的大型追悼会结束后几个月，我的朋友彼得·法图赫——一位成功的当地高管，也是旧金山49人队的铁杆球迷——开始跟我说他多么敬佩比尔·沃尔什的领导才能，他的思想多么超前。我随口提到，在他去世时，我正在和比尔合著一本书，但现在不打算出版了——我有点灰心丧气，他的离世让我彻底崩溃。“我可以读读吗？”彼得问，“我想知道比尔对领导力的看法。”
I offered to let him read the manuscript if he promised not to pass it around. “It’s just for you to read,” I told him. He agreed. One week later I saw him again at the San Francisco Tennis Club (where Bill used to play a frustrating game of tennis occasionally), and Peter was eager to tell me the following: “Steve, you’ve got to get Bill’s book published. It’s great. Just great.” He returned the manuscript and said, “Now I know why he was so exceptional. I’ve already started using some of his ideas myself.” Somehow, Peter’s honest and positive opinion got me back up and running.
我提出让他读一下手稿，前提是他保证不传阅。“这手稿只给你一个人看，”我告诉他。他同意了。一周后，我在旧金山网球俱乐部（比尔以前偶尔会在那里打网球，总是输得让人沮丧）又见到了他。彼得迫不及待地告诉我：“史蒂夫，你一定要把比尔的书出版。它太棒了，真的太棒了。”他把手稿还给我，说：“现在我终于明白他为什么如此杰出了。我已经开始借鉴他的一些想法了。”不知怎的，彼得坦诚而积极的评价让我重新振作起来。
A few weeks later, I contacted Bill’s only surviving son, Craig, who agreed to meet me and listen to the history of his father’s book on leadership. We met for lunch at the Fish Market Restaurant in Foster City, California, not too far from 711 Nevada Street, where Bill had begun his work building the 49er dynasty more than twenty-five years earlier. I gave Craig the manuscript for this book and told him that if he didn’t like it I would withhold it from publication. With his father’s death, he was the one who should now decide whether or not the book merited publication.
几周后，我联系了比尔唯一的在世儿子克雷格，他同意与我见面，听我讲述他父亲关于领导力的著作的创作历程。我们在加州福斯特城的鱼市餐厅共进午餐，这家餐厅离内华达街711号不远，二十五年前，比尔正是从那里开始了他的49人王朝的创建之路。我把这本书的手稿交给克雷格，告诉他如果他不喜欢，我会阻止出版。随着他父亲的去世，现在应该由他来决定这本书是否值得出版。
A few days later, Craig called: “I think you’ve really got something special here, Steve. I see why Dad wanted this available to the public.” And then he added that he had access to additional lecture notes by his father, as well as tapes and other material that might be useful. He could also supply original notes and information from a book for football coaches that Bill had written but withdrawn from publication. Also, and most important, he could offer his own insider’s perspective on his father’s incredible journey.
几天后，克雷格打来电话：“史蒂夫，我觉得你这东西真的很特别。我明白爸爸为什么想把这些公之于众了。” 他还补充说，他手头还有一些他父亲的讲稿、录音带和其他可能有用的资料。他还能提供比尔写给橄榄球教练的一本书的原始笔记和信息，那本书后来撤回了出版计划。而且，最重要的是，他还能以一个内部人士的身份，讲述他父亲这段非凡的人生历程。
And so Bill’s book was back on track once again, this time without Bill, but with the blessing and participation of his son. I contacted Jeffrey Krames, one of the publishing world’s foremost editors in the field of management and leadership (also the author of books on the leadership lessons of Jack Welch, Peter Drucker, Lou Gerstner, and others), who saw the deep value of the Bill Walsh philosophy of leadership when it came to management and team building. He, in turn, brought the great creative resources of Portfolio Publishing into play and gave us the green light. And that, in a big nutshell, is how Bill’s book on leadership got published. Looking back, it seems almost impossible.
于是，比尔的书稿再次走上了正轨，这次比尔本人并未参与，但得到了他儿子的支持和参与。我联系了杰弗里·克雷姆斯，他是出版界管理和领导力领域最杰出的编辑之一（也是杰克·韦尔奇、彼得·德鲁克、路易斯·格斯特纳等人领导力著作的作者），他看到了比尔·沃尔什的领导理念在管理和团队建设方面的深远价值。他随后调动了Portfolio Publishing强大的创作资源，并批准了我们的出版计划。简而言之，这就是比尔的领导力著作得以出版的经过。回想起来，这简直难以置信。
It has been an extraordinary experience for me. So many unusual happenings: Bill picking up the phone himself that day many years ago because his secretary was away on a family emergency (if he hadn’t, I doubt we would have gotten together for this book); his return to the NFL, which stopped the book in its tracks; Bill’s call to me years later saying he wanted to get this book published (nudged, it turns out, by my friend UCLA coach John Wooden); soon after, Bill’s final, fatal diagnosis of leukemia; his death; the mourning; the encouragement from Peter Fatooh; the blessing and full participation of Craig Walsh and the great perception of Jeffrey Krames and his boss at Portfolio, Adrian Zackheim. All I can figure is that Bill’s book was meant to be.
对我来说，这是一段非凡的经历。发生了太多不同寻常的事：多年前的某一天，比尔的秘书因家中紧急情况外出，他亲自接了电话（如果不是这样，我想我们可能就无法一起完成这本书了）；他重返NFL，导致这本书的写作一度停滞；几年后，比尔打电话给我，说他想出版这本书（后来才知道，这要归功于我的朋友，加州大学洛杉矶分校的教练约翰·伍登）；不久之后，比尔被确诊患有白血病，最终不治身亡；他的离世；哀悼；彼得·法图的鼓励；克雷格·沃尔什的祝福和全力支持；杰弗里·克莱姆斯以及他在Portfolio的老板阿德里安·扎克海姆的远见卓识。我只能说，比尔的这本书的出版是命中注定的。
Through it all there has been one fundamental and powerful constant: the substantive leadership wisdom of football’s legendary coach, Bill Walsh. His brilliance was evident in the first minute of our conversation in that little office on Sand Hill Road, and it continued every time he spoke.
贯穿始终的，是一个根本且强大的不变因素：那就是足球传奇教练比尔·沃尔什卓越的领导智慧。在我们于沙山路那间小办公室里交谈的第一分钟，他的才华就显露无疑，而且每次他开口说话，都令人叹服。
Bill Walsh loved to teach. This is his final lecture on leadership.
比尔·沃尔什热爱教学。这是他关于领导力的最后一次演讲。

PROLOGUE 序幕
To Succeed You Must Fail 要想成功，就必须经历失败。
I would never write anything that suggests the path to success is a continuum of positive, even euphoric experiences—that if you do all the right things everything will work out. Frequently it doesn’t; often you crash and burn. This is part and parcel of pursuing and achieving very ambitious goals. It is also one of the profound lessons I have learned during my career, namely, that even when you have an organization brimming with talent, victory is not always under your control. Rather, it’s like quicksilver—fleeting and elusive, not something you can summon at will even under the best circumstances. Almost always, your road to victory goes through a place called “failure.”
我绝不会写任何暗示成功之路是一连串积极甚至令人欣喜若狂的体验——仿佛只要你做对了所有事，一切都会迎刃而解。事实往往并非如此；你常常会遭遇惨败。这是追求和实现远大目标过程中不可避免的一部分。这也是我在职业生涯中学到的深刻教训之一：即使你拥有一个人才济济的团队，胜利也并非总是尽在掌握。它更像是水银——转瞬即逝，难以捉摸，即使在最佳情况下，你也无法随心所欲地将其召唤出来。几乎每次，通往胜利的道路都离不开一个名为“失败”的地方。
That reality was present throughout my career, from coaching the Huskies of Washington Union High School in Fremont, California, to the San Francisco 49ers, and all the stops along the way—San Jose State, Stanford University and the University of California-Berkeley, the Oakland Raiders, the Cincinnati Bengals, and the San Diego Chargers. Always the same principle was present: There is no guarantee, no ultimate formula for success.
从执教加州弗里蒙特华盛顿联合高中的哈士奇队，到旧金山49人队，再到一路走来的所有球队——圣何塞州立大学、斯坦福大学、加州大学伯克利分校、奥克兰突袭者队、辛辛那提猛虎队和圣地亚哥闪电队——我整个职业生涯都秉持着同样的原则：成功没有保证，也没有万能的成功秘诀。
However, a resolute and resourceful leader understands that there are a multitude of means to increase the probability of success. And that’s what it all comes down to, namely, intelligently and relentlessly seeking solutions that will increase your chance of prevailing in a competitive environment. When you do that, the score will take care of itself.
然而，一位意志坚定、足智多谋的领导者明白，提高成功概率的方法有很多。归根结底，关键在于运用智慧，坚持不懈地寻找能够增加在竞争环境中获胜机会的解决方案。当你做到这一点时，结果自然会水到渠成。
Professional football, in my opinion, is the moral equivalent of war. The stress, wear and tear, and assault on a person’s spirit and basic self-esteem are incredible. It takes an individual to the outer limits of his capabilities and may provide one of the ultimate studies of people because it is such a cruel, volatile, and emotionally and physically dangerous activity.
在我看来，职业足球在道德上等同于战争。它带来的压力、损耗以及对人的精神和基本自尊的打击都令人难以置信。它将个人的潜能推向极限，并且由于其残酷、动荡且在身心两方面都极具危险性，或许是对人性最深刻的剖析之一。
I also believe that NFL football, absent the extreme physical component, is the intellectual equivalent of business as it pertains to the fundamental task of leadership; specifically, organizing and managing a group of individuals to achieve difficult goals in an extremely competitive world.
我还认为，如果去掉极端的身体对抗，NFL橄榄球在智力层面上就等同于商业，因为它涉及到领导力的基本任务；具体来说，就是在一个竞争极其激烈的世界中组织和管理一群人来实现艰巨的目标。
The ideas, experiences, and conclusions I offer here are drawn from my own search for success in the context of my profession—football—and intended to add to your own knowledge of leadership in your profession, to give you insights on what a fellow traveler experienced during my own competitive journey.
我在此提出的想法、经验和结论都源于我在足球这一职业领域中追求成功的经历，旨在增进您对职业领导力的了解，让您了解一位同行者在我自己的竞技历程中所经历的一切。
Pursuing your ambitions, especially those of any magnitude, can be grueling and hazardous, and produce agonizing failure along the way, but achieving those goals is among life’s most gratifying and thrilling experiences. The ability to survive and overcome the former to attain the latter is a fundamental difference between winners and losers.
追求抱负，尤其是那些远大的目标，可能充满艰辛和风险，过程中难免遭遇痛苦的失败，但最终实现目标却是人生中最令人满足和激动人心的经历之一。能否在逆境中生存下来并最终获得成功，是成功者与失败者之间的根本区别。
I’ve observed that if individuals who prevail in a highly competitive environment have any one thing in common besides success, it is failure—and their ability to overcome it. “Crash and burn” is part of it; so are recovery and reward. As you’re about to see, I experienced more than my share of both. In the process, I’ve discovered a few things worth sharing, a few lessons worth learning.
我发现，在竞争激烈的环境中脱颖而出的人，除了成功之外，还有什么共同之处，那就是他们都经历过失败——以及他们克服失败的能力。“彻底失败”是其中的一部分；而复苏和回报也同样重要。正如你即将看到的，我经历过远超常人的失败和复苏。在这个过程中，我发现了一些值得分享的东西，也汲取了一些值得学习的经验教训。

PART I 第一部分
My Standard of Performance: An Environment of Excellence 我的绩效标准：追求卓越的环境
The ability to help the people around me self-actualize their goals underlines the single aspect of my abilities and the label that I value most—teacher. 帮助身边的人实现自我目标的能力，凸显了我能力中最重要的一点，也是我最珍视的头衔——教师。
—BILL WALSH
——比尔·沃尔什

How to Know if You’re Doing the Job 如何判断你是否胜任这份工作
When I give a speech at a corporate event, I often ask those in attendance, “Do you know how to tell if you’re doing the job?” As heads start whispering back and forth, I provide these clues: “If you’re up at 3 A.M. every night talking into a tape recorder and writing notes on scraps of paper, have a knot in your stomach and a rash on your skin, are losing sleep and losing touch with your wife and kids, have no appetite or sense of humor, and feel that everything might turn out wrong, then you’re probably doing the job.”
当我在公司活动上发表演讲时，我经常问在场的人：“你们知道如何判断自己是否在做好这份工作吗？” 当大家开始窃窃私语时，我会给出以下提示：“如果你每天凌晨三点还在对着录音机说话，在纸片上写笔记，胃里像打了个结，皮肤上起了疹子，睡眠不足，与妻子孩子疏远，没有食欲，也没有幽默感，并且感觉一切都可能出错，那么你可能真的在做好这份工作。”
This always gets a laugh, but not a very big one. Those executives in the audience recognize there is a significant price to pay to be the best. That price is not something they laugh at.
这总能引人发笑，但笑声并不热烈。台下的高管们都明白，要想成为佼佼者，是要付出巨大代价的。他们绝不会拿这个代价开玩笑。

Coaches Aren’t Supposed to Cry: Survive One Minute at a Time 教练不该哭：一分钟一分钟地熬过去
In my second year as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, we were preparing to play the defending AFC East champions, Don Shula’s powerful Miami Dolphins, a team that was formidable, especially at home in the Orange Bowl.
在我担任旧金山 49 人队主教练的第二年，我们正准备迎战卫冕美联东区冠军、唐·舒拉率领的强大的迈阿密海豚队，这是一支实力强劲的球队，尤其是在橙碗球场的主场作战时。
The showdown came in week eleven of our schedule and at the worst possible moment for me because after a great start to my second season—three straight wins against the New Orleans Saints, St. Louis Cardinals, and New York Jets—we had lost seven consecutive games. Our year was imploding. (The previous season, my first as head coach, our record had been 2-14, which meant that since I had taken over leadership of the 49ers we had won five games and lost twenty-one, the worst record in the NFL.)
这场决战发生在赛程的第11周，对我来说也是最糟糕的时刻。因为在我的第二个赛季开局非常出色——连续战胜新奥尔良圣徒队、圣路易斯红雀队和纽约喷气机队——之后，我们却遭遇了七连败。我们的赛季正在崩溃。（上个赛季，也就是我担任主教练的第一个赛季，我们的战绩是2胜14负，这意味着自从我接手49人队以来，我们只赢了5场，输了21场，是NFL最差的战绩。）
A loss to Miami on Sunday would be our eighth in a row and likely have enormous consequences, including the possibility of my being terminated or at least being put on a “death watch” by the media—an unofficial lame duck and powerless coach.
周日输给迈阿密将是我们的第八连败，而且可能会产生巨大的后果，包括我可能被解雇，或者至少被媒体列入“死亡观察名单”——成为一个非正式的跛脚鸭教练和无权无势的教练。
Conversely, I recognized that a victory against the Dolphins would stop the hemorrhaging and provide hope for salvaging the last part of our season, which, in turn, could have a positive impact on the following year. Huge stakes were on the table. I was somewhat hopeful, perhaps even optimistic.
相反，我意识到战胜海豚队就能止住颓势，为挽救赛季后半程带来希望，而这反过来又会对下个赛季产生积极影响。这场比赛至关重要。我当时抱有一些希望，甚至可以说是乐观。
Nevertheless, the professional and personal magnitude of the upcoming Miami-San Francisco game clouded the entire week’s practice for me and created a brittleness in my behavior that was out of character. I was brusque, short-tempered, and not as tuned in as I should have been.
然而，即将到来的迈阿密对阵旧金山的比赛对我而言意义重大，无论是职业层面还是个人层面，都影响了我整周的训练，也让我表现出一种反常的脆弱。我变得生硬、易怒，而且注意力也不如以往集中。
The game itself—played in suffocating Florida heat and humidity—turned into a bruising battle in front of over seventy-five thousand screaming Dolphin fans who had packed themselves into the stadium. For the 49ers it was like going to a wild party to which you are uninvited and unwelcome—everybody tries to throw you out the window.
比赛本身——在佛罗里达州闷热潮湿的天气中进行——在超过七万五千名挤满体育场、呐喊助威的海豚队球迷面前，演变成了一场激烈的较量。对于49人队来说，这就像去参加一个你不被邀请、也不受欢迎的狂欢派对——每个人都想把你扔出窗外。
Miami’s tropical sun had pushed daytime temperatures into the nineties, and dusk didn’t bring them down. In fact, the heat seemed to get worse, as if we were playing in a swamp, trying to move in quicksand. None of this appeared to affect Coach Shula’s team. They built an early lead and held onto it throughout the game. It seemed evident that we were headed for our eighth straight defeat—a potentially disastrous event.
迈阿密的烈日将白天的气温推高到九十多华氏度，即使到了黄昏也丝毫没有下降。事实上，酷热似乎愈演愈烈，就像我们在沼泽里踢球，在流沙中艰难前行。然而，这一切似乎并没有影响到舒拉教练的球队。他们早早建立起领先优势，并保持到了比赛结束。看起来，我们似乎注定要遭遇八连败——这无疑是一场灾难。
However, with time running down—less than two minutes remaining—49er kicker Ray Wersching, perhaps the league’s best field goal specialist, calmly nailed a winner to get us within a point: 17-16. Immediately, the entire San Francisco bench leaped up, pumping their fists and yelling wildly. You could feel this huge surge in momentum erupt. Unfortunately, it was a short-lived surge; our field goal did not count. To my dismay, a holding penalty was called against us and the score was nullified. Quickly, I again nodded at Ray, who strapped on his helmet, trotted out, and calmly kicked another field goal from five yards farther back. Again, raucous cheers erupted on our bench, but immediately another flag was thrown and another penalty called against us.
然而，随着比赛时间所剩无几——只剩不到两分钟——49人队的踢球手雷·沃辛，或许是联盟中最优秀的任意球专家，冷静地踢进一记制胜球，将比分追至17比16，仅落后一分。旧金山队的替补席顿时沸腾起来，挥舞着拳头，疯狂地呐喊。你能感受到一股巨大的势头瞬间爆发。可惜的是，这股势头转瞬即逝；我们的任意球被判无效。令我沮丧的是，裁判判罚我们犯规，得分被取消。我赶紧再次向雷点头示意，他戴上头盔，小跑上场，冷静地在五码开外再次踢进任意球。替补席上再次爆发出震耳欲聋的欢呼声，但裁判立刻又一次吹哨，判罚我们犯规。
Now the line of scrimmage put us out of field-goal range and forced us into a passing situation; we needed a first down to retain possession of the ball. Quickly, we completed a pass that gave us just enough yards to pick up the first down. The 49ers had survived for the moment, stayed alive. Or so it seemed.
现在，进攻线让我们无法射门得分，只能选择传球；我们需要一次首攻才能保住球权。我们迅速完成了一次传球，推进的码数刚好足够拿到首攻。49人队暂时保住了性命，至少看起来是这样。
As I watched in disbelief, a linesman raced in and gave Miami a spot so friendly it could have gotten him elected to local public office. Our drive had been stopped three times in a row under increasingly outrageous circumstances. What made it maddening was that Shula had been berating officials throughout the game whenever they made a call against the Dolphins. This seemed to be his reward—a spot he had to love and two penalties against us on the previous plays. As bad as the 49er season had become, nothing this agonizing and damaging had happened to us before. And the crowd loved it.
我难以置信地看着，边裁冲进来，给了迈阿密一个极其有利的判罚，简直能让他当选地方公职。我们的进攻已经连续三次在越来越离谱的情况下被终止。更让人恼火的是，舒拉在整场比赛中只要裁判做出对海豚队不利的判罚就破口大骂。这似乎是对他的“奖励”——一个他肯定喜欢的判罚，以及之前两次对我们不利的判罚。尽管49人队的赛季已经糟糕透顶，但我们之前从未遭遇过如此痛苦和惨痛的经历。而观众们却为此欢呼雀跃。
Sensing the imminent kill, fans went into a stadium-wide uproar as we silently turned the ball back to Miami—the game essentially over as the Dolphins extended our losing streak to eight games with their 17-13 victory. The pain of that loss haunts me even now as I think about those final seconds ticking off the clock.
眼看败局已定，球迷们在球场上爆发出一阵骚动，而我们却默默地将球权交还给了迈阿密——比赛实际上已经结束了，海豚队以17比13的比分获胜，将我们的连败纪录扩大到八场。即使现在，每当我想起比赛最后几秒钟的流逝，那场失利的痛苦依然萦绕着我。
It was a horrible and numbing defeat, overwhelming for me because of its potential impact—a job I had worked for my entire adult life was in jeopardy—but also because of the stupid, self-inflicted, almost suicidal way in which we lost. As the crowd roared its approval and Miami players and fans swarmed over the field, I stood alone on the sideline in a cocoon of grief, emotionally gutted, wondering if I had the strength to even get back to our locker room.
那是一场惨痛而令人麻木的失败，对我来说，它带来的潜在影响——我毕生为之奋斗的工作岌岌可危——以及我们愚蠢、自作自受、近乎自杀式的失败方式，都让我感到无比沉重。当人群发出震耳欲聋的欢呼声，迈阿密队的球员和球迷涌入球场时，我独自一人站在场边，沉浸在悲痛之中，心如刀绞，甚至怀疑自己是否还有力气回到更衣室。
Unless you’ve experienced this type of emotional shock and the bleak interior landscape it creates, it’s hard to comprehend the impact. The memory never leaves you and acts as both a positive and negative force, spurring you to work harder and harder while also creating a fear inside that it might happen again. (For me, that fear eventually became more than I could handle.)
除非你亲身经历过这种情感冲击以及它所带来的内心煎熬，否则很难理解它的影响。这段记忆会永远萦绕在你心头，既是积极的力量，也是消极的力量，它激励你更加努力，同时也让你内心充满恐惧，害怕悲剧重演。（对我而言，这种恐惧最终让我难以承受。）
Now Shula trotted briskly across the field to shake hands and offer a few perfunctory words of condolence. I have no clue as to what he said, but even though I was in some state of shock, instincts took over. I offered my hand; he shook it, shouted something in my ear, and disappeared back into the public pandemonium and celebration at midfield.
舒拉轻快地小跑过场，过来和大家握手，敷衍地说了几句慰问的话。我完全不知道他说了什么，虽然当时我有些震惊，但本能还是支配了我。我伸出手，他握了握，在我耳边喊了几句，然后就消失在球场中央的喧闹和庆祝人群中。
The next few hours—until we got out of the stadium complex and arrived at the Miami airport—remain a blur. I can’t remember what, if anything, I said to the players and coaches in the locker room or reporters in the press room. Probably I was on some kind of automatic pilot and experiencing what victims of violence go through when they blot out the memory of the assault.
接下来的几个小时——直到我们离开体育场抵达迈阿密机场——都模糊不清。我记不清自己在更衣室里跟球员和教练说了什么，或者在新闻发布室里跟记者说了什么。或许我当时就像处于一种自动驾驶状态，体验着暴力受害者试图抹去袭击记忆时所经历的一切。
While the moments immediately following that game are missing in my mind, the long trip home is vivid. Coaches aren’t supposed to cry, but I’m not ashamed to admit that on the night flight back to San Francisco I sat in my seat in the first row of the plane and broke down sobbing in the darkness. I felt like a casualty of war being airlifted away from the battlefield.
虽然赛后那一刻的记忆已经模糊，但漫长的回家之旅却历历在目。教练不应该哭，但我并不羞于承认，在飞回旧金山的夜航上，我坐在飞机第一排的座位上，在黑暗中崩溃大哭。我感觉自己就像一个战争伤员，被空运离了战场。
Bill McPherson, Neal Dahlen, John McVay, Norb Hecker, and some of the other San Francisco assistant coaches and staff understood the grief I was experiencing and shielded me from any players who might come into the area—they huddled around my seat, blocking off view of me, while making small talk and eating peanuts, acting like we were all involved in the conversation.
比尔·麦克弗森、尼尔·达伦、约翰·麦克维、诺布·赫克尔以及其他一些旧金山队的助理教练和工作人员理解我正在经历的悲痛，并保护我免受任何可能进入该区域的球员的打扰——他们围在我的座位周围，挡住了我的视线，一边闲聊一边吃花生，装作我们都参与了谈话。
Believe me, I was not participating in whatever it was they said or eating peanuts as I slumped down, depressed, in my dark little space, contemplating whether I should offer my resignation. Most debilitating of all—devastating—was a gnawing fear that I didn’t have what it takes to be an NFL head coach. At one point I actually decided to hand in my resignation the next morning; then I changed my mind.
相信我，我当时根本没参与他们说的那些话，也没像有些人那样，垂头丧气地窝在自己阴暗的小角落里吃花生，琢磨着要不要递交辞呈。最让我崩溃、最痛苦的，莫过于一种挥之不去的恐惧：我根本没能力胜任NFL主教练的职位。有那么一刻，我真的决定第二天早上就递交辞呈；后来，我又改变了主意。
I have tried to describe my anguish, but the words come up short. Everything I had dreamed of professionally for a quarter of a century was in jeopardy just eighteen months after being realized. And yet there was something else going on inside me, a “voice” from down deeper than the emotions, something stirring that I had learned over many years in football and, before that, growing up; namely, I must stand and fight again, stand and fight or it was all over.
我试图描述我的痛苦，但言语却显得苍白无力。我毕生追求的职业梦想，仅仅在实现十八个月后就岌岌可危。然而，我的内心深处还有另一种声音在涌动，一种超越情感的“声音”，一种我在足球生涯多年以及更早的成长经历中所领悟到的信念：我必须再次站起来战斗，站起来战斗，否则一切都将结束。
And that was the instinct that slowly prevailed as we headed home in the middle of a very dark night. I knew that in a matter of seven days the New York Giants were coming to town with the sole intent of making sure that neither I nor the San Francisco 49ers would stand and fight again.
就在我们漆黑的夜里开车回家时，这种本能慢慢占据了上风。我知道，七天后，纽约巨人队就要来旧金山了，他们唯一的目的就是要让我和旧金山49人队都再也无法站起来战斗。
In my mind—or gut—and in spite of the pain, I knew I had to force myself to somehow start looking ahead—to overcome my grief over the debacle in Miami—or it would severely damage our efforts to prepare properly for the battle with New York; my comportment would directly affect the attitudes and performance of everyone who looked to me for answers and direction. I had to do what I was being paid to do: be a leader.
在我的内心深处——或者说直觉上——尽管痛苦万分，我知道我必须强迫自己开始向前看，克服迈阿密惨败带来的悲痛，否则将会严重损害我们为与纽约的比赛所做的充分准备；我的言行举止将直接影响到所有向我寻求答案和方向的人的态度和表现。我必须履行我的职责：成为一名领导者。
I wish I could tell you that’s what happened—that I simply turned a switch and was magically transformed from an emotional basket case into an invincible field general. It wasn’t that way. It took time for me to stop despairing and regain some composure, to settle down and start thinking straight, but gradually, during those hard hours on the flight back to California, I began pulling myself together.
我真希望事情就是这样发生的——我只是轻轻按了一下开关，就神奇地从一个情绪崩溃的人变成了一个所向披靡的指挥官。但事实并非如此。我花了很长时间才不再绝望，重新找回一些平静，冷静下来，理清思路。但渐渐地，在返回加州的漫长飞行途中，我开始振作起来。
In the NFL events occur—hit you—at supersonic speeds with volcanic force during the regular season. There aren’t months or weeks to recover, not even days. Usually only hours or minutes. While you’re throwing a wolf out the back door, another is banging on your front door and two more are trying to crawl through the windows. I could hear the New York Giants at our front door.
在NFL常规赛期间，各种事件以超音速般的速度和火山爆发般的威力发生——并冲击着你。你没有几个月或几周的时间来恢复，甚至几天都没有。通常只有几个小时或几分钟。当你把一只狼从后门赶走时，另一只狼正在猛烈地敲打你的前门，还有两只狼正试图从窗户爬进来。我仿佛都能听到纽约巨人队就在我家门口了。
I can say with some pride that by the time we landed at San Francisco International Airport at 3:15 A.M. after a six-hour flight, I had pulled myself out of the hopelessness and begun working on the strategy we would employ against the Giants when they arrived in a week. I was wobbly but back up on my feet again. I even ate a couple of bags of peanuts and drank some orange juice.
我可以颇为自豪地说，经过六个小时的飞行，凌晨3点15分抵达旧金山国际机场时，我已经从绝望中走了出来，开始思考一周后巨人队到来时我们要采取的策略。虽然我当时有些踉跄，但总算重新站了起来。我甚至还吃了两包花生，喝了点橙汁。
Those awful feelings brought on by the events in Miami were in retreat because I was able to summon strength enough to pull my focus , my thinking, out of the past and move it forward to our next big problem. It does take strength to shift your attention off the pain when you feel as though your soul has been stripped bare.
迈阿密事件带来的那些糟糕感受逐渐消退，因为我鼓起勇气，将注意力从过去转移到下一个重大问题上。当你感觉自己的灵魂仿佛被剥得精光时，要将注意力从痛苦中转移开来，确实需要很大的勇气。
At times like that I would think back to my days as an amateur boxer, when I’d see a guy knocked flat on his back and then awkwardly struggle to one shaky knee. Everything is blurry, his balance is gone, consciousness is tenuous, he’s bleeding and bruised, but as bad as things are there is one message he hears ringing inside his head: “Stand up, boy; stand up and fight.” I know because as a young man I was that boxer.
每当这时，我就会想起自己当业余拳击手的日子。那时，我常常看到有人被击倒在地，然后笨拙地单膝跪地。眼前一片模糊，他失去了平衡，意识模糊，浑身是血，伤痕累累。但即便情况如此糟糕，他脑海中仍然回荡着一个声音：“站起来，孩子；站起来战斗。”我知道，因为年轻时，我就是那样的拳击手。
NFL football is no different from any professional endeavor, boxing or business or anything where the stakes are significant and the competition extreme: When knocked down, you must get up; you must stand and fight.
NFL橄榄球与任何职业活动、拳击、商业或任何风险重大、竞争激烈的领域并无不同：被击倒后，你必须站起来；你必须站起来战斗。
When the inevitable setback, loss, failure, or defeat comes crashing down on you—losing a big sale, being passed over for a career-making promotion, even getting fired—allow yourself the “grieving time,” but then recognize that the road to recovery and victory lies in having the strength to get up off the mat and start planning your next move.
当不可避免的挫折、损失、失败或挫败向你袭来——比如失去一笔大生意、错失一次能改变职业生涯的晋升机会，甚至被解雇——允许自己“哀悼一段时间”，但随后要认识到，通往复苏和胜利的道路在于有力量从困境中站起来，开始计划下一步行动。
This is how you must think if you want to win. Otherwise you have lost.
如果你想赢，就必须这样想。否则，你就输了。
For me, on that flight back home after the Miami loss, it meant working one minute at a time—literally—to regain composure, confidence, and direction.
对我来说，在迈阿密输球后回家的航班上，意味着要一分钟一分钟地努力——真的是一分钟一分钟地努力——才能重新找回冷静、自信和方向。
Failure is part of success, an integral part. Everybody gets knocked down. Knowing it will happen and what you must do when it does is the first step back. It’s what got me up after being knocked down and almost out in Miami. I knew I had to stand and start facing the imminent challenge of a battle with the New York Giants.
失败是成功的一部分，是不可或缺的一部分。每个人都会遭遇挫折。明白挫折终会发生，以及挫折发生时你必须做什么，是重新振作的第一步。正是这种信念，让我从迈阿密那次几乎被击倒的打击中重新站了起来。我知道我必须站起来，开始面对即将到来的挑战——与纽约巨人队的较量。
One other thing about that upcoming game: On Sunday we defeated the Giants 12-0 at Candlestick Park and regained a little equilibrium, even momentum. A week later we beat New England 21-17; the next week the 49ers engineered one of the greatest comebacks in NFL history. Trailing at the half, 35-7, we defeated New Orleans in overtime, 38-35.
关于即将到来的比赛还有一点：上周日我们在烛台公园以12比0击败了巨人队，找回了一些平衡，也重新找回了势头。一周后，我们以21比17战胜了新英格兰爱国者队；再下一周，49人队上演了NFL历史上最伟大的逆转之一。半场以7比35落后，我们在加时赛中以38比35击败了新奥尔良圣徒队。
In fact, in spite of losing to the Atlanta Falcons and Buffalo Bills in our last two games to finish with a 6-10 record, the worst was over. Unbeknownst to me, we had hit rock bottom against the Dolphins. Sixteen months after I spent part of a transcontinental flight experiencing an emotional meltdown, the San Francisco 49ers became world champions, defeating the Cincinnati Bengals 26-21 at the Silverdome in Pontiac, Michigan, in Super Bowl XVI. In fact, a football dynasty was in the works.
事实上，尽管我们在最后两场比赛中分别输给了亚特兰大猎鹰队和布法罗比尔队，最终以6胜10负的战绩收官，但最糟糕的时期已经过去。我当时并不知道，我们在对阵迈阿密海豚队的比赛中已经跌入谷底。在我经历了一次跨大陆航班上的情绪崩溃16个月后，旧金山49人队在第十六届超级碗中，于密歇根州庞蒂亚克的银穹体育场以26比21击败辛辛那提猛虎队，荣膺世界冠军。事实上，一个橄榄球王朝正在崛起。
During the ensuing fourteen years, the San Francisco 49ers won five Super Bowls. It happened only because at the moment of deepest despair I had the strength to stand and confront the future instead of wallowing in the past. Many can’t summon the strength; they can’t get up; their fight is over. Victory goes to another, a stronger competitor.
在接下来的十四年里，旧金山49人队赢得了五次超级碗冠军。这一切的发生，仅仅是因为在最绝望的时刻，我拥有了站起来面对未来的力量，而不是沉湎于过去。许多人没有这样的力量；他们无法重新站起来；他们的战斗已经结束。胜利最终会属于另一个人，一个更强大的竞争对手。
Competition at the highest level in sports or business produces gut-ripping setbacks. When you’re fighting for your survival professionally, struggling when virtually no one else knows or cares, and there’s nobody to bail you out, that’s when you might remind yourself of my own dark night of despair.
在体育或商业的最高级别竞争中，难免会遭遇令人痛彻心扉的挫折。当你为了职业生涯的生存而苦苦挣扎，几乎无人知晓或关心，也无人伸出援手时，你或许会想起我曾经经历的那段绝望的黑暗时期。
When you stand and overcome a significant setback, you’ll find an increasing inner confidence and self-assurance that has been created by conquering defeat. Absorbing and overcoming this kind of punishment engenders a sober, steely toughness that results in a hardened sense of independence and a personal belief that you can take on anything, survive and win.
当你挺身而出，克服重大挫折时，你会发现内心深处的自信和自尊与日俱增，这是战胜失败的结晶。承受并克服这种打击会培养出一种冷静、钢铁般的坚韧，最终形成一种强大的独立意识，以及一种相信自己能够应对一切、生存下来并取得胜利的信念。
The competitor who won’t go away, who won’t stay down, has one of the most formidable competitive advantages of all. When the worst happens, as it did to me, I was helped by knowing what it took to be that kind of competitor—to not go away, to get up and fight back.
永不放弃、永不言败的竞争者拥有最强大的竞争优势之一。当最糟糕的情况发生时，就像我曾经经历的那样，我之所以能够挺过来，是因为我深知成为那种竞争者需要具备哪些素质——永不放弃，重新站起来反击。
The Miami game was not the last time I faced a grim situation as head coach, but when downturns occurred during the upcoming years, I tried to adhere to some simple dos and don’ts for mental and emotional equilibrium in my personal and professional life; nothing profound, just a few plain and uncomplicated reminders that helped me manage things mentally and stay afloat:
MY FIVE DOS FOR GETTING BACK INTO THE GAME:
1. Do expect defeat. It’s a given when the stakes are high and the competition is working ferociously to beat you. If you’re surprised when it happens, you’re dreaming; dreamers don’t last long.
2. Do force yourself to stop looking backward and dwelling on the professional “train wreck” you have just been in. It’s mental quicksand.
3. Do allow yourself appropriate recovery—grieving—time. You’ve been knocked senseless; give yourself a little time to recuperate. A keyword here is “little.” Don’t let it drag on.
4. Do tell yourself, “I am going to stand and fight again,” with the knowledge that often when things are at their worst you’re closer than you can imagine to success. Our Super Bowl victory arrived less than sixteen months after my “train wreck” in Miami.
5. Do begin planning for your next serious encounter. The smallest steps—plans—move you forward on the road to recovery. Focus on the fix.
MY FIVE DON’TS:
1. Don’t ask, “Why me?”
2. Don’t expect sympathy.
3. Don’t bellyache.
4. Don’t keep accepting condolences.
5. Don’t blame others.
迈阿密那场比赛并不是我作为主教练最后一次遭遇困境，但在接下来的几年里，每当遇到低谷时，我都会尝试遵循一些简单的原则，以保持个人和职业生活中的心理和情绪平衡；这些原则并不深奥，只是一些简单明了的提醒，帮助我管理好心态，不至于崩溃：我的五条重返赛场的秘诀：1. 要做好失败的准备。当比赛充满挑战，对手全力以赴想要击败你时，失败是必然的。如果你对失败感到惊讶，那说明你还在做梦；做梦的人不会长久。2. 要强迫自己停止回顾过去，停止沉湎于刚刚经历的职业生涯“灾难”。那样只会让你陷入精神的流沙。3. 要给自己适当的恢复——或者说哀悼——时间。你已经被打击得晕头转向；给自己一些时间来恢复。这里的关键词是“一些”。不要让时间拖延。4.告诉自己，“我要重新站起来战斗”，要知道，往往在最糟糕的时候，你离成功比你想象的更近。我们在迈阿密遭遇“惨败”不到十六个月后就赢得了超级碗冠军。5. 开始为你的下一次重大挑战做准备。哪怕是最小的一步——计划——也能推动你走向康复之路。专注于解决问题。我的五条禁忌：1. 不要问“为什么是我？”2. 不要期待同情。3. 不要抱怨。4. 不要一直接受安慰。5. 不要责怪他人。

My Standard of Performance: High Requirements for Actions and Attitudes 我的工作标准：对行为和态度有很高的要求
People asked me over the years, “Bill, when you became head coach and general manager of the 49ers, did you have a timetable for winning the Super Bowl?” My answer is succinct: “No.”
多年来，人们一直问我：“比尔，当你成为49人队的主教练兼总经理时，你有没有制定赢得超级碗的时间表？”我的回答很简洁：“没有。”
Things were in such bad shape when I arrived that talk of a Super Bowl championship for San Francisco would have sounded delusional; people would have thought I was crazy. (In fact, some did think I was crazy for leaving a job at Stanford University, where I had been comfortably ensconced as head coach of a team that had just won two consecutive postseason bowl games—the Bluebonnet Bowl and the Sun Bowl. Additionally, I felt very much at home in the academic environment at Stanford.)
我刚到的时候，旧金山的情况糟透了，当时谈论旧金山队赢得超级碗冠军简直是痴人说梦；人们会觉得我疯了。（事实上，有些人确实觉得我疯了，因为我离开了斯坦福大学的工作，当时我在那里担任主教练，带领球队刚刚连续赢得了两场季后赛碗赛——蓝帽碗和太阳碗。此外，我在斯坦福的学术氛围中感觉非常自在。）
In the two years before I joined San Francisco, my predecessor as 49ers general manager, Joe Thomas, had basically gutted the entire 49er organization, forcing out head coach Monte Clark, whose 8-6 record had been the 49ers’ first winning season in four years; hiring and firing three head coaches in twelve months; impetuously and vindictively firing—humiliating—players in front of the team; trading away or releasing quality talent, including quarterback Jim Plunkett to the Oakland Raiders, whom he would soon take to two Super Bowl championships; and removing all “success” memorabilia from previous years (including trophies for three divisional championships, banners, plaques, game programs, photographs of teams, and even MVP awards).
在我加入旧金山49人队之前的两年里，我的前任总经理乔·托马斯基本上彻底重组了49人队，迫使主教练蒙特·克拉克离职，克拉克执教期间球队取得了8胜6负的战绩，这是49人队四年来的第一个胜率超过50%的赛季；在12个月内聘用并解雇了三位主教练；在全队面前鲁莽且带有报复性地解雇球员，令他们颜面尽失；交易或裁掉优秀人才，包括将四分卫吉姆·普伦克特交易到奥克兰突袭者队，普伦克特很快将带领突袭者队两次获得超级碗冠军；并移除了所有往年的“成功”纪念品（包括三个分区冠军的奖杯、横幅、牌匾、比赛手册、球队照片，甚至最有价值球员奖）。
Perhaps the highlight of Thomas’s mismanagement was his acquisition of O. J. Simpson from the Buffalo Bills when the superstar was at the end of his career—overweight, arthritic, and out of gas. Thomas had concluded that Simpson would attract fans simply because he was a local kid from San Francisco’s Potrero Hill neighborhood.
托马斯管理不善的典型例子或许就是他从布法罗比尔队签下O·J·辛普森。当时这位超级巨星已步入职业生涯末期——身材走样、关节炎缠身、状态下滑。托马斯想当然地认为，辛普森会吸引球迷，仅仅因为他是旧金山波特雷罗山社区的本地人。
Fans thought otherwise and decided that seeing Simpson sitting bored on the bench with a bag of ice on his knee was not worth the price of admission. The cost to the organization was extreme: Thomas gave Buffalo draft picks that included first-, second- (two of them), third-, and fourth-round choices over three years and appeared to have mortgaged away the future of the franchise. All of the above was part of his plan to start a “new era of 49er football.” It certainly was.
球迷们却不这么认为，他们觉得看到辛普森百无聊赖地坐在替补席上，膝盖上敷着冰袋，实在不值得花这笔钱去看球。而对于球队来说，代价更是惨重：托马斯将三年内包括首轮、次轮（两个）、三轮和四轮在内的选秀权拱手让给了布法罗，似乎已经透支了球队的未来。以上种种，都是他开启“49人队新时代”计划的一部分。的确如此。
What remained was a demoralized, chaotic, and near-mutinous organizational culture of failure that was epitomized by a team that produced a 2-14 record the year prior to my arrival (and was even worse than that record suggests). One writer declared that the San Francisco 49ers were the worst franchise in all of professional sports. Not just football— all professional sports.
剩下的只有士气低落、混乱不堪、近乎叛乱的失败组织文化，而这支球队在我到任前一年的战绩（2胜14负，实际表现甚至比战绩所显示的还要糟糕）正是这种失败文化的缩影。一位作家甚至断言，旧金山49人队是所有职业体育项目中最糟糕的球队。不仅仅是橄榄球——而是所有职业体育项目。
Joe Thomas was summarily fired; I was hired.
乔·托马斯被立即解雇；我被录用了。
That’s what I faced on my first day of work—an organization in turmoil; a team whose roster of talent was paper-thin and tattered; a future that seemed dismal, in part because in spite of that 2-14 season the year before I arrived, I didn’t even have a first-round draft pick.
这就是我上班第一天所面临的情况——一个处于动荡中的组织；一支人才匮乏、支离破碎的球队；一个看起来黯淡无光的未来，部分原因是尽管在我到来的前一年球队战绩为 2 胜 14 负，但我甚至连一个首轮选秀权都没有。
Emblematic of the organizational dysfunction were the organization’s substandard headquarters and training facility. There wasn’t enough space for a regulation-size football field, so the team used two “semifields” in Redwood City, California. The weight room was sparsely furnished with rusting weights, the showers ran cold if somebody flushed a toilet, and our offices were worn, sparse, and cramped.
组织内部运作失灵的典型表现是其总部和训练设施的简陋。场地不够大，无法容纳一个标准的足球场，所以球队只能在加州红木城租用两个“半场”。健身房里摆放着一些锈迹斑斑的器械，如果有人冲过马桶，淋浴的水就会变成冷水，而我们的办公室也破旧、简陋、拥挤不堪。
Consequently, I approached building the 49er organization with an agenda that didn’t include a timetable for a championship or even a winning season.
