Instead, I arrived with an urgent timetable for installing an agenda of specific behavioral norms—actions and attitudes—that applied to every single person on our payroll.
因此，我在组建49人队时，并没有设定夺冠时间表，甚至连赛季胜率都未定。相反，我制定了一套紧迫的计划，旨在为队中每一位员工建立一套具体的行为规范——包括行动和态度。
To put it bluntly, I would teach each person in the organization what to do and how to think. The short-term results would contribute both symbolically and functionally to a new and productive self-image and environment and become the foundation upon which we could launch our longer-term goal, namely, the resurrection of a football franchise.
坦白地说，我会教会组织里的每个人该做什么、该怎么思考。短期成果将在象征意义和实际操作层面上，帮助我们树立新的、高效的自我形象，营造积极的工作环境，并以此为基础，开启我们的长期目标——重振这支足球队。
For me to do this I had to have autonomy, the power to quickly make decisions in all relevant areas. Team owner Eddie DeBartolo understood this and named me general manager soon after I became head coach. Equally important, he let everyone in the organization know that I was the boss and that he would not undercut my authority. Without this power and support my task would have been virtually impossible given the abysmal situation.
为了完成这项工作，我必须拥有自主权，即在所有相关领域迅速做出决策的权力。球队老板埃迪·德巴托洛明白这一点，在我成为主教练后不久就任命我为总经理。同样重要的是，他让组织内的每个人都知道我是老板，他不会削弱我的权力。如果没有这种权力和支持，在当时糟糕的形势下，我的任务几乎是不可能完成的。
While the media eventually and inappropriately labeled me “the Genius,” the 49ers’ subsequent turnaround—from a 2-14 record my first season to Super Bowl champions twenty-four months later (becoming the first and only team in NFL history to go from the worst to the best in two seasons), from organizational chaos to praise from the Harvard Business Review for organizational excellence—was due in large part to many quantifiable, even nuts-and-bolts, skills available to you or anyone with drive and intelligence.
虽然媒体最终不恰当地称我为“天才”，但49人队随后的转变——从我执教的第一个赛季的2胜14负到24个月后的超级碗冠军（成为NFL历史上第一支也是唯一一支在两个赛季内从最差到最好的球队），从组织混乱到因卓越的组织能力而受到《哈佛商业评论》的赞扬——很大程度上归功于许多可量化的、甚至是具体的技能，这些技能你或任何有动力和智慧的人都可以掌握。
There was innovation and expertise, yes; force of will, certainly; and occasional good fortune, of course. But my organizational and managerial starting point was something else. I came to the San Francisco 49ers with an overriding priority and specific goal—to implement what I call the Standard of Performance. It was a way of doing things, a leadership philosophy that has as much to do with core values, principles, and ideals as with blocking, tackling, and passing; more to do with the mental than with the physical. While I prized preparation, planning, precision, and poise, I also knew that organizational ethics were crucial to ultimate and ongoing success.
创新和专业技能固然重要；意志力也必不可少；偶尔的好运自然也必不可少。但我组织和管理理念的出发点却截然不同。我来到旧金山49人队时，心中怀揣着一个至高无上的使命和明确的目标——推行我所谓的“绩效标准”。这是一种做事方式，一种领导哲学，它不仅关乎进攻、防守和传球，更关乎核心价值观、原则和理想；它更侧重于精神层面而非身体层面。我重视准备、计划、精准和沉着，但我也深知，组织伦理对于最终的成功和持续的成功至关重要。
It began with this fundamental leadership assertion: Regardless of your specific job, it is vital to our team that you do that job at the highest possible level in all its various aspects, both mental and physical (i.e., good talent with bad attitude equals bad talent).
一切始于这一基本的领导理念：无论你的具体工作是什么，对我们的团队来说，至关重要的是，你必须在工作的各个方面，包括心理和生理方面，都做到最高水平（也就是说，有才华但态度不好等于没才华）。

An Organization Has a Conscience 一个组织是有良知的。
Beyond the mechanical elements of doing jobs correctly, I assisted coaches, players, staff, and others in assimilating the values within my Standard of Performance, including what I believed regarding personal accountability among the organization and its personnel. This is consistent with my conviction that an organization is not just a tool like a shovel, but an organic entity that has a code of conduct, a set of applied principles that go beyond a company mission statement that’s tacked on the wall and forgotten. In fact, we had no mission statement on the wall. My mission statement was implanted in the minds of our people through teaching.
除了确保各项工作按部就班地完成之外，我还帮助教练、球员、工作人员和其他人员理解并践行我的绩效标准中所蕴含的价值观，包括我对组织及其成员个人责任的信念。这与我的理念相符：一个组织不仅仅是一把铲子之类的工具，而是一个有机的整体，它拥有自己的行为准则和一套切实可行的原则，远非那种贴在墙上、很快就会被遗忘的公司使命宣言所能比拟。事实上，我们公司并没有把使命宣言贴在墙上。我的使命宣言是通过教导的方式深深植入到每个人的心中的。
Great teams in business, in sports, or elsewhere have a conscience. At its best, an organization—your team—bespeaks values and a way of doing things that emanate from a source; that source is you—the leader. Thus, the dictates of your personal beliefs should ultimately become characteristics of your team.
无论是在商业、体育还是其他领域，优秀的团队都拥有良知。一个优秀的组织——你的团队——会体现出一种价值观和行事方式，而这种价值观和行事方式源于一个源泉；这个源泉就是你——领导者。因此，你个人的信念最终应该成为你团队的特征。
You must know what needs to be done and possess the capabilities and conviction to get it done. Several factors affect this, but none is more important than the dictates of your own personal beliefs. Collectively, they comprise your philosophy. A philosophy is the aggregate of your attitudes toward fundamental matters and is derived from a process of consciously thinking about critical issues and developing rational reasons for holding one particular belief or position rather than another.
你必须清楚需要做什么，并且具备完成它的能力和信念。诸多因素会影响这一点，但最重要的莫过于你个人的信念。这些信念共同构成了你的哲学。哲学是你对基本问题的态度总和，它源于对关键问题进行有意识的思考，并为持有某种特定信念或立场而非其他信念或立场而发展出合理的理由。
Many things shape your philosophy, including your background, experiences, work environment, education, aspirations, and more. By adhering to your philosophical tenets you are provided with a systematic, yet practical, method of deciding what to do in a particular situation.
塑造你人生哲学的因素有很多，包括你的背景、经历、工作环境、教育、抱负等等。遵循你的哲学原则，你就能获得一套系统而实用的方法，来决定在特定情况下应该怎么做。
It is a conceptual blueprint for action; that is, a perception of what should be done, when it should be done, and why it should be done. Your philosophy is the single most important navigational point on your leadership compass.
它是一份行动的概念蓝图；也就是说，它阐述了应该做什么、何时做以及为什么做。你的理念是你领导力指南针上最重要的指路明灯。
My Standard of Performance—the values and beliefs within it—guided everything I did in my work at San Francisco and are defined as follows: Exhibit a ferocious and intelligently applied work ethic directed at continual improvement; demonstrate respect for each person in the organization and the work he or she does; be deeply committed to learning and teaching, which means increasing my own expertise; be fair; demonstrate character; honor the direct connection between details and improvement, and relentlessly seek the latter; show self-control, especially where it counts most—under pressure; demonstrate and prize loyalty; use positive language and have a positive attitude; take pride in my effort as an entity separate from the result of that effort; be willing to go the extra distance for the organization; deal appropriately with victory and defeat, adulation and humiliation (don’t get crazy with victory nor dysfunctional with loss); promote internal communication that is both open and substantive (especially under stress); seek poise in myself and those I lead; put the team’s welfare and priorities ahead of my own; maintain an ongoing level of concentration and focus that is abnormally high; and make sacrifice and commitment the organization’s trademark.
我在旧金山工作期间，我的绩效标准——其中包含的价值观和信念——指导着我的一切工作，具体定义如下：展现出积极进取、智慧高效的职业道德，致力于持续改进；尊重组织中的每一位成员及其工作；全身心投入学习和教学，这意味着不断提升自身的专业技能；秉持公平公正的原则；展现出高尚的品格；重视细节与改进之间的直接联系，并坚持不懈地追求改进；展现出极强的自制力，尤其是在压力之下；展现并珍视忠诚；使用积极的语言，保持积极的态度；为自身的努力感到自豪，无论最终结果如何；愿意为组织付出额外的努力；妥善处理胜利与失败、赞扬与羞辱（既不要因胜利而得意忘形，也不要因失败而失控）；促进公开且实质性的内部沟通（尤其是在压力之下）；保持自身及团队成员的沉着冷静；将团队的福祉和优先事项置于个人利益之上；保持高度的专注力和注意力。并将牺牲和奉献作为该组织的标志。
These are also the basic characteristics of attitude and action—the new organizational ethos—I tried to teach our team, to put into our DNA. Of course, for this to happen the person in charge—whether a head coach, CEO, manager, or assembly-line foreman—must exhibit the principles, code of conduct, and behavior he or she is asking others to emulate. I believe I did this.
这些也是态度和行动的基本特征——新的组织精神——我试图将其传授给我们的团队，并融入我们的基因。当然，要做到这一点，负责人——无论是主教练、首席执行官、经理还是流水线工头——都必须以身作则，展现出他或她要求他人效仿的原则、行为准则和行为方式。我相信我做到了。
Make no mistake about it; my first commitment was to nurture an organizational conscience with this very high internal code of ethics, ideals, and attitudes. Concurrently, I was committed to identifying and hiring the best people I could find and teaching them what I deemed necessary to achieve the required levels of performance.
毋庸置疑，我的首要任务是培养一种组织意识，并以此为基础，构建一套高度内部化的道德准则、理想和态度。与此同时，我也致力于寻找并聘用最优秀的人才，并传授他们我认为达到预期绩效水平所必需的技能。
If you were lucky enough to receive a 49er paycheck, it meant you were part of an organization that had high expectations of itself and of you, whether you were a superstar or a secretary, manager or maintenance man, athlete, executive, or head coach. Those expectations, of course, went beyond ethics and attitude to specific performance standards and actions.
如果你有幸拿到旧金山49人队的薪水，那就意味着你加入了一个对自身和员工都抱有很高期望的组织，无论你是超级球星还是秘书，经理还是维修工，运动员、高管还是主教练。当然，这些期望不仅仅体现在道德和态度上，还包括具体的绩效标准和行为准则。

Specifics of My New Standards 我的新标准的具体细节
For returning players, veterans acquired in trades, and rookies such as Notre Dame’s Joe Montana and Clemson University receiver Dwight Clark, my Standard of Performance required not only maximum mental and physical effort, sacrifice, and commitment but also attention to such seemingly incidental requirements as “no shirttails out,” “positive attitude,” “promptness,” “good sportsmanship (no strutting, no posturing, no cheap shots),” “never sit down while on the practice field,” “no tank tops in the dining area,” “control of profanity,” “no fighting,” “treat fans with respect and exhibit a professional demeanor,” and many more, including “no smoking on premises,” which applied to all of us. Much of this may seem trivial to you, but it adds up and changes the environment.
对于回归球员、通过交易引进的老将以及像圣母大学的乔·蒙塔纳和克莱姆森大学的外接手德怀特·克拉克这样的新秀，我的绩效标准不仅要求他们付出最大的精神和体力努力、做出牺牲和全身心投入，还要求他们注意一些看似无关紧要的要求，例如“衬衫下摆不得外露”、“积极的态度”、“准时”、“良好的体育精神（不得趾高气扬、不得摆架子、不得恶意犯规）”、“在训练场上不得坐下”、“餐厅内不得穿背心”、“控制脏话”、“不得打架”、“尊重球迷并展现职业风范”等等，其中还包括“场馆内禁止吸烟”，这条规定适用于我们所有人。这些规定中的很多在你看来可能微不足道，但它们累积起来就会改变整个环境。
For example, how the players dressed at practice and the appearance they gave to others when taking the field was very important to me. I wanted our football team to look truly professional—impeccable. Thus, shirttails tucked in, socks up tight, and more were requirements.
例如，球员们在训练中的着装以及他们在球场上展现出的形象对我来说非常重要。我希望我们的橄榄球队看起来真正专业——无可挑剔。因此，衬衫下摆塞进裤子里，袜子拉紧等等都是硬性要求。
Later, when Jerry Rice, our great receiver, joined the team, he would stand in front of a full-length mirror as he got dressed before a game, not because he was vain or adoring himself—maybe there was a little of that—but mostly because he was just looking at that uniform; he was looking at perfection; perfection was what was in his mind when he entered the arena.
后来，我们伟大的接球手杰里·赖斯加入球队后，他会在赛前穿衣服时站在全身镜前，这并不是因为他虚荣或自恋——也许有一点点——而是因为他只是在看着那套队服；他在看着完美；当他走进赛场时，他的脑海中只有完美。
Jerry Rice was a professional and looked like a professional. And it all helped him in some way to think and perform like a professional. That “perfect” appearance—“ appropriate appearance” is more accurate—applied to others in the organization as well, because it is part of the motif that directs thinking into a mode I view as conducive to high performance. That perfect appearance was a predicate of perfect performance.
杰里·赖斯是一位专业人士，他的外表也像一位专业人士。这一切在某种程度上帮助他像专业人士一样思考和工作。这种“完美”的外表——更准确地说是“得体的外表”——也适用于组织中的其他人，因为它是引导人们进入一种我认为有利于高绩效的思维模式的准则之一。这种完美的外表是完美绩效的前提。
Of course, our coaching staff was meticulous and tenacious in analyzing and then teaching the requirements of each player’s position—much more so than on any other team I knew of. Here’s one very small example: After careful analysis, they identified thirty specific and separate physical skills—actions—that every offensive lineman needed to master in order to do his job at the highest level, everything from tackling to evasion, footwork to arm movement. Our coaches then created multiple drills for each one of those individual skills, which were then practiced relentlessly until their execution at the highest level was automatic—routine “perfection.”
当然，我们的教练团队一丝不苟、精益求精，在分析和指导每位球员的位置要求方面做得非常出色——远胜于我所知的任何其他球队。举个小例子：经过仔细分析，他们确定了每位进攻锋线球员必须掌握的三十项具体且独立的身体技能——动作——才能在高水平比赛中发挥出色，涵盖了从擒抱到闪避、从脚步移动到手臂动作等方方面面。我们的教练随后为每一项技能设计了多种训练方法，并进行不懈的练习，直到球员们能够下意识地、自然而然地做到极致——达到“完美”的境界。
Linemen were taught multiple blocking techniques to capitalize on what they saw across the line of scrimmage; most teams taught far fewer. Quarterbacks were coached on the refined requirements of a three-step, five-step, and seven-step drop back; how to hold the ball; where to hold the ball (the tip of the football must never drop below waist level on a pass play); scanning the entire field for receivers; when to throw and not to throw; throwing the ball at different velocities and different trajectories; and hundreds of other elements, both mental and physical.
进攻锋线球员被教授多种阻挡技巧，以便充分利用他们在进攻线上观察到的情况；大多数球队教授的技巧远少于此。四分卫则接受训练，学习三步、五步和七步后撤步的精细要求；如何持球；持球位置（传球时，橄榄球的尖端绝不能低于腰部）；如何观察整个球场寻找接球手；何时传球以及何时不传球；以不同的速度和轨迹传球；以及其他数百种技巧，包括心理和生理两方面。
Passing routes were designed down to the inch and then practiced until receivers learned how to be at that exact inch at the exact moment the ball arrived. On paper my diagrams of plays resembled detailed architectural drawings. And they required the same exactness in construction—execution—that a good contractor brings to building a skyscraper. If he’s sloppy in following the architectural schematic, the building falls down during the first stiff wind.
传球路线的设计精确到英寸，然后反复练习，直到接球手能准确地在球到达的那一刻出现在那个精确的位置。我的战术图在纸上看起来就像精细的建筑图纸。它们对施工——也就是执行——的精确度要求，就像一个优秀的承包商建造摩天大楼一样。如果他在遵循建筑图纸时马虎，那么大楼会在第一场强风中倒塌。
Our practices were organized to the minute—like a musical score for an orchestra that shows every musician what to play and when to play it. Our coaches then drilled the team so they could “play it” better and better. The specificity of detail and bombardment of information involved in doing this are mind-numbing to the casual observer—perhaps like the specifics of your own profession to an outsider.
我们的训练安排精确到分钟——就像管弦乐队的乐谱，清楚地标明了每个乐手该演奏什么曲目以及何时演奏。教练们会反复训练队员，让他们不断精进技艺。这种对细节的极致追求和信息量的爆炸式增长，对于外行人来说简直令人眼花缭乱——或许就像你自身职业的种种细节在外人看来一样。
My Standard of Performance applied to marketing, office personnel, and everyone else with the details applicable to their jobs, even to the extent of including specific instructions for receptionists on how to answer our telephones professionally. All of this increasingly demonstrated to others and to ourselves that we were on top of things, neither sloppy nor inattentive, and contributed to a greatly heightened sense of “this is who we are,” even though a strong case could have been made that “who we are” wasn’t much based on the initial won-lost records during my first two seasons: 2-14 and 6-10. Of course, that was part of my challenge—turning the self-image of the organization on its head, from toxic to top-notch.
我的绩效标准适用于市场营销、办公室人员以及所有其他员工，并详细规定了他们各自工作的具体要求，甚至包括对前台接待人员如何专业接听电话的具体指导。所有这些都逐渐向他人和我们自己证明，我们掌控着一切，既不马虎也不粗心，这极大地增强了我们对“这就是我们”的认同感。尽管从我执教头两个赛季的战绩来看（2胜14负和6胜10负），“我们究竟是谁”其实并不值得称道。当然，这也是我面临的挑战之一——彻底改变组织的自我认知，使其从糟糕透顶转变为一流水平。
More quickly than you might imagine, a transformation occurred in the quality of the team’s attitudes and actions. An environment developed in which adherence to the details of my Standard of Performance became second nature as we worked to become absolutely first class in every possible way on and off the field.
团队的态度和行为发生了翻天覆地的变化，速度之快令人难以置信。我们营造了一种氛围，在这种氛围下，严格遵守我的绩效标准已成为一种本能，我们努力在场上和场下各个方面都做到绝对一流。
Our groundskeepers raised their level of play to a point where Candlestick Park’s football field was increasingly among those in the best shape of any natural surface in the NFL, despite its proximity to San Francisco Bay, which produced a soggy subsoil and a mushy topsoil, and the effects of our winter rainy season. They often succeeded in spite of having these tremendous obstacles to overcome.
我们的场地维护人员不断提升工作水平，使得烛台公园的橄榄球场在NFL所有天然草坪中脱颖而出，尽管它毗邻旧金山湾，导致底土潮湿、表土泥泞，再加上冬季雨季的影响，球场状况依然名列前茅。他们克服了这些巨大的困难，屡屡取得成功。
Maintenance workers, ticket takers, parking lot attendants, and anyone receiving a paycheck with the emblem of the San Francisco 49ers on it were instructed as to the requirements of their own job’s Standard of Performance and expected to measure up.
维修工人、检票员、停车场管理员以及任何领取印有旧金山 49 人队队徽的工资单的人都被告知了自己工作绩效标准的要求，并被期望达到标准。
In fact, to encourage positive thinking, pride, and self-esteem, I insisted that specific equipment carrying the emblem of the San Francisco 49ers be treated with respect. For example, players were told their practice helmets, which carried our emblem, should never be tossed around, sat on, or thrown in the bottom of their lockers: “Wear it, hold it, or put it on the shelf in your locker.” The same applied to their game helmets, of course.
事实上，为了鼓励积极思考、增强自豪感和自尊心，我坚持要求球员们必须尊重带有旧金山49人队队徽的特定装备。例如，我告诉球员们，带有我们队徽的训练头盔绝不能随意丢弃、坐压或扔进储物柜底部：“戴上它，拿着它，或者把它放在储物柜的架子上。” 当然，比赛头盔也同样适用。
The San Francisco 49er emblem, and the helmet it was affixed to, signified that they were members of an organization with pride and high behavioral expectations. It was similar to saluting the American flag: Show it respect, because it represents who you are and what you value.
旧金山49人队的队徽以及与之相连的头盔，象征着他们隶属于一个充满自豪感且行为举止高尚的组织。这就像向美国国旗敬礼一样：尊重它，因为它代表着你的身份和价值观。
Respect for the emblem was important because it represented something very significant, namely, respect within the organization for one another. I would tolerate no caste systems, no assumption of superiority by any coaches, players, or other personnel. Regardless of the size of an employee’s check or the requirements of his or her job, I made it clear that he or she was 100 percent a member of our team, whether he or she was a superstar or secretary, black or white, manager or maintenance man.
尊重队徽至关重要，因为它代表着非常重要的意义，即组织内部成员之间的相互尊重。我绝不容忍任何等级制度，任何教练、球员或其他人员都不得抱有优越感。无论员工的薪水高低或工作职责如何，我都明确表示，无论他是明星球员还是秘书，无论他是黑人还是白人，无论他是经理还是维修工，他都是我们团队百分之百的一员。
In keeping with this philosophy, I forbade the traditional hazing of rookies and walk-ons—making them the butt of humiliation or physical punishment. When they arrived, I informed them, “You are a San Francisco 49er. As long as you’re here, you will be treated like one.” And it was true. They were respected, full-fledged members of our organization from day one and were treated as such until they proved otherwise. Of course, when they “proved otherwise” they were not subjected to hazing; they were subjected to termination.
秉持着这种理念，我禁止了对新人和非正式队员进行传统的欺凌——让他们遭受羞辱或体罚。他们刚到队时，我会告诉他们：“你们是旧金山49人队的一员。只要你们在这里，就会受到这样的对待。” 事实也的确如此。从第一天起，他们就是我们组织中受人尊敬的正式成员，并且一直受到这样的对待，直到他们证明自己并非如此。当然，当他们“证明自己并非如此”时，他们不会再遭受欺凌；他们会被开除。
Scouts, usually considered outliers who stopped by occasionally with information and opinions on prospects, were treated right by us. They came to feel like real members of our organization, rather than pizza delivery boys who showed up when called with hot tips about players.
球探通常被视为偶尔来访、提供球员信息和意见的“局外人”，但我们对待他们非常友好。他们逐渐觉得自己是我们组织真正的成员，而不是接到电话才出现、带来球员内幕消息的送披萨外卖员。

The Prime Directive Was Not Victory 最高指令并非胜利
From the start, my prime directive, the fundamental goal, was the full and total implementation throughout the organization of the actions and attitudes of the Standard of Performance I described earlier. This was radical in the sense that winning is the usual prime directive in professional football and most businesses.
从一开始，我的首要任务，也就是根本目标，就是在整个组织内全面彻底地贯彻我之前描述的绩效标准中的各项行动和态度。这在某种意义上是颠覆性的，因为在职业足球界和大多数企业中，胜利通常是首要目标。
Thus, in the beginning our players, coaches, and staff heard little talk from me about winning anything, and certainly not by some arbitrary date. In fact, during our second season one of the staff members went to Eddie DeBartolo and complained that I was adrift in minutiae and had no stated goal for the 49ers when it came to winning games, conference titles, or Super Bowl championships.
因此，一开始，我的球员、教练和工作人员很少听到我谈论赢得任何比赛，更别提在某个任意的日期之前了。事实上，在第二个赛季，一位工作人员去找埃迪·德巴托罗抱怨说，我过于关注细节，对49人队在赢得比赛、分区冠军或超级碗冠军方面没有任何明确的目标。
The staff member was wrong. I had very profound and organization-changing goals, but he didn’t accept my philosophy and was fired when I heard about what he had done behind my back. His betrayal was unacceptable. However, he was correct that I had no grandiose plan or timetable for winning a championship, but rather a comprehensive standard and plan for installing a level of proficiency—competency—at which our production level would become higher in all areas, both on and off the field, than that of our opponents. Beyond that, I had faith that the score would take care of itself.
那位员工错了。我的确有非常深刻且足以改变组织的宏伟目标，但他不接受我的理念，当我得知他在背后所作所为后，我便解雇了他。他的背叛令人无法接受。然而，他说的没错，我并没有宏大的夺冠计划或时间表，而只是制定了一套全面的标准和方案，旨在提升我们的专业水平——也就是能力——使我们在场上场下各个方面的表现都超越对手。除此之外，我相信比分会水到渠成。
In pursuing this ideal, I focused our personnel on the details of my Standard of Performance—trying to achieve it —rather than how we measured up against a given team (i.e., the score). “Let the opponent worry about that” was my thinking. I sought to channel the concentration of the 49ers toward improving performance on the field and throughout the organization with as little force as possible from outside influences such as the media, fans, friends, or the standings. This was a formidable task, but in large part I accomplished it.
为了实现这个理想，我让全体人员专注于我制定的绩效标准的细节——努力达到这个标准——而不是我们与特定球队的比较（例如比分）。我的想法是“让对手去操心这个”。我力求引导49人队将全部精力集中在提升场上表现以及整个球队的运营效率上，尽可能减少媒体、球迷、朋友或排名等外部因素的影响。这是一项艰巨的任务，但我在很大程度上完成了它。
Consequently, the score wasn’t the crushing issue that overrode everything else; the record didn’t mean as much as the season progressed, because we were immersed in building the inventory of skills, both attitu dinal and physical, that would lead to improved execution. That was the key. (The losses hurt, and the wins felt good. But neither was the primary focus of my effort or attention. At least, in the beginning. Unfortunately, that changed for me down the line.)
因此，比分并不是压倒一切的沉重负担；随着赛季的进行，战绩的重要性也逐渐降低，因为我们全身心投入到技能的积累中，包括态度和身体两方面，这些技能最终会提升我们的执行力。这才是关键所在。（失败固然令人沮丧，胜利固然令人欣喜。但这两者都不是我努力或关注的重点。至少在赛季初期是这样。不幸的是，后来我的想法发生了改变。）
I directed our focus less to the prize of victory than to the process of improving—obsessing, perhaps, about the quality of our execution and the content of our thinking; that is, our actions and attitude. I knew if I did that, winning would take care of itself, and when it didn’t I would seek ways to raise our Standard of Performance. At least, that was my plan. It may not sound very grandiose, but it was very comprehensive and was the platform from which I launched the turnaround.
我不再将注意力集中在胜利的奖赏上，而是放在改进的过程上——或许可以说是过于执着于执行的质量和思考的内容；也就是说，关注我们的行动和态度。我知道，如果我做到了这一点，胜利自然会水到渠成；而当胜利未能到来时，我会寻求提升我们绩效标准的方法。至少，这是我的计划。这听起来或许并不宏大，但它非常全面，也是我扭转局面的基石。
During this early period I began hiring personnel with four characteristics I value most highly: talent, character, functional intelligence (beyond basic intelligence, the ability to think on your feet, quickly and spontaneously), and an eagerness to adopt my way of doing things, my philosophy. These included assistant coaches I was very familiar with—managers—to install and nurture my organizational values and job criteria.
在早期阶段，我开始招聘具备我最看重的四个特质的人才：才能、品格、功能性智力（超越基本智力，能够迅速、自发地做出反应），以及渴望接受我的做事方式和理念。这其中也包括我非常熟悉的助理教练——也就是管理者——他们负责贯彻和培养我的组织价值观和工作标准。
I sought intelligence in employees, not just for the obvious reason, but also because a dull-witted staff member who’s aggressive creates anarchy; when you have one of those who thinks he’s intelligent in your midst, look out. The bull-headed know-it-all is a destructive force on your team.
我之所以在员工中寻找聪明才智的人，不仅是因为显而易见的原因，还因为一个头脑简单、咄咄逼人的员工会制造混乱；如果你的团队里有这种自以为是的人，那就得小心了。这种固执己见、自以为是的人会成为团队的破坏力量。
In that regard I sought individuals who had the ability to work with others. A fundamental element in this is not only the ability of a person to understand his own role and how it fits into the organization’s goal, but a knowledge or understanding of other people’s roles. Part of my job was to facilitate this mutual understanding and appreciation.
在这方面，我寻找的是那些具备与他人合作能力的人。这其中的一个基本要素不仅在于一个人能够理解自身角色及其在组织目标中的定位，还在于他/她能够了解或理解其他人的角色。我的工作之一就是促进这种相互理解和欣赏。
Individuals who didn’t measure up in various ways were removed without fanfare (usually), and those who challenged my authority did so at risk.
那些在各方面不合格的人会被悄无声息地清除出去（通常如此），而那些挑战我权威的人则会面临风险。

The Top Priority Is Teaching 教学是重中之重。
In a very real way, everything I did was teaching in some manner or other. I would take out a calendar and plan when I would talk about different subjects with individual players, with a squad, with the entire team, with position coaches, staff members, and others. I would discuss a topic from every angle, every approach, never repeating it the same way, such as when I spoke on the subject of communication and interdependence —trying to keep the idea fresh and not become rote.
实际上，我所做的每一件事都或多或少带有教学的意味。我会拿出日历，计划何时与个别球员、小组、全队、位置教练、工作人员以及其他人员讨论不同的主题。我会从各个角度、用各种方式探讨同一个话题，绝不重复，比如我谈到沟通和相互依存时——力求保持观点的新鲜感，避免落入俗套。
I was insisting that all employees not only raise their level of “play” but dramatically lift the level of their thinking—how they perceived their relationship to the team and its members; how they approached the vagaries of competition; and how willing they were to sacrifice for the goals I identified.
我坚持要求所有员工不仅要提高他们的“玩乐”水平，还要大幅提高他们的思维水平——他们如何看待自己与团队及其成员的关系；他们如何应对竞争的变幻莫测；以及他们为我确定的目标愿意做出多大的牺牲。
Much of this relates to the respect and sensitivity we accorded one another and to an appreciation of the roles each member of our organization fulfilled. Each player had a connection to and was an extension of his teammates.
这很大程度上源于我们彼此间的尊重和体谅，以及对组织中每位成员所扮演角色的认可。每位球员都与队友紧密相连，彼此互为补充。
On the field (and elsewhere) the assistant coaches and I were conscientious about educating players so they appreciated that when Jerry Rice caught a touchdown pass he was not solely responsible, but an extension of others—including those who blocked the pass rushers, receivers who meticulously coordinated their routes to draw defenders away from him, and the quarterback who risked being knocked unconscious attempting to throw the perfect pass. Jerry was taught the same. Likewise, Joe Montana understood that he was not some independent operator, but an extension of the left tackle’s block and the efforts of many others.
在球场上（以及其他场合），我和助理教练们都非常注重对球员的教育，让他们明白杰里·赖斯接球达阵并非孤军奋战，而是其他队友共同努力的结果——包括那些阻挡冲传的队友、精心配合跑位吸引防守队员的接球手，以及冒着被撞晕的风险也要传出完美传球的四分卫。杰里从小就被灌输了同样的道理。同样，乔·蒙塔纳也明白，他并非孤军奋战，而是左截锋的掩护以及其他许多队友共同努力的成果。
This concept applied beyond the team itself. Players had a connection to—and were an extension of—the coaching staff, trainers, team doctor, nutritionists, maintenance crew, and, yes, the people who answered the phones. Everybody was connected, each of us an extension of the others, each of us with ownership in our organization. I taught this just as you should teach it in your own organization.
这个理念不仅适用于球队本身，也适用于其他方面。球员与教练组、训练员、队医、营养师、后勤人员，甚至接电话的工作人员都息息相关，彼此之间是相互的延伸。每个人都紧密相连，我们每个人都是其他人的延伸，我们每个人都对自己的组织负有责任。我曾这样教导过大家，你们也应该在自己的组织中教授这个理念。
Victory is produced by and belongs to all. Winning a Super Bowl (or becoming number one in the marketplace, or reaching a significant quarterly production quota, or landing a big account) results from your whole team not only doing their individual jobs but perceiving that those jobs contributed to overall success. The trophy doesn’t belong just to a superstar quarterback or CEO, head coach or top salesperson. And this organizational perception that “success belongs to everyone” is taught by the leader.
胜利属于所有人，也由所有人共同创造。赢得超级碗（或成为市场第一，或完成重要的季度生产指标，或拿下大客户）的成果，不仅在于你的团队各司其职，更在于他们意识到自己的工作对整体成功至关重要。奖杯并非只属于超级四分卫、CEO、主教练或顶级销售员。而这种“成功属于每个人”的组织理念，正是由领导者灌输的。
Likewise, failure belongs to everyone. If you or a member of your team “drops the ball,” everyone has ownership. This is an essential lesson I taught the San Francisco organization: The offensive team is not a country unto itself, nor is the defensive team or the special teams, staff, coaches, or anyone in the organization separate from the fate of the organization. We are united and fight as one; we win or lose as one.
同样，失败是每个人的责任。如果你或你的团队成员“掉链子”，每个人都负有责任。这是我教给旧金山巨人队的一个重要教训：进攻组并非独立存在，防守组、特勤组、工作人员、教练，以及组织中的任何人都与组织的命运息息相关。我们团结一致，同舟共济；胜负与共。
Leaders sometimes wonder why they or their organization fail to achieve success, never seem to reach their potential. It’s often because they don’t understand or can’t instill the concept of what a team is all about at its best: connection and extension. This is a fundamental ingredient of ongoing organizational achievement. (Of course, incompetence as a leader is also a common cause of organizational failure.)
领导者有时会疑惑，为什么自己或组织无法取得成功，似乎永远无法发挥全部潜力。这通常是因为他们不理解或无法灌输团队成功之道：联结与协作。这是组织持续取得成就的根本要素。（当然，领导者能力不足也是组织失败的常见原因。）
Combat soldiers talk about whom they will die for. Who is it? It’s those guys right next to them in the trench, not the fight song, the flag, or some general back at the Pentagon, but those guys who sacrifice and bleed right next to them. “I couldn’t let my buddies down,” is what all soldiers say. Somebody they had never seen before they joined the army or marines has become someone they would die for. That’s the ultimate connection and extension.
战斗中的士兵会谈论他们愿意为谁而死。是谁？是那些与他们并肩作战、同处战壕的战友，不是战歌，不是国旗，也不是五角大楼里的某个将军，而是那些与他们一起牺牲、流血的战友。“我不能让我的战友失望，”所有士兵都会这样说。那些在他们入伍前素未谋面的人，如今却成了他们愿意为之献身的人。这才是最深厚的羁绊和最持久的联系。
I nurtured a variation of that extreme attitude in our entire organization, most especially the players: “You can’t let your buddies down. Demand and expect sacrifice from yourself, and they’ll do the same for you.” That is the measure, in my opinion, of any great organization, including a team of football players—that willingness to sacrifice for the team, to go the extra mile, the extra five or fifty miles. And it starts with the leader and your leadership staff.
我在整个组织中，尤其是在球员中，都培养了一种类似的极端态度：“你不能让你的队友失望。你要对自己提出要求并期望他们做出牺牲，他们也会为你做同样的事。”在我看来，衡量一个伟大组织（包括一支橄榄球队）的标准，就是这种为团队牺牲、竭尽全力、哪怕付出额外五英里或五十英里的意愿。而这一切都始于领导者和他的领导团队。
It has a transformative effect. Bonding within the organization takes place as one individual and then another steps up and raises his or her level of commitment, sacrifice, and performance. They demand and expect a lot of one another. That’s extremely important because when you know that your peers—the others in the organization—demand and expect a lot out of you and you, in turn, out of them, that’s when the sky’s the limit.
它具有变革性的影响。组织内部的凝聚力源于一个人的积极参与，进而带动其他人提升自身的投入、奉献和绩效水平。他们彼此要求很高，期望也很高。这一点至关重要，因为当你意识到你的同事——组织中的其他人——对你要求很高，而你反过来也对他们有很高的期望时，你的潜力将无限广阔。
It’s why egotism can hurt group pride and unity so much. An individual who acts like a big shot, as if he or she is solely responsible for what the team has accomplished, has taken over ownership of the group’s achievement. You may remember basketball’s Michael Jordan being interviewed after a game. The Chicago Bull would tell the media, “Scotty Pippen did a great job on defense; Dennis [Rodman] got a couple of key rebounds, and our bench really picked up the slack in the third quarter to give us a little breather. It was a great effort by everybody.” What Jordan didn’t mention might be the fact that he had scored fifty-five points, grabbed fifteen rebounds, and had twelve assists. As he matured as an on-court leader, he made everyone part of the victory.
这就是为什么自负会如此严重地损害团队的自豪感和团结。一个人如果表现得像个大人物，仿佛团队的成就都是他/她一人之功，那就等于窃取了团队的成果。你可能还记得篮球巨星迈克尔·乔丹在赛后接受采访的情景。这位芝加哥公牛队的球员告诉媒体：“斯科蒂·皮蓬在防守端表现出色；丹尼斯·罗德曼抢下了几个关键篮板；我们的替补球员在第三节挺身而出，弥补了之前的不足，让我们得以喘息。这是全队共同努力的结果。” 乔丹可能没有提到的是，他自己砍下了55分、抢下了15个篮板，并送出了12次助攻。随着他作为场上领袖的日渐成熟，他让每个人都成为了胜利的一部分。
The leader’s job is to facilitate a battlefield-like sense of camaraderie among his or her personnel, an environment for people to find a way to bond together, to care about one another and the work they do, to feel the connection and extension so necessary for great results. Ultimately, it’s the strongest bond of all, even stronger than money.
领导者的职责是营造一种如同战场般的战友情谊，让团队成员彼此建立联系，关心彼此和工作，感受到那种对取得卓越成果至关重要的联结和协作。归根结底，这是最牢固的纽带，甚至比金钱更强大。

Winners Act Like Winners (Before They’re Winners) 成功者在成为成功者之前就展现出成功者的行为。
The commitment to, and execution of, the specific actions and attitudes embodied in my Standard of Performance—some picky, some profound—may seem far removed from Super Bowl victories, but they were crucial to creating and cementing a 49er level of professionalism that I viewed as the foundation on which future success could be constructed. (That’s what the assistant coach who complained about my lack of focus on winning didn’t understand.)
我对自身行为准则中所体现的具体行动和态度的承诺和执行——有些细枝末节，有些意义深远——或许看似与超级碗的胜利相去甚远，但它们对于打造和巩固49人队的职业精神至关重要，而我认为这种职业精神是未来成功的基础。（那位抱怨我不够重视胜利的助理教练显然不理解这一点。）
Consequently, the 49er organization increasingly became known for our businesslike and very professional behavior even when we were losing more games than we were winning. There was no showboating allowed after touchdowns, no taunting of opponents, no demonstrations to attract attention to oneself, because one individual shouldn’t take credit for what our whole team had done. There was a minimum of whining, complaining, and backstabbing. And phones were answered in a professional manner: “San Francisco 49ers headquarters. How may I assist you?” All calls had to be returned within twenty-four hours.
因此，即使我们输多赢少，49人队也以严谨专业的态度而闻名。达阵后不允许炫耀，不允许嘲讽对手，不允许任何哗众取宠的行为，因为一个人的功劳不应该属于整个团队。抱怨、牢骚和背后捅刀的情况也极少发生。接听电话的语气也十分专业：“旧金山49人队总部。请问有什么可以帮您？”所有来电都必须在24小时内回复。
Eventually—within months, in fact—a high level of professionalism began to emerge within our entire organization. The 49ers’ self -perception was improving; individuals began acting and thinking in a way that reflected pride and professionalism, even as we continued to lose games. People want to believe they’re part of something special, an organization that’s exceptional. And that’s the environment I was creating in the early months and years at San Francisco.
事实上，几个月之内，我们整个团队就展现出了高度的专业精神。49人队的自我认知也在不断提升；即使我们仍在输球，队员们的言行举止也开始体现出自豪感和专业精神。人们渴望相信自己是某个特别的团队的一份子，一个卓越的组织。而这正是我在旧金山49人队最初几个月和几年里努力营造的氛围。
I moved forward methodically with a deep belief that the many elements of my Standard of Performance would produce that kind of mind set, an organizational culture that would subsequently be the foundation for winning games.
我稳步推进，深信我的绩效标准中的诸多要素将会产生那种心态，一种组织文化，而这种文化将成为赢得比赛的基础。
The culture precedes positive results. It doesn’t get tacked on as an afterthought on your way to the victory stand. Champions behave like champions before they’re champions; they have a winning standard of performance before they are winners.
文化先于积极成果而存在，它并非通往胜利之路上的事后补救措施。冠军在成为冠军之前就拥有冠军的风范；他们在成为赢家之前就具备了制胜的竞技水平。
It all sounds pretty simple, doesn’t it? But it’s a rough road. At the end of my first year, giving it everything I had, working more hours than seemed possible and after installing many of the elements of my Standard of Performance, this is what we had to show for it: the same miserable won-lost record as the year before I took over: 2-14. A cynic might have said, “Well, Bill, your switchboard operators answer the phones great, but your team stinks.”
听起来很简单，对吧？但这条路走起来却很艰难。第一年结束时，我倾尽全力，工作时间长得超乎想象，并且实施了我制定的绩效标准中的许多要素，结果却是这样：胜负记录和我接手前一年一样惨淡，2胜14负。有人可能会愤世嫉俗地说：“比尔，你的接线员接电话很棒，但你的球队太烂了。”
Nevertheless, my teaching in all areas was being implemented as the base for the future of the San Francisco 49ers. While the performance results were not good if measured strictly by the won-lost record, the organizational structure and environment were set in place to produce success. We lost most of our games, but we did not “stink.”
尽管如此，我在各个领域的教学成果都为旧金山49人队的未来奠定了基础。如果仅以胜负记录来衡量，球队的战绩并不理想，但组织架构和环境的构建已经为成功奠定了基础。我们输掉了大部分比赛，但我们并不“糟糕”。
In a way, an organization is like an automobile assembly line; it must be first class or the cars that come off it will be second rate. The exceptional assembly line comes first, before the quality car. My Standard of Performance was establishing a better and better “assembly line.” We were becoming a first-class organization in all areas.
从某种意义上说，一个组织就像一条汽车装配线；它本身必须是一流的，否则生产出来的汽车也只能是二流的。卓越的装配线先于优质的汽车。我的绩效标准就是打造一条越来越好的“装配线”。我们力求在各个方面都成为一流的组织。
Proof of that existed although it was not evident in our 2-14 record. I needed to look for evidence elsewhere. Very talented individuals had been hired; malcontents, underachievers, and the unmotivated were being rooted out and replaced; learning was well under way, with very productive attitudes and behaviors becoming the norm; and statistical evidence—the internal metrics—showed improvement, including going from virtually the worst-ranked offensive team to one of the best: number one in passing offense and sixth in total offense. Additionally, we had lost five games during my first season by a touchdown or less—close, competitive games. We lost an additional seven games by two touchdowns or less. Both were improvements over the previous season. Before you can win the fight, you’ve got to be in the fight.
虽然我们2胜14负的战绩并不明显，但事实的确如此。我需要从其他方面寻找证据。我们聘请了许多才华横溢的人才；那些心怀不满、表现不佳、缺乏动力的人都被清除并替换；学习工作进展顺利，积极的态度和行为已成为常态；统计数据——内部指标——也显示出进步，包括进攻端从几乎垫底跃升至顶尖行列：传球进攻排名第一，总进攻排名第六。此外，在我执教的第一个赛季，我们有五场比赛的失利分差都在一个达阵以内——都是势均力敌、竞争激烈的比赛。之后我们又有七场比赛的失利分差在两个达阵以内。这两项数据都比上个赛季有所进步。要想赢得胜利，首先要参与其中。
Even though my initial year as head coach produced the identical won-lost record, the resurrection of the San Francisco 49ers was under way; the organization’s behavioral “infrastructure” was essentially built.
尽管我担任主教练的第一年战绩与上一年相同，但旧金山 49 人队的复兴已经开始；该组织的行为“基础设施”基本上已经建成。
Achieving success takes patience, time, and fortitude. To demand the assimilation of my Standard of Performance throughout the organization, including the complex offensive plays and the specifics of player performance, when the roof is caving in—we lost thirteen of our first fourteen games—would have been challenging, even impossible, for many.
取得成功需要耐心、时间和毅力。当球队形势岌岌可危——前十四场比赛输了十三场——的时候，要要求整个组织接受我的绩效标准，包括复杂的进攻战术和球员的具体表现，对很多人来说都是一项挑战，甚至是不可能的。
In the beginning, Eddie DeBartolo, the owner, had the patience and gave me the time to persevere. Tough days lay ahead, including that trip to Miami during my second season that was almost fatal, but our ship had found its mooring. We were no longer adrift and being tossed around with abandon by the competition and ourselves.
起初，老板埃迪·德巴托洛很有耐心，给了我时间坚持下去。未来的日子充满艰辛，包括我第二个赛季那次几乎致命的迈阿密之旅，但我们的船终于找到了锚点。我们不再漂泊，不再被竞争对手和自己肆意摆布。
And in the turbulent and occasionally troubled times ahead it was indeed my Standard of Performance that kept us in contention or at the top for almost twenty years and produced five Super Bowl championships. This consistency of excellence and preeminence is difficult to achieve in professional sports—and equally hard in business.
在接下来的动荡岁月里，正是我坚持的卓越表现标准，使我们在近二十年的时间里始终保持竞争力，甚至稳居巅峰，并斩获五次超级碗冠军。这种持续的卓越和领先地位在职业体育界难以企及，在商业领域也同样难能可贵。

Seek to Be Near the Summit 力争靠近山顶
Within our organization the Standard of Performance served as a compass that pointed to true north. It embraced the individual requirements and expectations—benchmarks—required of our personnel in all areas regardless of whether things were going well or badly. That’s the toughest thing—constancy amid chaos or presumed perfection.
在我们组织内部，绩效标准就像指南针一样，指引我们前进的方向。它涵盖了所有领域员工的个人要求和期望——即基准——无论情况好坏，都必须达到这些要求和期望。最难的就是在混乱或看似完美的环境中保持稳定。
If things are going well, points being scored and games won, your organization may be elated and lose focus; if things are going poorly, as they were when I arrived at San Francisco, people are likely to be despondent and start looking for the exit. Incredibly, both can exist at the same time, as you’ll see later in a game we played against Kansas City. And, of course, between the ups and downs, the good times and bad, there are ongoing challenges to keep everyone firing on all cylinders at all times. Not to get too clever, but “consistent effort is a consistent challenge.”
如果一切顺利，球队不断得分、赢得比赛，你的团队可能会欣喜若狂，从而失去专注力；如果情况不妙，就像我刚到旧金山时那样，人们很可能会垂头丧气，开始寻找出路。令人难以置信的是，这两种情况可以同时存在，就像你稍后会在我们与堪萨斯城的比赛中看到的那样。当然，在起起伏伏、顺境逆境之间，始终存在着各种挑战，需要每个人时刻保持最佳状态。说得直白点，“持续努力本身就是一项持续的挑战”。
There’s an ebb and flow, an up and down, in every significant endeavor at every level. I cut through that ebb and flow with the Standard of Performance. It was our point of reference, what we always returned to when things wobbled—deeply entrenched, ongoing, and stabilizing regardless of the final score. My high standards for actions and attitudes within our organization never wavered—regardless of whether we were winning or losing.
在任何层面，任何重要的事业都有起伏跌宕。我凭借绩效标准来应对这种起伏。它是我们的参照点，是我们遇到困难时始终坚持的准则——它根深蒂固、持续有效，无论最终结果如何，都能起到稳定作用。我对组织内部行为和态度的高标准从未动摇——无论我们赢还是输。
I envisioned it as enabling us to establish a near-permanent “base camp” near the summit, consistently close to the top, within striking distance, never falling to the bottom of the mountain and having to start all over again. Initially, it meant I had to drastically change the environment, raise the level of talent, and teach everyone what they needed to know to get to where I wanted us to go.
我设想的是，我们可以在山顶附近建立一个近乎永久的“大本营”，始终保持在接近顶峰的位置，随时可以发起进攻，永远不会跌落山脚，不得不从头再来。最初，这意味着我必须彻底改变环境，提升团队的技能水平，并教会每个人达到我预期目标所需的一切知识。
It also meant that as the years accrued, personnel had to be changed so that we remained near the summit. Players past their peak or near the end of their usefulness had to be taken out of the organization. And, yes, this is as cruel and hard to do as it sounds. It is perhaps the hardest task I faced, and I tried to execute it in a humane, direct, and honest manner. But it’s impossible not to hurt an individual’s deep self-respect when it’s being done—when I had to look a great performer in the eye and say, “It’s time for you to leave.” There is perhaps no way you can do it without causing deep pain. But, the organization, our team, came first.
这也意味着，随着时间的推移，为了保持我们接近巅峰的地位，人员必须进行调整。那些过了巅峰期或接近职业生涯末期的球员必须离开球队。是的，这听起来残酷无情，做起来也十分艰难。这或许是我面临的最艰难的任务，我努力以人道、直接和诚实的方式来执行。但是，当我不得不直视一位优秀球员的眼睛，告诉他“是时候离开了”，这必然会伤害到他深厚的自尊心。或许，你根本无法做到不造成深深的痛苦。但是，球队，我们的利益，始终是第一位的。
Losing and winning was only part of it; there was always another contest. If I didn’t like the score, I would seek to step up the level of our Standard of Performance so that even in losing it was retained, but then elevated. It always went back to the requirements for actions and attitudes that I had formulated in my mind during the years before I took over as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers and then installed starting on my first day.
输赢只是其中的一部分；总会有下一场比赛。如果我对比分不满意，我会努力提升我们的表现标准，即使输球也要保持标准，甚至更高。这一切都要回归到我在执教旧金山49人队之前几年就已在脑海中构思好的行为和态度要求，并在我上任的第一天就开始贯彻执行。
In many ways, it comes down to details. The intense focus on those pertinent details cements the foundation that establishes excellence in performance. The simplest correct execution of procedures represents the commitment of players and staff to the organization and the organization to them. Specifics such as “shirttails in,” understanding and respecting the jobs of others in the organization, running exactly ten yards and not ten yards fifteen inches, exhibiting a positive attitude, answering the phones professionally, seeing the team as an extension of yourself—all contribute in varying degrees to a devotion to high standards visible to everyone. The self-image of the 49ers as a first-class professional outfit was nurtured and carefully developed in these incremental ways. That’s what I focused on, knowing that if I did so, winning would take care of itself.
在很多方面，关键在于细节。对这些关键细节的专注，巩固了卓越表现的基石。哪怕是最简单的流程执行，也体现了球员和工作人员对球队的忠诚，以及球队对他们的忠诚。诸如“衬衫下摆向内收拢”、理解并尊重球队其他成员的工作、跑十码而不是十五码、保持积极的态度、专业地接听电话、将球队视为自身延伸——所有这些细节都以不同程度地促成了球队对高标准的执着追求，而这种高标准是每个人都能感受到的。49人队作为一流职业球队的自我形象，正是通过这些循序渐进的方式，精心培育和建立起来的。我专注于此，因为我知道，只要我做到了这一点，胜利自然会水到渠成。

Establishing Your Standard of Performance 确立你的绩效标准
In quantifying and implementing your own version of the Standard of Performance, the following guidelines are a good reference point:
1. Start with a comprehensive recognition of, reverence for, and identification of the specific actions and attitudes relevant to your team’s performance and production.
2. Be clarion clear in communicating your expectation of high effort and execution of your Standard of Performance. Like water, many decent individuals will seek lower ground if left to their own inclinations. In most cases you are the one who inspires and demands they go upward rather than settle for the comfort of doing what comes easily. Push them beyond their comfort zone; expect them to give extra effort.
3. Let all know that you expect them to possess the highest level of expertise in their area of responsibility.
4. Beyond standards and methodology, teach your beliefs, values, and philosophy. An organization is not an inanimate object. It is a living organism that you must nurture, guide, and strengthen.
5. Teach “connection and extension.” An organization filled with individuals who are “independent contractors” unattached to one another is a team with little interior cohesion and strength.
6. Make the expectations and metrics of competence that you demand in action and attitudes from personnel the new reality of your organization. You must provide the model for that new standard in your own actions and attitude.
在量化和实施您自己的绩效标准时，以下准则可作为参考：1. 首先要全面认识、尊重并明确与团队绩效和产出相关的具体行动和态度。2. 清晰明确地传达您对团队高水平努力和执行绩效标准的期望。就像水一样，许多优秀的人如果任其自然，也会选择安于现状。在大多数情况下，您需要激励并要求他们向上攀登，而不是安于现状，做自己擅长的事情。要让他们超越舒适区，期望他们付出额外的努力。3. 让所有人明白，您期望他们在各自的职责范围内拥有最高水平的专业知识。4. 除了标准和方法论之外，还要传授您的信念、价值观和理念。组织不是无生命的物体，而是一个需要您培育、引导和强化的有机体。5. 强调“联系与拓展”。一个由彼此互不隶属的“独立承包商”组成的组织，其内部凝聚力和实力都十分薄弱。6. 将你对员工行为和态度的能力要求和衡量标准，使其成为组织的新常态。你必须以身作则，树立这一新标准的榜样。

How I Avoid Becoming a Victim of Myself 我如何避免成为自己的受害者
I have a terrible time closing out a set in tennis. Why? Because I tell myself to try harder and harder, to hit the ball better and better. I become a victim of myself and go into a kind of stupor because I’m trying so hard without really knowing what the heck I’m trying to do.
我打网球总是很难拿下最后一盘。为什么呢？因为我总是告诉自己要越来越努力，要把球打得越来越好。结果反而成了自己的受害者，陷入了一种麻木的状态，因为我拼命想打，却根本不知道自己到底在干什么。
The same thing can happen to you professionally. Individuals or organizations can get almost mesmerized by pressure and stress and be unable to function as cleanly as they are capable of doing. It happens everywhere all the time. Have you noticed, however, that great players and great companies don’t suddenly start hunching up, grimacing, and trying to “hit the ball harder” at a critical point? Rather, they’re in a mode, a zone in which they’re performing and depending on their “game,” which they’ve mastered over many months and years of intelligently directed hard work.
同样的情况也可能发生在你的职业生涯中。个人或组织可能会被压力和紧张感所左右，以至于无法发挥出应有的水平。这种情况时有发生。然而，你是否注意到，优秀的运动员和卓越的公司并不会突然在关键时刻畏缩不前、愁眉苦脸，试图“拼尽全力”？相反，他们早已进入一种状态，一种专注的状态，在这种状态下，他们能够发挥出最佳水平，并依靠他们经过数月甚至数年精心策划的艰苦工作所磨练出的“制胜之道”。
There’s only so much thinking you can isolate and focus on during that kind of extreme competitive pressure. It has to be tactical more than a conscious effort to really “try harder.” You just want to function very well, up to your potential, effortlessly—do what you already know how to do at the level of excellence you’ve acquired—whether in making a presentation or coaching a game or anything else. That’s why I’m no good in tennis at crunch time.
在那种极端的竞争压力下，你能集中精力思考的事情是有限的。与其刻意“更加努力”，不如采取一些战术。你只想发挥出最佳水平，毫不费力地展现你的潜力——把你已经掌握的技能发挥到极致，无论是做演讲、指导比赛还是其他任何事情。这就是为什么我在网球比赛的关键时刻发挥失常的原因。
In football, I was a master at crunch time because I had put in years of smart hard work in mastering my craft and creating a comprehensive Standard of Performance for my organization. In tennis, I haven’t done that, but it doesn’t matter much because I’m playing just for fun. The business of football, however, was not something I did just for fun. It was deadly serious.
在足球界，我之所以能成为关键时刻的制胜高手，是因为我多年来潜心钻研，精益求精，并为我的球队制定了一套全面的绩效标准。在网球界，我并没有做到这一点，但这无关紧要，因为我打网球只是为了娱乐。然而，足球的商业运作并非我为了娱乐而从事的，它关乎生死存亡。
The key to performing under pressure at the highest possible level, regardless of circumstance, is preparation in the context of your Standard of Performance and a thorough assimilation by your organization of the actions and attitudes contained within your philosophy of leadership. With that comes the knowledge that you—and they—can step into that high-pressure arena and go about your work while the score works itself out. Rather than feel that somehow I had to get a supreme effort from our personnel—“try harder and harder”—I trusted that it was going to happen because we had prepared thoroughly.
无论在何种情况下，能够在压力下发挥出最高水平的关键在于，根据你的绩效标准做好充分准备，并且你的团队彻底理解并贯彻你的领导理念中所包含的行动和态度。有了这些，你和你的团队成员就能自信地进入高压环境，专注于工作，最终结果自然会水到渠成。我并没有觉得我必须让团队成员付出巨大的努力——“更加努力”，而是相信一切终将水到渠成，因为我们已经做好了充分的准备。
Some leaders drive their team past being able to perform with poise and presence and into a state of anxiety where they’re not thinking as clearly as they should. They pump them up so much for the “big game” that they can’t perform well; it’s like a balloon that bursts when you blow too much air into it.
有些领导者过度激励团队成员，让他们无法保持沉着冷静、自信从容地完成工作，反而陷入焦虑状态，思维混乱。他们为了“关键时刻”过度吹捧，反而导致团队成员发挥失常；这就像气球吹气过量最终爆裂一样。
By focusing strictly on my Standard of Performance, the 49ers were able to play the bigger games very well because it was basically business as usual—no “try harder” mentality was used. In fact, I believed it would be counterproductive.
通过严格按照我的绩效标准执行，49人队能够在关键比赛中表现出色，因为一切都按部就班——没有“更加努力”的心态。事实上，我认为那样做反而会适得其反。
I might do even less strategizing for a Super Bowl game, because in the midst of the extreme pressure I placed a premium on fundamentals, the skills and the execution ability the team already possessed as a result of our concentration and hard work going all the way back to day one of training camp and the previous training camp and the one before that.
对于超级碗比赛，我可能更不会制定策略，因为在巨大的压力下，我更重视基本功、技能和执行能力，这些都是我们从训练营第一天、上一个训练营以及再上一个训练营开始，通过专注和努力训练而获得的。
Consequently, the San Francisco 49ers could function under tremendous stress and the forces that work on individuals in competitive situations. They were able to function under all the media hype and the absolute intensity of the circumstances we were in. In that kind of environment— your version of a big game—you must reach back and rely on your ability to do things at a high level. There isn’t much time to meditate or think things through. The pressure of the situation can just wipe that all out, and you’re left with the raw bones.
因此，旧金山49人队能够在巨大的压力下，以及在竞争环境中个人所面临的各种压力下保持正常运转。他们能够在媒体的过度炒作和我们所处环境的绝对紧张氛围下发挥出色。在这种环境下——也就是你们所说的“大赛”——你必须依靠自身强大的能力，在高水平的比赛中完成任务。你没有太多时间去思考或权衡利弊。比赛的压力会彻底摧毁你的所有思考，让你只剩下最原始的本能。
When you get to Wimbledon you’re not thinking, “Now I’m gonna play well.” You’re operating on nerves, depending almost completely on your game, how good it is. For us it meant I had to be sure our Standard of Performance was so good that our opponents were the ones who would be distracted by the intensity or importance of the game or what they might have to do to win.
到了温布尔登，你不会想着“现在我要好好发挥”。你会完全被紧张情绪左右，几乎完全取决于你的状态，取决于你的发挥有多好。对我们来说，这意味着我必须确保我们的表现水平足够高，让对手因为比赛的激烈程度、重要性或者他们为了赢球可能必须做的事情而分心。
So while the opponents had to elevate their game, we did too, but it was a very natural culmination of all our previous work. It’s similar to a wave that gathers force for many miles out at sea and eventually crashes down with tremendous power on the beach.
所以，虽然对手需要提升他们的水平，我们也一样，但这正是我们之前所有努力的自然结果。这就像海浪在离岸很远的地方积蓄力量，最终以巨大的威力拍打在沙滩上一样。
Over the months—and years—the San Francisco 49ers acquired the skill and proficiency to play right through extreme pressure and prevail. In golf and tennis I am unable to do that. But in my professional world—football—I became a master at it.
经过数月乃至数年的时间，旧金山49人队练就了在极端压力下也能保持竞技状态并最终取胜的技巧和能力。在高尔夫和网球方面，我无法做到这一点。但在我的职业领域——橄榄球——我却精通此道。

THE WALSH WAY 沃尔什路
The Organization Man 组织人
John McVay, Vice President for Football Administration
约翰·麦克维，足球管理副总裁







I’d been in football a long time when Bill Walsh (and owner Eddie DeBartolo) hired me during his first few weeks at San Francisco. My résumé included being an assistant coach at Michigan State University, head coach at Dayton University, and assistant and then head coach of the New York Giants in the NFL and working in the old World Football League doing every job imaginable with the Memphis Southmen. Bill figured I brought something to him because of all that experience.
我在橄榄球界摸爬滚打了很久，比尔·沃尔什（以及老板埃迪·德巴托洛）在旧金山49人队上任的头几周就聘用了我。我的履历包括：在密歇根州立大学担任助理教练，在代顿大学担任主教练，在NFL纽约巨人队担任助理教练和主教练，以及在当时的WFL（世界橄榄球联盟）为孟菲斯南方人队做过各种各样的工作。比尔认为，凭借我丰富的经验，我能给他带来一些东西。
Technically, I was his vice president/director of football operations, or as I told people, “I’m in charge of everything that nobody else wants to do.” Bill and I got along pretty good.
严格来说，我是他的副总裁/足球运营总监，或者正如我告诉别人的那样，“我负责所有别人不想做的事情。”我和比尔相处得很好。
Over the next ten years, I was heavily involved with contract negotiations, player personnel, scouts, equipment—everything except his coaching. I had a front-row seat for how Bill, in conjunction with Eddie, made something—a dynasty—out of nothing.
在接下来的十年里，我深度参与了合同谈判、球员人事、球探、装备等所有事务——除了他的执教。我亲眼见证了比尔如何与埃迪联手，从无到有地打造出一个王朝。
What I saw when I arrived at San Francisco to work with him was organization and management that I had never seen done at the level Bill Walsh did it. It was comprehensive, meticulously detailed, and practical. At least, after awhile that’s what I saw. Until Bill got it up and running the way he wanted it, things were rough. He had his work cut out for him.
我抵达旧金山与他共事时，看到的组织和管理水平是我前所未见的，比尔·沃尔什的水平简直令人叹为观止。他的工作全面、细致入微且务实。至少，过了一段时间后，我看到的就是这样。在比尔把一切安排妥当之前，情况相当艰难。他面临着巨大的挑战。
Bill was a great observer and student who had the good fortune to work not only with the Oakland Raiders and San Diego Chargers but with one of the NFL’s great masterminds, Paul Brown at Cincinnati. Brown was ahead of the rest of the league when it came to organization of time and management of people. I believe Bill liked what he saw at Cincinnati and then extended it, refined it in his own way, so that he developed an advanced organizational philosophy in his mind.
比尔是一位杰出的观察者和学习者，他有幸不仅在奥克兰突袭者队和圣地亚哥闪电队工作过，还在辛辛那提与NFL的伟大教练之一保罗·布朗共事。布朗在时间管理和人员管理方面遥遥领先于联盟其他球队。我相信比尔很欣赏他在辛辛那提所看到的，并在此基础上加以拓展和完善，最终形成了自己独特的组织理念。
He liked tight management principles and wanted things clear and easily understood. This was important because Bill’s overall system was complex. For it to work, people had to understand it. Consequently, he was explicit in his instructions: “Here’s what we’re going to do and here’s how we’re going to do it.” Bill was very demanding in that respect, not just of players but of everyone in the organization.
他喜欢严谨的管理原则，希望一切都清晰明了、易于理解。这一点至关重要，因为比尔的整体体系非常复杂。要想让这套体系有效运作，人们必须理解它。因此，他的指示非常明确：“我们要做什么，我们要怎么做。” 比尔在这方面要求很高，不仅对球员，对组织中的每个人都是如此。
He had written a series of lectures for each department detailing what he expected in all ways—appearance, attitude, performance, and more. He had it written out in detail for scouts, assistant coaches, equipment men, groundskeepers, and trainers. Even secretaries got specific and lengthy instructions from Bill himself. Did I mention the players? That’s when he really got going.
他为每个部门都准备了一系列讲稿，详细阐述了他对各方面的期望——包括外表、态度、表现等等。他甚至为球探、助理教练、器材管理员、场地维护人员和训练员都拟定了详细的要求。就连秘书们也收到了比尔亲自下达的详尽指示。我提过球员们吗？那才是他真正大展身手的时候。
Here’s how comprehensive and detailed, big picture/little picture, he could be: I came to work my first day not wearing a tie. Bill liked to distinguish between coaches (no ties) and administration (ties). I was in administration, but I told him, “Bill, all of my ties have New York Giants helmets on them.” He smiled and said, “John, I guess you’re buying a new tie today.” The small detail of wearing a tie was connected to his big concept of being a first-class operation, not just in point production, but in appearance and behavior, which he believed preceded scoring touchdowns; and he spelled it out word by word. I bought a new tie.
他做事既全面又细致，既能把握大局又能顾细节：我上班第一天没打领带。比尔喜欢区分教练（不打领带）和行政人员（打领带）。我当时在行政部门，但我告诉他：“比尔，我所有的领带上都有纽约巨人队的头盔图案。”他笑着说：“约翰，看来你今天得买条新领带了。”打不打领带这个小细节，与他打造一流团队的理念息息相关，他不仅注重得分，更注重仪容仪表和行为举止，他认为这些才是得分的先决条件；他把这些都解释得清清楚楚。于是，我买了条新领带。
Meetings were held, and he would take an hour or two with every employee so they knew exactly what he expected of them, what he wanted them to do and how he wanted them to do it. He made it very clear. There was no confusion in their minds as to what he expected. And because he had such a marvelous background and such a keen eye for running things, he expected a lot. That included respect for one another within the organization—no cliques or hierarchy.
他召开会议，每次都会花一两个小时和每位员工单独谈话，确保他们清楚地了解他对他们的期望、工作内容以及工作方式。他把一切都说得清清楚楚，员工们对他的期望一目了然。由于他拥有卓越的资历和敏锐的管理眼光，他对员工的要求也很高。这其中就包括组织内部的相互尊重——不允许有小团体或等级制度。
After he established his “organization”—got people in place and on the same page—he allowed department heads to function and intervened only if he became dissatisfied with something. Bill had set up an outstanding support mechanism of talented people, and he really had nothing to worry about except football. Of course, that was plenty to worry about, especially when he was taking over a 2-14 team.
在建立起自己的“组织架构”——也就是把人安排到位并达成共识之后——他放任各部门负责人运作，只有当他对某些事情不满时才会介入。比尔建立了一个由优秀人才组成的出色支持体系，他真的没什么可担心的，除了橄榄球。当然，橄榄球本身就够让人操心的了，尤其是在他接手一支2胜14负的球队时。
Having said that, I will also say this: Bill Walsh was the king. And we knew it. He was the one in complete control. And he knew it. But the interesting thing about it was that he didn’t act like a king, no bowing and scraping required. Bill wanted to be called Bill; everyone was on a first-name basis, but within that informality he simply did not allow for casual execution of your job. There was intensity and urgency, a focus all the time, a tight ship. He was friendly, but he held himself in a certain manner so that you knew he was in charge.
话虽如此，我还要补充一点：比尔·沃尔什才是真正的掌权者。我们都知道这一点。他完全掌控着一切。他也深知这一点。但有趣的是，他并不像个国王，不需要人卑躬屈膝。比尔希望别人直接叫他比尔；大家都直呼其名，但在这种轻松的氛围中，他绝不允许任何人敷衍了事。他做事认真负责，一丝不苟，严格把控着一切。他待人友善，但举手投足间都散发着一种权威感，让你明白他才是真正的领导者。
And why not? He took over a lousy situation. Eddie DeBartolo, the owner, needed somebody to come and grab that puppy by the throat and say, “Shape up or you’re out of here!” Bill did it without always stomping and screaming. He was demanding and tough, but people loved him even though he was insistent, a real stickler not only about playing football but about raising the image of the franchise from within.
为什么不呢？他接手的是一个糟糕的局面。老板埃迪·德巴托洛需要有人来严厉制止这支球队，告诉他：“要么振作起来，要么滚蛋！” 比尔做到了，但他并不总是大吼大叫。他要求严格，作风强硬，但人们爱戴他，尽管他很固执，不仅对球队的比赛表现一丝不苟，而且对提升球队内部形象也极其重视。
That’s where he started—by raising the self-image of the San Francisco 49ers organization. In football that’s tough to do when you’re not winning games. My tie was a good example. What the heck did it have to do with a Super Bowl? Bill saw the connection. It was one of the tiny things—thousands of them—that he put in place that were part of eventually winning.
他就是从提升旧金山49人队的自我形象开始的。在橄榄球界，如果球队一直赢不了球，提升自我形象就难上加难。我的领带就是一个很好的例子。这跟超级碗有什么关系呢？比尔看到了其中的联系。这只是他精心安排的众多细节之一——成千上万个细节——而这些最终都促成了胜利。
Communication within the organization was extremely important to Bill, especially between coaches and players. Even though our headquarters at 711 Nevada Street in Redwood City, California, weren’t so good, he saw the cramped offices where we were almost sitting on top of each other as an asset.
比尔非常重视组织内部的沟通，尤其是教练和球员之间的沟通。尽管我们位于加州红木城内华达街711号的总部条件并不理想，但他却把那些拥挤不堪、人与人之间几乎肩并肩坐着的办公室视为一种优势。
When somebody was talking on the phone or having a conversation, everybody could hear what was going on. In a strange way, it meant that everybody on the staff was in the loop. In fact, eight years later when the DeBartolos built an ultramodern and spacious facility, Bill was very worried that it would not only create a “country club” mentality but hurt our communication process. We couldn’t hear one another’s phone calls anymore!
当有人打电话或交谈时，每个人都能听到发生了什么。从某种意义上说，这意味着所有员工都了解情况。事实上，八年后，当德巴托洛一家建造了一座超现代化且宽敞的办公楼时，比尔非常担心这不仅会滋生一种“乡村俱乐部”式的氛围，还会影响我们的沟通。我们再也听不到彼此的电话了！
Bill Walsh was not afraid of talent. He hired assistant coaches who were extremely good, and he did it with the expectation that they would move on—up to head coaching positions. And in fact, about fifteen of them did. He didn’t feel that you sold your soul to the company store. While you were a 49er, you were expected to give it your all, but Bill was very enlightened in the way he supported the lives and careers of employees beyond just what they could do for his team.
比尔·沃尔什并不惧怕人才。他聘请了许多非常优秀的助理教练，并且期望他们能够晋升为主教练。事实上，大约有十五位助理教练最终做到了这一点。他并不认为你需要为了公司利益而出卖灵魂。作为一名49人队球员，你当然需要全力以赴，但比尔非常开明，他不仅关注员工为球队做出的贡献，也关注他们的生活和职业发展。
One thing that truly amazed me was his eye for talent when it came to football players. It was a gift that is hard to explain or overstate. He could see what others couldn’t spot. Joe Montana, Jerry Rice, Steve Young, and more are among superstar Hall of Fame NFL players who didn’t have a line of people knocking on their doors when Bill came calling. He was uncanny in that way.
真正让我惊叹的是他识人眼光，尤其是在橄榄球运动员方面。这是一种难以言喻的天赋，无论怎样强调都不为过。他能看到别人看不到的东西。乔·蒙塔纳、杰里·赖斯、史蒂夫·杨等等，这些NFL名人堂的超级巨星，在比尔来拜访他们的时候，并没有人蜂拥而至。他在这方面真是不可思议。
Here’s a good example. Early in Bill’s coaching at San Francisco, he was desperate for good players and would hold tryouts for anybody and everybody. We had truck drivers coming in with high-top work shoes; big bruisers from local bars tried out. We were so lean on talent that Bill gave everybody a look.
举个例子。比尔刚开始执教旧金山队时，他急需优秀球员，于是举办试训，来者不拒。我们甚至见过穿着高帮工作鞋的卡车司机，还有当地酒吧里那些身材魁梧的壮汉。当时我们人才匮乏，比尔几乎把所有人都考察了一遍。
One day it was ninety degrees and we had over a hundred prospects on the field going through the workout, trying to make the team, and I was standing up on the fire escape platform with Bill looking over this herd of guys. He said to me, “John, who’s that blond kid down there?” At first I couldn’t even tell who he was talking about. He pointed again: “Him, that kid over there with blond hair.” I checked my chart. “Bill Ring,” I replied. “Sign him,” Bill said. That was the end of the discussion.
有一天，气温高达九十度，一百多名新秀在球场上进行训练，争取进入球队名单。我和比尔站在防火梯平台上，看着这群小伙子们。他问我：“约翰，下面那个金发小子是谁？”我一开始根本没听清他在说谁。他又指了指：“就是他，那边那个金发小子。”我看了看我的球员名单。“比尔·林，”我回答道。“签下他，”比尔说。讨论就此结束。
Bill Ring gave us six productive years and helped us win Super Bowl XVI and Super Bowl XIX, even though others thought he wasn’t NFL material. Bill picked him out of a large pack of players with hardly a glance. He was simply unbelievable in the way he could spot potential in a person and then develop it.
比尔·林格为我们效力了六年，并帮助我们赢得了第十六届和第十九届超级碗，尽管其他人认为他没有进入NFL的实力。比尔几乎没怎么看就从一大群球员中选中了他。他发现一个人的潜力并将其培养出来的能力简直令人难以置信。
He was extremely precise in how he ran not only the nonfootball end of things but the on-field execution. I doubt any coach in the NFL was bringing the precision to it that Bill did—drawing up plays almost to the inch and then teaching the players to perform with that same exactness. And that Standard of Performance permeated the whole organization in people’s attitude and how they—we—did our jobs.
他不仅在非足球事务的管理上，而且在场上执行战术时，都极其严谨。我怀疑NFL中还有哪位教练能像比尔那样做到如此精准——他几乎精确到英寸地设计战术，然后教导球员们以同样的精准度执行。这种高标准的工作作风渗透到整个组织，影响着每个人的态度以及我们每个人的工作方式。
Bill Walsh was ahead of the times in many ways, but there was one thing he didn’t like: He hated to fire someone. At times, he had to make brutal personnel decisions, and I think it hurt him inside knowing his action would change another person’s life, and not necessarily for the better. Consequently, when it came to firing people, he was quick to assign that task to someone by the name of John McVay.
比尔·沃尔什在很多方面都走在了时代的前沿，但他有一件事却很不喜欢：他痛恨解雇员工。有时，他不得不做出残酷的人事决定，我想，他内心一定很痛苦，因为他知道自己的决定会改变他人的人生，而且未必是往好的方向改变。因此，一旦涉及到解雇员工，他总是会迅速把这项任务交给一个名叫约翰·麦克维的人。
I saw him work himself so hard over those ten years, and the toll was increasingly terrible. It didn’t have to be. Bill just had so much trouble letting up, getting out from under the increasingly crushing pressure of expectations that got sky-high as the decade rolled on. Burnout is what they call it, I guess; but who can argue with success?
我亲眼目睹他那十年里拼命工作，身心俱疲。其实本不该如此。比尔只是很难放松下来，摆脱随着十年过去而愈演愈烈的期望压力。我想，人们都称之为职业倦怠吧；但谁又能质疑成功呢？

PART II 第二部分
Success Is Not Spelled G-E-N-I-U-S: Innovation, Planning, and Common Sense 成功并非靠天才：创新、规划和常识。

Opportunity Is in the Eye of the Beholder 机会在于观察者的眼中。
Creating gold from dross is alchemy; making lemonade when you’re given lemons is leadership; making lemonade when you don’t have any lemons is great leadership.
化腐朽为神奇是炼金术；用柠檬做柠檬水是领导力；没有柠檬也能做柠檬水是伟大的领导力。
Here’s a little example of it: Post-it notes are a multimillion-dollar product that began as an accident when a scientist working in the laboratory unintentionally created a glue that didn’t stick very well. Obviously, nobody was looking for a glue that didn’t stick, but then a creative leader saw a way to turn it into lemonade—Post-it Notes.
举个例子：便利贴如今已成为价值数百万美元的产品，而它的诞生却源于一次意外。当时，一位科学家在实验室里无意中研制出一种粘性很差的胶水。显然，没人会需要这种不粘的胶水，但一位富有创意的领导者却从中看到了化腐朽为神奇的潜力——便利贴由此诞生。
I witnessed a football version of Post-it Notes many years ago when I was an assistant coach with the Cincinnati Bengals. See if it applies to your own resourcefulness in evaluating situations and figuring out what to do with “glue that doesn’t stick.”
多年前，我担任辛辛那提猛虎队助理教练时，就亲眼目睹过足球界的“便利贴”现象。看看它是否适用于你评估形势和解决“粘不住的胶水”问题的应变能力。
Early in the second half of our game with the Oakland Raiders, Bengals tight end Bob Trumpy (later a well-known announcer) came out of the huddle and lined up on the wrong end of the line of scrimmage—the left instead of the right side, as the play called for.
在我们与奥克兰突袭者队的比赛下半场开始不久，辛辛那提猛虎队的近端锋鲍勃·特朗皮（后来成为一位著名的解说员）从集合圈中出来，站在了进攻线错误的一端——左侧而不是右侧，这与战术要求不符。
Trumpy recognized his mistake almost immediately and tried to correct it by sliding over to the right side before the ball snap. The Raiders were utilizing a complex pass defense at the time, so when they saw Bob shifting from one end of the line of scrimmage to the other—legal, but not done—all hell broke loose.
特朗皮几乎立刻意识到自己的错误，并在开球前向右侧滑步试图纠正。当时突袭者队采用的是一套复杂的传球防守战术，所以当他们看到鲍勃从进攻线的一端移动到另一端——虽然合法，但并不合规——时，场面顿时一片混乱。
Oakland defensive backs began frantically flapping their arms and screaming, running around and creating havoc as they tried to react to the bizarre movement of Cincinnati’s wandering tight end. Three of them actually collided in the middle of the field. The whole scene was kind of funny, although nobody was laughing on either bench. We lost yardage on the play, and when Bob trotted to the sidelines with a sheepish look on his face, he muttered to head coach Paul Brown, “Sorry, Coach. It won’t happen again.” He was wrong.
奥克兰队的防守后卫们开始疯狂地挥舞手臂、尖叫，四处奔跑，试图应对辛辛那提队那位游离的近端锋的怪异动作，场面一片混乱。其中三名后卫甚至在中场相撞。整个场面颇为滑稽，尽管双方替补席上的人都没笑出来。我们因此损失了码数，鲍勃一脸尴尬地小跑到场边，低声对主教练保罗·布朗说：“对不起，教练。不会再发生了。” 他错了。
When we got back to Cincinnati and the assistant coaches looked at the Oakland game film, Bill Johnson, the offensive line coordinator, ran Trumpy’s play over and over for us on the projector. At first the room was filled with laughter as we saw the mayhem Trumpy’s mistake had precipitated. One man, however, wasn’t laughing—Bill Johnson. He was thinking.
回到辛辛那提后，助理教练们一起观看奥克兰比赛的录像。进攻线协调员比尔·约翰逊反复用投影仪播放特朗皮的失误。起初，房间里充满了笑声，因为我们看到特朗皮的失误引发了一场混乱。然而，有一个人却笑不出来——比尔·约翰逊。他正在思考。
Finally, he stopped rerunning the play, turned to us, and asked, “Fellas, what would happen if we put Trumpy in motion intentionally and worked plays off it?”
最后，他停止了重演这场比赛，转向我们问道：“伙计们，如果我们故意让特朗普动起来，然后根据他的动向制定战术，会发生什么呢？”
There was silence in the room; everyone sitting in the darkness recognized the interesting possibilities this might offer. In fact, I was awake most of that night thinking up ideas that would let us capitalize on Bill Johnson’s revelation, his crazy idea of how to turn a lemon into lemonade, an accident into an asset.
房间里一片寂静；所有坐在黑暗中的人都意识到这可能蕴藏着有趣的机遇。事实上，那天晚上我几乎彻夜未眠，绞尽脑汁地思考如何利用比尔·约翰逊的顿悟——他那看似疯狂的想法，却能将逆境转化为机遇，化危机为机遇。
Putting the tight end in motion caught on quickly around the NFL because it created new problems for the defense. Soon every team in the league had added it to their playbook. And it all started with a botched play.
让近端锋跑动进攻的策略迅速在NFL流行起来，因为它给防守方制造了新的难题。很快，联盟中的每支球队都将其加入到了战术手册中。而这一切都始于一次失败的进攻。
What’s your own version of Trumpy’s lemon and Johnson’s lemonade? Is it right there in front of you, unseen because your thinking is rigid and resistant to originality and change? How effective are you at turning nothing into something, something into something that changes everything?
你对特朗普的柠檬和约翰逊的柠檬水有什么理解？它是不是就在你眼前，只是因为你思维僵化、抗拒创新和改变而视而不见？你有多擅长化腐朽为神奇，把无变成有，再把有变成足以改变一切的东西？

The West Coast Offense: From Checkers to Chess 西海岸进攻体系：从跳棋到国际象棋
Here’s an example I’m proud of from my own coaching career. It profoundly—but unintentionally—changed the way NFL football is played. You may find in its genesis inspiration for extending your own receptiveness to innovation, for seeing what others don’t see.
以下是我执教生涯中一个令我引以为豪的例子。它深刻地——尽管并非有意为之——改变了NFL橄榄球的比赛方式。或许你能从它的起源中获得启发，从而提升你对创新的接受度，看到别人看不到的东西。
The West Coast Offense, considered by many to be one of the most dramatic changes in football during the last fifty years, was nothing more than my attempt to make the most out of what I had to work with as quarterback coach for the Cincinnati Bengals. And what I had wasn’t much—a recent expansion franchise with perhaps the least overall talent of any team in the AFL (soon to merge with the NFL).
西海岸进攻体系被许多人认为是过去五十年橄榄球运动中最剧烈的变革之一，而它只不过是我作为辛辛那提猛虎队四分卫教练，在现有条件下尽力发挥最大潜力的一次尝试。而我当时所拥有的资源并不多——这支新成立的球队或许是AFL（即将与NFL合并）所有球队中整体天赋最差的。
Among other things, the Bengals absolutely could not move the ball on the ground, because other teams were just too strong for us. That left the pass as our only option. Unfortunately, our quarterback, Virgil Carter, wasn’t much of a passer in the traditional sense of having a strong arm capable of throwing deep with accuracy. In fact, somebody told him, “Virgil, if you want to throw the football more than twenty yards you better fill it with helium.” (After he was released by Chicago, we acquired Carter on short notice to replace Greg Cook, a young quarterback with tremendous potential and a great arm. I have seen very few quarterbacks with his talent. Sadly, Greg tore his rotator cuff during his first season with the Bengals and never fully recovered.)
除此之外，猛虎队在地面进攻上完全无法推进，因为其他球队的地面进攻实在太强了。这使得传球成了我们唯一的选择。不幸的是，我们的四分卫维吉尔·卡特并非传统意义上的传球手，他没有那种强劲的臂力，无法精准地长传。事实上，有人曾对他说：“维吉尔，如果你想把球扔出20码以上，最好往里面灌氦气。”（卡特被芝加哥熊队裁掉后，我们迅速签下了他来顶替格雷格·库克。库克是一位年轻有潜力的四分卫，臂力惊人。我很少见到像他这样有天赋的四分卫。可惜的是，格雷格在加盟猛虎队的第一个赛季就撕裂了肩袖，之后再也没有完全康复。）
In studying films of Virgil and watching him in practice, I determined that while he didn’t have much of an arm, he was composed under pressure and could read defenses and was nimble physically and quick mentally. Carter was very intelligent—a Scholastic All-American while at Brigham Young University. Additionally, he was able to throw short passes pretty well. But dependable long strikes? No, that wasn’t him.
通过研究维吉尔的比赛录像和观察他的训练，我发现虽然他的臂力并不突出，但他在压力下沉着冷静，能够准确判断防守，而且身体灵活，思维敏捷。卡特非常聪明——在杨百翰大学就读期间曾入选全美学术明星队。此外，他的短传也相当不错。但是，要说可靠的长传？不，那可不是他的强项。
Virgil’s skills weren’t considered premium assets for an NFL starting quarterback, but that’s all there was. Consequently, I began creating plays that tried to make the most of Virgil’s “limited” abilities—first one play, then another and another.
维吉尔的技能并不足以让他成为一名NFL首发四分卫，但除此之外，他一无所有。因此，我开始设计一些战术，试图最大限度地发挥维吉尔“有限”的能力——先是一个战术，然后是另一个，再一个。
What I came up with called for Carter to throw lots of short, quick-release, timed passes to any one of multiple receivers running exact routes, usually within twelve yards of the line of scrimmage. No helium was required, because Virgil seldom had to throw the football more than fifteen yards.
我设计的方案是让卡特向多名跑特定路线的接球手中的任何一人传出大量短传，出手速度快，时机把握精准，通常在开球线十二码以内。不需要氦气，因为维吉尔很少需要把球传超过十五码。
In designing appropriate plays I was constantly choosing and mixing receivers from a choice of running backs, wide receivers, and tight ends. While each individual receiver’s running route was not complicated—simple, by position— collectively it was complex and made almost dizzying to the defense by the fact that over the years I eventually began “hiding” the same play cosmetically by altering our formation at the line of scrimmage.
在设计合适的战术时，我不断地从跑卫、外接手和近端锋中挑选和组合接球手。虽然每个接球手的跑动路线本身并不复杂——按位置来说很简单——但组合起来却很复杂，而且由于多年来我最终开始通过在开球线改变阵型来“隐藏”同样的战术，这几乎让防守方眼花缭乱。
Thus, receivers for the Bengals (and later the Chargers, Stanford University, and the 49ers) could line up in different spots before the snap but run a route to the same location and be ready for the quarterback’s pass, whether it came from Virgil Carter or Joe Montana. When you do this for scores of plays—and nobody in the NFL was doing it, in part because of the difficulty in creating, teaching, and executing the complexities of the system—you have an almost exponential multiplier of factors and “fool ers” the defense has to figure out instantaneously; often they would think they were seeing something brand new while the quarterback was, in a sense, seeing something “old”: his receivers in the same places seconds after the ball snap, even though the basic formation and routes run were quite different. (Conversely, I would also have receivers run routes to different locations off the same basic formation at the line of scrimmage.)
因此，辛辛那提猛虎队（以及后来的洛杉矶闪电队、斯坦福大学和旧金山49人队）的接球手可以在开球前站在不同的位置，但跑向同一个路线，随时准备接四分卫的传球，无论传球者是维吉尔·卡特还是乔·蒙塔纳。当你在数十个回合中都这样做时——而当时NFL中没有人这样做，部分原因是创建、教授和执行这套复杂体系的难度极大——防守方必须瞬间破解的因素和“迷惑”几乎呈指数级增长；他们常常以为自己看到了全新的战术，而四分卫在某种意义上看到的却是“旧战术”：开球几秒钟后，接球手仍然站在相同的位置，即使基本阵型和跑动路线截然不同。（反过来，我也会让接球手在开球线采用相同的基本阵型，跑向不同的位置。）
To make it all work, I “stretched” the field horizontally to create more room—used all available space from sideline to sideline—to avoid bunching our receivers and their defenders just beyond the line of scrimmage. (The width of a football field is much greater than most fans appreciate—- 53.3 yards. I used all of that width, slightly less than half the length of an NFL field, in designing plays, thus turning the approximately 15 yards of depth—Virgil’s most effective range—and 53.3 yards of width into a wide-open war zone being hit not by long bombs but short ones. At least, that was the plan.)
为了让一切顺利进行，我横向“拉长”了场地，创造了更多空间——充分利用了从边线到边线的所有可用空间——以避免我们的接球手和防守队员在开球线外过于密集。（橄榄球场的宽度远超大多数球迷的想象——53.3码。我在设计战术时充分利用了这宽度，略小于NFL球场长度的一半，从而将大约15码的纵深（维吉尔最有效的传球范围）和53.3码的宽度变成了一个开阔的战场，这里不是长传的战场，而是短传的战场。至少，这是我的计划。）
Over the years, I created an array of pass options that the defense had to figure out, usually in less than 3.5 seconds. Often it was over—the lightning-quick short pass completed—before they knew what hit them.
多年来，我设计了一系列传球选择，防守方必须在3.5秒内破解。很多时候，比赛还没结束——闪电般的短传就完成了——他们还没反应过来就被我打爆了。
Because the passes were often just beyond the line of scrimmage, slower linebackers and safeties were forced into coverage against quicker running backs whom I “converted” into potential receivers. This was a key to maximizing yardage on our pass plays, because I counted on the backs and tight ends to run for yardage after they caught the ball.
由于传球经常刚好越过开球线，速度较慢的线卫和安全卫不得不去防守速度更快的跑卫，而我则把这些跑卫“改造”成了潜在的接球手。这对于最大化传球码数至关重要，因为我指望跑卫和近端锋在接球后能够跑动推进。
In the middle of this seeming bedlam, the quarterback’s job—and Virgil was the first of them—was to immediately scan the field, locate an open receiver among up to five possibilities amid an attacking pack of rushers, and throw a precise pass. Not an easy task.
在这看似混乱的局面中，四分卫的任务——维吉尔是第一个——是立即扫视全场，在多达五名可能接球的球员中找到一名空位接球手，并精准地传球。这绝非易事。
Of course, that’s where we capitalized on Carter’s “limited” skills: great composure, nimble feet, good ability to read defenses, ability to throw short passes with accuracy. The skills necessary to run my offense were not lesser skills than those of the traditional strong-armed quarterback; they were different skills—equally valuable, perhaps more so, and uncommon. No strong arm? No problem. Perhaps the greatest quarterback of all time, Joe Montana, carried a résumé that lacked mention of a powerful throwing arm.
当然，我们正是利用了卡特“有限”的技能：沉着冷静、脚步灵活、善于解读防守、短传精准。执行我的进攻体系所需的技能并不比传统强力四分卫的技能逊色；它们是不同的技能——同样重要，甚至可能更重要，而且并不常见。没有强力臂？没问题。或许是史上最伟大的四分卫乔·蒙塔纳，他的履历中也没有提到他拥有强劲的臂力。
Of course, my many short-pass plays and their cosmetic variations—“looks”—would open up running and downfield passing opportunities, which we exploited. Ideally, we would present an ongoing assortment of plays that kept the defense off balance and vulnerable.
当然，我设计的众多短传战术及其变化——“假动作”——会创造出跑动和长传的机会，而我们也充分利用了这些机会。理想情况下，我们会不断变换战术，让防守方难以招架，变得不堪一击。
That’s how NFL offensive football was changed from checkers to chess. A defense good at checkers but not chess was at a major competitive disadvantage. The Cincinnati Bengals offense started playing advanced checkers with my offensive designs. By the time I got to San Francisco, I was teaching teams how to play advanced chess. The media called it the West Coast Offense.
这就是NFL进攻战术从跳棋转变为国际象棋的原因。一支防守方如果只会跳棋而不会下国际象棋，就会处于巨大的竞争劣势。辛辛那提猛虎队的进攻战术开始运用我的进攻设计，就像玩高级跳棋一样。等我到了旧金山，我已经开始教其他球队如何玩高级国际象棋了。媒体称之为“西海岸进攻”。
While all of this was initially being developed—and once I began it was in development throughout my career—there was never a thought in my mind that it would alter football in any radical way. Rather, I was looking at a situation that had little going for it and trying to get something going. I was forced to be innovative to a degree I didn’t foresee.
虽然这一切最初都在筹备之中——而且一旦我开始着手，它就贯穿了我整个职业生涯——但我从未想过它会以任何根本性的方式改变足球。相反，我当时面对的是一个几乎毫无希望的局面，我试图从中有所作为。我被迫进行创新，其程度之深是我始料未及的。
It worked well enough to give us a fighting chance. In fact, with Virgil at the helm of my unorthodox but evolving offense, the Bengals won the AFC Central division that year with an 8-6 record in spite of losing six of our first seven games while I was thinking up and installing my new plays. In retrospect, this may be one of the more amazing feats I’ve ever been part of. Although we lost in the play-offs to the eventual Super Bowl champions, the Baltimore Colts, 17-0, the effectiveness of my new offensive scheme was startling.
这套战术效果不错，给了我们一线生机。事实上，在维吉尔的带领下，辛辛那提猛虎队凭借我那套非传统但不断改进的进攻体系，最终以8胜6负的战绩赢得了当年的美联中区冠军。要知道，那段时间我还在构思和实施我的新战术，前七场比赛我们输掉了六场。现在回想起来，这或许是我参与过的最令人惊叹的成就之一。虽然我们在季后赛中以0比17惨败给了最终的超级碗冠军巴尔的摩小马队，但我新进攻体系的有效性着实令人震惊。
By then I had spotted an unsung but promising quarterback at Minnesota’s Augustana College, Ken Anderson. We drafted him, and his wider range of skills allowed me to expand my offensive ideas much further. When Virgil was injured, he soon became our starting quarterback.
那时我在明尼苏达州奥古斯塔纳学院发现了一位名不见经传但极具潜力的四分卫——肯·安德森。我们选中了他，他全面的技术让我得以进一步拓展我的进攻理念。维吉尔受伤后，他很快就成为了我们的首发四分卫。
Ken was a quick learner and eventually became so adept that he is the NFL’s all-time leader for a season’s completion percentage—70.60 percent. Another of my quarterbacks is in third place—San Francisco’s Steve Young with 70.28 percent.
肯恩学习能力很强，最终技艺精湛，以70.60%的单赛季传球成功率成为NFL历史上最高的四分卫。我的另一位四分卫排名第三——旧金山49人队的史蒂夫·杨，他的传球成功率为70.28%。
Quickly, what I had put together in a growing package of plays—short and less risky passes to multiple receivers flooding the secondary—became our stock in trade. Eventually, variations of it were incorporated by every team in the NFL and many at the college level. It was born of necessity, bred of innovation and creativity applied to existing—and so-called limited—assets.
很快，我精心编排的这套战术——短传给多名涌入后防线的接球手，风险较低——就成了我们的制胜法宝。最终，NFL的每支球队以及许多大学球队都采用了这套战术的变种。它诞生于现实的需要，孕育于对现有（甚至是所谓的有限）资源的创新和创造力。
And here’s an interesting but very irritating footnote: For my effort in coming up with a successful new way of doing things, I received the disparagement of many in the NFL, especially old-timers who dismissively called it the nickel-and-dime, dink-and-dunk, fancy-pants, or finesse offense—even the swish-and-sway. Their condescension stemmed from the fact that my approach didn’t rely on the traditional brute force, grinding ground game, or spectacular “long bomb” pass of old-time NFL football. It wasn’t physical enough for them.
这里还有一个有趣但又令人恼火的插曲：我努力想出一种行之有效的新方法，却遭到了许多NFL球员的贬低，尤其是那些老前辈，他们轻蔑地称之为“五分钱进攻”、“短传进攻”、“花哨进攻”或“技巧进攻”，甚至还叫它“花哨的传球”。他们居高临下的态度源于我的方法并不依赖于传统NFL橄榄球中常见的蛮力、地面推进或精彩的“长传”。在他们看来，这种方法不够强硬。
Mine was a different approach to gaining yardage, controlling the ball (and clock), and scoring touchdowns. In a sense, the naysayers were seeking victory, but only if it came the old-fashioned way. They were locked into the past and unwittingly locking themselves out of the future. Leaders do this to themselves and their organizations all the time.
