凭借他强大的意志力，他促使我们分析自己的工作内容以及如何表达想要传达的信息。在他面前，你根本无法弄虚作假。那种吹哨、跑动、擒抱、再来一遍的敷衍了事是行不通的。一切都必须经过深思熟虑，在脑海中清晰明确。为此，他鼓励我们去向扶轮社或狮子会等当地团体发表演讲，因为他知道这会让我们更加认真地思考自己要说什么以及如何表达。他也明白，这是良好的公共关系。
He brought in very good coaches and taught us how to be great coaches. Maybe that explains why so many of his assistants eventually became head coaches in their own right. In the history of coaching, nobody’s had more of his assistant coaches—first- and second-generation—go on to head coaching positions.
他引进了非常优秀的教练，并教会我们如何成为卓越的教练。或许正因如此，他的许多助理教练最终都成为了主教练。在教练史上，没有人比他培养出更多——无论是第一代还是第二代——最终成为主教练的助理教练。
Bill forced us to think at a higher level, which was the starting point for getting players to play at a higher level and the organization to operate at a higher level. That was his total focus, like an obsession. All he talked about was improvement. And he knew how to teach improvement.
比尔迫使我们从更高的层面思考问题，这既是球员发挥更高水平、球队运作更高效的基础，也是一切的起点。他全身心投入其中，近乎痴迷。他谈论的只有进步，而且他深谙如何指导进步之道。
Maybe you can’t ultimately explain greatness—the kind Bill Walsh had—but let me offer this observation. He had a brilliant mind for football, and from the start back at Washington High School, where he was a head coach, Bill had been studiously preparing himself for the opportunity he was finally given at San Francisco—learning and thinking at every single step. When Eddie DeBartolo called him with the offer to become head coach of an NFL franchise, Bill knew he was ready and believed his system would work.
或许你无法最终解释伟大——像比尔·沃尔什那样的伟大——但我想提出一点看法。他拥有卓越的橄榄球天赋，从在华盛顿高中担任主教练起，比尔就一直在为最终在旧金山获得的机会精心准备——每一步都不断学习和思考。当埃迪·德巴托洛打电话邀请他成为一支NFL球队的主教练时，比尔知道自己已经准备好了，并且相信他的体系会奏效。
Because of that belief, he had the discipline to stay with it even when things were bad. That’s not to say he didn’t have his rough patches, because he was very insecure and took some knocks that shook his belief in himself. Listen to this: After his seventh or eighth year—I had moved on to a head coaching position by then—he got so down and depressed he called me up to see if I had any interest in taking over as head coach of the 49ers so he could concentrate on executive duties. And he meant it; he was ready to go to DeBartolo and talk him into letting me take over as head coach. I declined, and soon after that, Bill was back on his horse and into the fray.
正是因为这份信念，他才拥有在逆境中也能坚持到底的自律。当然，这并不意味着他一帆风顺，因为他内心非常缺乏安全感，也曾遭受过一些打击，动摇了他的自信。听听这个故事：在他执教的第七年或第八年——那时我已经升任主教练——他情绪低落，甚至打电话给我，问我是否愿意接任49人队的主教练一职，这样他就可以专注于管理工作。他是认真的；他准备去找德巴托洛，说服他让我接任主教练。我拒绝了，不久之后，比尔就重拾信心，再次投入到工作中。
On the field he was advanced. He conducted practice at a fast tempo, full-throttle delivery of information with extraordinary demands for precision in execution. If you were supposed to go twelve yards and you added an extra half yard, it was a big deal. You heard about it in no uncertain terms. Accuracy, accuracy, precision in execution of everything at all levels. No sloppiness. Game -level focus was the price of admission.
他在场上技艺精湛。他以极快的节奏进行训练，全神贯注地传递信息，对执行的精准度要求极高。如果你应该跑十二码，却多跑了半码，那可就糟了。你会听到毫不含糊的批评。在各个层面，所有动作都必须做到精准、准确、再精准。容不得半点马虎。进入他的体系，就必须具备比赛级别的专注力。
Obviously, the physical component is huge in football, but what Bill did was make the mental component even bigger. He taught what he wanted done, and he was a great teacher. He taught players, he taught coaches, he taught staff, he taught, taught, taught. And in that teaching he created belief in ourselves as a team, an organization, because it was apparent that what he was teaching was not only absolutely right, it was advanced. He cleared the deadwood dissenters out and taught the rest of us what it took to get the job done at the highest level.
显然，身体素质在橄榄球运动中至关重要，但比尔的贡献在于他让心理素质的重要性更加凸显。他言传身教，是一位杰出的导师。他教导球员、教练、工作人员，他不断地教导、教导、再教导。在他的教导中，他让我们作为一个团队、一个组织建立起自信，因为我们清楚地认识到，他所传授的不仅完全正确，而且极具前瞻性。他清除了那些消极的异议者，并教会了我们其他人如何在最高水平的赛场上取得成功。
I would tell you this: Bill’s gift for teaching created belief in him, conviction in us. Bill Walsh was the consummate teacher. With the naysayers gone, he had a team of talented people who were ready and willing to be led to the promised land.
我会这样告诉你：比尔卓越的教学天赋赢得了大家的信任，也让我们对他深信不疑。比尔·沃尔什是一位完美的老师。随着那些质疑者的离去，他拥有了一支才华横溢的团队，他们渴望并准备好跟随他走向应许之地。

PART III 第三部分
Fundamentals of Leadership: Concepts, Conceits, and Conclusions 领导力基础：概念、假设和结论

“I Am the Leader!” “我是领导者！”
Someone will declare, “I am the leader!” and expect everyone to get in line and follow him or her to the gates of heaven or hell. My experience is that it doesn’t happen that way. Unless you’re a guard on a chain gang, others follow you based on the quality of your actions rather than the magnitude of your declarations. It’s like announcing, “I am rich!” when you’re broke. After your announcement, you’re still broke, and everybody knows it. In a sense, Barry Switzer found this out in Dallas with the Cowboys when he took over.
有人会高喊：“我是领袖！”然后期望所有人乖乖听话，跟着他/她去天堂或地狱。但我的经验是，事情并非如此。除非你是苦役犯，否则人们追随你，取决于你的行动质量，而不是你宣言的力度。这就像你身无分文却高喊“我发财了！”一样。你喊完之后，依然一无所有，人尽皆知。从某种意义上说，巴里·斯威策接手达拉斯牛仔队时就体会到了这一点。
As head coach at the University of Oklahoma, he had achieved tremendous results, including three national championships and one of the highest winning percentages of any college coach in history. Some consider him one of the best college football coaches ever.
作为俄克拉荷马大学的主教练，他取得了辉煌的成绩，包括三次全国冠军，以及大学橄榄球历史上最高的胜率之一。一些人认为他是史上最优秀的大学橄榄球教练之一。
When Switzer moved to the NFL and took over for Jimmy Johnson as head coach of the Dallas Cowboys (Johnson “retired” as head coach because of ongoing struggles over control and credit issues with owner Jerry Jones), he inherited a terrific football team that had won the previous two Super Bowls by a combined score of 82-30 (the Buffalo Bills were the opponent in both games).
当斯威策转战 NFL 并接替吉米·约翰逊担任达拉斯牛仔队的主教练时（约翰逊因与老板杰里·琼斯在控制权和信用问题上持续斗争而“退休”），他继承了一支非常优秀的橄榄球队，这支球队此前两次赢得超级碗，总比分是 82-30（两场比赛的对手都是布法罗比尔队）。
Initially, Coach Switzer got results from the Cowboys on the momentum of what Johnson and Jones had built. However, in my opinion, Switzer’s continuing freewheeling lifestyle, habits, and behavior—he was generally viewed as a “good ol’ boy”—did not command the respect necessary to keep superstar quarterback Troy Aikman, Hall of Fame running back Emmett Smith, and other outstanding Dallas performers functioning as a cohesive, dedicated, and overpowering football team. Things gradually began to erode.
最初，斯威策教练凭借约翰逊和琼斯建立的势头，带领牛仔队取得了一些成绩。然而，在我看来，斯威策一贯的放荡不羁的生活方式、习惯和行为——他通常被视为一个“老好人”——并没有赢得足够的尊重，无法让超级四分卫特洛伊·艾克曼、名人堂跑卫埃米特·史密斯以及其他杰出的达拉斯球员保持团结、专注和强大的团队凝聚力。情况逐渐恶化。
Barry Switzer’s off-field conduct (e.g., being detained while carrying a gun in his briefcase at the Dallas airport, reports of carousing, and other distracting activities) continually got him the wrong kind of publicity. Plus, he favored the “buddy system” approach to coaching; he had favorites among the players, and everybody knew it. Of course, those who weren’t “buddies” inevitably began to feel like second-class citizens, which usually leads to the creation of a second-class organization.
巴里·斯威策的场外行为（例如，在达拉斯机场因公文包里藏枪而被拘留、酗酒闹事的报道以及其他一些扰乱球队形象的活动）不断给他带来负面舆论。此外，他偏爱“哥们儿式”的执教方式；他偏爱某些球员，人尽皆知。当然，那些不是他“哥们儿”的球员不可避免地会觉得自己低人一等，而这通常会导致球队整体水平下降。
Additionally, his organizational abilities and attention to detail—painstaking attention to perfecting small but important issues—were relatively laid-back. This last item is important because if the person in charge is casual in these areas, others will follow suit.
此外，他的组织能力和对细节的关注——一丝不苟地追求完美，即使是细小但重要的问题——却相对比较随意。最后一点很重要，因为如果负责人在这方面不够认真，其他人也会效仿。
The Dallas Cowboys’ intense focus, commitment, and consequent extraordinary performance results went down during Switzer’s four seasons there. His leadership skills at the NFL level may not have commanded the respect or generated the loyalty necessary for ongoing dominance from that extremely talented Dallas organization.
在斯威策执教达拉斯牛仔队的四个赛季里，球队的专注度、投入程度以及由此带来的卓越战绩均有所下滑。他在NFL层面的领导能力或许未能赢得这支才华横溢的达拉斯球队应有的尊重和忠诚，从而无法使其继续保持统治地位。
All of this contributed to the decline of the Cowboys—which had long-lasting effects: The Cowboys did not repeat as Super Bowl champions in his first season; during Switzer’s second season, Dallas won Super Bowl XXX, but two years later he was out following a 6-10 season and a fourth-place finish in the NFC East. He never coached again in the NFL, and during the five years following his departure, the Dallas Cowboys lost 60 percent of their games. Would this have occurred had Jimmy Johnson remained as head coach? I doubt it.
这一切都导致了牛仔队的衰落——而且影响深远：斯威策执教的第一个赛季，牛仔队未能卫冕超级碗冠军；在斯威策执教的第二个赛季，达拉斯赢得了第三十届超级碗，但两年后，在经历了一个6胜10负、国联东区排名第四的赛季后，他便离开了球队。此后他再也没有在NFL执教过，在他离开后的五年里，达拉斯牛仔队的胜率高达60%。如果吉米·约翰逊继续担任主教练，这种情况还会发生吗？我对此表示怀疑。
Declaring, “I am the leader!” has no value unless you also have the command skills necessary to be the leader. This is true anywhere. Barry Switzer had skills that made him a top college football coach. His skills and style were less effective in leadership at the highest levels in the NFL. It took a while, but ultimately what he did and how he did it caught up with him and the Dallas Cowboys.
光说“我是领导者！”毫无意义，除非你具备成为领导者所需的统帅能力。这在任何领域都适用。巴里·斯威策拥有成为顶尖大学橄榄球教练的技能，但他的技能和风格在NFL最高级别的领导岗位上却显得力不从心。虽然过了一段时间，但他的所作所为以及他行事的方式最终还是让他和达拉斯牛仔队付出了代价。

The Common Denominator of Leadership: Strength of Will 领导力的共同要素：意志力
There is no one perfect or even preferable style of leadership, just as there is no perfect politician or parent. Bill Gates is different from Steve Jobs; Vince Lombardi was different from me.
领导风格没有完美无缺，甚至没有绝对的优劣之分，正如没有完美的政治家或父母一样。比尔·盖茨与史蒂夫·乔布斯截然不同；文斯·隆巴迪也与我迥然不同。
We have, however, seen a move away from the dictatorial type of leadership, an approach that didn’t fit me and that I do not think is conducive to long-term success, especially in a corporate setting. You may get results for a week or a few months, but the cumulative effects of bullying people, creating an environment of ongoing fear, panic, and intimidation, are a situation where employees become increasingly tuned out and immune to all of your noise. And, of course, the talented ones look for a job with a better outfit.
然而，我们已经看到一种摒弃独裁式领导的趋势。这种领导方式并不适合我，而且我认为它不利于长期成功，尤其是在企业环境中。你或许能在短短一周或几个月内取得成效，但长期欺凌员工、营造持续的恐惧、恐慌和恐吓氛围，最终会导致员工对你的所有言论都越来越麻木不仁。当然，优秀的人才也会另谋高就。
The tyrant still exists in leadership, in both sports and business, but is in retreat. The strong-willed personality, however, is not disappearing anywhere anytime soon, whether in sports, nonprofits, or corporate America.
暴君式的领导者仍然存在于体育界和商界，但正在退却。然而，无论是在体育界、非营利组织还是美国企业界，强势的个性都不会很快消失。
The leader who will not be denied, who has expertise coupled with strength of will, is going to prevail. Here are three people, head coaches I know personally and whose abilities I respect, who are dissimilar in many ways but exactly the same in one area—strength of will. They will not be denied:
不屈不挠、兼具专业知识和坚定意志的领导者终将获胜。以下三位都是我认识且非常敬重的教练，他们在很多方面都截然不同，但在一点上却完全一致——那就是坚定的意志。他们必将取得胜利：
Mike Holmgren’s Green Bay Packers won Super Bowl XXXI, and he’s been very successful as head coach of the Seattle Seahawks; before that he was one of my assistant coaches at San Francisco, so I know him pretty well. Here’s my capsule description of Mike: He is thoughtful, intelligent, and assertive—an excellent teacher who, beneath his surface appearance of being amenable and open to everything, absolutely knows what he wants and gets it; and everybody in his organization understands that.
迈克·霍姆格伦执教的绿湾包装工队赢得了第31届超级碗，他作为西雅图海鹰队的主教练也取得了巨大的成功；在此之前，他曾是我的助理教练，所以我对他很了解。以下是我对迈克的简要评价：他思维缜密、才智过人、意志坚定——是一位优秀的教练，表面上他平易近人、乐于接受一切，但实际上他非常清楚自己想要什么，并且总能达成目标；他团队中的每个人都明白这一点。
Mike is unswerving in moving toward his goal.
迈克正坚定不移地朝着他的目标前进。
Tom Landry won Super Bowl VI and Super Bowl XII as head coach of the Dallas Cowboys. Almost as impressive is his streak of twenty consecutive winning seasons. Here’s my description of Landry: Tom had a tremendous mind for technical football and was inordinately well organized and very strong mentally—a no-nonsense guy greatly respected for the exemplary standards he demanded of himself and those who worked with him. Tom didn’t like to show emotion. (Walt Garrison, a former running back for Dallas, was asked if he’d ever seen Landry smile. He replied, “No, but I was only on his team for nine years.”)
汤姆·兰德里曾作为达拉斯牛仔队的主教练，带领球队赢得了第六届和第十二届超级碗。他连续二十个赛季取得胜利的纪录也同样令人印象深刻。以下是我对兰德里的评价：汤姆对橄榄球技术有着惊人的理解力，组织能力极强，心理素质也非常高——他是一位一丝不苟、严于律己的人，对自己和与他共事的人都要求极高，因此备受尊敬。汤姆不喜欢流露情感。（前达拉斯牛仔队跑卫沃尔特·加里森曾被问及是否见过兰德里笑过。他回答说：“没有，但我只在他队待了九年。”）
And, like Holmgren, Tom Landry was unswerving in moving toward his goal.
和霍尔姆格伦一样，汤姆·兰德里也坚定不移地朝着他的目标前进。
Jimmy Johnson won a national championship as head coach of the University of Miami Hurricanes and two consecutive Super Bowl championships at Dallas. Here’s my description of Jimmy: a smart guy with an exuberant personality who brought in outstanding people and delegated well. He was not the technical football expert that Landry was, but a better salesman. (Landry was a good salesman unintentionally. Jimmy intended to be good at selling himself and his system, and he was.)
吉米·约翰逊曾作为迈阿密大学飓风队的主教练赢得过一次全国冠军，并在达拉斯牛仔队连续两次夺得超级碗冠军。我对吉米的评价是：他聪明睿智，个性热情洋溢，善于招揽优秀人才，并且能够出色地进行授权。他不像兰德里那样是技术精湛的橄榄球专家，但他更擅长推销。（兰德里是一位无意中成为优秀推销员的人。吉米则有意推销自己和他的体系，而且他成功了。）
And, like Holmgren and Landry, Jimmy Johnson was unswerving in moving toward his goal.
和霍尔姆格伦、兰德里一样，吉米·约翰逊也坚定不移地朝着他的目标前进。
I pick these three because they’ve all enjoyed the ultimate success in football—a Super Bowl championship (or two)—and because they are so different in many ways, Holmgren seemingly amenable and flexible, Landry stoic and stern, Johnson like Robert Preston in The Music Man —exuberant and lively.
我选择这三位是因为他们都在足球领域取得了最终的成功——一个（或两个）超级碗冠军——而且他们在很多方面都非常不同：霍尔姆格伦似乎随和灵活，兰德里坚忍严厉，约翰逊就像《音乐人》中的罗伯特·普雷斯顿——热情洋溢、活力四射。
What they share beyond expertise and great success, however, was their indomitable will. They simply would not quit in their effort to install their own system, to push forward with their plan, not someone else’s or a committee’s. Keep in mind that all three of them were handed tough jobs, teams in trouble (e.g., Dallas was an expansion franchise and went 0-11-1 in their first season under Landry).
然而，除了专业知识和巨大成功之外，他们共同拥有的还有他们不屈不挠的意志。他们坚持不懈地推行自己的体系，而不是别人或委员会的计划，绝不放弃。要知道，他们三人接手的都是棘手的任务，执教的都是陷入困境的球队（例如，达拉斯是一支新成立的球队，在兰德里执教的第一个赛季战绩为0胜11负1平）。
Some leaders are volatile, some voluble; some stoic, others exuberant; but all successful leaders know where we want to go, figure out a way we believe will get the organization there (after careful consideration of relevant available information), and then move forward with absolute determination. We may falter from time to time, but ultimately we are unswerving in moving toward our goal; we will not quit. There is an inner compulsion—obsession—to get it done the way you want it done even if the personal cost is high.
有些领导者性情多变，有些则滔滔不绝；有些沉稳冷静，有些则热情洋溢；但所有成功的领导者都清楚我们的目标，在仔细权衡所有相关信息后，找到一条我们认为能够带领组织实现目标的路径，然后坚定不移地向前迈进。我们或许会偶尔遇到挫折，但最终我们会毫不动摇地朝着目标前进；我们绝不放弃。内心深处有一种强烈的冲动——甚至可以说是执念——即使个人付出高昂的代价，也要按照自己想要的方式完成任务。
It is good to remind yourself that this quality—strength of will—is essential to your survival and success. Often you are urged to “go along to get along,” solemnly advised that “your plan should’ve worked by now,” or told other variations that amount to backing away from a course you believe in your heart and know in your head is correct.
要时刻提醒自己，意志力这种品质对你的生存和成功至关重要。你常常会听到别人劝你“随波逐流”，或者郑重其事地告诉你“你的计划现在应该已经奏效了”，或者听到其他种种类似的劝告，这些话无非是让你放弃自己内心深处坚信、理智上也清楚是正确的道路。
You look around the room and find yourself with only a few supporters. Or perhaps not even a few. Heads are bowed, everybody’s eyes are lowered, looking down at their hands, embarrassed to look at you. You may be standing alone. This is when you find out if you’re a leader.
你环顾四周，发现只有寥寥几个支持者。或许连几个都没有。大家都低着头，目光垂落，低头看着自己的双手，羞于直视你。你可能孤身一人。这时，你才能真正看清自己是否具备领导才能。
In my years as a head coach, I wanted a democratic-style organization with input and communication and freedom of expression, even opinions that were at great variance with my ideas. But only up to a point. When it was time for a decision, that decision would be made by me according to dictates having to do with one thing only, namely, making the team better.
在我担任主教练的那些年里，我一直想要一个民主式的组织，鼓励大家参与、沟通和自由表达，即使是与我的想法大相径庭的意见。但这种自由是有界限的。当需要做决定时，我会根据一个唯一的原则来做出决定，那就是：让球队变得更好。
And once the decision was made, the discussion was over. My ultimate job, and yours, is not to give an opinion. Everybody’s got an opinion. Leaders are paid to make a decision. The difference between offering an opinion and making a decision is the difference between working for the leader and being the leader.
一旦做出决定，讨论就结束了。我的最终职责，也是你的职责，不是发表意见。每个人都有自己的看法。领导者的职责是做出决策。发表意见和做出决策之间的区别，就是为领导者工作和成为领导者之间的区别。
I was never a screamer, but everyone knew not to buck me when I’d decided what we were going to do. Just like Mike Holmgren, Tom Landry, Jimmy Johnson, and many others, I was unswerving in moving toward my goal. Once I had accumulated and evaluated the available information, I did it my way. And so should you.
我从不大声嚷嚷，但大家都知道，一旦我决定了要做什么，就不要跟我作对。就像迈克·霍尔姆格伦、汤姆·兰德里、吉米·约翰逊以及其他许多人一样，我坚定不移地朝着目标前进。一旦我收集并评估了所有可用的信息，我就按自己的方式来做。你也应该这样做。
Now, let me address a problem this prerequisite leadership trait—strength of will—can pose, namely, the problem of determining when “my way” is the wrong way.
现在，让我来谈谈这种必备的领导特质——意志力——可能带来的一个问题，即如何判断“我的方式”何时是错误的方式。

Be Wrong for the Right Reasons 为正确的理由而犯错
Coaches, like leaders anywhere, often try to force a plan past the point of reality. In football we may want to establish a passing game and persist too long because we’re preoccupied with it, determined by our own will to make it happen even when it’s ill conceived or ill timed. This is no different from a corporate leader who imposes a plan of action beyond the point of no return, the point where continuing makes no sense and becomes destructive.
教练和任何领域的领导者一样，常常会试图强行推行超出现实范围的计划。在橄榄球比赛中，我们可能想要建立一套传球体系，却因为过于执着于此而坚持过久，一心只想让它成功，即使这个体系构思不周或时机不当。这与企业领导者强行推行行动计划并无二致，后者往往会使计划走向无法挽回的地步，以至于继续下去毫无意义，反而会适得其反。
It’s a delicate balance: You must persevere to achieve anything of import, but at what stage does perseverance become pigheadedness? When does your unswerving determination to do it your way—what you deem the “right way”—take you and your organization over the cliff?
这是一种微妙的平衡：要想取得任何重要的成就，都必须坚持不懈，但坚持不懈在什么情况下会变成固执己见？你一意孤行，坚持按你认为的“正确方式”行事，何时会将你和你的组织带入深渊？
Years ago, when I was head coach at Stanford University, we played Tulane University in the second game of our season. In my pregame preparation, while watching hours of game film, I had determined that we could—and would—rely on our running game against a mediocre Tulane defense. The previous week in the season opener we had lost by only six points to number one-ranked Colorado and had run the ball successfully.
多年前，我担任斯坦福大学主教练时，赛季第二场比赛我们对阵杜兰大学。赛前，我花了几个小时观看比赛录像，最终认定我们可以——而且也应该——依靠跑动进攻来对抗实力平庸的杜兰大学防守。前一周的赛季揭幕战中，我们仅以6分之差惜败于排名第一的科罗拉多大学，那场比赛我们的跑动进攻也颇为成功。
Now we were in New Orleans for the Tulane game, and I announced in the middle of a press conference that I challenged Tulane to deal with Stanford’s ground game, dared them to try and stop us. Well, they did.
当时我们身在新奥尔良，准备参加与杜兰大学的比赛。在新闻发布会上，我突然宣布，我向杜兰大学发起挑战，让他们来应对斯坦福大学的地面进攻，让他们试试能不能阻止我们。结果，他们真的做到了。
It took me into the middle of the third quarter to realize I was a victim of my own mistaken assessment, rhetoric, and subsequent stubbornness: We were behind 17-6 and on the verge of losing because I was determined to show that our “unstoppable” running game couldn’t be stopped.
直到第三节中段，我才意识到自己是自己错误评估、言论和随后的固执的受害者：我们以 6-17 落后，眼看就要输掉比赛，因为我决心证明我们“势不可挡”的跑动进攻是无法被阻止的。
Somehow it dawned on me: I was staying with a bad plan because my ego was committed to the stupid challenge I had made while boasting about our running game to the media. Tulane’s defense was stronger than I had concluded after watching their game films. However, I didn’t want to be proved wrong in front of sixty-five thousand spectators in the Super-dome who had read my boast in the sports section of the New Orleans Times-Picayune or heard it on radio or television.
我突然意识到：我之所以坚持一个糟糕的计划，是因为我的自尊心让我执迷不悟，执迷于之前在媒体面前吹嘘我们跑动进攻时提出的愚蠢挑战。看完他们的比赛录像后，我才意识到杜兰大学的防守比我预想的要强得多。然而，我不想在超级穹顶体育馆六万五千名观众面前被打脸，他们可能在《新奥尔良时报》体育版上读到过我的吹嘘，或者在广播电视上听到过。
When I recognized the mental trap I had set and stepped into, I abandoned our ground game and allowed quarterback Guy Benjamin’s passing skills to get us going. The results were immediate, and Stanford won 21-17. However, I had jeopardized the game by locking my ego into a strategy that was failing. I did not allow logic or the reality of the game to pierce my veil of pride. It was my ego and strength of will that had almost killed us.
当我意识到自己落入了心理陷阱并深陷其中时，我放弃了地面进攻，转而依靠四分卫盖伊·本杰明的传球技巧来打开局面。效果立竿见影，斯坦福大学最终以21比17获胜。然而，我却因为固执己见而将比赛的胜利拱手让给了对手。我没有让逻辑和比赛的现实刺破我骄傲的面纱。正是我的自负和固执己见几乎葬送了我们。
I had all but lost that game for our young team because I didn’t want to back off something I’d bragged about. I was caught up in my own rhetoric about Stanford’s running game when I had a quarterback who was one of the finest passers in college football. Even now I’m a little embarrassed to think about the level of immaturity I demonstrated during an important game. Obviously, this was not my best moment as a leader.
那场比赛，我几乎是葬送了我们这支年轻球队的胜利，因为我不想推翻自己之前吹嘘过的东西。我当时满脑子都是斯坦福的跑动进攻，却忽略了自己手下有一位大学橄榄球界最优秀的传球手之一。即使现在回想起来，我在那场重要比赛中表现出的不成熟仍然让我感到有些尴尬。显然，那不是我作为领导者最光彩的时刻。
Here’s a similar example, away from the game of football, that you may recall. Years ago, the executives at Coca-Cola decided to replace classic Coke with a new version of it. Tests seemed to suggest that the new flavor was favored by potential buyers over the time-tested Coke that had become a worldwide brand and a proven phenomenon. Coca-Cola went ahead and replaced it—took the classic Coke off shelves worldwide—amid great fanfare. The sales results were not good. In fact, it was a fiasco. But those same executives, committed as they were to the new product and having spent tens of millions of dollars on it, recognized “their way” was the wrong way. New Coke was introduced in April and taken off the shelves in July.
这里有一个与足球无关的类似例子，你可能还记得。多年前，可口可乐公司的高管决定用一款新口味的可乐取代经典可乐。测试结果似乎表明，潜在消费者更喜欢新口味，而不是久经考验、已成为全球品牌和成功案例的经典可乐。可口可乐公司大张旗鼓地完成了替换——在全球范围内将经典可乐下架。然而，销售结果并不理想。事实上，这是一次彻底的失败。但那些高管们，尽管对新产品充满信心，并且已经投入了数千万美元，最终还是意识到“他们的方式”是错误的。新可乐于四月上市，七月便下架了。
So the question is this: How do you know when it’s time to quit, to try another approach, to move in a different direction, regardless of whether it’s a commitment to a football team’s running game, a company’s marketing plan, or a new hire? When is it time to say, “I’m wrong”? Here’s the answer: There is no answer; there is no cut-and-dried formula.
所以问题是：无论你投入的是足球队的跑动战术、公司的营销计划，还是新员工的招聘，你如何知道何时该放弃、何时该尝试其他方法、何时该转向其他方向？何时该说“我错了”？答案是：没有答案；没有万能的公式。
We all have in our mind inspiring examples of individuals who persevered beyond the point of reason and common sense and prevailed. We tend to ignore the more numerous examples of individuals who persisted and persisted and finally failed and took everybody down with them because they would not change course or quit. We ignore them because we never heard about them. Failure rarely garners the amount of attention that victory does.
我们每个人心中都有一些鼓舞人心的例子，他们超越了理智和常识的极限，最终取得了成功。然而，我们往往忽略了更多坚持不懈却最终失败，甚至拖累所有人的例子，因为他们不愿改变方向或放弃。我们忽略他们，是因为我们从未听说过他们。失败很少像胜利那样引人注目。
Thus, the epic journey of Arctic explorer Ernest Shackleton is worth noting because we’ve heard about him. Shackleton took the crew of the HMS Endurance on a monumental and courageous expedition aimed at crossing the Antarctic on foot. Many have been inspired by his exploits; even the name of his ship— Endurance —is used for motivation.
因此，北极探险家欧内斯特·沙克尔顿的史诗之旅值得一提，因为我们都听说过他。沙克尔顿率领“坚忍号”的船员们进行了一次意义非凡且英勇无畏的探险，目标是徒步穿越南极洲。他的壮举激励了许多人；甚至他所驾驶的船的名字——“坚忍号”——也被用来激励人们。
I also greatly admire his courage, loyalty, and dedication, but in case you forgot, his expedition was doomed; it ended in failure: The HMS Endurance was trapped in ice and crushed. Shackleton’s incredible commitment to his men ultimately saved them from death, although three of the rescuers died in the process. The magnitude of his ultimately successful rescue effort—rather than the failure to reach his primary goal—is what we remember. I, too, am inspired by his raw drive to save his men. I also keep in mind the loss of his ship and the failure of his expedition.
我也非常钦佩他的勇气、忠诚和奉献精神，但或许你忘了，他的探险注定失败；最终以失败告终：皇家海军“坚忍号”被困冰层中，最终损毁。沙克尔顿对船员们的无比忠诚最终拯救了他们，尽管三名救援人员在救援过程中牺牲。我们记住的是他最终成功的救援行动，而不是他未能实现主要目标。我也被他拯救船员的坚定信念所感动。同时，我也铭记着他的船只沉没和探险的失败。
In every leader’s work there are times when you must coldly evaluate the path down which you are taking your organization. In my own work, the Tulane experience was valuable because it was an example of persisting for the wrong reason.
每位领导者在工作中都会遇到需要冷静评估组织发展方向的时候。就我个人而言，杜兰大学的经历很有价值，因为它让我意识到，坚持下去的理由是错误的。
The lesson I took from it was this: A leader must be keen and alert to what drives a decision, a plan of action. If it was based on good logic, sound principles, and strong belief, I felt comfortable in being unswerving in moving toward my goal. Any other reason (or reasons) for persisting were examined carefully. Among the most common faulty reasons are (1) trying to prove you are right and (2) trying to prove someone else is wrong. Of course, they amount to about the same thing and often lead to the same place: defeat.
我从中得到的教训是：领导者必须敏锐地洞察决策和行动计划背后的驱动因素。如果决策和计划基于合理的逻辑、健全的原则和坚定的信念，我便能安心地朝着目标坚定不移地前进。任何其他坚持的理由，我都会仔细审视。最常见的错误理由包括：（1）试图证明自己是对的；（2）试图证明别人是错的。当然，这两种理由本质上并无二致，而且往往会导致同样的结果：失败。
Losing—failure—is part of the package for a leader in a competitive career. I was always reluctant to change a course of action that I had committed to in pursuit of a goal, but after my pigheaded persistence against Tulane University, I became scrupulous in analyzing when a change of course was appropriate, when “my way” was the wrong way.
在竞争激烈的职业生涯中，失败是领导者不可避免的一部分。我以前总是不愿改变为了实现目标而制定的行动方案，但在与杜兰大学的较量中，我固执己见，最终失败。这次经历让我开始认真分析何时应该改变策略，何时“我的方法”是错误的。
A leader must have a vision, which is simply an elevated word for “goal.” Significant time and resources will be applied to achieving that goal. Therefore, it is of paramount importance that you proceed and persist for the correct reasons; your tactics must be sound and based on logic seasoned with instinct. If I led our team down the road to failure, I wanted to make sure the quality of my reasoning was very solid. If we went down, I wanted to go down for the right reasons. That’s tough enough to take, but what is toughest of all—what is inexcusable—is to fail because you are unwilling to admit that your way was the wrong way and that a change of course is your only path to victory.
领导者必须有愿景，这其实就是“目标”的另一种说法。为了实现这个目标，需要投入大量的时间和资源。因此，至关重要的是，你的行动和坚持必须出于正确的理由；你的策略必须合理，并且建立在逻辑和直觉之上。如果我带领团队走向失败，我希望确保我的推理非常充分。如果我们失败了，我希望失败的理由是正确的。这已经够难接受了，但最难接受的——也是最不可原谅的——是因为你不愿意承认自己的方法错了，不愿意承认改变方向才是通往胜利的唯一途径。
Few things are more painful for a leader than losing because your reasoning is faulty, your conclusions flawed, your logic skewed by emotions, pride, or arrogance. One of the great leadership challenges is to recognize when hubris has you in its grip before it is too late to change. Here’s a short checklist worth keeping in mind when it comes to persevering, to doing it “your way” at all costs:
1. A leader must never quit.
2. A leader must know when to quit.
3. Proving that you are right or proving that someone is wrong are bad reasons for persisting.
4. Good logic, sound principles, and strong belief are the purest and most productive reasons for pushing forward when things get rough.
对于领导者而言，最痛苦的事情莫过于因推理错误、结论有误、逻辑受情绪、骄傲或傲慢蒙蔽而导致的失败。领导者面临的一大挑战在于，如何在为时已晚之前，意识到自己已被傲慢所掌控。以下是一份简短的清单，值得在坚持不懈、不惜一切代价“按自己的方式来”时牢记：1. 领导者绝不能放弃。2. 领导者必须知道何时应该放弃。3. 证明自己正确或证明别人错误并非坚持的理由。4. 良好的逻辑、健全的原则和坚定的信念，才是逆境中奋力前行的最纯粹、最有效的理由。

Protect Your Turf 保护你的草坪
The head of the 49er scouts, Howard White, was incensed when I was named general manager; he wanted the job and felt he deserved it. During a tense meeting in which I told him he wasn’t going to be general manager, White announced that not only was he resigning but all of our scouts were quitting out of loyalty to him.
49人队球探主管霍华德·怀特得知我被任命为总经理后勃然大怒；他一直想要这份工作，并且觉得自己理应得到它。在一次气氛紧张的会议上，我告诉他他不会担任总经理，怀特随即宣布他不仅要辞职，而且我们所有的球探都会出于对他的忠诚而集体辞职。
His threat carried tremendous weight, since the scouts happened to be in town for a predraft conference, a series of meetings that would chart our future talent acquisitions and, in effect, my future. My authority—my leadership—was being challenged at a critical moment. Howard knew it and was more than pleased to put a gun to my head.
他的威胁威力巨大，因为球探们恰好来到这里参加选秀前的会议，这一系列会议将决定我们未来的人才引进，实际上也决定了我的未来。我的权威——我的领导地位——正面临着关键时刻的挑战。霍华德心知肚明，并且非常乐意拿枪指着我的头。
I felt, however, that I had no option but to call Howard out and call him on his threat. I knew more about judging talent for my system than anyone, including Howard. I therefore accepted his “resignation” and then asked John Ralston, a member of our staff, to immediately inform all of the other scouts that we accepted their resignations as tendered by their boss. That was a bombshell.
然而，我别无选择，只能当面质问霍华德，揭穿他的威胁。我比任何人都更了解如何根据我的体系来评判人才，包括霍华德在内。因此，我接受了他的“辞职”，然后让我们的同事约翰·拉尔斯顿立即通知所有其他球探，我们已经接受了他们老板递交的辞呈。这可真是个重磅消息。
The scouts’ response was swift and unequivocal: “We want to stay; we’re not unhappy that Howard White is leaving; we didn’t offer to follow him out the door,” or words to that effect. My problem was over, but only because I had stood my ground and protected my turf when my position and authority were challenged. Leaders who don’t understand what their territory is and how to protect it will soon find themselves with no turf to protect.
球探们的反应迅速而明确：“我们想留下；我们并不介意霍华德·怀特离开；我们也没有提出要跟着他一起走。”或者类似的话。我的问题解决了，但这仅仅是因为我在地位和权威受到挑战时坚持了自己的立场，捍卫了自己的地盘。那些不了解自己领地范围以及如何捍卫领地的领导者，很快就会发现自己无地可守。

Be a Leader—Twelve Habits Plus One 成为领导者——十二个习惯加一个
A defining characteristic of a good leader is the conviction that he or she can make a positive difference—can prevail even when the odds are stacked against him or her. A successful leader is not easily swayed from this self-belief. But it happens.
优秀领导者的一个显著特征是坚信自己能够带来积极的改变——即使面对重重困难也能取得胜利。成功的领导者不会轻易动摇这种自信。但这种情况并非不可能发生。
When you fall prey to the naysayers who eagerly provide you with all the reasons why you won’t succeed, why you can’t win, and why you should quit, you have lost the winner’s edge. When that happens, the game is over, regardless of your profession.
当你屈服于那些急于给你列举各种理由，告诉你为什么你不会成功、为什么你赢不了、为什么你应该放弃的唱衰者时，你就失去了制胜优势。一旦这种情况发生，无论你从事什么职业，游戏就结束了。
In addition to expertise and knowledge of the specific competitive environment, I believe a leader must also have certain habits (to use a word popularized by Dr. Stephen Covey) that contribute to his or her effectiveness, that create and cement his or her winner’s edge. In my view a truly effective leader must be certain things. Here are twelve habits I have identified over the years that will make you be a better leader:
1. Be yourself. I am not Vince Lombardi; Vince Lombardi was not Bill Walsh. My style was my style, and it worked for me. Your style will work for you when you take advantage of your strengths and strive to overcome your weaknesses. You must be the best version of yourself that you can be; stay within the framework of your own personality and be authentic. If you’re faking it, you’ll be found out.
2. Be committed to excellence. I developed my Standard of Performance over three decades in the business of football. It could just as accurately (although more awkwardly) been called “Bill’s Prerequisites for Doing Your Job at the Highest Level of Excellence Vis-à-Vis Your Actions and Attitude on Our Team.” My commitment to this “product”—excellence—preceded my commitment to winning football games. At all times, in all ways, your focus must be on doing things at the highest possible level.
3. Be positive. I spent far more time teaching what to do than what not to do; far more time teaching and encouraging individuals than criticizing them; more time building up than tearing down. There is a constructive place for censure and highlighting negative aspects of a situation, but too often it is done simply to vent and creates a barrier between you and others. Maintain an affirmative, constructive, positive environment.
4. Be prepared. (Good luck is a product of good planning.) Work hard to get ready for expected situations—events you know will happen. Equally important, plan and prepare for the unexpected. “What happens when what’s supposed to happen doesn’t happen?” is the question that you must always be asking and solving. No leader can control the outcome of the contest or competition, but you can control how you prepare for it.
5. Be detail-oriented. Organizational excellence evolves from the perfection of details relevant to performance and production. What are they for you? High performance is achieved small step by small step through painstaking dedication to pertinent details. (Caution: Do not make the mistake of burying yourself alive in those details.) Address all aspects of your team’s efforts to prepare mentally, physically, fundamentally, and strategically in as thorough a manner as is humanly possible.
6. Be organized. A symphony will sound like a mess without a musical score that organizes each and every note so that the musicians know precisely what to play and when to play it. Great organization is the trademark of a great organization. You must think clearly with a disciplined mind, especially in regard to the most efficient and productive use of time and resources.
7. Be accountable. Excuse making is contagious. Answerability starts with you. If you make excuses—which is first cousin to “alibiing”—so will those around you. Your organization will soon be filled with finger-pointing individuals whose battle cry is, “It’s his fault, not mine!”
8. Be near-sighted and far-sighted. Keep everything in perspective while simultaneously concentrating fully on the task at hand. All decisions should be made with an eye toward how they affect the organization’s performance—not how they affect you or your feelings. All efforts and plans should be considered not only in terms of short-run effect, but also in terms of how they impact the organization long term. This is very difficult.
9. Be fair. The 49ers treated people right. I believe your value system is as important to success as your expertise. Ethically sound values engender respect from those you lead and give your team strength and resilience. Be clear in your own mind as to what you stand for. And then stand up for it.
10. Be firm. I would not budge one inch on my core values, standards, and principles.
11. Be flexible. I was agile in adapting to changing circumstances. Consistency is crucial, but you must be quick to adjust to new challenges that defy the old solutions.
12. Believe in yourself. To a large degree, a leader must “sell” himself to the team. This is impossible unless you exhibit self-confidence. While I was rarely accused of cockiness, it was apparent to most observers that I had significant belief—self-confidence—in what I was doing. Of course, belief derives from expertise.
13. Be a leader. Whether you are a head coach, CEO, or sales manager, you must know where you’re going and how you intend to get there, keeping in mind that it may be necessary to modify your tactics as circumstances dictate. You must be able to inspire and motivate through teaching people how to execute their jobs at the highest level. You must care about people and help those people care about one another and the team’s goals. And you must never second-guess yourself on decisions you make with integrity, intelligence, and a team-first attitude.
除了对特定竞争环境的专业知识和经验之外，我认为领导者还必须具备某些习惯（借用史蒂芬·柯维博士推广的一个词），这些习惯有助于提升其效能，创造并巩固其制胜优势。在我看来，真正高效的领导者必须具备某些特质。以下是我多年来总结的十二个能让你成为更优秀领导者的习惯：1. 做你自己。我不是文斯·隆巴迪；文斯·隆巴迪也不是比尔·沃尔什。我的风格就是我的风格，而且它对我有效。当你发挥自身优势并努力克服自身弱点时，你的风格也会对你有效。你必须成为最好的自己；坚守你的个性框架，保持真诚。如果你弄虚作假，终会被识破。2. 致力于追求卓越。我在足球行业从业三十余年，逐步形成了我的绩效标准。它也可以更准确地（尽管可能略显笨拙地）被称为“比尔关于如何在团队中以最高水平的行动和态度完成工作的先决条件”。我对卓越这一“产品”的承诺先于我对赢得足球比赛的承诺。无论何时何地，你都必须专注于以最高水平完成工作。3. 保持积极的态度。我花在教导别人该做什么上的时间远远多于教导别人不该做什么；花在教导和鼓励别人上的时间远远多于批评别人；花在建设上的时间远远多于破坏。批评和指出问题的负面方面固然有其建设性的意义，但很多时候，人们只是为了发泄情绪而这样做，反而会在你和他人之间筑起一道屏障。要保持积极、建设性、乐观的工作氛围。4. 做好准备。（好运源于周密的计划。）努力为预期的情况做好准备——那些你知道会发生的事情。同样重要的是，要为意外情况做好计划和准备。 “当预期的事情没有发生时该怎么办？”这个问题你必须始终思考并解决。任何领导者都无法控制比赛或竞赛的结果，但你可以控制你如何为之准备。5. 注重细节。卓越的组织源于对与绩效和生产相关的细节的精益求精。对你而言，这些细节是什么？高绩效是通过对相关细节的精益求精，一步一个脚印地实现的。（注意：不要让自己被这些细节淹没。）尽可能全面地考虑团队在心理、生理、基本功和战略层面所做的准备工作。6. 保持条理。如果没有乐谱来组织每一个音符，交响乐听起来就会一团糟，因为乐谱会让乐手们清楚地知道该演奏什么以及何时演奏。优秀的组织是优秀组织的标志。你必须思路清晰、思维严谨，尤其是在如何最有效、最高效地利用时间和资源方面。7. 勇于承担责任。找借口是会传染的。责任感始于你。如果你找借口——这与“开脱”如出一辙——你周围的人也会如此。你的组织很快就会充斥着互相指责的人，他们的口号是：“都是他的错，不是我的！”8. 要兼顾近处和远处。在保持全局观的同时，也要全神贯注于手头的任务。所有决策都应该着眼于它们如何影响组织的绩效，而不是它们如何影响你或你的感受。所有努力和计划不仅要考虑短期影响，还要考虑它们对组织的长期影响。这非常困难。9. 要公平。旧金山49人队善待员工。我相信你的价值观与你的专业知识一样，对成功至关重要。合乎道德的价值观会赢得你所领导的人的尊重，并赋予你的团队力量和韧性。要清楚自己的立场。然后，坚持你的立场。10. 要坚定。在我的核心价值观、标准和原则上，我绝不妥协。11.要灵活变通。我善于适应不断变化的环境。保持一致性固然重要，但你必须迅速调整以应对那些无法用旧方法解决的新挑战。12. 相信自己。在很大程度上，领导者必须向团队“推销”自己。除非你展现出自信，否则这是不可能的。虽然我很少被指责自大，但大多数观察者都清楚地看到，我对自己的工作充满信心。当然，信心源于专业知识。13. 成为一名领导者。无论你是主教练、首席执行官还是销售经理，你都必须知道自己要去哪里，以及如何到达那里，同时要记住，根据情况需要，你可能需要调整策略。你必须能够通过指导人们如何以最高水平完成工作来激励和鼓舞他们。你必须关心员工，并帮助他们彼此关心，关心团队的目标。而且，你永远不能对自己基于正直、智慧和团队至上的态度所做的决定产生怀疑。

Sweat the Right Small Stuff: Sharp Pencils Do Not Translate into Sharp Performance 注重细节：削尖的铅笔并不等同于出色的表现
Coach George Allen was a demon on details. As head coach of the Washington Redskins, he was preparing to face the Miami Dolphins in Super Bowl VII at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. A few days before the game, he sent a staff member out to the Coliseum for an entire afternoon to chart the movement of the sun during the hours when the game would be played. George wanted to know exactly where it would be so he could calculate the “sun advantage” if the Redskins won the coin toss. This is an example of sweating the right small stuff.
乔治·艾伦教练对细节极其讲究。作为华盛顿红皮队的主教练，他正准备在洛杉矶纪念体育馆迎战迈阿密海豚队，争夺第七届超级碗的入场券。比赛前几天，他派了一名工作人员到体育馆待了一整个下午，记录比赛期间太阳的运行轨迹。乔治想确切地知道太阳的位置，以便在红皮队赢得掷硬币后计算出“太阳优势”。这正是精益求精、一丝不苟的典型例子。
Later, in a turbulent and brief tenure as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams, George supposedly took time off from his coaching responsibilities to design a more efficient system of serving food, a way of reducing the amount of time players spent in the lunch line. He took time out of his jam-packed schedule to personally draw up a schematic for those players wanting soup with their meals: One line was designated for those wanting crackers with their soup; the other for those who didn’t want any crackers. This is an example of sweating the wrong small stuff. Owner Carroll Rosenbloom fired him before the regular season even began. (I should note that while George wasn’t fired for designing a “crackerless” line, it may have been symptomatic of what he was doing—sweating the wrong details.)
后来，在乔治短暂而动荡的洛杉矶公羊队主教练任期内，据说他曾抽出时间，放下教练工作，设计一套更高效的供餐系统，以减少球员在午餐排队的时间。他甚至从自己繁忙的日程中抽出时间，亲自绘制了一张示意图，专门针对那些想在餐点中搭配汤的球员：一条队伍供那些想在汤里加饼干的球员使用；另一条队伍则供那些不需要饼干的球员使用。这正是典型的斤斤计较。老板卡罗尔·罗森布鲁姆在常规赛开始前就解雇了他。（需要指出的是，虽然乔治并非因为设计了“不加饼干”的队伍而被解雇，但这或许正是他问题的症结所在——斤斤计较于无关紧要的细节。）
While it is critically important to concentrate on the smallest relevant aspects of your job without losing sight of the big picture, it is easy to become so completely overwhelmed by ongoing setbacks that you start focusing on issues completely extraneous to improvement in an attempt to keep from having to look at intractable problems.
虽然专注于工作中最小的相关方面而不忽略大局至关重要，但很容易被持续不断的挫折彻底压垮，以至于开始关注与改进完全无关的问题，试图避免面对棘手的问题。
Seeing it in others, I watched for it in my own behavior—as you should in yours—knowing that it would significantly reduce my ability to be effective, that it was dodge, a way of diverting my attention. A coach who becomes afflicted with the malady of “trivialities” might suddenly and compulsively worry about whether all of the practice uniforms have been laundered correctly (“Can’t you get all of those grass stains out?”); obsess over luncheons with local fan clubs; and take inordinate pride in various award ceremonies or alumni gatherings.
看到别人有这种倾向，我便开始留意自己的行为——你也应该如此——因为我知道这会大大降低我的工作效率，这是一种逃避，一种转移注意力的方式。一个教练如果患上了“琐事癖”，可能会突然变得异常在意训练服是否都洗干净了（“难道就洗不掉那些草渍吗？”）；对与当地球迷俱乐部的午餐聚会格外执着；并且对各种颁奖典礼或校友聚会过度自豪。
All of this is an escape mechanism—a method of distracting yourself from the tough work ahead. George Allen isn’t the only NFL coach who became immersed in the meaningless at the expense of the meaningful. A Seattle head coach once diverted himself from the hardships of fixing a dismal team and organization by focusing more on how the Seahawks performed during the national anthem than on how they performed during a game. Valuable practice time was actually spent rehearsing the national anthem “formation”—lining players up by height and number in a perfectly straight row, feet together, helmets held in the left hand by the face guard, no gum chewing, no movement, shirttails tucked in, and actually singing the words. This was going on at a time when the team was in the tank.
这一切都是一种逃避机制——一种让自己分心，逃避未来艰巨任务的方法。乔治·艾伦并非唯一一位沉迷于无关紧要之事而忽略真正重要之事的NFL教练。西雅图海鹰队的一位主教练就曾为了逃避重振球队和俱乐部的困境，将注意力更多地放在海鹰队奏国歌时的表现上，而不是他们在比赛中的表现。宝贵的训练时间竟然被用来排练奏国歌时的“队形”——球员们按身高和号码排成一排笔直的队伍，双脚并拢，左手握住头盔的面罩，不嚼口香糖，一动不动，衬衫下摆塞进裤子里，并且认真地唱着歌词。而这一切，都发生在球队正处于低谷的时候。
Of course, it’s an easy trap to fall into, because the trivialities I noted are typical of what a desperate leader can grab onto and control when everything seems out of control. It creates a false and fatal sense of accomplishment, a trap with serious consequences because it keeps you from addressing the key thoughts and solutions, the tough decisions that are at the core of accomplishing a very difficult task; that is, the task of turning things around.
当然，这很容易让人落入陷阱，因为我提到的这些琐事，正是走投无路的领导者在一切似乎失控时会抓住并控制的典型例子。它会制造一种虚假而致命的成就感，这是一个后果严重的陷阱，因为它会让你无法思考关键问题和解决方案，无法做出那些构成完成一项极其艰巨任务——扭转局面——核心的艰难抉择。
As a leader, when you find yourself with a host of problems that seemingly defy solution and start dwelling on the least relevant or even irrelevant aspects of your job—constantly sitting on the phone with nonessential conversations, doing endless e-mailing, writing memo after memo, fiddling around getting all your pencils sharpened and lined up perfectly, being excessively concerned about hurting feelings and trying to make sure everyone is comfortable, straightening out your desk drawer, getting wrapped up in the details of the annual Christmas party, and a million other kinds of stupid busywork, tell yourself this: “There’ll be plenty of time for pencils, parties, and socializing when I lose my job, because that’s what’s going to happen if I continue to avoid the hard and harsh realities of doing my job.”
作为领导者，当你发现自己面临一系列看似无法解决的问题，并开始纠结于工作中那些最不相关甚至无关紧要的方面——比如不停地打电话进行无关紧要的谈话、没完没了地发邮件、写一份又一份的备忘录、摆弄铅笔，确保铅笔都削得整整齐齐、过度在意别人的感受，努力让每个人都感到舒适、整理办公桌抽屉、沉迷于年度圣诞派对的细节，以及其他数不胜数的琐碎杂事时，不妨这样告诉自己：“等我丢了工作，有的是时间去折腾铅笔、参加派对、社交，因为如果我继续逃避工作中那些艰难残酷的现实，丢掉工作终究是必然的。”
And that’s exactly what happened to the coach of the Seattle Seahawks. Just like George Allen, he was fired, in spite of the fact that his team could sing the national anthem better than any other outfit in the NFL.
西雅图海鹰队的教练就遭遇了这样的情况。就像乔治·艾伦一样，他被解雇了，尽管他的球队唱国歌比NFL其他任何球队都唱得好。
Sharpening pencils in lieu of sharpening your organization’s performance is one way to lose your job. Here are ten additional nails you can pound into your professional coffin:
1. Exhibit patience, paralyzing patience.
2. Engage in delegating—massive delegating—or conversely, engage in too little delegating.
3. Act in a tedious, overly cautious manner.
4. Become best buddies with certain employees.
5. Spend excessive amounts of time socializing with superiors or subordinates.
6. Fail to continue hard-nosed performance evaluations of longtime—“tenured”—staff members, the ones most likely to go on cruise control, to relax.
7. Fail to actively participate in efforts to appraise and acquire new hires.
8. Trust others to carry out your fundamental duties.
9. Find ways to get out from under the responsibilities of your position, to move accountability from yourself to others—the blame game.
10. Promote an organizational environment that is comfortable and laid-back in the misbelief that the workplace should be fun, lighthearted, and free from appropriate levels of tension and urgency.
与其费尽心思提升组织绩效，不如专注于自身事务，否则很容易丢掉工作。以下十条建议或许能助你早日走下职业宝座：1. 过度耐心，甚至到了令人麻木的地步。2. 过度授权——要么过度授权，要么授权不足。3. 行事作风沉闷，过于谨慎。4. 与某些员工过于亲密。5. 花太多时间与上级或下级社交。6. 未能坚持对长期员工（即“资深员工”）进行严格的绩效评估，因为他们最容易放松懈怠。7. 未能积极参与新员工的评估和招聘工作。8. 信任他人，让他们承担你的基本职责。9. 想方设法逃避自身职责，将责任推卸给他人——玩弄甩锅游戏。10.营造一种舒适轻松的组织环境，错误地认为工作场所应该充满乐趣、轻松愉快，并且没有适当的紧张和紧迫感。
For leaders in all professions, including coaches in the NFL, looking for relief from the high anxieties, deep frustrations, and toxic emotions that go with the job can lead you to do everything but your job—worrying about issues of lesser and lesser relevance with greater and greater consequences.
对于各行各业的领导者，包括 NFL 的教练，如果想要摆脱工作带来的高度焦虑、深深的挫败感和有害情绪，就可能导致他们去做所有与工作无关的事情——担心一些越来越无关紧要、但后果却越来越严重的问题。
The tangential aspects of your job become attractive because they’re monumentally easier to control than what you’re there to do; specifically, to create high performance; this is the toughest part to live with, concentrate on, and control. You use the peripheral stuff as an escape mechanism, rather than tackling what may appear, and indeed may be, unsolvable problems until finally you’re done, finished, sitting there with nothing to show for your leadership efforts but a cup of sharp pencils.
工作中那些无关紧要的琐事之所以显得诱人，是因为它们比你真正应该做的——创造卓越绩效——要容易掌控得多。而创造卓越绩效才是最难应对、最难集中精力、最难掌控的部分。你把这些琐事当作逃避现实的手段，而不是去解决那些看似无解、实际上也可能确实无解的问题。直到最后，你筋疲力尽，坐在那里，除了几支削好的铅笔，什么也没留下，你的领导努力也付之东流。

Good Leadership Percolates Down 优秀的领导力自下而上地发挥作用。
The trademark of a well-led organization in sports or business is that it’s virtually self-sustaining and self-directed—almost autonomous. To put it in a more personal way, if your staff doesn’t seem fully mobilized and energized until you enter the room, if they require your presence to carry on at the level of effort and excellence you have tried to install, your leadership has not percolated down.
在体育或商业领域，一个管理良好的组织的标志是它几乎能够自我维持和自我管理——近乎自主。更具体地说，如果你的员工只有在你走进房间后才显得精神抖擞、充满活力，如果他们需要你的存在才能继续保持你所设定的努力和卓越水平，那么你的领导力还没有真正渗透到每个成员心中。
Ideally, you want your Standard of Performance, your philosophy and methodology, to be so strong and solidly ingrained that in your absence the team performs as if you were present, on site. They’ve become so proficient, highly mobilized, and well prepared that in a sense you’re extraneous; everything you’ve preached and personified has been integrated and absorbed; roles have been established and people are able to function at a high level because they understand and believe in what you’ve taught them, that is, the most effective and productive way of doing things accompanied by the most productive attitude while doing them. Fundamentally sound actions and attitudes are the keys.
理想情况下，你希望你的绩效标准、理念和方法论能够强大而根深蒂固，即使你不在场，团队也能像你在现场一样高效运作。他们已经变得如此精通、高度调动、准备充分，以至于从某种意义上说，你反而显得多余；你所宣扬和践行的一切都已被他们吸收和内化；角色分工明确，团队成员能够高效工作，因为他们理解并相信你所传授的一切，也就是最有效、最高效的方式，以及在工作中保持积极的态度。从根本上来说，正确的行动和态度才是关键。
Consequently, I was very pleased when I began overhearing 49er coaches repeating my ideas to one another and subsequently to our players. Later, when I heard the players using my terms or phrases—my personal dialogue or choice of words that represented concepts and ideas—I knew that I’d made a connection, that my leadership had percolated down. (Of course, seeing it produce an improving won-lost record was better evidence.)
因此，当我开始无意中听到49人队的教练们互相交流，并随后向球员们重复我的想法时，我非常高兴。后来，当我听到球员们使用我的术语或短语——我个人用来表达概念和想法的对话或用词——我知道我与他们建立了联系，我的领导力已经渗透到他们心中。（当然，看到球队胜负记录的提升才是更有力的证据。）
This is extremely important because an organization is crippled if it needs to ask the leader what to do every time a question arises. I didn’t want an organizational psyche of leadership dependency, of being semi-dysfunctional without me around making every decision. Here are specific examples in which my leadership philosophy percolated down.
这一点至关重要，因为如果组织每次遇到问题都需要向领导请教，那么它就会运转不畅。我不想让组织形成一种对领导的依赖心态，不想让组织在没有我的情况下就无法正常运作。以下是一些具体的例子，它们体现了我的领导理念。
My battle cry was “Beat ’em to the punch!” which I repeated over and over to coaches and players through the years. It meant, “Hurt your opponents before they hurt you. Strike first.” It was like a mantra of competition for me. Soon I was hearing it repeated by others. I saw it on the field as the 49ers became known for establishing an early lead, which, of course, changed the dynamics of a game in our favor.
我的战斗口号是“先发制人！”多年来，我一遍又一遍地对教练和球员们重复这句话。它的意思是“在对手伤害你之前先下手为强，先发制人。”这就像我的比赛信条。很快，我听到其他人也这么说。我在球场上亲眼见证了这一点，49人队以早早取得领先而闻名，这当然改变了比赛的走向，使我们占据了优势。
Another was “Commit, explode, recover (if you’re wrong)!” which was shorthand for having a plan of attack, executing it suddenly and powerfully, and then reacting quickly and intelligently to the results of what you’ve done. It was a way of thinking and performing, a philosophy— my philosophy, my approach to competing. It, too, was soon part of our organization’s vernacular and attitude.
另一个口号是“全力以赴，全力爆发，即使犯错也要迅速恢复！”，这其实就是制定行动计划，迅速有力地执行，然后根据行动结果快速而明智地做出反应。这是一种思维方式和行动方法，一种理念——我的理念，我的竞争方式。很快，它也融入了我们组织的语言和态度之中。
“Four-minute offense” meant we were ahead late in the game and wanted to take time off the clock, avoid penalties, not go out of bounds, control the ball, and more. When that situation arose, I didn’t have to say anything. Players would be shouting it to each other: “Four-minute offense! Four-minute offense!” It was satisfying to hear because it meant they had come to understand and embrace what I was teaching.
“四分钟进攻”指的是比赛临近尾声，我们领先，想要消耗时间，避免犯规，不出界，控制球权等等。当这种情况发生时，我无需多言，队员们就会互相喊道：“四分钟进攻！四分钟进攻！”听到他们喊叫，我感到很欣慰，因为这意味着他们已经理解并接受了我所教授的战术。
I instructed our maintenance crew to put up a white five-foot-square grease board with “I WILL NOT BE OUTHIT ANY TIME THIS SEASON!” printed in bold letters across the top. I got out my Magic Marker and signed it—“Bill Walsh.” Then everybody on the team signed it. It was a frame of mind, an attitude that I sought to instill.
我指示后勤人员挂上一块五英尺见方的白色油纸板，上面用粗体字印着“本赛季我绝不会被任何一次击倒！”。我拿出记号笔，在上面签了名——“比尔·沃尔什”。然后全队都签了名。这是一种心态，一种我想要灌输给队员们的态度。
“I will not be outhit any time this season!” was about the physical aspect of the profession, but also about the mental and emotional—a state of mind. And everybody on the team literally signed up for it—a contract. This, too, was soon in the air, repeated, absorbed, part of our DNA.
“这个赛季我绝不会输给任何人！”这不仅关乎这项职业的体能层面，更关乎心理和情感层面——一种精神状态。队里的每个人都真切地认同了这一点——这就像签了合同一样。很快，这句话就传遍了全队，被反复提及，被人们吸收，最终融入了我们的血液。
My leadership had percolated down and had begun taking on a life of its own. It went beyond my phrases, of course, and included everything from offensive and defensive schemes to the precision and professionalism applied to all matters in training camp and the regular season. And much more.
我的领导力已经渗透到各个层面，并开始逐渐形成一种独立的生命力。当然，它不仅仅体现在我的言辞中，还涵盖了从进攻和防守策略到训练营和常规赛中所有事务的精准性和专业性等方方面面。远不止于此。
Ultimately, you hope your ideas and way of doing things become so strongly entrenched that the organization performs as effectively without you as with you. That’s the goal and, in fact, it happened to me.
最终，你希望你的理念和做事方式能够根深蒂固，以至于无论有没有你，组织都能高效运转。这就是目标，事实上，我就做到了。
When I retired as head coach of the 49ers following our victory in Super Bowl XXIII, the organization moved forward without a hitch and continued its dominance for years. Why? In part because my leadership philosophy had become ingrained within the San Francisco 49ers.
当我带领旧金山49人队赢得第二十三届超级碗冠军后，我从主教练的岗位上退休，球队并没有因此停滞不前，而是继续保持了多年的统治地位。为什么？部分原因是我的领导理念已经深深融入了旧金山49人队。
It takes nothing away from my successor George Seifert’s coaching nor the great abilities of his coaching staff to suggest that my Standard of Performance had become so ingrained with the 49ers during my decade of teaching that when I retired they were able to practice, prepare, and perform at the same level of excellence—higher, in fact—as during my final season.
指出我的继任者乔治·塞弗特的执教水平以及他的教练团队的卓越能力，丝毫不会贬低他。事实上，在我执教的十年间，我的执教标准已经深深融入了49人队的体系，以至于当我退休时，他们能够以与我执教的最后一个赛季相同的卓越水平——甚至更高——进行训练、准备和比赛。
This is a reliable indication of an effective leader, namely, one who creates a self-sustaining organization able to operate at the highest levels even when he or she leaves.
这是衡量一位领导者是否高效的可靠指标，即能够创建一个自我维持的组织，即使他或她离开，该组织也能在最高水平上运作。
The responsible leader of any company or corporation aggressively seeks to ensure its continued prosperity. It’s the mark of a forward-thinking leadership. A strong company that goes south after the CEO retires is a company whose recently departed CEO didn’t finish the job. If everything goes great when you’re around but slows or stops in its tracks when you’re not there, you are not fulfilling your responsibilities. Your leadership has not percolated down.
任何公司或企业的负责任的领导者都会积极寻求确保其持续繁荣发展。这是具有前瞻性领导力的标志。一家曾经强大的公司，如果在首席执行官退休后走向衰落，那说明这家公司离任的首席执行官并没有完成其未竟的事业。如果你在任时一切顺利，而你离开后却步履蹒跚甚至停滞不前，那么你就没有尽到自己的职责。你的领导力没有真正贯彻到基层。

Nameless, Faceless Objects 无名无面物体
Demonizing the competition is a common but contrived method for stirring up emotions. We see it used in sports (most frequently), business, or war to motivate people, to light a fire under them. Coaches will attempt to incite players by reminding them that the upcoming opponent “wants to embarrass us on Monday Night Football ; wants to make us look like fools in front of the whole goddamn country!” or “is trying to take away your job so you won’t be able to send your kids to a good school,” or a laundry list of other supposedly incendiary but usually silly declarations. (The “genius” tag the media put on me was used in this way occasionally by coaches to stir up their teams, to demonize me.)
妖魔化竞争对手是一种常见但人为的煽动情绪手段。我们在体育（最常见）、商业或战争中都能看到这种做法，用来激励人们，点燃他们的斗志。教练会试图通过提醒球员即将到来的对手“想在周一晚上的橄榄球赛上让我们丢脸；想让我们在全国人民面前出丑！”或者“想抢走你的工作，让你没法送孩子上好学校”，或者其他一系列看似煽动性但通常很愚蠢的言论来煽动球员。（媒体给我贴上的“天才”标签，有时也被教练用这种方式煽动他们的球队，妖魔化我。）
I generally preferred the opposite approach in characterizing the other team and its players. To me they were objects that were both faceless and nameless: Nameless, Faceless Objects.
在描述对方球队及其球员时，我通常更倾向于采用相反的方法。在我看来，他们是既没有面孔也没有名字的客体：无名无脸的客体。
My logic was that I wanted our focus directed at one thing only: going about our business in an intensely efficient and professional manner—first on the practice field, later on the playing field. I felt that moving attention away from that goal to create artificial and manufactured “demons” was artificial and usually nonproductive, especially when done repeatedly (as is usually the case with those who like the technique).
我的逻辑是，我希望我们只专注于一件事：以极其高效和专业的态度开展工作——先在训练场上，然后在正式比赛中。我认为，将注意力从这个目标转移到人为制造的“恶魔”上是人为的，而且通常毫无益处，尤其是在反复这样做的时候（那些喜欢这种技巧的人通常会这样做）。
Whether it’s sports, sales, management, or almost any other competitive context, consistent motivation usually comes from a consuming desire to be able to perform at your best under pressure, namely, the pressure produced by tough competition. If a player needed me to light a fire under him by turning the other team into a demon, he was lacking something I couldn’t give him. Of course, there are exceptions to every rule.
无论是体育、销售、管理，还是几乎任何其他竞争领域，持续的动力通常源于一种强烈的渴望，即在压力下发挥出最佳水平，尤其是在激烈竞争带来的压力下。如果一个球员需要我通过激怒对手来激发他的斗志，那说明他缺少一些我无法给予他的东西。当然，凡事皆有例外。
On some occasions I would resort to the “demonizing” tactic to spark life into a player or group of players who for unknown reasons were flat. Keep in mind, I used this device intermittently and unpredictably, which is exactly why it worked. When I launched into a demonizing speech, the players didn’t just roll their eyes and think, “Oh, boy, there goes Walsh again, trying to get us fired up.” Here’s an example of the way I would use it, although the circumstances were unique.
有时我会用“妖魔化”战术来激发某个或某些球员的斗志，因为他们不知何故状态低迷。请记住，我使用这招是断断续续、出其不意的，而这正是它奏效的原因。当我开始“妖魔化”演讲时，球员们不会只是翻白眼，心想：“哎呀，沃尔什又来了，想让我们兴奋起来。”下面是我使用这招的一个例子，虽然当时的情况比较特殊。
On the bus ride from our hotel to Giants Stadium for a game against the New York Giants, the energy was flat, the players’ voices not just subdued but nearly silent, almost eerily silent. I became increasingly uncomfortable with what I sensed from my seat at the front of the bus. Was it complacency, lack of confidence, or something else? Regardless of the cause, the effect could be a disaster in just a few hours. So I decided it was time to manufacture a demon.
从酒店到巨人体育场观看对阵纽约巨人队的比赛，巴士上的气氛十分沉闷，球员们的声音不仅微弱，几乎听不见，静得可怕。坐在巴士前排，我越来越感到不安。这是自满、缺乏自信，还是别的什么原因？无论原因是什么，几个小时后都可能酿成灾难。于是，我决定制造一个“恶魔”。
Leaning across the aisle, I instructed the bus driver to pull into an empty parking lot just a few miles from Giants Stadium. The lot was in a desolate part of town—a few deserted buildings were nearby, a liquor store was on the corner, trash blew across the blacktop. It was an unusual place to stop.
我探身越过过道，示意巴士司机把车停到离巨人体育场几英里外的一个空停车场。停车场位于城里一个偏僻的地方——附近有几栋废弃的建筑，街角有一家酒铺，垃圾散落在柏油路上。这的确是个不寻常的停车地点。
The bus driver opened the doors in what looked like the middle of nowhere; I stood up and shouted over the heads of players and coaches, “Everybody out! Right now, let’s go. Move it! Move it!”
巴士司机在看似荒无人烟的地方打开了车门；我站起来，越过球员和教练的头顶大喊：“所有人下车！马上出发！快走！快走！”
The team was confused but complied—gathering alongside the bus and studying me as I paced back and forth, fuming, with a rolled-up copy of the New York Post in my hands.
队员们虽然感到困惑，但还是照做了——他们聚集在巴士旁，看着我拿着卷起来的《纽约邮报》来回踱步，怒气冲冲。
I opened the Post and looked down at it with an anguished and disgusted expression on my face. Slowly I started shaking my head back and forth and then looked up at the team and launched into an angry tirade.
我打开报纸，低头看着它，脸上带着痛苦和厌恶的表情。我慢慢地摇了摇头，然后抬起头看向队友，开始愤怒地咆哮起来。
“Have any of you read this?” I asked with disgust. Of course none of the players knew what “this” was so they remained silent or shook their heads. It was like they had been called into the principal’s office for unknown but ominous reasons.
“你们谁看过这个？”我厌恶地问道。当然，球员们都不知道“这个”是什么，所以他们要么沉默不语，要么摇头。就好像他们因为某种不祥的原因被叫到校长办公室一样。
“Goddamn it! I’m sick and tired of what the New York media elite is saying about us!” I yelled, waving the Post in their faces. “The papers, television, fans—everybody out there is trying to make us look like some Brie-eating, wine-sipping pushovers; we’re back to being called a laughingstock!”
“该死的！我受够了纽约媒体精英们对我们的诋毁！”我怒吼着，挥舞着《纽约邮报》。“报纸、电视、粉丝——所有人都想把我们描绘成一群吃着布里奶酪、喝着葡萄酒的软弱可欺之辈；我们又沦为笑柄了！”
I threw down the paper and stormed away.
我扔下报纸，怒气冲冲地走了。
The team was stunned. They simply didn’t know how to respond. Immediately, I returned and continued the diatribe: “They’re ridiculing us and who we are, all that we’ve accomplished, making jokes about us and the big ‘genius’ who coaches you, and I’m sick of it. I can’t take this. I just can’t stand this shit any more!”
队员们都惊呆了，完全不知道该如何回应。我立刻回到队伍里，继续我的长篇大论：“他们嘲笑我们，嘲笑我们是谁，嘲笑我们取得的所有成就，嘲笑我们，嘲笑你们那个所谓的‘天才’教练，我受够了！我忍无可忍了！我再也忍受不了这种狗屁倒灶的事了！”
I walked slowly along the loosely assembled front row of 49ers—studying them like General George Patton inspecting his troops. My anguish burrowed in: “I had to tell you this, fellas; I had to tell you because you’ve got to put a stop to it; you’ve got to help me get control of this thing. A team like ours has so much tradition; it’s absolutely unforgivable that this organization is being mocked! Will you help me? Can you shut ’em up? Can you stop this kind of crap from continuing any longer? Can you stuff it down their goddamn throats?”
我沿着49人队那群松散地聚集在前排的球员缓缓走着，像巴顿将军检阅部队那样仔细打量着他们。我的痛苦涌上心头：“伙计们，我必须告诉你们这些；我必须告诉你们，因为你们必须阻止这一切；你们必须帮我控制局面。像我们这样的球队有着如此深厚的传统；这支球队竟然被人如此嘲弄，简直不可饶恕！你们愿意帮我吗？你们能让他们闭嘴吗？你们能阻止这种狗屁倒灶的事继续下去吗？你们能把这些话硬塞进他们嘴里吗？”
Before I could finish that last sentence, the team roared back their support, shouting some expletives Patton might have smiled at. There was blood in the air. As the players poured back into the bus with a vengeance, I glanced at Bobb McKittrick, one of my assistant coaches, and he gave me a little wink. Bobb knew exactly what I was up to.
我还没说完最后一句话，队员们就爆发出震耳欲聋的欢呼声，夹杂着一些巴顿将军听了可能会会心一笑的脏话。空气中弥漫着怒火。球员们气势汹汹地涌回大巴，我瞥了一眼我的助理教练之一鲍勃·麦基特里克，他朝我眨了眨眼。鲍勃完全明白我的意图。
My show of contrived anger directed toward the New York “demon”—the media, not the New York team itself—was effective only because it was so atypical of my usual cold-blooded perspective on opponents; namely, that they were “Nameless, Faceless Objects,” simply anonymous prey to be dispatched. And the New York Giants were easily dispatched that particular Sunday afternoon.
我刻意表现出的对纽约“恶魔”（指媒体，而非纽约巨人队本身）的愤怒之所以奏效，仅仅是因为这与我平日里对对手冷酷无情的看法截然不同；在平日里，我视他们为“无名无姓的客体”，仅仅是需要消灭的匿名猎物。而那个星期天的下午，纽约巨人队果然被我轻易地消灭了。
Bill Parcells, when he was head coach of the New York Jets, once created a “demon” out of his own team. Disgusted with the effort the Jets were displaying in the final practice before a crucial Monday Night Football appearance with the New England Patriots, Coach Parcells angrily stormed off the field in a rage and took all of his coaches with him.
比尔·帕塞尔斯担任纽约喷气机队主教练时，曾把自己的球队变成了“魔鬼”。在与新英格兰爱国者队进行一场至关重要的周一夜赛前的最后一次训练中，喷气机队的表现令帕塞尔斯教练非常失望，他怒气冲冲地离开了球场，并带走了所有教练。
Veteran Jets players were forced to lead the team through the final hour of practice. Everyone got the message implicit in Parcell’s show of disgust with them. The players picked up the level of performance and intensity which ultimately created a 24-14 victory over the Patriots at Foxboro, Massachusetts
老将们被迫带领喷气机队完成了最后一小时的训练。帕塞尔教练对他们表现出的厌恶之情，让所有人都明白了其中的含义。球员们提升了训练水平和强度，最终在马萨诸塞州福克斯堡以24比14战胜了爱国者队。
Afterward, Parcells said there was no intent on his part to stir up the emotions of his team, no connection between his actions and the outcome of the game, nothing contrived at all. Of course, the ability to say that with a straight face is proof of Bill’s exceptional acting ability.
事后，帕塞尔斯表示，他无意煽动球队情绪，他的行为与比赛结果没有任何关联，一切都是他精心策划的。当然，他能面不改色地说出这样的话，足以证明比尔高超的演技。
Leaders who regularly employ this tactic of demonizing opponents destroy its effectiveness because it’s soon recognized as a ploy to stir up emotions. As soon as that happens, it’s ignored. Nevertheless, it had value in my system because it was used sparingly and performed convincingly.
经常使用妖魔化对手这种策略的领导者会削弱其效果，因为这种做法很快就会被识破，被视为煽动情绪的伎俩。一旦被识破，这种策略就会被弃之不顾。然而，在我的体系中，这种策略仍然有其价值，因为它使用得当，而且效果显著。
I often wonder what would have happened if Bob Costas or some other announcer had happened to drive by just as I was delivering my speech in that desolate Meadowlands parking lot.
我常常想，如果鲍勃·科斯塔斯或其他播音员碰巧开车经过，而我当时正在荒凉的梅多兰兹停车场发表演讲，那会发生什么呢？

The Rules May Change, But the Game Goes On: I Strike Out the First Time, Not the Second 规则或许会变，但游戏仍在继续：我第一次出局，而不是第二次。
A strike in 1987 by the Players Association tested the judgment of everybody in the NFL—owners, players, union officials, management, and, of course, the head coach of each team. This was not the first time I had been called upon to deal with a strike. Earlier, during my disastrous fourth season at San Francisco, the league had faced a players’ strike. In addition to our reeling from the aftereffects of winning our first Super Bowl, the suspension of games that year turned everything on its head and created one of the worst seasons I ever had in football. I simply was unprepared for events.
1987年球员协会的罢工考验了NFL所有人的判断力——老板、球员、工会官员、管理层，当然还有各队的主教练。这并非我第一次遭遇罢工。此前，在我执教旧金山49人队的第四个赛季，联盟就曾面临过球员罢工。除了刚刚赢得首个超级碗的喜悦之外，那年的比赛停摆更是雪上加霜，让我经历了职业生涯中最糟糕的赛季之一。我当时完全没有做好准备。
My own choices through that strike-shortened season had not been good. This time around—’87—I wanted to make decisions that would benefit the organization in what was going to be a tumultuous time. It was particularly challenging because nobody really knew for certain what was going to happen.
在那个因罢工而缩短的赛季里，我自己的选择并不明智。这一次——1987年——我希望做出对球队有利的决定，因为那将是一个动荡的时期。这尤其具有挑战性，因为没有人真正知道未来会发生什么。
Owners had decided to continue playing—no suspension of games or the season—with teams consisting mostly of replacement players. Many in the league assumed that games played during the strike wouldn’t actually count; many considered them virtually exhibition games. I didn’t make that mistake. This time around, I intended to use whatever logic and resources were available so that when the strike ended, the San Francisco 49ers would be standing tall amid whatever wreckage ensued.
老板们决定继续比赛——不暂停比赛，也不取消赛季——但球队主要由替补球员组成。联盟里很多人都认为罢工期间的比赛不算数；许多人甚至把它们看作是表演赛。但我没有犯同样的错误。这一次，我打算运用一切可用的逻辑和资源，确保罢工结束后，旧金山49人队能够在随之而来的混乱局面中屹立不倒。
We all knew going into the season that a strike was imminent. It was only a question of when. Consequently, in training camp we invited a disproportionate number of players to join us, knowing that many of them wouldn’t make the regular “prestrike” team. What we were interested in, however, was scouting individuals as potential replacement players. I also recognized that having them with us in camp would familiarize them with the 49er system in the event that they were called back during the upcoming strike.
赛季开始前我们都知道罢工迫在眉睫，只是时间问题。因此，在训练营期间，我们邀请了数量远超正常水平的球员加入我们，尽管我们也知道他们中的许多人可能无法进入罢工前的常规阵容。然而，我们真正感兴趣的是考察潜在的替代球员。我也意识到，让他们和我们一起参加训练营，可以让他们熟悉49人队的体系，以便在即将到来的罢工期间被召回时能够迅速适应。
By the end of training camp, we had a virtual replacement roster in order. Assistant coaches had spent lots of time with them, teaching them the 49er way of doing things. When the strike was called by the players’ union, we were as ready for it as an organization could be. Most other teams couldn’t make that claim. In fact, in our first “strike” game—the one in which I “demonized” the New York media on the way to Giants Stadium—we faced a New York organization coached by Bill Parcells, who had made assumptions completely the opposite of mine. His organization apparently didn’t believe the strike games would count and didn’t make contingency plans in case the games mattered. It was a big mistake. We won that game—beat the Giants handily on the way to a 13-2 regular season record. (We later lost in the NFC play-offs to the Minnesota Vikings.)
训练营结束时，我们几乎已经组建好了一支完整的替补阵容。助理教练们花了很多时间指导他们，教他们49人队的行事方式。当球员协会发起罢工时，我们已经做好了万全的准备。大多数其他球队都做不到这一点。事实上，在我们的第一场“罢工”比赛中——也就是我在前往巨人体育场的路上“痛斥”纽约媒体的那场比赛——我们面对的是由比尔·帕塞尔斯执教的纽约巨人队，他的想法与我截然相反。他的球队显然认为罢工比赛的成绩无关紧要，也没有制定任何应急预案。这是一个巨大的错误。我们赢下了那场比赛——轻松击败巨人队，最终取得了13胜2负的常规赛战绩。（后来我们在NFC季后赛中输给了明尼苏达维京人队。）
The lesson I had learned in fumbling through the earlier strike was useful this time around; namely, don’t assume because of odd circumstances that everything will somehow sort itself out. Rather, play for keeps all the time. The clock never stops running; there is never a “time-out” when what you do is somehow less meaningful.
上次罢工中我跌跌撞撞摸索出来的教训这次派上了用场：那就是，不要因为一些特殊情况就以为一切都会迎刃而解。相反，要始终全力以赴。时间永不停歇；你所做的一切，永远不会因为某种原因而变得不再那么重要。
Leading into and during the 1987 strike, I made a conscious decision that the NFL season was going to be played in a different and complicated new way—that a new set of rules and assumptions was going to be utilized—and I did my best to figure out those rules and assumptions to the advantage of our organization. The season was extremely trying, but the results were excellent. I had learned my lesson the first time around.
在1987年罢工前夕和罢工期间，我意识到NFL赛季将会以一种截然不同且更为复杂的方式进行——一套全新的规则和假设将被采用——我尽我所能地去理解这些规则和假设，以求为我们球队带来利益。那个赛季极其艰难，但结果却非常出色。我从第一次的失败中吸取了教训。

You Must Have a Hard Edge 你必须有棱角
From a very early stage in my development as a leader, I found myself at odds with the common practice of abusing individuals emotionally, physically, or psychologically. When I came into the NFL as a very low-level assistant with the Oakland Raiders, I was deeply affected in a negative way by how roughly people were treated. Oakland was not the only team with a heavy-handed approach. A boot-camp mentality was the prevailing paradigm for NFL coaches. For reasons I can’t clearly define, it struck me as Neanderthal, clumsy, and a counterproductive way to achieve maximum productivity.
从我领导力发展的早期阶段起，我就对那种在情感、身体或心理上虐待他人的普遍做法深恶痛绝。当我以奥克兰突袭者队基层助理教练的身份进入NFL时，人们粗暴的对待方式深深地影响了我。奥克兰并非唯一一支采取这种强硬手段的球队。“新兵训练营”式的管理模式在NFL教练中盛行。出于我无法确切描述的原因，这种做法在我看来原始、笨拙，而且根本无法达到最高的效率。
Having said that, I also recognized that a leader needs a very hard edge inside; it has to lurk in there somewhere and come out on occasion. You must be able to make and carry out harsh and, at times, ruthless decisions in a manner that is fast , firm , and fair . Applied correctly, this hard edge will not only solve the immediate difficulty, but also prevent future problems by sending out this important message: Cross my line and you can expect severe consequences. This will have ongoing benefits for your organization.
话虽如此，我也意识到领导者内心必须具备非常强硬的一面；这种强硬必须潜藏在某个地方，并在必要时爆发出来。你必须能够快速、坚定、公平地做出并执行严厉甚至有时是残酷的决定。如果运用得当，这种强硬不仅能解决眼前的难题，还能通过传递这样一个重要信息来预防未来的问题：胆敢越过我的底线，必将承担严重的后果。这将对你的组织产生持续的益处。
In my second year as 49er head coach, I was presented with a difficult situation that required action but could easily have been put off because of the situation. One of our top players, left tackle Ron Singleton, had decided during the off-season that he deserved not only more publicity and attention, but also much more money—almost twice as much as he was being paid on his contract. He had a good point: At 6 feet 6 inches and 287 pounds, he was responsible for protecting the blind side—the back—of our right-handed quarterbacks—Steve DeBerg and Joe Montana. It was a crucial position, and Ron was doing a good job. And he knew it.
在我担任49人队主教练的第二年，我遇到了一个棘手的问题，需要采取行动，但当时的情况很容易让我拖延。我们的一名顶级球员，左截锋罗恩·辛格尔顿，在休赛期决定，他不仅应该获得更多的曝光度和关注度，还应该得到更高的薪水——几乎是他合同薪水的两倍。他的想法不无道理：身高6英尺6英寸，体重287磅的他，肩负着保护我们右手四分卫史蒂夫·德伯格和乔·蒙塔纳的盲侧——也就是后侧——的重任。这是一个至关重要的位置，而罗恩做得非常出色。他也深知这一点。
To further his cause, Singleton hired an agent, somewhat unusual at the time but fine with me, and began trying to renegotiate his contract with the team.
为了推进自己的计划，辛格尔顿聘请了一位经纪人，这在当时有点不寻常，但我并不介意，并开始尝试与球队重新谈判合同。
I felt that his demands were out of line with the relatively frugal salary schedule of our team (the lowest in the NFL) but nevertheless found myself in a tough situation, because he was an outstanding member of an offensive line that was exhibiting real potential.
我觉得他的要求与我们球队相对节俭的薪资标准（NFL 最低）不符，但我仍然陷入了困境，因为他是进攻锋线上的一名杰出成员，而这条锋线展现出了真正的潜力。
However, the problem wasn’t the attempt to increase his income. The fatal flaw in behavior was the unfortunate tendency he and his agent had of playing the race card. They argued that racism was built into the 49er organization, that we were unwilling to negotiate seriously and give him more money because he was an African American. This was absolutely false. Everyone was treated the same, especially when it came to money; specifically, nobody got paid very much, including me (my first-year salary as head coach and general manager in the National Football League was $160,000, probably the lowest in the league—and I had to fight for that).
然而，问题不在于他试图增加收入。致命的缺陷在于他和他的经纪人不幸地倾向于打种族牌。他们声称49人队内部存在根深蒂固的种族歧视，我们不愿意认真谈判，不愿意给他更高的薪水，仅仅因为他是非裔美国人。这完全是无稽之谈。每个人都受到同样的对待，尤其是在薪酬方面；具体来说，包括我在内，没有人拿很高的薪水（我担任国家橄榄球联盟主教练兼总经理的第一年薪水是16万美元，可能是联盟中最低的——而且我还是争取来的）。
Additionally, Ron was verbally abusive to certain staff members, a very serious breach of my Standard of Performance, which demanded respectful behavior toward all others on the 49er payroll.
此外，罗恩还对某些员工进行言语辱骂，这严重违反了我的绩效标准，该标准要求对49人队所有员工都保持尊重的态度。
Things came to a head after an unproductive contract session, when Ron left my office and proceeded to walk through our locker room making disparaging remarks about me and the 49ers, throwing in several racially charged comments for good measure, right in front of our equipment manager, Chico Norton, to whom he also made dismissive remarks. A few minutes later, news of what was going on filtered back to my office.
在一次毫无成效的合同谈判后，事情彻底爆发了。罗恩离开我的办公室，径直走进更衣室，对我以及旧金山49人队出言不逊，还夹杂着几句带有种族歧视色彩的言论，而这一切都发生在我们的装备经理奇科·诺顿面前，他对诺顿也冷嘲热讽。几分钟后，事情的经过传回了我的办公室。
Immediately, I called in R. C. Owens, a former 49er player and cocre ator of the “alley-oop pass,” who worked in public relations for us, and asked him to go to Mr. Singleton’s locker and clear it out: “Shoes, shirts, socks, everything. Put it all in a box and deliver it to his house.” In less than an hour, R.C. had placed the cardboard box and its contents on the front steps of now ex-49er Ron Singleton.
我立刻打电话给R·C·欧文斯，他曾是49人队的球员，也是“空中接力传球”的共同发明者，当时在我们公司负责公关工作。我让他去辛格尔顿先生的更衣柜里把东西都清空：“鞋子、衬衫、袜子，所有东西。把它们都装进一个箱子里，送到他家。”不到一个小时，R·C就把纸箱和里面的东西放在了前49人队球员罗恩·辛格尔顿家门口的台阶上。
Word of my decision circulated fast. Everybody knew what had happened and why. It sent out a vitally important message: There are consequences—at times harsh consequences—for ignoring the spoken and unspoken code of conduct that was part of the standards I had established. Ron Singleton was not exempt from my code of behavior just because he was an important component of our future. People got the message: If a top player such as Ron Singleton could be fired for breaking some fundamentally important element of my Standard of Performance, so could anyone.
我的决定很快传开。每个人都知道发生了什么以及原因。这传递了一个至关重要的信息：无视我制定的明文或不成文的行为准则（这些准则构成了球队标准的一部分）是要付出代价的——有时甚至是严厉的代价。罗恩·辛格尔顿虽然是我们未来计划的重要组成部分，但他也不能因此而免受我的行为准则的约束。人们明白了：如果像罗恩·辛格尔顿这样的顶级球员都会因为违反我绩效标准中某些至关重要的要素而被解雇，那么任何人都可能面临同样的后果。
The “cardboard box” incident became a focal point, a reminder throughout the 49er organization of the hard edge, the severe action I was willing to take if circumstances dictated, if I was pushed too far. It served me well over the years.
“纸箱事件”成了焦点，它时刻提醒着49人队上下，我的强硬作风，以及在形势需要、被逼到绝境时，我愿意采取的严厉措施。多年来，这让我受益匪浅。
From time to time, leaders must show this hard edge. They must make those around them somewhat uneasy, even ill at ease, in not knowing what to expect from you, the leader. The knowledge that there is this hardness inside you can have a very sobering effect on those who might otherwise be sloppy—those who occasionally need to be reminded of your policies and practices.
领导者有时必须展现出强硬的一面。他们必须让周围的人感到不安，甚至焦虑，因为不知道该如何期待领导者的下一步行动。这种强硬的一面能够起到警醒作用，让那些平时可能比较马虎的人——那些偶尔需要被提醒领导者政策和做法的人——保持清醒的头脑。
Members of your organization should be empowered by the expertise and motivation you offer—the Standard of Performance you have defined—but also by their very clear understanding of the consequences of taking you too far.
组织成员应该能够从你提供的专业知识和动力（即你所定义的绩效标准）中获得力量，但同时也应该非常清楚地了解，如果过度依赖你，将会带来怎样的后果。
There’s a positive aesthetic to my persona; it’s an image that can be misleading because it suggests a professorial—soft—attitude; a reluctance to bring down the hammer. But inside I have a hard edge, a willingness to mete out punishment and take action that may hurt individuals. It doesn’t reveal itself often, but it’s there. And those within our organization learned to respect it. You will benefit if that same understanding exists within your team.
我的形象给人一种积极正面的感觉；这种形象可能会误导人，因为它给人一种温和、谦逊的印象，仿佛不愿轻易采取严厉的措施。但我的内心却很坚韧，我愿意惩罚他人，采取可能伤害到他人的行动。这种坚韧并不常显露，但它确实存在。我们组织里的人都学会了尊重这一点。如果你的团队也能做到这一点，你将会受益匪浅。

The Inner Voice vs. the Outer Voice 内心的声音与外在的声音
Leadership is expertise. It is not rhetoric or cheerleading speeches. People will follow a person who organizes and manages others, because he or she has credibility and expertise—a knowledge of the profession—and demonstrates an understanding of human nature.
领导力是专业技能，而不是花言巧语或鼓舞人心的演讲。人们会追随那些能够组织和管理他人的人，因为他或她拥有信誉和专业技能——对本行业的了解——并且展现出对人性的理解。
With rare exceptions, San Francisco 49er football players did not attain some new level of performance because of my pregame or halftime talks (although I felt pleased with myself and it satisfied me to give those inspirational speeches, especially if someone said afterward, “Great job, Bill.”).
除了极少数例外，旧金山 49 人橄榄球队员并没有因为我的赛前或中场讲话而达到新的竞技水平（尽管我对自己感到满意，发表这些鼓舞人心的演讲也让我感到满足，尤其是当有人事后说“干得好，比尔”时）。
After years of coaching, I knew that by the time our players went through the tunnel and under the goalposts onto the field, my inspirational words were history—forgotten.
经过多年的执教，我知道当我们的队员们穿过球员通道，越过球门柱进入球场时，我那些激励人心的话语就成了历史——被遗忘了。
On the field, the 49ers depended totally on the regimen and skills they had learned. My teaching and the great teaching of the 49er assistant coaches was the decisive factor in competition, not halftime speeches or homilies delivered standing on a chair in the locker room.
在球场上，49人队完全依赖于他们所习得的训练方法和技能。我的指导以及49人队助理教练们的出色指导才是比赛的决定性因素，而不是中场休息时的演讲或站在更衣室椅子上发表的说教。
Furthermore, once the game started, the players responded to me not on the basis of my sideline shouting (seldom done), but because I could function under stress. I was clearheaded and made sound decisions. They saw it and knew it and responded like professionals.
此外，比赛开始后，球员们对我的回应并非源于我在场边的呐喊（这种情况很少发生），而是因为我能在压力下保持冷静。我头脑清晰，决策果断。他们看到了这一点，也明白这一点，并像职业球员一样做出了回应。
The same is true elsewhere. Whatever great excitement you may stir up in your employees with a rousing speech about a big quarter or blowing away a sales quota starts to evaporate the minute they exit the conference room.
其他地方的情况也一样。无论你用一番慷慨激昂的演讲，比如吹嘘季度业绩大增或超额完成销售目标，激起员工们多么大的热情，这种热情都会在他们离开会议室的那一刻开始消散。
The true inspiration, expertise, and ability to execute that employees take with them into their work is most often the result of their inner voice talking, not some outer voice shouting, and not some leader giving a pep talk.
员工带入工作的真正灵感、专业知识和执行能力，往往源于他们内心的声音，而不是外界的叫喊，也不是领导的激励讲话。
For members of your team, you determine what their inner voice says. The leader, at least a good one, teaches the team how to talk to themselves. An effective leader has a profound influence on what that inner voice will say.
对于团队成员而言，你的决定在于他们内心的声音。优秀的领导者会引导团队成员如何与自己对话。一位高效的领导者对团队成员的内心声音有着深远的影响。
The great leaders in sports, business, and life always have the most powerful and positive inner voice talking to them, which they, in turn, share with and teach to their organization. The specifics of that inner voice varies from leader to leader, but I believe all have these four messages in common:
1. We can win if we work smart enough and hard enough.
2. We can win if we put the good of the group ahead of our own personal interests.
3. We can win if we improve. And there is always room for improvement.
4. I know what is required for us to win. I will show you what it is.
体育、商业和生活中的伟大领袖，内心总有一个强大而积极的声音在与他们对话，而他们也会将这种声音分享并传授给他们的组织。这种内心的声音因人而异，但我相信他们都传递着以下四个共同的信息：1. 只要我们足够聪明、足够努力，就能赢得胜利。2. 只要我们把集体的利益置于个人利益之上，就能赢得胜利。3. 只要我们不断进步，就能赢得胜利。而且，进步永无止境。4. 我知道我们赢得胜利需要什么。我会向你们展示那是什么。

Montana’s Leadership by Example: Cool, Calm, and Collected 蒙大拿州的领导力以身作则：冷静沉着
Quarterback Joe Montana’s historic career included four Super Bowl championships (three Super Bowl MVP awards) and was due in large part to the fact that in addition to having talent he was a natural-born leader. The manner in which he accomplished all of this is worthy of examination as it offers invaluable insights on the essence of leadership.
四分卫乔·蒙塔纳的职业生涯堪称传奇，他带领球队四次夺得超级碗冠军（三次荣膺超级碗MVP），这很大程度上归功于他不仅天赋异禀，更是一位天生的领袖。他取得这一切成就的方式值得我们深入研究，因为它为我们理解领导力的本质提供了宝贵的启示。
At first I was puzzled by Montana’s effectiveness as a leader, because he didn’t have the swagger of a Joe Namath or the rough-and-tough attitude of a Dan Marino. He didn’t stand out as what sociologists call the alpha male—a man whose aggressive competitive instincts are readily apparent, like his great teammate in later years, Steve Young.
起初，我对蒙塔纳的领导才能感到困惑，因为他既没有乔·纳马斯那样的傲慢，也没有丹·马里诺那样的强硬作风。他不像社会学家所说的“阿尔法男”那样，拥有显而易见的攻击性和竞争本能，就像他后来的伟大队友史蒂夫·杨那样。
If you watched Joe Montana interact with a group of athletes, he wasn’t the guy you’d pick out as “the Man” around whom everything focused and everyone congregated. He didn’t appear to need attention or acclaim and was good at sharing credit. Others sought and fed off attention, but not Joe. This is a little unusual among superstars in sports (or business).
如果你观察乔·蒙塔纳与一群运动员的互动，你会发现他并非那种万众瞩目的“中心人物”。他似乎并不需要关注或赞誉，而且很擅长与人分享荣誉。其他人追求并利用关注，但乔却并非如此。这在体育界（或商界）的超级巨星中并不常见。
Nevertheless, this superb player (by way of Pennsylvania’s Ringgold High School and the University of Notre Dame), a guy who never saw a professional football game in person until he played in one, was a leader of the highest caliber who led with one fundamental and powerful leadership technique: his own example.
然而，这位杰出的球员（毕业于宾夕法尼亚州林戈尔德高中和圣母大学），在自己参加职业橄榄球比赛之前从未亲眼看过一场职业橄榄球比赛，是一位最高水平的领导者，他运用了一种基本而强大的领导技巧：以身作则。
There were several reasons for his effectiveness that became apparent as I watched him over the early years. Of course, Joe had the talent, but talent alone won’t make you a leader (as we see each year with various NFL teams and assorted CEOs).
