He had courage, but the ability to risk physical injury from human wrecking machines like the New York Giants’ great cornerback Lawrence Taylor did not in itself instill loyalty in his teammates.
在早期的观察中，我逐渐发现他之所以如此高效，有几个原因。当然，乔天赋异禀，但光有天赋并不足以成为一名领导者（这一点我们每年都能在不同的NFL球队和形形色色的CEO身上看到）。他有勇气，但即便他敢于冒着被像纽约巨人队传奇角卫劳伦斯·泰勒这样的“人形破坏机器”撞伤的风险，也并不能凭此赢得队友的忠诚。
Beyond his rare talent, there was something else working for Joe that had a profound effect on others and created a willingness to accept him as the on-field leader—the kind of leader you would put your faith in and follow into battle. And it was something that is especially applicable in a corporate setting.
除了他罕见的天赋之外，乔身上还有一种特质深深地影响着他人，使他成为场上领袖——那种值得信赖、愿意追随他上战场的领袖。而这种特质在企业环境中也同样适用。
Joe Montana’s leadership was grounded in this key characteristic: Despite the fact that he was the starting quarterback, with all of the trappings that come with that position, he never played favorites or believed that a person’s reputation, status, or credentials entitled him to special treatment. When you worked with Joe, you were treated as an equal. There were no stars in the Montana system, including Joe Montana. That corny old cliché, “One for all and all for one,” could have been written with him in mind.
乔·蒙塔纳的领导力根植于一个关键特质：尽管他是首发四分卫，拥有这个位置所带来的一切特权，但他从不偏袒任何人，也从不认为一个人的名望、地位或资历就应该让他享有特殊待遇。与乔共事，你就会受到平等的对待。在蒙塔纳的体系中，没有所谓的明星，包括他自己。那句老套的格言“我为人人，人人为我”仿佛就是为他量身打造的。
His leadership skills were demonstrated more by behavior on the field or in the locker room than by what he might say just before or during the game. Joe’s interaction with other players and coaches was democratic, sincere, and understated. He led with his own talent, quiet confidence, and unassuming demeanor.
他的领导才能更多地体现在球场上或更衣室里的行为，而非赛前或赛中所说的话。乔与其他球员和教练的互动平和、真诚且低调。他凭借自身的天赋、沉稳的自信和谦逊的举止引领球队。
Joe never stood up and gave a rah-rah speech to our team at halftime, but as the gravity of a situation increased, so did his own intensity. He could become almost trancelike at times of heightened pressure. This accounted for the amazing thirty-one fourth-quarter comebacks he engineered during his NFL career. Equally impressive—perhaps more so—is the fact that in four Super Bowl games he never threw a single interception.
乔从不在中场休息时站起来给球队做鼓舞士气的演讲，但随着局势的严峻程度，他的专注度也随之提升。在压力巨大的时刻，他几乎会进入一种恍若入神的境界。这解释了他职业生涯中为何能完成31次第四节逆转。同样令人印象深刻——甚至更令人印象深刻——的是，他在四场超级碗比赛中从未被拦截过一次。
Joe didn’t have to talk the talk because he walked the walk. And without really working at it, he found that everyone else was walking the walk right behind him.
乔无需夸夸其谈，因为他言行一致。而且，他毫不费力地发现，其他人也都紧随其后，言行一致。
What he did and the way in which he did it offers a great model that is applicable in any setting. Joe Montana is one of the best examples I have ever seen that proved you don’t need to shout, stomp, or strut to be a great leader—just do the job and treat people right. Isn’t that an essential element in getting people to trust and follow you?
他所做的一切以及他做事的方式，提供了一个适用于任何环境的绝佳范例。乔·蒙塔纳是我见过的最佳例子之一，他证明了成为一名优秀的领导者并不需要大喊大叫、跺脚或趾高气扬——只需要做好本职工作，善待他人。这难道不是赢得他人信任和追随的关键要素吗？
Incredibly, his personality and style didn’t change when Joe began to emerge as maybe the best quarterback in history and the center of attention for every football writer and television reporter in America. He remained conscientious about sharing credit. Consequently, nobody resented, was jealous of, or envied all the adulation and publicity he received.
令人难以置信的是，当乔逐渐崭露头角，成为史上最伟大的四分卫之一，并成为全美所有足球记者和电视记者关注的焦点时，他的个性和风格却丝毫未变。他始终谦逊地与他人分享荣誉。因此，没有人对他所获得的赞誉和关注感到不满、嫉妒或羡慕。
These traits, which I’m sure were instilled by his parents, Theresa and Joe Sr., were a perfect match for the Standard of Performance I had established within the 49er organization. A fundamental component of my system was the recognition that everyone in our organization—regardless of his or her responsibilities, reputation, or paycheck—was a respected member of the group. Others had to be taught this, but Joe understood it before he ever put on a 49er jersey.
我相信这些特质是他的父母特蕾莎和老乔灌输给他的，它们与我在49人队内部建立的绩效标准完美契合。我的体系中一个至关重要的组成部分是：我们组织中的每个人——无论其职责、声誉或薪水如何——都是团队中受人尊敬的一员。其他人需要后天学习才能明白这一点，但乔在穿上49人队球衣之前就已经领悟了。
I was lucky to have a quarterback in my years at San Francisco who exhibited this important leadership quality right from the start. His leadership example of doing your job, treating others with respect, expecting people to do their jobs, and holding them accountable is a formula for success that will work in any good organization.
我在旧金山效力期间很幸运，遇到一位从一开始就展现出这种重要领导力的四分卫。他以身作则，做好自己的本职工作，尊重他人，期望他人尽职尽责，并让他们承担责任，这种领导方式在任何优秀的组织中都行之有效。
Montana’s kind of leadership is a great starting point, in my view, for what any good leader strives to do, namely, bring out the best in people. In order to manage people effectively, you must act responsibly and professionally in your capacity as leader. In this regard, you should employ an approach that is based on the following principles:
1. Treat people like people. Every player on our team wore a number; no player on our team was “just a number.” Treat each member of your organization as a unique person. I was never pals with players, but I never viewed any of them as an anonymous member of an organizational herd.
2. Seek positive relationships through encouragement, support, and critical evaluation. Maintain an uplifting atmosphere at work with your ongoing positive, enthusiastic, energizing behavior.
3. Afford everyone equal dignity, respect, and treatment.
4. Blend honesty and “diplomacy.” At times, it is both humane and practical to soften the heavy blow of a demotion or termination with compassion and empathy. It will also help prevent or reduce a toxic response that can ripple through the organization when word spreads that someone feels he or she has been treated roughly without cause. Nevertheless, “rough treatment” serves a purpose occasionally.
5. Allow for a wide range of moods, from serious to very relaxed, in the workplace depending on the circumstances. Set the acceptable tone by your own demeanor, and develop the fine art of knowing when to crack the whip or crack a joke. In the middle of our second Super Bowl season, Joe Montana threw three interceptions against Cincinnati in the first half. We were getting beaten decisively. What was the correct response from me? Bark at him to bear down and try harder, scold him, or what? As he came off the field following his third interception, I pulled him over and asked him innocently, “How’s it going out there, Joe?” He got my joke, and I think it took off some of the pressure and anger he had at himself. Things improved, he got going in the second half, and we won. Maybe in another situation my approach would have been more critical. You have to have a feel for it.
6. Avoid pleading with players to “get going” or trying to relate to them by adopting their vernacular. Strong leaders don’t plead with individuals to perform.
7. Make each person in your employ very aware that his or her well-being has a high priority with the organization and that the well-being of the organization must be his or her highest professional priority.
8. Give no VIP treatment. Except on a very short-term “reward” basis that is understood as such—for example, a special parking spot for the employee of the month.
9. Speak in positive terms about former members of your organization. This creates a very positive impression and signals that respect and loyalty extend beyond an individual’s time on your payroll.
10. Demonstrate interest in and support for the extended families of members of the organization.
11. Communicate on a first-name basis without allowing relationships to become buddy-buddy. Deep resentments can develop when others see you playing favorites by exhibiting a special bond with select members of the group.
12. Don’t let differences or animosity linger. Cleanse the wound before it gets infected.
在我看来，蒙大拿的领导方式是一个很好的起点，它体现了任何优秀领导者努力的目标——激发员工的潜能。为了有效地管理员工，作为领导者，你必须以负责任和专业的态度行事。在这方面，你应该遵循以下原则：1. 把人当人看待。我们队里的每个队员都有号码；没有哪个队员“仅仅是个号码”。把组织里的每个成员都当作独一无二的个体来对待。我从未和队员们称兄道弟，但我从未把他们中的任何一个视为组织中默默无闻的一员。2. 通过鼓励、支持和批判性评估来建立积极的关系。用你持续积极、热情、充满活力的行为，在工作中营造积极向上的氛围。3. 给予每个人平等的尊严、尊重和待遇。4. 兼顾诚实和“外交手腕”。有时，用同情和共情来减轻降职或解雇带来的沉重打击，既人道又实际。这也有助于预防或减少因有人无故受到粗暴对待而引发的负面情绪，避免这种情绪在组织内部蔓延。然而，“粗暴对待”有时也有其存在的意义。5. 根据具体情况，允许工作场所存在各种情绪，从严肃到非常轻松。通过自身的举止树立合适的氛围，并培养把握何时严厉批评、何时开玩笑的艺术。在我们第二个超级碗赛季中期，乔·蒙塔纳在上半场对阵辛辛那提猛虎队的比赛中被抄截三次。我们当时处于落后局面。我应该怎么做？是冲他吼让他振作起来，更加努力？还是训斥他？在他第三次被抄截后下场时，我把他拉到一边，无辜地问他：“乔，你今天怎么样？”他听懂了我的玩笑，我想这减轻了他对自己产生的一些压力和愤怒。情况有所好转，他在下半场找回状态，我们最终赢得了比赛。或许在其他情况下，我的做法会更加严厉。你必须对此有所感觉。6. 避免恳求员工“快点行动”，也不要试图通过模仿他们的语言来与他们建立联系。优秀的领导者不会恳求员工努力工作。7. 让你的每位员工都清楚地意识到，他们的福祉在组织中至关重要，而组织的福祉必须是他们最高的职业目标。8. 不要给予任何特殊待遇。除非是短期的“奖励”，并且这种奖励必须明确是奖励——例如，为当月最佳员工提供一个专属停车位。9. 用积极的语气谈论你组织的前成员。这会给人留下非常积极的印象，并表明你对他们的尊重和忠诚超越了他们离开公司的时间。10. 对组织成员的家人表现出关心和支持。11. 以名字相称进行沟通，但不要让关系发展成亲密无间的哥们儿。如果你与某些成员表现出特殊关系，从而偏袒他们，其他人可能会对此产生深深的怨恨。12.不要让分歧或敌意持续下去。在伤口感染之前进行清洁处理。
One of the great strengths of General George S. Patton, perhaps one of the best general officers in the history of the U.S. military, was his ability to work with and lead those individuals under his command. The manner in which he did this is applicable beyond the military to sports, business, and leadership in a broad range of areas.
乔治·S·巴顿将军或许是美国军事史上最杰出的将领之一，他最大的优势之一就是善于与下属合作并领导他们。他这种领导方式不仅适用于军事领域，也适用于体育、商业以及众多其他领域的领导力。
In his “Letter of Instruction Number 1” (from War As I Knew It) , which was written for officers under his command in the U.S. Third Army, Patton offered six key dictates. You should evaluate each one and determine whether you can utilize it in your own “command.”
在巴顿将军为他麾下美国第三集团军军官撰写的《第一号指示信》（出自《我所了解的战争》）中，他提出了六项关键指示。你应该评估每一项指示，并确定它们是否适用于你自己的“指挥”工作。
1. Remember that praise is more valuable than blame. Remember, too, that your primary mission as a leader is to see with your own eyes and be seen by your own troops while engaged in personal reconnaissance.
1. 记住，表扬比责备更有价值。还要记住，作为领导者，你的首要任务是在进行个人侦察时，亲眼观察并让你的部下看到你。
2. Use every means before and after combat to tell troops what they are going to do and what they have done.
2. 在战斗前后，要用尽一切手段告诉部队他们要做什么和已经做了什么。
3. Discipline is based on pride in the profession [my italics] of arms, on meticulous attention to details, and on mutual respect and confidence. Discipline must be a habit so ingrained that it is stronger than the excitement of battle or the fear of death.
3. 纪律建立在对军旅生涯的自豪感、对细节的精益求精以及相互尊重和信任之上。纪律必须成为一种根深蒂固的习惯，其力量甚至超过战斗的刺激或对死亡的恐惧。
4. Officers must assert themselves by example and by voice. They must be preeminent in courage, deportment and dress.
4. 军官必须以身作则，言辞有力，展现出卓越的领导力。他们在勇气、举止和着装方面必须出类拔萃。
5. General officers must be seen in the front line during action.
5. 将军们在作战时必须出现在前线。
6. There is a tendency for the chain of command to overload junior officers by excessive requirements in the way of training and reports. You will alleviate this burden by eliminating non-essential demands.
6. 指挥链往往存在一种倾向，即通过过多的训练和报告要求，使基层军官不堪重负。您可以通过取消不必要的要求来减轻这种负担。
There is much in Patton’s letter to think about. Obviously, some of it pertains only to war, but almost all of it has relevance to what you do if you adopt and adapt it appropriately: praising rather than blaming; getting out and working amid your “troops”; precisely describing what you want done; taking pride in the profession; paying attention to details; creating habits that hold up under pressure; and removing nonessentials in the workload. It’s all great stuff from a great leader.
巴顿的信中有很多值得深思的地方。显然，其中一些内容只与战争有关，但几乎所有内容，只要你加以适当吸收和调整，都与你的日常工作息息相关：表扬而非责备；走出去，与你的“部队”并肩作战；清晰地描述你想要完成的任务；以自己的职业为荣；注重细节；养成能在压力下保持的习惯；以及剔除工作中不必要的事务。这些都是一位伟大领导者的宝贵经验。

Don’t Let Anybody Call You a Genius 别让任何人称你为天才
Nobody, including me, expected the 49ers to win the Super Bowl so soon after I was hired as head coach—going from a 2-14 record my first year to world champions twenty-four months later. (To put it another way, we lost twenty-six of the first thirty-five games I coached; then sixteen games later we won Super Bowl XVI.) Consequently, and in part because of the complexities of our pass-based offense, the media began referring to me as “the Genius.”
包括我在内，谁也没想到49人队在我担任主教练后这么快就能赢得超级碗——从我执教第一年的2胜14负，到24个月后的世界冠军。（换句话说，在我执教的前35场比赛中，我们输掉了26场；然后16场比赛之后，我们就赢得了第十六届超级碗。）因此，部分原因是由于我们以传球为主的进攻体系的复杂性，媒体开始称我为“天才”。
When the name was first attached to me, I was naive enough to be flattered and did nothing to discourage writers from using it. I may have even been thinking, “Hey, maybe there’s something to it.” I hope not, but everybody likes to read and hear good things about themselves. Besides, what possible downside could there be?
当这个名字最初与我联系在一起时，我天真地感到受宠若惊，并没有阻止其他作家使用它。我甚至可能还想着：“嘿，也许这名字真有点道理。” 我希望不是这样，但谁不喜欢听到别人夸奖自己呢？再说，这又能有什么坏处呢？
I learned soon enough that an inflated label like “Genius,” or any other form of hyperbole, comes with a big downside—that buying into what people say about you can create both external and internal problems, making your life and job a lot tougher than they already are. It happened very soon for me.
我很快就明白，像“天才”这样过高的标签，或者任何其他夸张的言辞，都会带来巨大的弊端——轻信别人对你的评价会造成内外的双重困扰，让你的生活和工作比原本就艰难得多。我很快就体会到了这一点。
Following our first Super Bowl victory, the San Francisco 49ers lost twelve of our next twenty-two games—just over 50 percent. (In fact, our record was 3-6 in the strike-shortened season immediately following that Super Bowl championship.)
在赢得首个超级碗冠军后，旧金山49人队在接下来的22场比赛中输掉了12场——胜率略高于50%。（事实上，在紧随其后的因罢工而缩短的赛季中，我们的战绩为3胜6负。）
Soon some writers, coaches, and fans began using the nickname “Genius” dismissively, even derisively. When a play backfired, somebody in the stands would inevitably shout, “There goes the Genius again,” or “Hey, Genius, back to the laboratory.”
很快，一些作家、教练和球迷开始轻蔑地、甚至嘲讽地使用“天才”这个绰号。当一次战术失误时，看台上总会有人喊道：“天才又来了！”或者“嘿，天才，回实验室去吧！”
I learned that opposing coaches would incite players by talking sarcastically about the big “Genius” who was sitting calmly at his desk in San Francisco thinking up new ways to embarrass them on Sunday. Reporters wrote columns analyzing whether I was a “Genius” or a flash in the pan; whether the West Coast Offense was real or a house of cards.
我发现，对方教练会用讽刺挖苦的语气谈论那个坐在旧金山办公桌前、镇定自若地琢磨着如何在周日羞辱他们的“天才”，以此来激怒球员。记者们也纷纷撰文分析我究竟是“天才”还是昙花一现；西海岸进攻体系究竟是真材实料还是摇摇欲坠。
I must admit, all of this was painful for both me and my family. Believe me, my wife, Geri, never operated under the illusion that she was married to a genius. In fact, at one point, after a hard-fought but narrow loss to the New Orleans Saints at Candlestick Park, she and I were leaving the stadium when an older woman wearing a 49ers scarf noticed us and eagerly rolled down the window of her car and waved in our direction. “Bill, Bill Walsh? May I ask you a question?” she inquired. We walked over to within a few feet of her car, and I leaned toward her open window with a smile on my face.
我必须承认，这一切对我和我的家人来说都非常痛苦。相信我，我的妻子格里从未幻想过自己嫁给了一个天才。事实上，有一次，在烛台公园球场，我们队惜败给新奥尔良圣徒队后，我和她正要离开球场，一位戴着49人队围巾的老妇人注意到了我们，她热情地摇下车窗，朝我们挥手。“比尔，比尔·沃尔什？我可以问你个问题吗？”她问道。我们走到离她车几英尺远的地方，我面带微笑地探身靠近她敞开的车窗。
Suddenly she erupted: “You stupid son of a bitch! That was the worst job of coaching I’ve ever seen. You owe me a refund.” She rolled up her window and drove away. Geri and I stood there stunned, embarrassed. Then we started chuckling. “She shouldn’t talk to a genius like that,” my wife said with a smile. “By the way, don’t forget to clean out the garage when we get home. We need to make room for all of your trophies.”
她突然爆发了：“你这个蠢货！这是我见过最糟糕的教练！你欠我钱！”说完，她摇上车窗，开车走了。我和格里呆呆地站在那里，尴尬极了。然后我们忍不住笑了起来。“她不该跟那样的天才说话，”我妻子笑着说。“对了，回家后别忘了把车库收拾干净。我们得腾出地方放你那些奖杯。”
The incident only reminded me of what I already knew; namely, that the title I really wanted—the title that indicated the highest praise—was “teacher” or “coach”; combined, they make you a leader. The “Genius” label was an albatross around my neck.
这件事只是让我更加确信我早已知晓的事实：我真正想要的头衔——那个代表最高赞誉的头衔——是“教师”或“教练”；两者结合起来，才能让你成为一名领导者。“天才”这个标签对我来说简直就是个沉重的负担。
Nevertheless, it’s easy to get caught up in or enamored of lofty titles, praise, and flattery as you subconsciously attempt to become the character others have created out of who you are. That character isn’t you, but it’s an addictive attraction if the plaques, awards, and commendations start rolling in. Believing your own press clippings—good or bad—is self-defeating. You are allowing others, oftentimes uninformed others, to tell you who you are.
然而，人们很容易沉迷于高高的头衔、赞扬和奉承，潜意识里试图成为别人根据你自身塑造出来的形象。那个形象并非真正的你，但如果奖牌、奖项和表彰纷至沓来，它就会像毒药一样让人上瘾。相信媒体对你的各种评价——无论是好是坏——都无异于自毁前程。你实际上是在允许他人，尤其是那些不了解情况的人，来定义你。
The real damage occurs when you start to believe that future success will come your way automatically because of the great ability of this caricature you have suddenly become, that the hard work and applied intelligence you utilized initially are not as crucial as they once were. That’s when you get lazy; that’s when you let your guard down. When that happens, you’re not a genius—you’re a genuine fool.
真正的危害在于，当你开始相信未来的成功会因为你突然变成的这个“天才”而自动降临，而你最初付出的努力和运用智慧不再像以前那样至关重要。那时你就会变得懒惰，放松警惕。当这种情况发生时，你不是天才，而是彻头彻尾的傻瓜。
When the “Genius” title turned on me, I backed away from it as far as I could get. A story got going among fans that the sign on my parking space at 49ers headquarters said “The Professor.” It wasn’t true, but it would have been an improvement over “The Genius.”
当“天才”这个称号给我带来麻烦时，我竭力摆脱它。球迷们开始流传一个故事，说我在49人队总部停车位上的牌子写的是“教授”。这当然不是真的，但总比“天才”好。

The Leverage of Language 语言的杠杆作用
You demonstrate a lack of assuredness when you talk constantly in negatives. When attempting to help someone attain that next level of performance, a supportive approach works better than a constantly negative or downside-focused approach.
你如果总是说负面的话，就会显得缺乏自信。在帮助别人提升绩效时，支持性的方法比总是消极或只关注缺点的方法更有效。
I could be very cutting, very sharp in criticizing a player or coach, but I always made an effort to counter it by following up the barbs with more upbeat input immediately afterward. I avoided creating a chain of negatives. Here’s an example.
我批评球员或教练时可能会非常尖锐，言辞犀利，但我总是努力用积极正面的评价来弥补批评的不足。我避免制造一连串的负面情绪。举个例子。
One Tuesday morning during a preseason workout at our training facility in Santa Clara, California, future Hall of Fame quarterback Steve Young was practicing a crossing pass route with Brent Jones. Steve threw a bad ball. His mechanics weren’t right—in fact, they were sloppy, especially for someone at his high skill level. Young wasn’t focused on what he was doing; instead, he was just going through the motions. This may not sound serious—one pass among many at practice—but it is a cardinal sin in my philosophy.
一个周二的早晨，在加州圣克拉拉训练基地的一次季前训练中，未来的名人堂四分卫史蒂夫·杨正在和布伦特·琼斯练习横向传球路线。史蒂夫传出了一个糟糕的球。他的动作不规范——事实上，他的动作非常粗糙，尤其对于他这样高水平的球员来说更是如此。杨并没有专注于自己的动作；他只是机械地重复着动作。这听起来或许并不严重——只是训练中众多传球中的一次失误——但在我的理念中，这却是不可饶恕的罪过。
I was standing directly behind him with my arms across my chest and said sternly, “Lousy! That was laughable, Steve. Damn it, do it again, and this time do it right.” I was very stern, trying to jack up his intensity and get him focused on what he was doing.
我站在他身后，双臂抱胸，严厉地说：“太糟糕了！简直可笑，史蒂夫。该死的，再来一次，这次好好做。”我语气非常严厉，想让他集中注意力，认真对待他正在做的事情。
The squad reset, and Steve took the snap, dropped back three steps, and threw a second pass—this time with a beautiful and perfect motion, physical artistry that made it a little work of art. I said, “That was good. Stay with that,” and walked away rubbing my hands together. He looked over at me and gave me a thumbs-up. Steve had gotten my message (and the message wasn’t so much about his throwing motion as it was about his concentration). My praise was sparse, but meaningful because it was rarely effusive.
队伍重新调整位置，史蒂夫接球后后退三步，再次传球——这次他的动作优美流畅，堪称完美，简直像一件艺术品。我说：“不错，保持这样。”说完，我搓着手走开了。他回头看了我一眼，竖起了大拇指。史蒂夫明白了我的意思（其实我说的不是他的投掷动作，而是他的专注力）。我的赞扬不多，但却意义非凡，因为我很少夸张。
When I criticized or gave feedback to someone, it wasn’t defeatist. It was always focused on the here and now and never conjured up images or incidents of poor play over the previous days or weeks (for example, “Your motion was lousy. That’s why you’ve been throwing interceptions for the last three weeks. How long is it going to take to get it right? I’m getting tired of seeing this over and over.”).
当我批评或给别人反馈时，我的态度并非消极悲观。我总是着眼于当下，从不提及过去几天或几周的糟糕表现（例如，“你的跑动太糟糕了。这就是为什么你过去三周一直在传球被拦截。到底要多久才能改正？我已经厌倦了反复看到这种情况。”）。
It creates a sense of piling on, of browbeating. When that happens, you lose credibility and respect because the subject of your continuous criticism sees it as a personal attack. Others see it and react the same way. (This is not to say I never piled on or wasn’t occasionally guilty of browbeating.)
这会给人一种落井下石、咄咄逼人的感觉。一旦出现这种情况，你就会失去信誉和尊重，因为你持续批评的对象会将其视为人身攻击。其他人也会有同样的反应。（这并不是说我从未落井下石，或者偶尔没有咄咄逼人的行为。）
If you’re growing a garden, you need to pull out the weeds, but flowers will die if all you do is pick weeds. They need sunshine and water. People are the same. They need criticism, but they also require positive and substantive language and information and true support to really blossom.
如果你在种花，你需要拔除杂草，但如果你只拔杂草，花儿也会枯萎。它们需要阳光和水分。人也是如此。他们需要批评，但也需要积极、实质性的语言、信息和真诚的支持才能真正绽放光彩。
If you’re perceived as a negative person—always picking, pulling, criticizing—you will simply get tuned out by those around you. Your influence, ability to teach, and opportunity to make progress will be diminished and eventually lost. When that happens, you become useless, a hindrance to progress. When your feedback is interpreted as a personal attack rather than a critique with positive intentions, you are going backward.
如果你被视为一个消极的人——总是挑剔、指责、批评——你周围的人就会对你置之不理。你的影响力、教学能力和进步机会都会减弱，最终甚至消失。到那时，你就变得毫无用处，成为进步的绊脚石。当你的反馈被解读为人身攻击而非善意的批评时，你就是在退步。
Constructive criticism is a powerful instrument essential for improving performance. Positive support can be equally productive. Used together by a skilled leader they become the key to maximum results. Most of us seem to be more inclined to offer the negative. I don’t know why, but it’s easier to criticize than to compliment. Find the right mixture for optimum results.
建设性批评是提升绩效的有力工具，积极的支持同样至关重要。一位优秀的领导者若能将二者结合运用，便能取得最佳成效。我们大多数人似乎更倾向于提出负面评价。我不知道为什么，但批评总比赞扬容易。找到合适的组合，才能获得最佳效果。

Don’t Beat Around the Bush (When Describing a Bush) （描述灌木丛时）不要拐弯抹角
Former Cleveland and Cincinnati head coach Paul Brown taught me a lot during the eight years I worked for him as an assistant coach. Among his many talents was direct communication. He was clear, specific, and comprehensive without an ounce of ambiguity. I like his approach and recommend the same for you. Here’s an example of how he insured that everyone was on the same page.
在我担任克利夫兰和辛辛那提前主教练保罗·布朗的助理教练的八年里，他教会了我很多。他众多才能之一就是直截了当的沟通能力。他说话清晰、具体、全面，没有丝毫含糊不清之处。我很欣赏他的这种风格，也推荐你学习。以下是他如何确保每个人都步调一致的例子。
On the first day of each season’s training camp, Brown would give a lecture to the squad that covered his own Standard of Performance—what he expected (demanded) in all areas. Of course, a leader’s personal example is perhaps the most powerful teaching tool, but words have their own power and specificity.
每个赛季训练营的第一天，布朗都会给全队做一次演讲，阐述他自己的绩效标准——他对球队各个方面的期望（要求）。当然，领导者的言传身教或许是最有力的教育工具，但言语本身也具有强大的力量和具体的指导意义。
Brown would start each season with the phrase, “Gentlemen, let’s set the record straight,” and then proceed to do exactly that. Step by step by step, specific after specific, he would cover every aspect of being on the Cincinnati Bengals football team.
布朗每个赛季都会以这样一句话开场：“先生们，让我们把事情说清楚”，然后他就会说到做到。他会一步一步、一丝不苟地讲解辛辛那提猛虎队橄榄球队的方方面面。
He discussed how to wear the uniform, how to dress for meals, how each player was expected to keep his locker in order. He told players how he wanted them to respond to coaching, how to take notes during lectures, how teaching would be done, and what to expect from each assistant coach.
他讲解了如何穿着队服、用餐时的着装，以及每位球员如何保持更衣柜的整洁。他还告诉球员们他希望他们如何回应教练的指导、如何在课堂上记笔记、教学方式以及每位助理教练的工作内容。
Brown covered such specifics as punctuality, the training-room rules, what would happen when players were waived (this always sent a chill through the group), and the overall environment he intended to create. Furthermore, he shared his policy of treating each player—stars, backups, veterans, rookies, free agents—equally, with the same high level of respect and dignity.
布朗详细讲解了诸如准时性、训练室规则、球员被裁掉后的处理方式（这总是让全队感到不寒而栗）以及他想要营造的整体氛围等细节。此外，他还分享了他对待每一位球员——无论是明星球员、替补球员、老将、新秀还是自由球员——都秉持平等对待、给予同样高度尊重和尊严的原则。
Each year his lecture, and this was only a sampling of topics, lasted about four hours (and voluminous printed material supplemented the lecture). Paul Brown was thorough enough that when the Bengals personnel left the meeting room they knew precisely what they were supposed to do in the coming weeks and that their head coach expected them to enthusiastically adhere to every procedure, policy, and timetable he had specified.
每年他的讲座——这只是其中一部分主题——大约持续四个小时（此外还有大量的印刷材料作为补充）。保罗·布朗的讲解非常详尽，以至于当辛辛那提猛虎队的队员们离开会议室时，他们都清楚地知道接下来几周自己应该做什么，而且他们的主教练也期望他们热情地遵守他制定的每一项程序、政策和时间表。
Needless to say, he continued with this kind of direct and clear communication in the months that followed—in practice, during games, and elsewhere.
毋庸置疑，在接下来的几个月里，他在训练中、比赛中以及其他场合都继续保持着这种直接而清晰的沟通方式。
What he laid out was measurable. And he measured it on a regular basis—his version of your company’s year-end review. (You will note that I included some of Brown’s material in my own Standard of Performance and expanded greatly on it. Like Paul Brown, I attempted to be clear, specific, and direct in putting forth my own requirements concerning actions and attitude.)
他提出的标准是可以衡量的，而且他会定期进行衡量——这相当于你们公司的年终考核。（你会注意到，我在自己的绩效标准中引用了布朗的一些内容，并对其进行了大量扩展。和保罗·布朗一样，我力求清晰、具体、直接地提出我对行为和态度的要求。）
Vince Lombardi had a similar appreciation for the benefits of direct—specific—communication. Supposedly, he started each season’s training camp by assembling the team and announcing, as he held it over his head, “Gentlemen, this is a football.” That’s how Vince began his introduction of the fundamentals of his particular system, with clear communication. Both Brown and Lombardi understood the necessity of spelling out in detail what you expect from employees and doing it in a manner that is unambiguous and comprehensive.
文斯·隆巴迪也同样深谙直接、具体沟通的重要性。据说，他每个赛季训练营开始时都会召集全队，然后举起橄榄球，大声宣布：“先生们，这就是橄榄球。” 这就是文斯用清晰的沟通方式，开始介绍他那套独特体系的基本原则。布朗和隆巴迪都明白，必须详细阐明对员工的期望，而且要以明确、全面的方式进行。
It is an important element in why these great coaches succeeded. Employees can thrive in an environment where they know exactly what is expected of them—even when those expectations are very high.
这是这些伟大教练取得成功的重要因素之一。员工在清楚了解自身职责的环境中能够茁壮成长——即便这些职责要求很高。
When it comes to telling people what you expect from them, don’t be subtle, don’t be coy, don’t be vague. What is your version of, “Gentlemen, this is a football”?
当你想告诉别人你对他们的期望时，不要拐弯抹角，不要含糊其辞，不要模棱两可。你如何表达“先生们，这是个足球”？

Don’t Mistake Grabbin’ for Tackling 不要把抓取误认为是擒抱
There’s another story about Vince Lombardi worth mentioning because it points out a high-priority responsibility of any leader. During a game in which his Green Bay Packers were giving up one gain after another, as the opponent marched down the field, he screamed out at his defensive players, “Grabbin’, grabbin’, grabbin’! Nobody’s tackling!!! What the hell is going on out there?”
关于文斯·隆巴迪，还有另一个值得一提的故事，因为它揭示了任何领导者的一项重要职责。在一场比赛中，他的绿湾包装工队屡屡让对手推进，眼看对手步步紧逼，隆巴迪冲着防守队员们大喊：“抓人！抓人！抓人！没人擒抱！场上到底发生了什么？”
Lombardi could see that his defensive players were not getting it done, were not really doing the hard job of tackling runners. He let them know that “grabbin’ ” was not their job description and simply going through the motions was going to get them beat.
隆巴迪看出他的防守队员没有尽职尽责，没有真正完成擒抱持球进攻队员的艰巨任务。他告诉他们，“抓人”并不是他们的职责，只是敷衍了事只会让他们输掉比赛。
A leader must know when his team is making a lot of noise signifying nothing. UCLA’s coach John Wooden summed it up like this: “Don’t mistake activity for achievement.” (John Wooden, Wooden on Leadership .) Lombardi was more graphic in his language but was addressing the same issue.
领导者必须清楚，当团队大张旗鼓地做事却毫无意义时，该如何应对。加州大学洛杉矶分校的教练约翰·伍登曾这样总结：“不要把忙碌误认为成就。”（约翰·伍登，《伍登论领导力》）隆巴迪的措辞更为直白，但所指的也是同一个问题。

Communication Creates Collaboration: Big Ears Are Better Than Big Egos 沟通促进合作：倾听胜于自负
In an earlier time, leadership—most visibly in sports, but also commonly in business—required no greater people skills than those of a blunt-force object. Ohio State’s Woody Hayes, Alabama’s Bear Bryant, and Green Bay’s Vince Lombardi all enjoyed their image as hard taskmasters whose primary people skills appeared to be intimidation and humiliation.
在过去，领导力——最明显地体现在体育界，但也常见于商界——所需的人际交往能力并不比钝器强多少。俄亥俄州立大学的伍迪·海耶斯、阿拉巴马大学的熊·布莱恩特和绿湾包装工队的文斯·隆巴迪都乐于扮演严厉的管理者，他们的主要人际交往技巧似乎就是恐吓和羞辱。
Henry Jordan, one of Vince’s top players, reportedly said, only partially in jest, “When Coach Lombardi says, ‘Sit down,’ I don’t look for a chair.” (When asked if Lombardi gave his stars special treatment, Jordan replied, “No. He treats us all the same—like dogs.”) Leadership in sports and business has generally moved away from this forceful, heavy-handed approach, although there are still plenty of examples of it—some very successful, in fact.
文斯·隆巴迪麾下最优秀的球员之一亨利·乔丹曾半开玩笑地说：“隆巴迪教练说‘坐下’的时候，我可不会去找椅子。”（当被问及隆巴迪是否对他的明星球员特殊照顾时，乔丹回答说：“没有。他对我们都一样——就像对待狗一样。”）体育界和商界的领导层总体上已经摒弃了这种强硬、专横的管理方式，尽管仍然有很多这样的例子——事实上，其中一些非常成功。
While leadership still involves occasionally using a heavy-handed approach—“my way or the highway”—collaboration is required more than ever these days to obtain optimal results. These results only occur when you are able to bring out the full potential of your personnel. Quality collaboration is only possible in the presence of quality communication; that is, the free-flowing and robust exchange of information, ideas, and opinions. And “having big ears”—the skill of being a great listener—is the first law of good communication. (The second law is “When you’re not listening, ask good questions.”)
尽管领导力有时仍然需要采取强硬手段——“要么听我的，要么走人”——但如今，为了取得最佳成果，协作比以往任何时候都更加重要。而只有充分发挥员工的潜力，才能实现这些成果。高质量的协作离不开高质量的沟通；也就是说，信息、想法和意见的自由流畅、有效交流至关重要。“善于倾听”——也就是成为一名优秀的倾听者——是良好沟通的第一法则。（第二法则是“当你没在听的时候，要提出好问题。”）
For me it meant I had to set aside certain aspects of my own ego—e.g., talking too much—and really listen to what talented individuals in the organization had to say. I had to learn that communication is not a one-way street; it’s a two-way, three-way, every-way street. This is a challenge for some of us to put into practice, because it’s usually a hell of a lot easier to tell somebody what to do than to listen to his or her suggestions and ideas (especially when you think that you have all the answers on a wide range of subjects).
对我而言，这意味着我必须放下一些自我——比如，滔滔不绝——真正倾听组织里有才华的人的意见。我必须明白，沟通不是单行道，而是双向的、三向的、全方位的交流。对我们中的一些人来说，做到这一点并不容易，因为告诉别人该怎么做通常比倾听他们的建议和想法容易得多（尤其当你觉得自己对各种各样的问题都了如指掌的时候）。
As a group, I wanted each of us to be as interested in finding out what others thought as in telling others what we thought. (Of course, I also didn’t want a staff made up of talented people who just sat there listening all the time.)
作为一个团队，我希望我们每个人都能像表达自己的想法一样，对了解他人的想法感兴趣。（当然，我也不希望我的团队成员都是些才华横溢却只会坐在那里听别人说话的人。）
At 49er staff meetings everyone understood they were expected to participate, communicate, and collaborate, to be part of the discussion regardless of the topic being addressed. I would go around the conference table seeking input from each coach, scout, and executive. If someone said, “That’s not something I’m familiar with, Bill,” I told them firmly, “Talk to somebody who can get you familiar with it.” (Among other things, this had the added advantage of keeping everyone on their toes and tuned in. They never knew when I would solicit their opinion on something.)
在49人队的员工会议上，每个人都明白自己应该参与、沟通和协作，无论讨论什么话题，都要积极发言。我会绕着会议桌走一圈，征求每位教练、球探和高管的意见。如果有人说：“比尔，我对这个不太了解。”我会坚定地告诉他们：“去找个懂行的人问问。”（这样做还有一个好处，就是能让每个人都保持警觉，认真听讲。他们永远不知道我会什么时候征求他们的意见。）
An individual doesn’t need to be an expert to ask an intelligent question or offer useful insights. A sentence beginning with the words “This may sound dumb, but . . .” can be the start of a fruitful discussion if you’ve hired talented and intelligent people. The person most familiar with a topic—you, for example—can get myopic, in need of an outside perspective.
一个人并不需要成为专家才能提出有见地的问题或提供有用的见解。如果你聘请了才华横溢、聪明睿智的人，那么以“这听起来可能有点傻，但是……”开头的一句话就能开启一场富有成效的讨论。最熟悉某个话题的人——比如你——可能会变得目光短浅，这时就需要一些局外人的视角。
I also knew that fear of being shunted aside or told, “That’s a stupid question,” keeps valid questions from being asked. Rarely was anyone working with me derided for their inquiries or opinions. (Of course, by hiring smart people I eliminated the vast majority of dumb questions.)
我也知道，害怕被冷落或被告知“这是个愚蠢的问题”，会让人不敢提出合理的问题。很少有人会因为提出问题或发表意见而遭到嘲笑。（当然，通过聘用聪明的人，我避免了绝大多数愚蠢的问题。）
Nor did I ever want staff members or others to have cause to say, “Hey, nobody listens to me,” just because their idea or suggestion wasn’t used. Communication means people will disagree—strongly at times—but they must understand that disagreement should not fester. “Get a cup of coffee, put your arm around the shoulder of the person you’re bumping heads with, and say, ‘Let’s talk about this,’ ” was my directive. “You’re not always right, nor is the other person. Sometimes you’re both wrong. Sometimes there are three sides to a coin.” I wanted to work with people smart enough to have independent thinking but strong enough to change their opinion when evidence or logic suggested it.
我也不希望员工或其他人因为自己的想法或建议没有被采纳而抱怨“没人听我的”。沟通意味着人们会有分歧——有时甚至是激烈的分歧——但他们必须明白，分歧不应该持续恶化。我的指示是：“喝杯咖啡，搂住和你意见不合的人的肩膀，说：‘我们来谈谈吧。’你并不总是对的，对方也不一定总是对的。有时你们双方都错了。有时，一枚硬币有三面。”我希望与那些既聪明到可以独立思考，又足够坚定，能够在证据或逻辑表明需要改变观点时及时调整立场的人共事。
Communication is complex. It’s not just the King’s English. Body language, gender connection, age connection, role connection, affluence and wealth connection, receiving or taking directions, and the state of mind of one person or another are all elements in communicating with someone.
沟通很复杂，不仅仅是使用标准的英语。肢体语言、性别关系、年龄关系、角色关系、财富状况、接受或执行指令，以及一个人的心理状态，都是与他人沟通的要素。
It’s not just being able to talk back and forth. It’s recognizing when to say it, how to say it, when to listen, whom you’re talking with, how they feel, what you’re trying to get down to, how important the circumstance is, what the necessity is timewise, and how rapidly the decision must be made.
不仅仅是能够一来一往地交谈。更重要的是要懂得何时该说，怎么说，何时该听，你在和谁说话，他们的感受如何，你想表达什么，情况有多重要，时间有多紧迫，以及必须多快做出决定。
These are complex skills you must possess as part of your own basic Standard of Performance that is part of your leadership inventory. While a healthy ego is crucial in leadership, it turns unhealthy when self-confidence becomes arrogance, assertiveness becomes obstinacy, and self-assurance becomes reckless abandon. This is manifested when communication from leadership amounts to “Shut up and listen”—when your ego gets bigger than your ears.
这些都是你必须具备的复杂技能，它们是你基本绩效标准的一部分，也是你领导力素质体系的重要组成部分。健康的自尊心对领导力至关重要，但当自信变成傲慢、果断变成固执、自信变成鲁莽行事时，它就会变得不健康。当领导者的沟通方式变成“闭嘴听着”时，这种情况就会显现出来——那时你的自尊心已经膨胀到听不进别人说话的地步了。
Ironically, a big display of ego is sometimes hiding insecurity or lack of confidence. That kind of individual is overly protective of his or her turf or attempting to establish position in the pecking order by making others conform to his or her wishes. This, of course, reduces or removes creative vitality and collaboration.
讽刺的是，极度自负有时反而掩盖了内心的不安全感或缺乏自信。这类人过度维护自己的地盘，或者试图通过强迫他人服从自己的意愿来确立地位。这无疑会削弱甚至扼杀创造力和协作精神。
If you are uncomfortable walking around your team’s workplace, awkward and out of place, you are a disconnected leader—not really part of the team. Sitting in your office with the door closed and issuing edicts from on high is not communication, and is certainly not collaborative leadership.
如果你在团队工作场所走动时感到不自在，显得笨拙格格不入，那么你就是一位脱离团队的领导者——你并没有真正融入团队。坐在办公室里，关上门，高高在上地发号施令，这不是沟通，更不是协作型领导。
You should be willing to go to someone’s office or desk and help him or her do his or her job. You want to be able to facilitate what people are doing when necessary. The 49ers coaching staff—including me—was not hidden away like a secret cabal that was seen only occasionally. Among many other things, at least once a week each coach spent his lunch hour in the locker room with the team. Eating a tuna fish sandwich and drinking a Pepsi next to players was an unassuming way to break down barriers and facilitate organizational familiarity, which facilitates better interaction. Your can also learn a lot while eating your sandwich.
你应该乐于去别人的办公室或办公桌旁，帮助他们完成工作。你需要在必要时为他人的工作提供便利。49人队的教练组——包括我——并非像秘密组织那样隐匿起来，偶尔才会露面。其中一项重要举措是，每位教练每周至少会抽出一个午餐时间，和队员们一起待在更衣室里。和球员们一起吃金枪鱼三明治、喝百事可乐，这种看似不起眼的方式却能打破隔阂，增进彼此的了解，从而促进更好的互动。而且，你还可以一边吃三明治一边学习。
(Obviously, there was also constant interaction every minute during practice and at other times during the day, but often it was in the context of preparation or planning. Not informal, casual “How’s the family?”- style interaction.)
（当然，在训练期间以及一天中的其他时间，他们也每时每刻都有互动，但通常是在准备或计划的背景下进行的，而不是像“家里人怎么样？”那样非正式、随意的互动。）
This was similar in a way to the approach of Dave Packard and Bill Hewlett, founders of Hewlett-Packard and charter members of Silicon Valley. They called it “management by walking around.” Both men were constantly circulating and talking with their employees in the labs, production areas, and research facilities, recognizing that personal communication was often necessary to back up written instructions.
这与惠普公司创始人、硅谷先驱戴夫·帕卡德和比尔·休利特的做法有相似之处。他们称之为“走动式管理”。两人经常在实验室、生产区和研发中心巡视，与员工交谈，他们认识到，面对面的沟通往往是书面指令的有力补充。
Dave and Bill were not alone in this approach. Silicon Valley has many billion-dollar companies whose CEO will work directly with a maintenance person when it’s important, or sit down momentarily with middle managers and help them do their job. There is no stratification or pecking order where they try to figure out where everybody fits socially. There just isn’t room for a hierarchy.
戴夫和比尔并非孤例。硅谷有很多市值数十亿美元的公司，它们的CEO会在必要时亲自与维修人员一起工作，或者抽出时间与中层管理人员交流，帮助他们完成工作。这里没有等级之分，也没有人会费心思去判断每个人在公司里的地位。因为这里根本没有等级制度的容身之地。
Jack Welch, former CEO of General Electric, called it “boundaryless” communication and worked hard to remove barriers to the flow of information within the corporation. Everybody is in the loop and expected to participate.
通用电气前首席执行官杰克·韦尔奇称之为“无边界”沟通，并致力于消除公司内部信息流动的障碍。每个人都能了解情况，并被期望参与其中。
As a former boxer, I’d suggest that if your left hand doesn’t know what your right hand is doing, you’ll get knocked out. Your right hook must be in sync with your left jab. For this to occur, your brain must communicate so your hands can collaborate. The same principle applies in business and in sports.
作为一名前拳击手，我认为，如果你的左手和右手动作不一致，你就会被击倒。你的右勾拳必须与左直拳同步。要做到这一点，你的大脑必须与双手协调配合。同样的道理也适用于商业和体育运动。

Be a King Without a Crown 做一位没有王冠的国王
Even though I had virtually complete autonomy through most of my ten years as head coach of the 49ers, I was never called Coach Walsh. In fact, everyone in the organization was addressed by their first name, including me. I wanted no barriers such as rank or title to clog up productive interaction, no chain of command to produce a sense that instead of a real team we were just a collection of isolated individuals on a totem pole of power belonging to small independent units.
尽管在我担任旧金山49人队主教练的十年间，我几乎拥有完全的自主权，但没有人叫我“沃尔什教练”。事实上，球队里的每个人都被直呼其名，包括我自己。我不想让等级或头衔之类的障碍阻碍有效的沟通，也不想让等级森严的指挥链让人觉得我们并非真正的团队，而只是权力阶梯上各自独立的个体，隶属于不同的小单位。
Rank, titles, or inferred status can impede open communication in an environment where people thrive on helping one another. Here’s just one small instance that demonstrates how the absence of such barriers manifested itself in our organization.
在人们乐于互助的环境中，等级、头衔或隐含的地位可能会阻碍坦诚沟通。以下这个小例子就足以说明，在我们组织中，消除这些障碍会带来怎样的益处。
At halftime during a midseason game with the New Orleans Saints, I told our offensive team that if we got near the Saints’ thirty-yard line I was going to call a specific pass play that I’d been saving for the situation. Sure enough, early in the third quarter we got to the Saints’ twenty-seven-yard line, but in the heat of the moment I forgot about the play I’d promised in the locker room to use.
在赛季中期与新奥尔良圣徒队的比赛中场休息时，我告诉进攻组，如果我们能推进到圣徒队30码线附近，我就会使用一个我特意留着以备不时之需的传球战术。果然，第三节刚开始不久，我们就推进到了圣徒队27码线，但临阵磨枪之下，我竟然忘记了之前在更衣室里答应过的那个战术。
Steve Young, our backup quarterback, who was standing close by, immediately leaned over and reminded me of what I had said earlier. I listened; we scored. (This example demonstrates two important points: (1) Young understood and practiced communication and collaboration. He felt free to speak up even though it might be embarrassing to me since in the heat of the moment I had completely forgotten what I said earlier, and (2) Steve was selfless, team first, in bringing forth information that his “rival” quarterback, Joe Montana, would use successfully.)
我们的替补四分卫史蒂夫·杨当时就站在附近，他立刻俯身过来提醒我之前说过的话。我听从了他的提醒；我们得分了。（这个例子说明了两个要点：(1) 杨理解并实践了沟通与协作。尽管当时我情绪激动，完全忘记了之前说过的话，可能会让我感到尴尬，但他仍然毫不犹豫地指出来；(2) 史蒂夫无私奉献，团队至上，主动提供信息，让他的“对手”四分卫乔·蒙塔纳能够成功运用。）
I wanted no separate divisions where people felt that the only thing that mattered was their specific area of responsibility, that somehow their welfare was separate from that of the rest of us. Steve was like that—a team player.
我不想看到任何各自为政的部门，让员工觉得只有自己的职责范围才重要，好像他们的福祉与我们其他人的福祉无关。史蒂夫就是这样的人——一个团队合作者。
Thus, the defensive coordinator understood that doing his job was not all that mattered—that the welfare of the offense was not somehow another island of no concern to him. Everyone understood the only welfare that mattered was the organization’s. If our ship sank, we all drowned.
因此，防守协调员明白，做好自己的本职工作并非一切——进攻组的成败并非与他无关的孤岛。每个人都明白，唯一重要的只有整个组织的成败。如果我们的船沉了，我们所有人都会遭殃。
For that to happen—for individuals to merge their own interests with those of the team—good communication must exist in an open atmosphere where intellectual interaction is a given.
要实现这一点——即个人将自己的利益与团队的利益融合起来——必须在开放的氛围中存在良好的沟通，在这种氛围中，思想交流是必不可少的。
Former UCLA basketball coach John Wooden has always urged, “Be more concerned with finding the right way than in having it your way.” When you reach the point where someone in your organization comes up with an idea better than the one you’ve been extolling for weeks or months and it makes you happy, you’re an authentic communicator and collaborator.
前加州大学洛杉矶分校篮球队教练约翰·伍登一直告诫我们：“与其执着于按自己的方式来，不如更关注找到正确的方法。” 当你所在组织中的某个人提出了一个比你推崇了数周甚至数月的想法更好的主意，并且让你感到高兴时，你就是一个真诚的沟通者和合作者。
A leader who just wants to hear “yes” is like a child who only wants to eat candy. Soon the youngster’s teeth are gone. Likewise, a leader who wants people standing in line to agree with him or her will soon be history, having sailed into the sunset as captain of the ship of fools.
一个只想听到“是”的领导者，就像一个只想吃糖的孩子。很快，孩子的牙齿就会掉光。同样，一个只想让排队的人都同意他/她的领导者，很快就会被时代淘汰，就像一艘愚人船的船长，最终驶向夕阳。
This involves setting aside your ego, resisting the temptation to let the world know how smart you are or think you are. If you’re doing your job, the team will recognize your abilities. In turn, you must recognize their talent and bring forth their potential in a collaborative way.
这意味着要放下自我，克制住想要炫耀自己聪明才智的冲动。如果你尽职尽责，团队自然会认可你的能力。反过来，你也必须认可他们的才能，并以协作的方式激发他们的潜力。
A sales manager who resists input from his or her sales team automatically limits its potential; a manager who holds forth at the conference table might as well be sitting there alone; a football coach with small ears and a big ego will soon be watching the game on television at home instead of from the sidelines.
销售经理如果拒绝听取销售团队的意见，就会限制团队的潜力；经理如果在会议上滔滔不绝，那还不如独自一人坐在那里；足球教练如果耳朵小、自负，很快就会在家里的电视机前看比赛，而不是在场边指挥。
“Listen and learn” isn’t a bad motto; neither is “Listen and lead.” In most organizations the leader’s example sets the tone for everyone else. One of the greatest and most neglected skills in leadership is the ability to listen. If someone told me that leadership is as easy as one, two, three, I’d reply, “Only if the one, two, and three are as follows:
1. Listen
2. Learn
3. Lead”
“倾听和学习”并非坏格言；“倾听和领导”亦然。在大多数组织中，领导者的榜样会为其他人定下基调。领导力中最重要却又最常被忽视的技能之一就是倾听能力。如果有人告诉我领导力就像一二三一样简单，我会回答：“只有当这三步分别是：1. 倾听；2. 学习；3. 领导”时，领导力才算简单。
Fourteen of the assistant coaches who worked with me at San Francisco went on to head coaching jobs in the NFL or at the college level. I believe a big part of the reason for this extraordinary upward mobility was that they were fully included in the communication and collaborative decision-making process during their tenures with me. They were also good listeners.
在旧金山与我共事的14位助理教练后来都成为了NFL或大学球队的主教练。我认为他们取得如此卓越的晋升，很大程度上是因为在我手下工作期间，他们充分参与了沟通和协作决策过程。而且，他们也都是优秀的倾听者。
They did well because our organization valued communication and collaboration; I did well for the same reason. Everybody can be a winner when “Be a Good Listener” is at the top of your leadership mission statement. Good collaboration begins with big ears.
他们表现出色，是因为我们组织重视沟通与协作；我也同样表现出色。当“善于倾听”成为领导使命宣言的首要原则时，每个人都能成为赢家。良好的协作始于倾听。

Create Uncertainty 制造不确定性
Great leaders are not necessarily predictable people. One of the best I’ve ever known is Pete Newell, who for many years was head basketball coach at the University of California-Berkeley. Among other things, his team won the national championship—March Madness—in 1959, and he was later voted Coach of the Year. His teams were consistently competitive, well taught, and among the nation’s best.
伟大的领导者未必都是循规蹈矩的人。我认识的最优秀的领导者之一是皮特·纽厄尔，他曾多年担任加州大学伯克利分校篮球队的主教练。他的球队在1959年赢得了全国冠军——“疯狂三月”锦标赛的冠军，他本人也因此被评为年度最佳教练。他的球队始终保持着强大的竞争力，训练有素，并且是全美最优秀的球队之一。
Coach Newell did lots of things right, but I was particularly intrigued by his ability to keep individuals sharp and on their toes—to keep them from falling into a mental comfort zone, which can occur when the person in charge becomes too predictable. This comfort zone is dangerous because it creates an often almost imperceptible lowering of intensity, focus, and energy, which leads directly to reduced effort, additional mistakes, and diminished performance.
纽维尔教练做对了很多事情，但我尤其欣赏他让队员们保持敏锐和警觉的能力——他能防止队员们陷入心理上的舒适区，而这种舒适区往往发生在领导者过于循规蹈矩的时候。这种舒适区很危险，因为它会在不知不觉中降低队员们的强度、专注力和精力，从而直接导致努力程度降低、失误增多和整体表现下降。
Watching Pete’s Golden Bears during practices at their gym in Berke ley, I saw that he could suddenly become very worked up, severe, and critical—lashing out without warning or apparent cause. He would spot some minor miscue, and suddenly everything would change. It was something to witness—out of the blue, lightning and thunder from Newell over seemingly nothing situations.
在伯克利体育馆观看皮特的金熊队训练时，我发现他有时会突然变得非常激动、严厉和挑剔——毫无预兆地发火，也没有任何明显的原因。他会注意到一些小小的失误，然后一切都会立刻改变。亲眼目睹这一切真是令人震惊——纽厄尔会因为一些看似无关紧要的小事，突然间像雷霆般暴跳如雷。
And then just as quickly—usually, but not always—his verbal and emotional squall would pass. When he had addressed the little “issue” that had set him off, Pete would become lighthearted and even engage in humor as the practice resumed. But it was evident the players were now on edge and would subsequently ebb and flow with his demeanor, attitude, and emotions—looking to him for a response and reacting to his behavior. He was the focal point the others responded to.
然后，通常——但并非总是如此——他的言语和情绪风暴就会很快平息下来。当他解决了引发他情绪的小“问题”之后，皮特就会变得轻松愉快，甚至在训练继续进行时还会开些玩笑。但很明显，球员们此时都有些紧张，他们的情绪、态度和举止都会受到他的影响——他们都在关注他的反应，并根据他的行为做出相应的反应。他是其他人反应的焦点。
Of course, the little “issue” that had set him off—for example, a pass that he declared not crisp—was often an excuse to fix the larger concern, which was usually the level, or lack thereof, of intensity, energy, and attention.
当然，让他生气的那个小“问题”（例如，他认为传球不够干脆利落）通常只是一个借口，用来解决更大的问题，而更大的问题通常是强度、能量和注意力的水平（或缺乏水平）。
Players were kept on their toes because Pete Newell was somewhat unpredictable. They knew that a toughness lurked within and that he was willing and able to bring it forth if he felt it necessary. It kept them on their toes.
球员们始终保持警惕，因为皮特·纽厄尔有些难以捉摸。他们知道他骨子里透着一股强硬劲儿，而且如果他认为有必要，他随时准备也有能力展现出来。这让他们时刻保持警惕。
Effective leaders often have this quality. They understand that if you’re predictably difficult or predictably easygoing, others become predictably comfortable. In a highly competitive environment, feeling comfortable is first cousin to being complacent.
高效的领导者通常具备这种特质。他们明白，如果你总是表现得过于强势或过于随和，其他人也会变得习以为常。在竞争激烈的环境中，安于现状往往与自满无异。
Personally, when I sensed from time to time that our team or staff was getting comfortable, I wasn’t afraid to exercise whatever acting skills I could summon. During a practice that was lacking high energy and laser-like focus, I might suddenly just let my emotions boil over, throw down my clipboard, chew out an assistant coach (they knew what I was up to), and exhibit the emotions and language I’d seen Pete Newell display so effectively: “I can’t take this anymore! We’ve got to pick it up or I’m gonna make some changes here, because this has got to stop!” The players didn’t even know what “this” was. It didn’t matter.
就我个人而言，每当我感觉到我们的团队或工作人员开始懈怠时，我都会毫不犹豫地使出浑身解数。在训练中，如果队员们缺乏高昂的斗志和高度的专注力，我可能会突然情绪爆发，扔掉手中的记事板，狠狠地训斥助理教练（他们知道我的意图），然后像皮特·纽厄尔那样，用他那套行之有效的语言和情绪吼道：“我受够了！我们必须振作起来，否则我就要做出一些改变了，这种情况必须停止！”队员们甚至不知道“这种情况”指的是什么。但这无关紧要。
What I was doing in that instance was for effect, something to shatter their comfort zones. Having jarred their attention, given them a jolt, I’d get right back to business. Rarely would I get personal or do any damage. It was a somewhat contrived outburst that served like the snarl of a tiger when you get too close to its cage. Used sparingly, it is an effective leadership tool.
我当时的做法是为了制造效果，打破他们的舒适区。在引起他们的注意、让他们警醒之后，我会立刻回到正题。我很少会进行人身攻击或造成任何伤害。这是一种略显刻意的爆发，就像老虎靠近笼子时发出的咆哮。如果使用得当，它是一种有效的领导工具。
The people around you must feel somewhat on edge with you at times because they know there’s another side of your personality—ill at ease because they don’t always know what to expect and have come to understand there’s a toughness within you. Ideally, those you lead are driven to excel by the expertise, example, inspiration, and motivation you offer—the Standard of Performance you define and personify—but sometimes you have to snarl to remind them of the consequences of straying from your standards.
你身边的人有时难免会感到有些不安，因为他们知道你性格中还有另一面——他们感到不自在，因为他们不知道该如何应对，也逐渐意识到你内心深处其实很坚强。理想情况下，你所领导的人会因为你提供的专业知识、榜样、启发和动力而努力追求卓越——这就是你所定义和践行的绩效标准——但有时你必须严厉警告他们，让他们明白违背你的标准会带来怎样的后果。
This is part of the tough (at times severe) side of leadership necessary to eliminate a comfort zone, which can creep into an organization and keep it from pushing on to higher and higher levels. One of the tools I used to accomplish this was to emulate Pete Newell—to shake things up with a somewhat contrived show of temper that comes from nowhere and disappears just as quickly.
这是领导力中强硬（有时甚至是严厉）的一面，它能打破舒适区，防止舒适区悄然渗入组织，阻碍其不断进步。我用来达到这个目的的方法之一，就是效仿皮特·纽厄尔——突然爆发一场略显刻意的暴脾气，然后又迅速消失，以此来打破现状。
There are times, of course, when a snarl must be replaced with a bite, when you are not acting, but instead taking serious action. One year during practice at our training camp in Rocklin, California, a rookie lineman, a muscular and swaggering guy trying out for the squad, broke through the offensive line and got to Joe Montana. At that point, he knew what to do, namely, nothing. You do not make contact with our quarterback during practice drills or plays.
当然，有时候，咆哮必须转化为实际行动，你不能只是装腔作势，而是要采取严肃的行动。有一年，在我们位于加州罗克林的训练营里，一名身材魁梧、趾高气扬的新秀前锋，为了争取加入球队，突破了进攻防线，直奔乔·蒙塔纳而去。当时，他很清楚该怎么做，那就是什么都不要做。在训练或比赛中，你不能和我们的四分卫有任何身体接触。
This fellow didn’t follow the rule. Apparently to show us what a great tackler he was—or maybe he was just stupid—he proceeded to deck Joe with a vicious hit. It’s not overstating it to say this guy put our whole season on the line for an instant. I fired him right there, before Joe even got back up on his feet. “Get that son of a bitch out of here,” I yelled at an assistant coach. “Right now. Don’t even let that son of a bitch take a shower!”
这家伙不守规矩。他显然是为了向我们炫耀他那高超的擒抱技巧——或许他只是蠢——狠狠地撞倒了乔。毫不夸张地说，这家伙差点让我们整个赛季都毁了。乔还没站起来，我就把他炒了。“把那狗娘养的弄出去！”我冲着一个助理教练吼道，“马上！别让他有机会洗澡！”
Sometimes you snarl; sometimes you bite; sometimes you smile and give a thumbs-up. There’s a little bit of the actor in all good leaders.
有时候你会咆哮；有时候你会咬人；有时候你会微笑并竖起大拇指。所有优秀的领导者身上都带有一点表演的特质。

Play with Poise 沉着冷静地比赛
Leadership requires poise under pressure. An organization that wit nesses its leader at loose ends when troubles arise will look elsewhere for strength and direction. Knowing in advance what I would do in various situations—for example, scripting a game—was insurance that I could stay poised when it counted. Here’s a good example of how it stabilized my thinking and behavior in a high-pressure, pivotal game that was played under arctic conditions and afforded the winner a trip to the Super Bowl.
领导力要求在压力下保持沉着冷静。如果领导者在遇到问题时束手无策，组织就会另寻他人来提供力量和方向。提前预知在各种情况下该如何应对——例如，事先制定比赛策略——就像是确保我在关键时刻能够保持冷静的保障。以下就是一个很好的例子，它展现了这种策略如何在严寒条件下进行的一场高压关键比赛中稳定我的思维和行为，而这场比赛的胜者将获得超级碗的入场券。
The 49ers had arrived in Chicago during an arctic cold-snap to face the Bears at Soldier Field in a game that would decide the NFC championship. Local fans and media had started proclaiming the Bears “the Team of Destiny” because, after preseason media reports suggesting the team was fading, they had gone 12-4 during the regular season.
49人队在寒风凛冽的芝加哥抵达，准备在士兵球场迎战熊队，这场比赛将决定NFC冠军的归属。当地球迷和媒体开始称熊队为“天命之队”，因为在季前赛媒体报道熊队状态下滑之后，他们在常规赛中取得了12胜4负的战绩。
Having won Super Bowl XX three years earlier, they were now a game away from a return trip, and Chicago had begun to celebrate early. Why? Because their opponents were coming in from the West Coast, meaning they were “wine-sipping, Brie-eating, effete athletes,” as one popular Midwest image of the 49ers had it. Adding substance to that characterization was our tough 10-9 midseason loss to the Bears in a game at Chicago.
三年前赢得第二十届超级碗后，他们距离重返超级碗仅一步之遥，芝加哥人早已开始提前庆祝。为什么？因为他们的对手来自西海岸，这意味着他们是“爱喝葡萄酒、吃布里奶酪、娘娘腔的运动员”，就像中西部地区对49人队的一个流行刻板印象。而我们在赛季中期客场以9比10惜败给芝加哥熊队，更是印证了这种刻板印象。
During the warm-up in freezing conditions, Chicago’s big and seemingly less intelligent linemen were parading around in short shirtsleeves and strutting their stuff like tough guys. Some of the 49ers looked over and wondered, “What’s wrong with them? They’re gonna freeze to death.” But the posturing continued, a little psychology to intimidate or embarrass us. (The previous season, in San Francisco, the Bears had lost to the 49ers 41-0. Immediately after the final gun, Mike Ditka, a tempestuous, in-your-face coach, had reacted to our cheering fans by hurling his gum into the stands on his way to the locker room. Of course, he got three hundred pieces of gum thrown right back at him. Somebody even filed assault charges for being hit by Ditka’s wad of gum. The Chicago media, of course, played this up in the days before our NFC championship game.)
在冰天雪地的热身赛中，芝加哥那些身材高大、看起来头脑简单的进攻锋线球员穿着短袖衬衫，趾高气扬地四处走动，摆出一副硬汉的姿态。一些49人队的球员看着他们，心想：“他们怎么了？他们快要冻死了。” 但他们的摆拍仍在继续，这显然是想用一些心理战术来恐吓或羞辱我们。（上个赛季，在旧金山，熊队以0比41惨败给49人队。比赛结束后，脾气暴躁、咄咄逼人的教练迈克·迪特卡看到我们球迷的欢呼声，便将手中的口香糖扔进了看台，然后径直走向更衣室。当然，他立刻遭到了300多块口香糖的回击。甚至有人因为被迪特卡扔回来的口香糖砸中而提起人身攻击诉讼。芝加哥媒体当然在NFC冠军赛前的几天里大肆渲染了这件事。）
Now I was in Chicago with their screaming fans, the wind howling with a twenty-six-below-zero windchill and the entire season at stake. In addition to all the play-off pressure and other distractions, there was this: Right behind our bench was a Cyclone fence holding spectators back. Standing at the fence was an inebriated Bears fan with a big megaphone that could have called across the Great Lakes. The guy had picked his spot carefully, because his plan was to ride me mercilessly during the game.
现在我身处芝加哥，周围是熊队球迷的呐喊，寒风呼啸，体感温度零下26度，整个赛季的成败都悬于一线。除了季后赛的压力和其他种种干扰之外，还有一件事：就在我们替补席后面，一道防撞围栏挡住了观众。围栏边站着一个醉醺醺的熊队球迷，手里拿着一个大喇叭，声音大到能传到五大湖对面。这家伙显然是精心挑选了位置，因为他打算在比赛中狠狠地羞辱我。
Before it even started, he was shouting through his megaphone, with the volume turned up, about my anatomy, which he decided was not adequate for most males. He questioned my sexual preferences, with accompanying speculation. This went on and on—really crude stuff, but as the game progressed and it got colder and colder, his mouth began to freeze up. He’d try to say, “Walsh, you’ve got a big fat a-a-a-a-a-sssssss,” until finally he couldn’t even talk any more. You would think I could tune out somebody like that, but it’s tough. It was just another factor that could easily have interfered with my focus and decision-making abilities. It didn’t.
比赛还没开始，他就拿着扩音器，音量开到最大，对我评头论足，说我的身材不符合大多数男性的标准。他还质疑我的性取向，并进行各种猜测。这种事没完没了——真是粗俗不堪，但随着比赛进行，天气越来越冷，他的嘴巴也开始僵住了。他努力想说：“沃尔什，你的屁股又大又肥”，直到最后连话都说不出来。你可能会觉得我应该能屏蔽掉这种人，但其实很难。这只是另一个很容易影响我专注力和决策能力的因素。但它并没有。
We had a well-designed game plan with thorough contingency options that were right in front of me on my clipboard. We stuck to the plans, because there was no way I could consistently make intelligent and rational decisions with the freezing wind, the noise, the cold, the megaphone man, the Bears’ great team, and sixty-seven thousand fans bearing down on us.
我们制定了一套周密的比赛计划，并准备了详尽的应急方案，这些都记录在我的战术板上。我们严格执行计划，因为在凛冽的寒风、嘈杂的噪音、刺骨的寒冷、扩音器里的呐喊、强大的熊队以及六万七千名球迷的包围下，我根本不可能始终做出明智理智的决定。
We won 28-3, and I defy anyone to think they’re so strong, so able, so gifted they can make clear-cut good decisions in the middle of that kind of pandemonium under that kind of stress.
我们以 28-3 获胜，我倒要看看有没有人会认为他们如此强大、如此有能力、如此有天赋，能够在那种混乱和压力下做出清晰正确的决定。
The San Francisco 49ers had talent and were well schooled. Neither matters if the person in charge falters or fails when it matters most. Having a clear idea of what your options are—situational planning—helps you be a leader when leadership is required.
旧金山49人队天赋异禀，训练有素。但如果负责人临危不乱，在最关键的时刻失职或失败，这一切都将毫无意义。清晰了解自己的选择——也就是进行情境规划——才能在需要领导的时候发挥领导作用。
Two weeks later, we won Super Bowl XXIII.
两周后，我们赢得了第23届超级碗。

Teaching Defines Your Leadership 教学塑造你的领导力
People say there are winners and losers in life. But typically, it’s more like this: There are winners, and there are people who would like to be winners but just don’t know how to do it. Intelligent and talented people who are motivated can learn how to become winners if they have someone who will teach them.
人们常说人生有赢家和输家。但通常情况下，情况更接近于此：有些人是赢家，有些人渴望成为赢家，却不知如何实现。聪明有才华且积极进取的人，只要有人指导，就能学会如何成为赢家。
Leadership, at its best, is exactly that: teaching skills, attitudes, and goals (yes, goals are both defined and taught) to individuals who are part of your organization. Most things in life require good teaching—raising a family and educating children, running a company or sales team, or coaching athletes—so it’s unfortunate that more people don’t spend the time and thought required to do it effectively.
领导力，其精髓就在于此：向组织成员传授技能、态度和目标（没错，目标既需要定义也需要传授）。生活中大多数事情都需要有效的指导——养育子女、管理公司或销售团队、指导运动员——因此，令人遗憾的是，很多人并没有投入足够的时间和精力来有效地做到这一点。
I was fortunate in this area, because I learned through the observation and study of tremendous teachers. Consequently, when I look back on my years as an assistant coach and head coach, what gives me great satisfaction is not necessarily a Super Bowl championship or an award, but the experience of recognizing ability in a person and then teaching that individual how to reach his potential in ways that helped our team.
我在这方面很幸运，因为我通过观察和学习一些非常优秀的老师而获益匪浅。因此，当我回顾自己担任助理教练和主教练的那些年时，真正让我感到满足的并非超级碗冠军或任何奖项，而是发现一个人的才能，并指导他如何发挥自身潜力，从而帮助球队取得进步。
That process—seeing someone I had evaluated, selected, and taught break out and do great things—is what it’s really all about for me, the source of my greatest pleasure in leadership. In my experience, this is what it takes to be a good teacher: passion, expertise, communication, and persistence.
对我而言，看到我评估、选拔和培养的人脱颖而出、成就斐然，这才是领导工作的真正意义所在，也是我作为领导者最大的乐趣所在。依我之见，成为一名优秀的教师需要具备以下素质：热情、专业知识、沟通能力和坚持不懈。

1. Passion is not just having a desire to do the job of teaching.

1. 热情不仅仅是渴望从事教学工作。

Passion is a love for the act of teaching itself—believing in your heart that it is not a means to an end, but an end in itself. In order to have passion, you must love the topic you teach. My love of football and teaching it is so strong that when I was a coach it became hard to shut my mind off and think about something else.
激情是对教学本身的热爱——发自内心地相信教学不是达到目的的手段，而是目的本身。要拥有激情，你必须热爱你所教授的科目。我对足球和足球教学的热爱如此强烈，以至于当我担任教练时，我很难让自己的思绪从足球中抽离出来，去想其他的事情。
I might be half asleep or dreaming, or talking to someone, and my mind would drift away from the conversation and a play would take shape in my mind. I could see all twenty-two players moving in response to what I had drawn up.
我可能半睡半醒，也可能在做梦，或者在和人聊天，思绪会突然飘离谈话，脑海中浮现出一出戏的雏形。我能看到二十二名球员根据我设计的剧本做出相应的动作。
Diagrams of plays kept flowing through my head—the X ’s and O ’s, the lines and arrows going through my mind constantly, like a computer’s screen saver where the objects keep changing shape and moving around.
战术图解不断在我脑海中浮现——X 和 O，线条和箭头不断地在我脑海中穿梭，就像电脑屏幕保护程序一样，上面的物体不断改变形状和移动。
Once during a get-together with friends, I was sitting on a couch in front of the fireplace with my arm around my wife, Geri. Unconsciously I began diagramming a passing play on her shoulder with my index finger while carrying on a conversation with someone across the room.
有一次和朋友聚会，我坐在壁炉前的沙发上，手臂搭在妻子格里的肩上。我一边和房间另一头的人聊天，一边不知不觉地用食指在她肩膀上画出传球的示意图。
After a while, Geri looked at me and asked, “Honey, did it score a touchdown?” I didn’t know what she was talking about until she told me; I didn’t know I had been drawing a play on her arm with my finger. That’s how much I love it; that’s how much you need to love teaching your team. It is not a duty or burden that you get out of the way so you can move on to “important” things. It is the important thing.
过了一会儿，格里看着我问：“亲爱的，它达阵了吗？” 直到她告诉我，我才明白她在说什么；我之前根本不知道自己一直在用手指在她胳膊上画战术。这就是我有多热爱这项运动；这就是你必须有多热爱教你的队员。这不是一项职责或负担，你不需要把它推掉，然后去做其他“重要”的事情。它本身就是最重要的事。
For me it was a fundamental source of personal joy. I was consumed by the process of developing the abilities of others. You do it because you really care for it; you do it because you have to.
对我而言，这是个人快乐的重要来源。我全身心投入到培养他人能力的过程中。你做这件事是因为你真心热爱它；你做这件事是因为你不得不做。

2. Expertise is the inventory of knowledge and experience you possess on a particular subject.

2. 专业技能是指你在某一特定领域所拥有的知识和经验的积累。

You’re not necessarily born with it; you develop it, research it, thrive on learning as much about your subject as you possibly can.
这并非与生俱来；而是需要后天培养、研究，尽可能多地学习相关知识才能精通。
The greater your expertise, the greater your potential to teach, the stronger and more productive you can be as a leader. Without it you are disabled and will garner less and less respect from your team because they will sense that you’re not on top of things, let alone able to teach them something meaningful. People know when you don’t have the answers.
你的专业知识越丰富，你的教学潜力就越大，作为领导者你就越强大、越高效。反之，如果你缺乏专业知识，你就会束手无策，团队也会越来越不尊重你，因为他们会感觉到你对事情一无所知，更别提教给他们一些有意义的东西了。人们一眼就能看出你是否掌握答案。
Here’s a good rule of thumb: “The more you know, the higher you go.” To advance in any profession, I believe it is imperative to understand all aspects of that profession, not just one particular area: Only expertise makes you an expert.
一条很好的经验法则是：“知识越多，晋升越高。” 我认为，要想在任何行业取得进步，必须了解该行业的方方面面，而不仅仅是某个特定领域：只有精通才能成为专家。
When assistant coaches approach me and ask, “Bill, what is the best route to getting a head coaching position?” I tell them they must expand their base of knowledge and develop their inventory of skills and profi ciencies in all phases of the job: “You may be an offensive coordinator and making more money than your offensive line coach who’s reporting to you, but unless you know offensive line coaching, he’s the de facto offensive coordinator. He determines your fate, because he knows more than you do.”
当助理教练来问我：“比尔，怎样才能成为主教练？”我会告诉他们，他们必须拓展知识面，提升在工作各个环节的技能和能力：“你或许是进攻协调员，收入比你的进攻线教练高，但除非你懂进攻线训练，否则他才是实际上的进攻协调员。他决定你的命运，因为他比你懂得更多。”
Your team will sense it, that you are not as knowledgeable in what you do as you should be. They will sense that you don’t have the answers, that you lack a strong understanding of the “how” of doing things. When this occurs, they will not follow you.
你的团队会察觉到，你对自己的工作不够精通。他们会感觉到你没有答案，对做事的“方法”缺乏深刻的理解。当这种情况发生时，他们就不会追随你。
A teacher gains expertise by seeking out great teachers, mentors, and other sources of information and wisdom in a relentless effort to add to his or her own knowledge. My teachers—outstanding in their own particular ways—included John Ralston at Stanford; Al Davis at Oakland (and by default, the great Sid Gillman under whom Al had served in San Diego with the Chargers); the Bengals’ Paul Brown; Tommy Prothro of the San Diego Chargers; Bob Bronzan, my coach at San Jose State, where I was a wide receiver; and others who showed me the value of teaching and how to do it. (In business this means actively seeking the counsel of those you respect in your profession, as well as studying printed material and publications that you determine will provide pertinent input.)
教师要想积累专业知识，就必须不断寻求优秀教师、导师以及其他信息和智慧的来源，孜孜不倦地充实自己的学识。我的老师们——他们各有千秋——包括斯坦福大学的约翰·拉尔斯顿；奥克兰大学的阿尔·戴维斯（顺便也包括伟大的西德·吉尔曼，阿尔曾在圣地亚哥闪电队效力于吉尔曼麾下）；辛辛那提猛虎队的保罗·布朗；圣地亚哥闪电队的汤米·普罗索；我在圣何塞州立大学担任外接手时的教练鲍勃·布朗赞；以及其他让我明白教学价值和方法的老师们。（在商业领域，这意味着积极寻求你所尊敬的业内人士的建议，并研读你认为能够提供相关见解的印刷资料和出版物。）

3. Communication is the ability to organize and then successfully convey your informed thoughts.

3. 沟通是组织和成功传达你所掌握的思想的能力。

Many mistakenly believe that just presenting facts—information—is teaching. Successful teaching is a two-way process. Just as a pass is not successful until the receiver catches it, successful teaching requires reception, retention, and comprehension of your message. Some teach by word, others by deed—their example is the teacher. The best teaching uses both forms of communication, word and deed. And in all situations, enthusiasm for the subject matter is what powers the communication connection to those you teach.
许多人误以为仅仅呈现事实——信息——就是教学。成功的教学是一个双向互动的过程。正如传球只有被接住才算成功一样，成功的教学也需要被接收、记住并理解你的信息。有些人用言语教学，有些人用行动教学——他们的榜样就是老师。最好的教学是将言语和行动这两种沟通方式结合起来。而且在任何情况下，对教学内容的热情才是与被教学者建立有效沟通的关键。
I have spent literally thousands of hours in front of an overhead projector diagramming and explaining plays to a bunch of easily bored athletes sitting on hard metal chairs and taking notes in a dimly lit room with bad ventilation. This can get dull fast, even if you’re the player in the diagram who’s going to be carrying the ball for a touchdown.
我曾无数次坐在投影仪前，给一群坐在硬邦邦的金属椅子上、在通风不良的昏暗房间里做笔记的、很容易感到无聊的运动员讲解战术图。即使你是图上那个即将持球达阵的球员，这种工作也会很快变得枯燥乏味。
To me, the intricacies and potential of each individual play were exciting; each one was like a ten-thousand-dollar Rolex watch with unique, highly crafted, and precision-made features that I cherished. I wanted to convey my sincere enthusiasm and real excitement to the players.
对我而言，每场比赛的精妙之处和无限潜力都令人兴奋不已；每场比赛都像一块价值一万美元的劳力士腕表，拥有独特、精湛且精准的工艺，令我倍感珍惜。我渴望将这份真挚的热情和激动传递给球员们。
I did it with facial and body language—moving assuredly and with energy, rubbing my hands together as if I were savoring a fine meal. And I did it with an enthusiastic tone of voice and positive words. The goal was to get the team as enthusiastic and excited as I was about the play’s potential. I couldn’t do it by reciting information as if I were reading from a phone book.
我运用面部表情和肢体语言来表达——动作自信而充满活力，双手搓动，仿佛在品味一顿美味佳肴。我还用热情洋溢的语气和积极的措辞来表达。我的目标是让团队和我一样，对这部剧的潜力充满热情和兴奋。如果我像念电话簿一样背诵信息，是无法达到这个目的的。
Here is a list of descriptions I used to set up and create excitement for seven different plays during a presentation in preparation for a game with the Dallas Cowboys:
• “Guys, this one should knock ’em on their asses!”
• “Now, here’s one I think is almost perfect for us.”
• “I think we’re gonna have some fun with this one. It’s a beauty!”
• “Fellas, this next one should score . No question about it.”
• “Here’s one play that is really just excellent . Forget excellent. It’s better than excellent.”
• “ This one will work just great. You’ll see why right now.”
• “Oh, boy , this is terrific. Just look at what this one does!”
以下是我在为与达拉斯牛仔队的比赛做准备时，在演示中用来介绍和激发大家对七个不同战术的兴趣的描述：• “伙计们，这招肯定能把他们打趴下！”• “接下来这招我觉得对我们来说简直完美。”• “我觉得这招肯定能让我们玩得很开心。太漂亮了！”• “伙计们，下一个肯定能得分。毫无疑问。”• “这招简直太棒了。不，不是棒，是比棒还要棒。”• “这招肯定很管用。你们马上就会明白为什么了。”• “哇，这招太厉害了。看看这招的效果！”
Bang! Bang! Bang! Bang! Each one was something special, with its own special introduction and personality. Other teams might use just a number to identify a play. My plays were never just numbers to me, and I didn’t want them to be just numbers to our team. They were distinct entities with personality, character, and potential of their own. Never a number. They were my children, and I bragged about them like a proud parent.
砰！砰！砰！砰！每一个战术都独一无二，有着自己独特的介绍和个性。其他球队可能只会用数字来标识战术。但对我来说，我的战术绝不仅仅是数字，我也不希望它们对我们的球队来说仅仅是数字。它们是拥有个性、特色和潜力的独立个体。它们绝非数字。它们就像我的孩子，我像骄傲的父母一样为它们感到自豪。
After presenting the details of a specific play, I’d repeat a variation of my opening observation: “I’m telling you, we could have a five-hundred-yard day!” or, “Wait’ll they see this one coming. They won’t know what hit ’em!” I started and finished my description with nothing but optimism, enthusiasm , and belief. Never a caveat, no “ifs,” no hesitancy.
在详细描述完某个战术之后，我会重复一遍开场白：“我跟你说，我们今天能拿下五百码！”或者，“等着瞧吧，他们肯定会被打得措手不及！”我的描述从始至终都充满乐观、热情和信念。从不留任何疑虑，从不说“如果”，也从不犹豫。
My body language and positive words were never contrived, phony, or overdone. I genuinely had great affection—love, in fact—for what I was teaching. But X ’s and O ’s, squiggly lines, and squares and circles with arrows pointing in various directions can be boring, even deadening when presented without energy and enthusiasm. I wanted to convey to the team that what I was offering them was alive, that it had magic in it. I made sure my demeanor conveyed that; I showed them I really cared. You must do the same if you want to light a fire in those you lead.
我的肢体语言和积极的言辞从不矫揉造作、虚假做作或过分夸张。我真心热爱我所教授的内容。但是，如果缺乏活力和热情，那些X、O、弯弯曲曲的线条、方框和圆圈，以及指向各个方向的箭头，就会变得枯燥乏味，甚至令人窒息。我想让团队感受到，我所提供的知识是鲜活的，蕴含着魔力。我确保我的举止能够传达这一点；我让他们看到我真心在乎他们。如果你想点燃你所带领的团队的热情，你也必须这样做。
Your enthusiasm becomes their enthusiasm; your lukewarm presentation becomes their lukewarm interest in what you’re offering.
你的热情会感染他们，你的冷淡只会让他们对你提供的产品或服务产生冷淡的兴趣。
I came to understand over my years as an assistant coach that when the audience is bored, it’s not their fault. And when they’re plugged in and excited, it’s because of you, the person in charge.
多年担任助理教练的经历让我明白，当观众感到无聊时，那不是他们的错。而当他们全神贯注、兴奋不已时，那是因为你，是负责人。

4. Persistence is essential because knowledge is rarely imparted on the first attempt.

4. 坚持不懈至关重要，因为知识很少能一次成功传授。

One of the keys to successfully executing the complexities of the West Coast Offense was my devotion to the principle of persistence.
成功执行西海岸进攻战术的关键之一，是我对坚持不懈原则的坚持。
We did the same drills over and over again; I said essentially the same thing over and over, discussed the same information, concepts, and principles over and over. Gradually, my teaching stuck. Eventually, successful execution became almost automatic, even under extreme duress, because like air, my teaching was everywhere.
我们一遍又一遍地重复同样的练习；我一遍又一遍地重复同样的话，一遍又一遍地讨论同样的信息、概念和原则。渐渐地，我的教学深入人心。最终，即使在极端压力下，也能几乎自动地成功执行，因为我的教学就像空气一样无处不在。

While passion, expertise, communication, and persistence are the four essentials of good teaching and learning, I would also add these nuts-and-bolts practices to facilitate what you do as a leader who is a great teacher:
1. Use straightforward language. No need to get fancy.
2. Be concise. For many leaders it’s harder to be brief than to be long-winded. We love to hear ourselves talk.
3. Account for a wide range of difference in knowledge, experience, and comprehension among members of your organization. For me it could be seen in the way I communicated one on one with an experienced superstar such as Jerry Rice or a first-year offensive guard who was learning the ropes of our system. This difference in content depending on whom I was talking to and in what circumstance was always factored in to my teaching.
4. Account for some members of the group being more receptive and ready to learn than others (for reasons out of your control).
5. Be observant during your comments. Know if you’re connecting.
6. Strongly encourage note taking.
7. Employ a somewhat unpredictable presentation style. “Droning on” is the most common style, and you may have to work on stepping it up so that you don’t fall into the “drone trap.”
8. Organize with logical, sequential building blocks in your communication.
9. Encourage appropriate audience participation.
10. Use visual aids.
11. Remember Sun-tzu: “With more sophistication comes more control.” The more you work at refining your teaching—increasing its sophistication—the greater your control of the teaching (and learning) process.
热情、专业知识、沟通和坚持是优秀教学的四大要素，除此之外，我还想补充以下几点切实可行的做法，以帮助您成为一名优秀的领导者和教师：1. 使用简洁明了的语言，无需华丽辞藻。2. 言简意赅。对许多领导者来说，言简意赅比长篇大论更难。我们都喜欢滔滔不绝。3. 考虑到组织成员在知识、经验和理解力方面的差异。例如，我与经验丰富的超级巨星（如杰里·赖斯）或正在学习我们体系的第一年进攻后卫进行一对一交流时，会根据谈话对象和具体情况调整教学内容。4. 考虑到小组中某些成员比其他成员更容易接受新知识、更愿意学习（这并非您所能控制）。5. 在发言时保持观察，确保自己与听众建立了联系。6. 强烈建议记笔记。 7. 采用略微出人意料的演讲风格。“滔滔不绝”是最常见的风格，你可能需要努力提升演讲水平，以免落入“冗长乏味”的陷阱。8. 在沟通中运用逻辑清晰、循序渐进的模块进行组织。9. 鼓励适当的听众参与。10. 使用视觉辅助工具。11. 记住孙子兵法：“技艺精湛，掌控自如。”你越努力改进教学——提高教学的精湛程度——你对教学（和学习）过程的掌控力就越强。

The Thrill of Teaching 教学的乐趣
Now that I’ve outlined my ideas about teaching, it should not surprise you to know that the most gratifying time of my life as a teacher was probably not with the San Francisco 49ers. It was much earlier, when I was with the Cincinnati Bengals, when I was personally responsible for teaching a wide assortment of skills and ideas to a diverse group of individuals—quarterbacks, wide receivers, tight ends—and creating and implementing the passing game. And I did this all without the great responsibilities that come with being a head coach, with the “distractions” that took me away from teaching.
既然我已经阐述了我的教学理念，那么你应该不会惊讶地发现，我作为教师生涯中最有成就感的时光，或许并非是在旧金山49人队。而是更早的时候，我在辛辛那提猛虎队执教时。那时，我负责向一群背景各异的球员——四分卫、外接手、近端锋——传球战术的制定和实施，并教授他们各种各样的技能和理念。而且，我当时并没有像现在这样，肩负起主教练的重任，也没有那些会分散我教学精力的“干扰”。
During practice at Cincinnati, I would devote a specific amount of time exclusively to the wide receivers, at other times just the quarterbacks, then the entire offense; later I would work alone on offensive schemes and then teach them to others. I was always teaching or thinking about how to be more effective as a teacher.
在辛辛那提训练期间，我会专门抽出一段时间指导外接手，有时只指导四分卫，有时则指导整个进攻组；之后我会独自研究进攻战术，然后再教给其他人。我总是在教别人，或者思考如何才能更有效地教书。
Today four different coaches would be hired to handle these jobs, but I was lucky in being able to do them all—no administrative duties, no executive responsibilities, no financial issues as I assumed with the 49ers. Just plain, old-fashioned teaching. I was a kid in a candy store and loved it all—every single minute of it.
如果放在今天，这些工作可能需要聘请四位不同的教练来负责，但我很幸运能够全部胜任——没有行政职责，没有管理责任，也没有像在49人队时那样处理财务问题。只是单纯地、传统的教学。我当时就像个进了糖果店的孩子，无比享受这一切——每一分钟都让我无比快乐。
When my results were productive, it was even more satisfying—Bruce Coslet became an outstanding tight end and later head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals; Bob Trumpy became an All-Pro tight end; Chip Myers, Isaac Curtis, and Charlie Joiner were All-Pro wide receivers; Virgil Carter maximized his quarterbacking skills, Ken Anderson led the NFL in passing and was an MVP. But the deepest satisfaction was in the process of teaching itself. Witnessing the evolution of their abilities and seeing it applied in the context of our organization—and on the field during games—was the source of great gratification.
当我的指导取得成效时，我更是感到无比欣慰——布鲁斯·科斯莱特成为了一名杰出的近端锋，后来又担任了辛辛那提猛虎队的主教练；鲍勃·特鲁姆皮成为了一名全明星近端锋；奇普·迈尔斯、艾萨克·柯蒂斯和查理·乔伊纳都成为了全明星外接手；维吉尔·卡特充分发挥了他的四分卫才能；肯·安德森荣膺NFL传球王并当选MVP。但最深层的满足感来自于教学过程本身。亲眼见证他们能力的提升，并看到这些能力在我们球队以及赛场上得到应用，这才是最大的成就感来源。
That Cincinnati experience was as much fun as I’ve ever had in football, maybe as gratifying as Super Bowl championships or financial rewards, because I had the opportunity to do more hands-on teaching than I did later on. It was just great fun. Although before the pressure and huge expectations got built up, the 49ers’ experience in the first few years was thrilling too. Both were so fulfilling for the same reason—teaching, helping people achieve higher and higher levels of performance in the context of competing (and often prevailing) in my profession. I suppose you could conclude that for me the process of getting to the top was much more gratifying in many ways than the process of trying to stay on top.
在辛辛那提的经历是我在橄榄球生涯中最快乐的时光之一，或许其满足感不亚于超级碗冠军或丰厚的经济回报，因为我获得了比后来更多的实践教学机会。那段经历真的非常棒。虽然在压力和巨大期望到来之前，旧金山49人队最初几年的经历也同样令人兴奋。这两段经历都让我感到无比充实，原因相同——那就是教学，帮助人们在我的职业竞争（并且往往最终获胜）的背景下不断提升自身水平。我想，你可以得出这样的结论：对我而言，攀登顶峰的过程在很多方面都比努力维持顶峰的过程更有成就感。
Interesting enough, many executives have told me they experience the same pleasure in developing and advancing the skills of their own employees. Companies led by good teachers, those with passion, expertise, communication skills, and persistence, do very well.
有趣的是，许多高管告诉我，他们在培养和提升员工技能的过程中也获得了同样的乐趣。那些由优秀的导师领导的公司——这些导师充满热情、拥有专业知识、沟通技巧和毅力——往往发展得非常成功。
Looking back, perhaps the lesson I would draw is this: If you don’t love it, don’t do it. I loved it—teaching people how to reach in deep to fulfill their potential, how to become great. And when you do that with a group, you, as the leader, enjoy the thrill of creating a great team. For me it was like creating a work of art. Only instead of painting on a canvas, I had the great joy of creating in collaboration with others.
回首往事，我或许能从中汲取的教训是：如果你不热爱它，就不要去做。我热爱这份工作——教导人们如何深入挖掘自身潜力，如何成就卓越。当你带领团队做到这一点时，作为领导者，你会享受到打造优秀团队的成就感。对我而言，这就像创作一件艺术品。只不过，我不是在画布上作画，而是与他人合作，共同创造，并从中获得巨大的喜悦。

THE WALSH WAY 沃尔什路
The House Cleaner 清洁工
Bill McPherson, Assistant Coach, San Francisco 49ers
比尔·麦克弗森，旧金山49人队助理教练







Starting day one as head coach and general manager of the San Francisco 49ers, Bill Walsh came in and started cleaning out the building of people—fired everybody that he could fire, like assistant coaches, staff, and office personnel. He couldn’t fire the players all at once, but he was quick to start getting rid of them, too, the ones who didn’t meet his performance or attitude standards.
比尔·沃尔什上任旧金山49人队主教练兼总经理的第一天起，就开始大刀阔斧地清洗球队——他能解雇的都解雇了，包括助理教练、工作人员和行政人员。他无法一次性解雇所有球员，但他很快就开始清理那些表现或态度不符合他标准的球员。
Within two years, much of the team he had inherited was gone. The Super Bowl champions his third year only had a few of the original hold overs. He had cleaned house.
不到两年，他接手的那支队伍大部分都已离队。在他执教的第三年，超级碗冠军队只剩下寥寥几名老队员。他彻底清洗了球队。
One coach he kept on from the prior administration, Mike White, he knew from when they had been assistant coaches together, and Bill liked his expertise and attitude. But there weren’t many, hardly any at all. He wanted people in his new organization who did it his way, and believe me, he had a crystal clear concept of what “his way” was.
他留用了前任管理层的一位教练，迈克·怀特。他们以前一起担任助理教练，比尔很欣赏怀特的专业能力和态度。但这样的人不多，几乎找不到。他希望新团队里的人都能按照他的方式行事，而且相信我，他对“他的方式”有着非常清晰的认识。
I knew Bill going back further than anybody in the organization when he hired me that first year—back to his days coaching football at Washington High School, and before that when I had seen him as a boxer.
我认识比尔的时间比组织里的任何人都早——在他第一年聘用我的时候，我就已经认识他了——那时他还在华盛顿高中执教橄榄球，在那之前，我还见过他打拳击。
Later, I was an assistant coach at Santa Clara College and he was coaching a semipro team called the San Jose Apaches. They were such a low-budget operation they didn’t even have their own football field to practice on—they worked out at nearby Wilcox High School. In fact, they didn’t even have their own projector to watch game film on. Bill would come over to Santa Clara College and use ours and while he was there basically give us his “chalk talks,” just casually explain his philosophy when it came to football. It was evident that his mind was extraordinary. He was a mismatch for the ragtag team he was in charge of—like a Formula 1 race car on a dirt track.
后来，我在圣克拉拉学院当助理教练，他执教一支叫圣何塞阿帕奇队的半职业球队。这支球队预算非常有限，甚至连自己的足球场都没有——他们只能在附近的威尔科克斯高中训练。事实上，他们连一台放映机都没有，用来播放比赛录像。比尔会来圣克拉拉学院，借用我们的设备，然后给我们讲解他的“战术指导”，也就是随意地阐述他对足球的理念。很明显，他的思维非常独特。他和这支他执教的杂牌军简直是天作之合——就像一辆一级方程式赛车在泥泞赛道上驰骋一样。
Nevertheless, I was surprised years later, when we began to work together at San Francisco, to see how comprehensive his knowledge was. He just had the whole thing thought out in his mind. Those staff meetings were really something, because it was apparent he knew exactly, precisely, what he wanted to do, which included exactly what he wanted us to do. And to make sure we did it, he gave us his big red binder playbook with all of his complex formations in it.
然而，几年后，当我们开始在旧金山共事时，我惊讶地发现他的知识面如此广博。他似乎已经把所有事情都考虑周全了。那些员工会议真是精彩纷呈，因为很明显，他非常清楚自己想要做什么，包括他希望我们做什么。为了确保我们能够执行他的指示，他还把那本厚厚的红色活页战术手册给了我们，里面记录着他所有复杂的阵型。
But it wasn’t like any regular playbook I’d ever seen. He had gone out and had it printed up almost like a textbook; routes and X ’s and O ’s were neat and clean— professional , not hand drawn and messy. Nobody had done it like that before. That’s what characterized everything Bill Walsh did: professionalism, first class.
但这跟我以前见过的任何普通战术手册都不一样。他把它打印出来，几乎跟教科书一样；路线、战术符号都整齐划一——专业，而不是手绘的杂乱无章。以前没人这么做过。这就是比尔·沃尔什做事的风格：专业，一流。
