Bill liked order. If he walked into an office and saw a picture hanging crooked, he’d go over and straighten it. That sounds silly, but it goes to his desire for precision in how things looked and were done—a picture on the wall had to be exactly right, and a play on the field had to be exactly right.
比尔喜欢秩序。如果他走进办公室，看到一幅画挂歪了，他就会走过去把它扶正。这听起来有点傻，但这体现了他对事物外观和做事方式的精准追求——墙上的画必须一丝不苟，球场上的每一个动作也必须精准无误。
That same attitude applied to media relations and the message the media got from the 49ers organization. One man gave the media the message: Bill Walsh. The coaches who worked with him were not supposed to talk to reporters about the team. Bill did that; Bill controlled the output of information to the media.
这种态度同样适用于媒体关系以及49人队向媒体传递的信息。只有一个人向媒体传达了信息：比尔·沃尔什。与他共事的教练们不应该接受记者关于球队的任何采访。比尔自己做了这件事；比尔控制着向媒体发布的信息。
He was a master at making us feel that we were persecuted by the outside world—discounted or ridiculed. Bill had a hundred different ways to get the team cranked up about having to prove to the media or other teams that they were wrong to dismiss us.
他很擅长让我们觉得我们受到了外界的迫害——被轻视或嘲笑。比尔有上百种方法可以激励球队，让我们觉得必须向媒体或其他球队证明，他们轻视我们是错误的。
He didn’t like showboating or anything that suggested somebody was better than anybody else in his organization. Mutual respect among all employees was big for him, and boy, if he saw evidence to the contrary, he’d go off. One of his assistant coaches owned a Corvette with a personalized license plate that drew attention to himself—that this guy was a coach with the 49ers, which suggested, “I’m a big shot.”
他不喜欢炫耀，也不喜欢任何暗示自己比组织里其他人更优秀的行为。他非常重视员工之间的互相尊重，如果他发现任何相反的证据，他都会勃然大怒。他的一位助理教练拥有一辆科尔维特跑车，车牌是定制的，这很引人注目——仿佛在说：“这家伙是49人队的教练，这暗示着‘我是个大人物’。”
Right away Bill spotted it in our parking lot, and that night during our coaches’ meeting, he lit into it: “Somebody in this room has a red Corvette with a stupid license plate on it. I want the #@*!*% license plate off that car before you come in here to work tomorrow.” He was livid. “Whoa,” I thought to myself, “this guy is tough.” Of course, that’s what Bill wanted me and the other coaches to think.
比尔一眼就看到了停在我们停车场里的那辆车，当晚教练会议上，他勃然大怒：“在座各位谁有辆红色克尔维特，车牌号太丑了。明天上班前，你们都给我把那该死的车牌换掉！”他气疯了。“哇，”我心想，“这家伙真够狠的。”当然，这正是比尔想让我和其他教练这么想的。
He was a great motivator because he had such a grasp of all the techniques to keep individuals plugged in and paying attention. He could really read a room—he’d love you up, but then, if you screwed up, watch out. You were always on a short string, on the edge of your chair, because he kept you guessing. He could turn it on and turn it off at exactly the right times. We were nervous about getting too happy and even more nervous about getting down in the dumps, because we knew Bill would tolerate neither.
他是个很棒的激励者，因为他深谙各种调动人心、集中注意力的技巧。他很会察言观色——他会热情地讨好你，但如果你犯了错，那就等着瞧吧。你总是提心吊胆，如坐针毡，因为他总是让你猜不透他的意图。他总能在恰到好处的时候调动气氛，也能在最恰当的时候戛然而止。我们既害怕过于兴奋，又害怕情绪低落，因为我们知道比尔绝不容忍任何负面情绪。
He’d say to us coaches, “I’m going to yell at you in front of the players once in awhile. When that happens, don’t get upset with me. Your players will work even harder for you because they’ll feel sorry for you.” Bill used that one in training camp. However, most of the time he wasn’t doing it for effect.
他会对我们教练说：“我偶尔会在球员面前冲你们吼。到时候别怪我。你们的球员会更努力地为你们训练，因为他们会同情你们。”比尔在训练营里经常用这招。不过，大多数时候他这么做并不是为了吓唬人。
I remember him spotting an assistant coach allowing a slant pattern to be run just a little bit off the exact route Bill had designed. It was just a few inches off, but from the other side of the field he saw it and started running all the way across the practice field, shouting to do it right.
我记得他发现一位助理教练让队员跑斜线时稍微偏离了比尔设计的路线。虽然只差了几英寸，但他从球场另一边看到了，便一路跑过训练场，大声喊着让他们改正。
Bill would get incensed if you messed with his plays. He knew they would work, but only if they were done exactly right. That’s why it was so important to him when he began hiring his assistant coaches at San Francisco that we be good teachers. He wanted things taught properly—his offense, of course, but then the defense, the special teams, the staff responsibilities. I think he felt those plays he was designing were very special, like a new invention that was guaranteed to work, but they wouldn’t work unless the coaches were good teachers.
如果你擅自改动比尔的战术，他会勃然大怒。他知道这些战术肯定有效，但前提是必须执行得一丝不苟。正因如此，当他开始在旧金山聘请助理教练时，他才格外重视教练的教学能力。他希望教练们能正确地传授战术——当然，进攻战术必不可少，但防守、特勤组、教练组职责等等也同样重要。我想他觉得自己设计的那些战术非常特别，就像一项全新的发明，保证有效，但前提是教练们必须具备良好的教学能力。
He didn’t want puppets, however, guys just taking orders. He would even throw out some radical schemes on plays for us to consider, just to shake up our thinking. He wanted input, but once the decision was made, he wanted it carried out precisely.
但他不想要傀儡，不想要只会听命行事的人。他甚至会提出一些激进的剧本构想让我们考虑，只是为了激发我们的思考。他希望我们提出意见，但一旦做出决定，就要求一丝不苟地执行。
Bill would be there at practice with three-by-five cards and one of those little golf pencils in his back pocket. If he pulled out a three-by-five card and starting writing, you just hoped it wasn’t about something you’d done wrong, because he’d let you know about it that night.
比尔总会带着几张三乘五英寸的卡片和一支高尔夫球专用铅笔出现在训练场上。如果他掏出卡片开始写东西，你只会祈祷上面写的不是你做错了什么，因为他当晚就会让你知道。
Bill raised the self-image of the organization. Players, for example, eventually had lockers with their pictures and names on them and plaques under their names listing any awards they had won—MVP, Pro Bowl, and others.
比尔提升了球队的自我形象。例如，球员们最终都拥有了贴有自己照片和名字的更衣柜，名字下方还有铭牌，列出了他们获得的所有奖项——最有价值球员、职业碗等等。
He had a brilliant mind coupled with a steel will. When it came to leadership, running the whole show, Bill was very strong—no question about who was in charge of things. But he had another side to him that was harder to understand. Several times during his ten years with the 49ers, he got so discouraged, depressed maybe, that he was on the verge of calling it quits, giving up.
他才智过人，意志坚定。在领导方面，比尔掌控全局，能力非凡——毫无疑问，谁才是真正的掌舵人。但他也有不为人知的一面，让人难以捉摸。在他效力旧金山49人队的十年间，有好几次他都感到极度沮丧，甚至可以说是抑郁，几乎想要放弃一切。
After his fourth season, which was miserable, he instructed John McVay, vice president for football administration, to tell all of us coaches to go to the East-West Game and look for jobs. [Editor’s note: The East-West Game was an all-star game with top college players that drew a large group of coaches from NFL teams.] Why? Bill was intent on quitting, and that meant we’d probably get fired by his replacement. He changed his mind, but a lot of us were asking around about jobs at that game.
在他执教的第四个赛季结束后，那是一个糟糕的赛季，他指示足球管理副总裁约翰·麦克维告诉我们所有教练都去参加东西方全明星赛，找工作。[编者注：东西方全明星赛是由顶尖大学球员参加的全明星赛，吸引了众多NFL球队的教练前来观赛。] 为什么？比尔当时一心想辞职，这意味着我们很可能会被他的继任者解雇。他后来改变了主意，但我们很多人都在那场比赛期间四处打听工作机会。
Bill put so much into his coaching and leadership that he became drained emotionally over time. He never let down, even for a second, but I think the fun kind of went out of it for him after the second Super Bowl championship.
比尔在执教和领导方面投入了太多，以至于随着时间的推移，他的精神状态变得非常疲惫。他从未懈怠过，哪怕一秒钟也没有，但我认为，在第二次超级碗夺冠之后，他似乎就失去了执教的乐趣。
But through it all, you really wanted to fight for him. And we did.
但无论如何，你真的想为他而战。而我们也做到了。

PART IV 第四部分
Essentials of a Winning Team: People, Priorities, and Performance 打造卓越团队的要素：人员、优先事项和绩效

Money Talks. Treating People Right Talks Louder. 金钱固然重要，但善待他人更有说服力。
The most important attribute of any organization is the way it treats its people, its commitment to the individuals on the team. San Francisco owner Eddie DeBartolo insisted on a first-class operation—travel, accommodations, and more. He was willing to spend money and spent lots of it over the years. But money alone doesn’t determine whether an organization is first class.
任何组织最重要的特质在于它如何对待员工，以及它对团队成员的承诺。旧金山49人队的老板埃迪·德巴托罗坚持提供一流的服务——包括差旅、住宿等等。他愿意为此投入资金，而且多年来也确实投入了大量资金。但金钱本身并不能决定一个组织是否一流。
We had no money initially. What we had was an organizational philosophy, the internal culture I installed, which was first-class in its treatment and respect for people. From the first day I took over, we treated people right. More than money, that’s what made the San Francisco 49ers a first-class organization internally. I had extremely high expectations—the Standard of Performance—of everyone on our payroll, but in return they could expect fair and decent treatment from me. And they got it.
我们最初一分钱都没有。但我们拥有的是一种组织理念，一种我建立的内部文化，这种文化在对待和尊重员工方面堪称一流。从我接手的第一天起，我们就善待员工。比起金钱，正是这一点让旧金山49人队成为一家内部一流的俱乐部。我对所有员工都抱有极高的期望——绩效标准——但作为回报，他们可以期待得到我公平合理的对待。而他们也确实得到了。
Some critics claimed the 49ers won Super Bowl championships by spending exorbitantly on salaries and perks. Those critics ignore the fact that we won our first Super Bowl championship with the lowest salaries of any team in the entire NFL. As mentioned, my own pay as head coach and general manager—typically two separate jobs—was $160,000, and I had to fight to get that, even though it was at the bottom end of the salary scale for head coaches in the league.
一些批评人士声称，49人队之所以能赢得超级碗冠军，是因为他们在薪资和福利上挥霍无度。这些批评人士忽略了一个事实：我们赢得第一个超级碗冠军时，球队的薪资是整个NFL所有球队中最低的。正如我之前提到的，我作为主教练兼总经理（通常是两份独立的工作）的年薪是16万美元，而且我为了争取到这个薪水费了不少周折，尽管这在联盟所有主教练的薪资水平中属于最低的。
In those earliest days, when I was building a team that would become highly competitive in just three years, it wasn’t money talking; it was dedication, expertise, and intelligently applied effort. It was sacrifice and commitment to our people. In turn, I got the best those people had to give our organization.
在创业初期，当我着手组建一支仅用了三年时间就极具竞争力的团队时，金钱并非关键；关键在于奉献精神、专业技能和巧妙运用努力。关键在于对员工的牺牲和承诺。而作为回报，我也获得了员工们能为公司贡献的最佳力量。
Additionally, Eddie had a gift for connecting with players and staff and showed his appreciation and friendship in small ways that made a big impression—a birthday card to a player (or a player’s child); a note of condolence when something bad happened to an employee; social events such as special dinners for staff members and their wives, who became football widows during the season because their husbands worked such ridiculous hours; personal contact with and a true interest in the lives of the people on his payroll.
此外，埃迪很擅长与球员和工作人员建立联系，他用一些小事表达自己的感激和友谊，这些小事却给人留下了深刻的印象——比如给球员（或球员的孩子）寄一张生日贺卡；当员工遭遇不幸时写一张慰问卡；举办一些社交活动，比如为员工及其妻子举办特别晚宴，这些妻子在赛季期间因为丈夫工作时间过长而成了“足球寡妇”；与他手下的员工保持个人联系，并真正关心他们的生活。
Eddie spent big money along the way, but these smaller expressions told people in the organization, “You’re part of a family here,” and they responded. He was really good at that because he meant it. Money may buy you the best car in racing, but it won’t go very far (or fast) unless you treat it right. The same goes for the individuals on your team. The highest-paid, most talented people that you can go out and hire will not perform to their potential unless they feel as if they are part of something special—a family that treats them right.
埃迪一路以来投入巨资，但他用一些细微的举动向团队传递了一个信息：“你们在这里就像一家人一样”，而他们也积极响应。他在这方面做得非常出色，因为他言出必行。金钱或许能让你买到赛车界最好的赛车，但如果你不善待它，它就无法发挥出应有的水平。这同样适用于你团队中的每一位成员。即使你聘请了薪水最高、最有才华的人才，如果他们没有感受到自己是某个特别的群体——一个善待他们的大家庭——他们也无法发挥出全部潜力。

You’re as Good as Your Good People 你的好人越多，你的好人就越多。
The bus carrying head coach Paul Brown and most of the team from the hotel to the stadium took a wrong turn and got lost. It became apparent that the guy behind the steering wheel didn’t know what he was doing and was going around in circles. Brown was livid. He stormed up to the driver and barked: “Fella, I’m not mad at you . I’m mad at the SOB who hired you.”
载着主教练保罗·布朗和大部分队员从酒店前往体育场的巴士走错了路，迷路了。很明显，司机根本不知道自己在干什么，一直在原地打转。布朗勃然大怒，冲到司机面前吼道：“伙计，我不是生你的气，我是生那个雇你的混蛋的气！”
Brown understood organizational accountability—where the buck stops. He knew that an organization is only as good as the people who work there and that the leader determines who works there.
布朗深谙组织责任制——谁该承担最终责任。他明白，一个组织的优劣取决于其员工的素质，而领导者决定谁能胜任这份工作。
I came to appreciate and utilize this fact after an unusual situation developed soon after I joined San Francisco as head coach. Within hours, we began diligently looking for a new general manager—the guy largely responsible for determining “who works there.” Unfortunately, nobody we wanted wanted us. Miami’s George Young, Seattle’s Dick Mansberger, and Baltimore’s Ernie Accorsi were among those who perfunctorily turned me down when offered the job as 49er GM.
在我刚到旧金山担任主教练不久，就发生了一件不同寻常的事情，在那之后，我才真正体会到这一点并加以运用。几个小时之内，我们就开始积极寻找新的总经理——这个人很大程度上负责决定“谁能在这里工作”。不幸的是，我们心仪的人选都不愿意聘用我们。迈阿密的乔治·杨、西雅图的迪克·曼斯伯格和巴尔的摩的厄尼·阿科西等人，在我被邀请担任49人队总经理时，都敷衍地拒绝了我。
It dawned on me that San Francisco was Siberia in the eyes of knowledgeable executives and managers in the NFL. They viewed our dire situation as hopeless, worse than a new expansion team starting from scratch, simply unfixable in the foreseeable future. (I even offered George Young more money than he was making in Miami to come out west and run things for the 49ers.) We were getting nowhere.
我突然意识到，在NFL那些见多识广的高管和经理眼里，旧金山简直就是西伯利亚。他们认为我们当时的处境毫无希望，比一支从零开始的新扩充球队还要糟糕，而且在可预见的未来根本无法改变。（我甚至给乔治·杨开出了比他在迈阿密更高的薪水，让他来西部执掌49人队。）我们毫无进展。
Things took a new direction during a breakfast meeting with Eddie DeBartolo and his trusted aide, Carmen Policy. Out of the blue, Eddie suggested that since the turndowns were piling up we stop looking and that I take the job—be head coach as well as general manager. It was a somewhat unwelcome suggestion, because I felt my hands were full already. But it very quickly made sense: I’d be the one hiring my staff—the people who would decide my future and the future of my organization. I was disappointed that I hadn’t come up with the idea myself.
在与埃迪·德巴托洛及其得力助手卡门·波利共进早餐时，事情出现了新的转机。埃迪突然提议，既然拒绝的人越来越多，我们就停止寻找新教练，让我接受这份工作——既担任主教练又兼任总经理。这个提议让我有些不悦，因为我觉得自己已经忙得不可开交了。但很快我就意识到，这其中的道理：我将亲自组建我的团队——这些人将决定我以及我所在机构的未来。我懊恼自己竟然没想到这个主意。
I proceeded expeditiously to sign up proven talent—coaches and administrators, my staff—who were both attuned to my philosophy and compatible with my personality. After being turned down by everyone, I was suddenly hearing yes, yes, yes. Why? Simple. I offered jobs to outstanding people I had previously worked with or worked for or knew very well—the cream of the crop from a list of former associates in my contact book going back all the way, in one case, to my days as an amateur boxer. They knew and believed in me as much as I knew and believed in them. A general manager from the outside would not have been able to do this—more likely, he would have been hiring people from his own contact book, imposing his associates on me. It might have worked, but it would have been a long shot.
我迅速着手招募那些才华横溢、经验丰富的教练、管理人员以及我的团队成员，他们不仅认同我的理念，也与我的个性相符。在被所有人拒绝之后，我突然听到的却是一片赞许。为什么？很简单。我向那些我曾经共事、为之效力或非常熟悉的优秀人才发出了邀请——他们都是我从通讯录中精挑细选出来的精英，其中一位甚至可以追溯到我还是业余拳击手的时候。他们了解我、信任我，正如我了解他们、信任他们一样。一个外来的总经理不可能做到这一点——他很可能会从自己的人脉圈里招人，把他的熟人强加给我。也许这种方法也能奏效，但成功的可能性微乎其微。
Each of these talented men accepted my job offer and came to San Francisco as a known and compatible quantity. There was mutual respect and understanding, and often a proven record of being able to work together. They hit the ground running, and two of them, Denny Green and Norb Hecker, didn’t have far to run. Both were just a few miles down the freeway from the 49ers headquarters at 711 Nevada Street in Redwood City, California. They began work immediately. (Another, George Seifert, an outstanding defensive coordinator when we worked together at Stanford, joined us in my second season with the 49ers.)
这些才华横溢的男士都接受了我的工作邀请，来到旧金山，他们彼此熟识，配合默契。我们之间互相尊重和理解，而且他们之前也曾有过合作的经验。他们很快就投入工作，其中两位，丹尼·格林和诺布·海克，离旧金山49人队总部（位于加州红木城内华达街711号）很近。他们俩都住在离总部几英里远的高速公路旁。他们立即开始了工作。（另一位是乔治·塞弗特，我们曾在斯坦福大学共事，他是一位杰出的防守协调员，在我执教49人队的第二个赛季，他加入了我们。）
Thus, from early in my tenure at San Francisco, I was surrounded and supported by staff who didn’t have to learn about me or my system. And vice versa.
因此，从我刚到旧金山任职开始，我就得到了众多员工的支持，他们无需了解我或我的体系。反之亦然。
It was a transforming experience; in the course of a few weeks I’d gone from casting about for a general manager who would come in with a steep learning curve about me—how and why I did things—to putting together a really excellent staff that was soon in sync.
这是一次意义非凡的经历；短短几周内，我从四处寻找一位需要快速了解我（我的做事方式和原因）的总经理，转变为组建了一支非常优秀的团队，而且团队很快就步调一致。
As a result, there were no bad mis-hires and we were able to proceed right from the start almost as if we’d been working together successfully for years. And in a way, there was some truth to it. This, in large part, explains what some viewed as an inexplicable turnaround by San Francisco—from NFL doormats to the NFL’s dominant team, champions—in so short a time. We had a first-rate, compatible staff in sync right from the start.
因此，我们没有出现任何招聘失误，几乎从一开始就能像已经成功合作多年一样顺利开展工作。某种程度上来说，这确实有一定道理。这在很大程度上解释了旧金山队为何能在如此短的时间内完成看似不可思议的转变——从NFL的垫底球队一跃成为NFL的霸主和冠军。我们从一开始就拥有一支一流且配合默契的团队。
Nevertheless, even in a situation as ideal as this, you must expect differences in performance levels among staff members and recognize the necessity of getting and keeping them on the same page— your page—in their new environment.
然而，即使在这样理想的情况下，你也必须预料到员工之间的绩效水平会有所不同，并且要认识到在新环境中让他们与你保持一致的必要性。
Here are two short lists I created that address what I deem as essential traits in a staff member and the way I went about keeping them on the same page of their new book—the book called “The San Francisco 49ers: Bill Walsh, Head Coach, General Manager, Boss.”
以下是我创建的两个简短列表，分别阐述了我认为员工应具备的基本特质，以及我如何让他们在新书——名为《旧金山 49 人队：比尔·沃尔什，主教练、总经理、老板》——中保持一致。
My checklist of personal qualities—assets—in potential staff members:
1. A fundamental knowledge of the area he or she has been hired to manage. You may think this is so self-evident it’s insulting to include. However, often we are tempted to hire simply on the basis of friendship or other user-friendly characteristics. They can be important. Expertise is more important.
2. A relatively high—but not manic—level of energy and enthusiasm and a personality that is upbeat, motivated, and animated. Groups will often collectively take on the personality of their department head (e.g., in football, their position coach). A negative, complaining staff member will be emulated by those he or she is in charge of. So will a positive go-getter.
3. The ability to discern talent in potential employees whom he or she will recommend to you.
4. An ability to communicate in a relaxed yet authoritative—but not authoritarian—manner.
5. Unconditional loyalty to both you and other staff members. If your staff members are chipping away at one another, the organization is weakened from within—like a tree full of termites. There is, in my view, no offense more serious than disloyalty.
我对潜在员工的个人素质（或称优势）清单：1. 对其受聘管理的领域有基本的了解。您或许认为这一点显而易见，无需赘述。然而，我们常常会因为友谊或其他亲切友好的特质而选择招聘。这些特质固然重要，但专业技能更为关键。2. 精力充沛、热情洋溢（但并非狂热），性格积极向上、充满动力和活力。团队成员往往会受到部门主管（例如，在橄榄球运动中，会受到位置教练的影响）的集体影响。一个消极抱怨的员工会被其下属效仿，而一个积极进取的员工也会如此。3. 能够识别潜在员工的才能，并向您推荐合适的人选。4. 能够以轻松而权威（而非专制）的方式进行沟通。5. 对您和其他员工保持绝对忠诚。如果你的员工互相倾轧，组织就会从内部被削弱——就像一棵被白蚁蛀蚀的树。在我看来，没有什么比不忠更严重的罪行了。
My checklist for keeping good staff members on the same page:
1. You must establish clear parameters for your staff regarding the overall method by which you expect things to be done. They must be reminded—instructed, when necessary—of your Standard of Performance: philosophy, style and substance, strategies and tactics.
2. Any philosophical differences that crop up must be identified and addressed by you in private meetings with the individual(s). Sweeping them under the rug is misdirected management.
3. You must recognize that staff members may work in different ways, using approaches that are at variance with yours. This can be relatively inconsequential as long as you and the staff member are philosophically compatible on the key issues (e.g., attention to detail, exhibiting respect to all members of the organization). Insisting on a totalitarian, lockstep mentality removes creativity from within.
4. To ensure unanimity throughout the staff, make unannounced visits to various department meetings. You can lose elements of your team to a maverick staff member if you’re invisible long enough.
5. Don’t cede inordinate power or control to a staff member simply because you are relieved to have an experienced and proven performer come on board. Assigning complete control without any monitoring of methods or means can allow a separate kingdom to develop, which will split your organization into factions.
6. Sometimes a staff member may intentionally teach a philosophy that is at odds with your code of conduct, in the belief that it conforms to your philosophy. He or she may also, on occasion, unconsciously revert to his or her own techniques or philosophy. This does not constitute insubordination until you have firmly pointed out the issue and the staff member continues to put forth ideas that are counter to what you want done. Then you must take corrective action that goes beyond a “reminder.”
7. Be alert for those staff members who seek to use their position to teach and express their personal beliefs. Politics and religion are the two most common areas.
8. Remember Mike Ditka’s comment on leadership after his Bears won a Super Bowl championship: “Personal contact is part of hands-on management. Go to the other guy’s office; tell him what you have in mind so there is no misunderstanding.”
我的确保优秀员工步调一致的清单：1. 你必须为员工设定清晰的准则，明确你期望他们以何种方式完成工作。必须提醒他们——必要时还要指导他们——你的绩效标准：理念、风格和实质、策略和战术。2. 任何出现的理念分歧都必须由你与相关人员私下沟通并解决。掩盖分歧是错误的管理方式。3. 你必须认识到，员工的工作方式可能与你不同，他们采用的方法也可能与你有所差异。只要你和员工在关键问题上（例如，注重细节、尊重组织中的所有成员）的理念一致，这种差异就无关紧要。坚持独裁式的、僵化的思维模式会扼杀内部的创造力。4. 为了确保全体员工的一致性，可以不定期地突击检查各个部门的会议。如果你长期保持低调，团队中的一些成员可能会因为某个特立独行的员工而流失。5. 不要因为一位经验丰富、业绩卓著的员工加入团队而感到欣慰，就轻易地将过多的权力或控制权交给该员工。在不监督方法或手段的情况下赋予其完全的控制权，可能会导致一个独立的“王国”形成，最终分裂成不同的派系。6. 有时，员工可能会故意宣扬与你的行为准则相悖的理念，因为他们认为这种理念符合你的价值观。他们也可能偶尔会无意识地回归到自己的方法或理念。在你明确指出问题所在，而该员工仍然继续提出与你的意愿相悖的想法之前，这并不构成不服从。这时，你必须采取比“提醒”更有效的纠正措施。7. 警惕那些试图利用职位来宣扬和表达个人信仰的员工。政治和宗教是两个最常见的领域。8.还记得迈克·迪特卡在带领芝加哥熊队赢得超级碗冠军后对领导力的评价吗？“亲自接触是亲力亲为的管理的一部分。去对方的办公室，告诉他你的想法，这样就不会产生误会。”

The Over and Under: The Art of Managing Confidence 自信的艺术：高低起伏
More people are more familiar with losing than with winning. Consequently, losing is not that difficult to deal with, in the sense that we’ve all faced it, lived it, and are familiar with the fallout it can produce. We have seen people lose heart, self-destruct, turn on one another, and become disloyal. We know the whole syndrome of losing, but leaders often don’t think very much about the other side of the coin—winning; especially winning big.
比起成功，人们更熟悉失败。因此，失败并不难应对，因为我们都经历过失败，也了解失败带来的后果。我们目睹过人们灰心丧气、自我毁灭、反目成仇、背信弃义。我们深谙失败的种种弊端，但领导者往往忽略了硬币的另一面——成功，尤其是大获全胜。
As with losing, there is fallout from success, and many of the symptoms are the same. The only difference is that you go down with a smile on your face instead of a frown.
就像失败一样，成功也会带来负面影响，而且很多症状都一样。唯一的区别在于，成功之后你会面带微笑地接受失败，而不是愁眉苦脸。
Our first Super Bowl championship team had forty-five dedicated and disciplined players on the roster. Soon afterward, and to varying degrees, eight of them self-destructed and ended their careers too early by mishandling their lives through drugs and alcohol, stupid lifestyles, and becoming consumed with themselves. A couple of them still can’t cope with life. Many other good players and people on that team were also thrown off stride to varying degrees. Why? Because they won the Super Bowl; we were the world champions of football.
我们第一支赢得超级碗冠军的球队拥有45名忠诚自律的球员。不久之后，其中八名球员不同程度地走向自我毁灭，因沉迷毒品和酒精、生活方式愚蠢、自我中心而过早地结束了自己的职业生涯。其中几人至今仍无法正常生活。球队中许多其他优秀的球员和成员也不同程度地受到了影响。为什么？因为他们赢得了超级碗；我们是世界橄榄球冠军。
This response—being knocked off balance emotionally and mentally—is one of the fundamental reasons it is so difficult to continue winning; it’s true in business as in sports. Repeat winners at the high end of competition are rare, because when success of any magnitude occurs, there is a dis orienting change that we are unprepared for. I, too, was somewhat thrown off by our first Super Bowl victory. Having navigated through long losing streaks and losing seasons, having climbed to the top and led a team at the bottom of the barrel to a world championship, I had little knowledge of the new terrain.
这种情绪和心理上的失衡反应，是难以持续取胜的根本原因之一；无论在商业还是体育领域，皆是如此。在高水平的竞争中，能够卫冕冠军的人寥寥无几，因为任何程度的成功都会带来一种令人迷失方向的巨变，而我们对此毫无准备。我本人也曾被我们第一次超级碗的胜利弄得有些不知所措。经历过漫长的连败和赛季的低谷，攀升至顶峰，带领一支垫底的球队夺得世界冠军，我对这全新的局面几乎一无所知。
How else can you explain that in the season immediately following that championship—Super Bowl XVI—and with virtually the same personnel, we lost twice as many games as we won in that strike-shortened season? The explanation is, in part, quite simple: Success Disease.
除此之外，你如何解释在赢得超级碗冠军后的下一个赛季——第十六届超级碗——而且几乎是同样的人员配置，我们输掉的比赛场次却是那个因罢工而缩短的赛季中获胜场次的两倍？部分原因很简单：成功综合症。
The second-richest man in America, Warren Buffett, says one of his biggest challenges is to help his top people—all wealthy beyond belief—stay interested enough to jump out of bed in the morning and work with all the enthusiasm they did when they were poor and just getting started.
美国第二大富豪沃伦·巴菲特表示，他面临的最大挑战之一是帮助他最得力的团队成员——他们都富可敌国——保持足够的兴趣，让他们每天早上都能精神抖擞地起床，像他们贫穷创业之初那样充满热情地工作。
Buffett is addressing that difficult situation of trying to motivate yourself or your team when you’ve become a winner. Success Disease—overconfidence is a major symptom—can happen in any profession and can be as difficult to remedy as underconfidence. Over- and underconfidence are an ongoing challenge in leadership.
巴菲特正在探讨一个难题：当你成为成功者之后，如何激励自己或团队。成功综合症——过度自信是其主要症状之一——可能发生在任何行业，而且与缺乏自信一样难以克服。过度自信和缺乏自信都是领导力面临的持续挑战。
When you reach a large goal or finally get to the top, the distractions and new assumptions can be dizzying. First comes heightened confidence, followed quickly by overconfidence, arrogance, and a sense that “we’ve mastered it; we’ve figured it out; we’re golden.” But the gold can tarnish quickly. Mastery requires endless remastery. In fact, I don’t believe there is ever true mastery. It is a process, not a destination. That’s what few winners realize and explains to some degree why repeating is so difficult. Having triumphed, winners come to believe that the process of mastery is concluded and that they are its proud new owners.
当你达成远大目标或最终登顶时，各种干扰和新的假设可能会让你眼花缭乱。首先是信心倍增，紧接着是过度自信、傲慢自大，以及一种“我们已经掌握了诀窍，我们已经找到了答案，我们已经万事如意”的感觉。但金光闪闪，转瞬即逝。精通需要不断地重新精进。事实上，我不认为存在真正的精通。它是一个过程，而非终点。这正是少数成功者未能意识到的，也在某种程度上解释了为什么复制成功如此艰难。胜利之后，成功者往往会认为精通的过程已经结束，而他们自己则是这项技艺的骄傲拥有者。
Success Disease makes people begin to forego to different degrees the effort, focus, discipline, teaching, teamwork, learning, and attention to detail that brought “mastery” and its progeny, success. The hunger is diminished, even removed in some people.
成功综合症使人们在不同程度上放弃了那些带来“精通”及其衍生品——成功——的努力、专注、自律、教学、团队合作、学习和对细节的关注。对成功的渴望减弱了，甚至在某些人身上完全消失了。
“Complacency” may be too strong a word to describe it, maybe not. Perhaps “contentment” describes it. You feel content after navigating up the hard and treacherous road to victory. This is understandable; you should feel satisfaction and contentment. But when it lingers—sets in—you and your team are suffering from Success Disease. It can create a lack of respect for the competition, a feeling of superiority, and an assumption that you can win at will, turn it on when it counts. The time to turn it on (and leave it on) is before it counts. In fact, my belief is that it counts all the time.
用“自满”来形容或许有些过重，也许并不为过。或许“满足”更贴切。当你历经艰辛险阻最终走向胜利时，你会感到满足。这可以理解；你应该感到欣慰和满足。但如果这种感觉挥之不去，甚至根深蒂固，那么你和你的团队就患上了“成功综合症”。它会导致对竞争对手缺乏尊重，产生一种优越感，并误以为自己可以随心所欲地取胜，在关键时刻才真正发挥作用。然而，真正应该在关键时刻之前就开启（并保持）这种心态的，恰恰是关键时刻到来之前。事实上，我认为关键时刻无处不在。
And, of course, when you couple contentment with underestimating the competition, you—all by yourself—have set yourself up for defeat. Imagine that.
当然，当你安于现状，低估竞争对手时，你——完全是自己——已经注定要失败。想想看。
There are specific actions I took based on the lessons learned after the 49ers’ experience with Success Disease following our first Super Bowl championship. They are very effective, although there is no guarantee that in following them you will fend off the fallout from achievement; specifically, Success Disease:
1. Formally celebrate and observe the momentous achievement—the victory—and make sure that everyone feels ownership in it. Praise, bonuses, and other rewards can make it special. This is a unique opportunity to strengthen the bond everyone feels to your organization, especially the special role players who get less attention.
2. Allow pats on the back for a limited time. Then formally return to business as usual by letting everyone know the party is over. Nevertheless, don’t tighten down too far. Victory can produce enormous energy—so powerful and overwhelming that in sports grown men will burst out in tears and run around like little children at Christmas. You must channel that powerful force and enthusiasm into the work ahead to solidify and build on the gains made by your team in achieving their recent success. Make sure the power of your victory propels you forward in a controlled manner.
3. Be apprehensive about applause. Instruct your team on the pitfalls of listening to accolades from those outside (and even inside) the organization. The praise can become a hindrance to buckling down to the hard sacrifice that will be required ahead. Ongoing applause can turn the head of the most disciplined and determined member of your team. Watch that it doesn’t turn your own head.
4. Develop a plan for your staff that gets them back into the mode of operation that produced success in the first place. Don’t assume it will happen. Hold meetings to explain what steps must be taken to sustain momentum; refocus personnel by covering in detail why success was achieved; review with them why they prevailed.
5. Address specific situations that need shoring up; focus on the mistakes that were made and things that were not up to snuff in the success. Point out deficiencies and the need to find remedies for them.
6. Be demanding. Do not relax . Hold everyone to even higher expectations. Don’t relax your Standard of Performance. The Standard of Performance is always in a state of refinement to raise performance. That’s your gold standard, the point of reference above everything else, including the won-lost record, Super Bowl titles, shareholder value, quotas, sales, or praise from people who don’t have to get down in the trenches with you and do the real work.
7. Don’t fall prey to overconfidence so that you feel you can or should make change for the sake of change. Change is inevitable, but change is not a casual consideration. When you’re flush with victory, you can take on a mind-set that says, “Hey, let’s try this!” Only in the most desperate situation is change made simply for the sake of change.
8. Use the time immediately following success as an opportunity to make hard decisions, including elevation or demotion of individuals who contributed—or didn’t—to the victory. This window is brief. Use it.
9. Never fall prey to the belief that getting to the top makes everything easy. In fact, what it makes easier is the job of motivating those who want your spot at the top. Achievement, great success, puts a big bull’s-eye on your back. You are now the target—clearly identified—for all your competitors to aim at.
10. Recognize that mastery is a process , not a destination.
根据旧金山49人队在首次赢得超级碗冠军后遭遇“成功综合症”的经验教训，我采取了一些具体的行动。这些行动非常有效，但并不能保证遵循这些行动就能完全避免成功带来的负面影响，特别是“成功综合症”：1. 正式庆祝并纪念这一重大成就——胜利，并确保每个人都感受到自己是胜利的一份子。表扬、奖金和其他奖励可以使胜利更加特别。这是一个加强每个人与组织之间联系的绝佳机会，尤其是那些不太受关注的特殊角色成员。2. 允许大家在有限的时间内互相鼓励。然后正式回归日常工作，让大家知道庆祝活动已经结束。但是，不要过度限制。胜利会产生巨大的能量——如此强大和令人难以承受，以至于在体育界，成年男子会喜极而泣，像过圣诞节的孩子一样奔跑嬉戏。你必须将这种强大的力量和热情引导到未来的工作中，巩固和发展团队在近期成功中所取得的成果。确保胜利的力量以一种可控的方式推动你前进。3.要警惕掌声。要告诫你的团队，不要轻信来自组织内外人士的赞扬。赞扬可能会阻碍他们为即将到来的艰苦挑战而努力奋斗。持续不断的掌声甚至会让团队中最自律、最坚定的成员也变得懈怠。要警惕自己也容易被赞扬冲昏头脑。4. 为你的员工制定一个计划，让他们重新回到最初取得成功时的工作模式。不要想当然地认为这会自动发生。召开会议，解释必须采取哪些步骤来保持势头；通过详细讲解成功的原因来重新集中员工的注意力；与他们一起回顾他们取得胜利的原因。5. 解决需要改进的具体情况；重点关注在成功过程中犯的错误和做得不够好的地方。指出不足之处以及需要找到的补救措施。6. 保持高标准。不要放松警惕。对每个人都提出更高的要求。不要降低你的绩效标准。绩效标准始终处于不断完善的状态，以提升绩效。这是你的黄金标准，高于一切的参照点，包括胜负记录、超级碗冠军、股东价值、配额、销售额，甚至是那些无需与你并肩作战、亲力亲为的人的赞扬。7. 不要陷入过度自信的陷阱，以至于你觉得可以或应该为了改变而改变。改变是不可避免的，但改变并非儿戏。当你沉浸在胜利的喜悦中时，你可能会抱着“嘿，我们试试这个！”的想法。只有在最绝望的情况下，才会为了改变而改变。8. 利用成功后的这段时间做出艰难的决定，包括提拔或降职那些为胜利做出贡献或没有做出贡献的人。这段时间很短暂，务必把握。9. 永远不要相信登上顶峰会让一切都变得容易。事实上，它让激励那些觊觎你顶峰的人变得更容易。成就，巨大的成功，会让你成为众矢之的。你现在成了所有竞争对手的目标——目标明确，不容忽视。10. 要认识到，精通是一个过程，而非终点。
When your organization achieves a significant goal, you must demonstrate the strongest and most demanding adherence to your own established ideals and principles—the Standard of Performance you abide by. This is essential, because if you fall prey to the consequences of winning, you will soon be dealing with the consequences of losing.
当你的组织达成一项重大目标时，你必须展现出对自身既定理想和原则——即你所遵循的绩效标准——最坚定、最严格的坚持。这一点至关重要，因为如果你屈服于胜利的喜悦，很快就会面临失败的后果。
This, in my experience, is the reason it’s tough to repeat, whether it’s a regional or national sales contest or a number one position in a high-tech industry. It’s one of the reasons only six teams in the history of the NFL have won the Super Bowl and then repeated by winning it again the next year. The San Francisco 49ers are among that small group of organizations that fought off Success Disease—if only for two years. That may not sound like much, but in the history of the Super Bowl, no team has been able to win three in a row. Success Disease is one of the reasons why.
依我之见，这就是为什么无论是在区域或全国销售竞赛中，还是在高科技行业中保持领先地位，都难以卫冕的原因。这也是为什么NFL历史上只有六支球队赢得超级碗后，第二年又成功卫冕的原因之一。旧金山49人队就是这少数几支成功抵御“成功综合症”的球队之一——尽管他们只保持了两年。这听起来或许不算什么，但在超级碗的历史上，还没有哪支球队能够实现三连冠。“成功综合症”正是其中的原因之一。
When things are going best is when you have the opportunity to be the strongest, most demanding, and most effective in your leadership. A strong wind is at your back, but it requires an understanding of the perils produced by victory to prevent that wind from blowing you over.
当一切进展顺利时，你就有机会展现出最强势、最严苛、最高效的领导力。你顺风顺水，但同时也需要了解胜利带来的风险，以免被这股力量冲垮。

The Under: Strive to Be a One-Point Underdog 看好小分：力争成为一分劣势方
It is extremely difficult to resist the debilitating temptations of Success Disease—to work even harder and smarter than before, to fend off overconfidence. Of course, you should allow for elation and celebration without letting it contaminate the future, but it takes some creativity and mental agility to keep your team focused when they are on top—when they are feeling full of themselves and invincible. Thus, when we faced an opponent the 49ers were expected to easily beat, I had to come up with some innovative reasoning as to why we could just as easily lose, why we should consider ourselves the underdog—ideally a one-point underdog.
抵制“成功综合症”带来的种种诱惑极其困难——它会让你比以前更加努力、更加聪明地工作，并抑制过度自信。当然，你应该允许团队享受喜悦和庆祝，但不要让这种情绪影响未来。然而，当团队处于巅峰状态，感觉自己所向披靡、所向披靡时，你需要一些创造力和思维敏捷性来保持他们的专注。因此，当我们面对一个49人队被认为可以轻松取胜的对手时，我必须想出一些新颖的理由，解释为什么我们同样有可能输掉比赛，为什么我们应该把自己视为弱者——理想情况下，是只落后一分。
For example, we faced Kansas City during a season in which the 49ers were defending Super Bowl champions, while the Chiefs had lost five consecutive games and were just getting worse and worse.
例如，我们曾在一个赛季中与堪萨斯城酋长队交锋，当时49人队是卫冕超级碗冠军，而酋长队已经连输五场，而且情况越来越糟。
As we prepared for the mid-November game at Candlestick Park, I earnestly told our team, “Fellas, I’m afraid of these guys; I really am. The Chiefs are angry because they’ve been humiliated publicly and privately for over a month. Honestly, this is a very dangerous situation for us. They can put it all behind them by knocking us off. They can come out and just explode on us.” I continued with this line of reasoning for many minutes.
在备战11月中旬在烛台公园举行的比赛时，我郑重地告诉队员们：“伙计们，我真怕他们，真的。酋长队现在怒火中烧，因为他们一个多月以来在公开场合和私下里都受到了羞辱。说实话，这对我们来说非常危险。他们只要击败我们就能把一切都抛在脑后。他们可能会一上来就对我们群起而攻之。” 我继续这样说了好几分钟。
Of course, everybody on the outside was telling our players the opposite—that Kansas City would just lie down. Having won Super Bowl XIX several months earlier, and in spite of a regular season that was far from stellar, some 49ers might have been inclined to listen and take a little breather and let up. That’s when Success Disease insinuates itself into the organization. (In fact, it seemed to have already begun. After that 18-1 Super Bowl season, we were 5-5 going into the Kansas City game—perhaps the best 5-5 team in NFL history.)
当然，外界所有人都告诉我们的球员，情况恰恰相反——堪萨斯城会就此放弃。几个月前刚刚赢得第十九届超级碗，尽管常规赛表现平平，一些49人队的球员或许会听从这种说法，稍作喘息，放松一下。而这正是“成功综合症”悄然侵蚀球队的时候。（事实上，它似乎已经开始了。在18胜1负的超级碗赛季之后，我们在对阵堪萨斯城的比赛前战绩是5胜5负——或许是NFL历史上最强的5胜5负球队。）
It was always my goal to create and maintain a working environment both on and off the field that had a sense of urgency and intensity but did not feel like we were in constant crisis mode. Ideally, I wanted to instill in each member of our group the belief that, regardless of the opponent, we were a one-point underdog , that the upcoming team was just a little better than we were or had motivation enough to really raise their level of play—the Kansas City Chiefs, for example. I wanted our team to believe that we could win, but only if we worked hard. This was challenging when they were surrounded by evidence of how “great” they were—public adulation, acclaim, and Super Bowl rings and a trophy that were still fresh in their minds.
我的目标始终是营造并维持一种场上场下都充满紧迫感和紧张感的工作氛围，但又不至于让人感觉我们一直处于危机状态。理想情况下，我希望让团队中的每一位成员都相信，无论对手是谁，我们都只是以一分之差处于劣势，即将到来的对手要么比我们略胜一筹，要么动力十足，会全力以赴——比如堪萨斯城酋长队。我希望我的队员们相信我们能够获胜，但前提是我们必须努力拼搏。当他们被各种“伟大”的表象所包围时，做到这一点就变得极具挑战性——公众的赞誉、表彰，以及那些仍然历历在目的超级碗戒指和奖杯。
When you can instill the one-point-underdog attitude in both yourself and your organization, complacency and overconfidence are kept at bay. My ability to do that was one of the primary reasons San Francisco was focused during the week’s preparation for Kansas City. We won 31-3, in part because I had temporarily immunized our team against Success Disease.
当你在自己和团队中都灌输了“一分劣势”的心态时，自满和过度自信就会被有效抑制。我之所以能做到这一点，是旧金山队在备战堪萨斯城酋长队的一周里保持专注的主要原因之一。我们最终以31比3大胜，部分原因在于我暂时让球队免受了“成功综合症”的困扰。
(My comments for that game, in fact, addressed two different attitudes that may have existed within the team. Some players were victims of Success Disease—overconfidence—because of the Super Bowl championship. Others may have started cashing out on the season because of our 5-5 won-lost record. Either way, cocky or cashing out, I needed to create a positive attitude adjustment and the one-point-underdog mentality was part of the solution.)
（事实上，我对那场比赛的评论针对的是队内可能存在的两种不同的心态。一些球员因为赢得了超级碗冠军而患上了“成功综合症”——过度自信。另一些球员则可能因为我们5胜5负的战绩而开始对这个赛季失去信心。无论如何，无论是自负还是放弃，我都需要帮助他们调整心态，而“一分劣势”的心态正是解决方案的一部分。）
Nevertheless, the ongoing and ultimate safeguard against attitudes that are detrimental to the team is your dedication and monumental adherence to the Standard of Performance you have created. This is always the way to win, the road to a goal even more elusive than success; namely, consistent success.
然而，防止出现损害团队利益的态度，最根本、最持久的保障，在于你对自身所制定的绩效标准的坚定承诺和严格遵守。这才是通往胜利的必由之路，也是通往比成功本身更难企及的目标——持续成功——的必由之路。

Seek Character. Beware Characters. 寻找品格，警惕人品。
Cedrick Hardman, an extremely talented defensive end, found himself increasingly unhappy when I took over the 49ers, because he had just gone through two losing seasons, including a 2-14 year just prior to my arrival. His discontent grew greater during my first year as head coach, which produced another 2-14 won-lost record. Four victories over two entire seasons can cause despair in some.
塞德里克·哈德曼是一位极具天赋的防守端锋，在我接手旧金山49人队后，他越来越不开心，因为此前他刚刚经历了两个赛季的失利，包括我到来之前的2胜14负。在我执教的第一年，球队的战绩依然是2胜14负，他的不满情绪更是与日俱增。两个赛季只赢了四场，这足以让一些人感到绝望。
Nevertheless, he had been an outstanding player with the organization for several seasons (the leader in sacks for eight straight years), and I strongly believed he was going to be a key performer, a leader, on our emerging team. Unfortunately, he proved me wrong.
然而，他曾是球队几个赛季以来的杰出球员（连续八年蝉联擒杀王），我坚信他会成为我们这支新兴球队的关键人物和领袖。可惜，他用实际行动证明我错了。
Cedrick was basically a good guy who was just unable to cope with his perception that things would not get better. As a result, his attitude worsened and his performance on the field suffered. Because of his disappointment, perhaps despair, and the fact that he wasn’t getting what he wanted out of the game—namely, victory—he began sniping at and belittling teammates for their efforts as we continued to lose nearly 90 percent of our games that first season. Then he began disparaging the assistant coaches, the owners, the staff, and eventually me. I tolerated it longer than I should have because of his talent, even though in his state of mind his play was far below what he was capable of had he gotten his act together.
塞德里克本质上是个好人，只是他无法接受现状不会好转的现实。结果，他的态度每况愈下，场上表现也一落千丈。由于失望，或许是绝望，再加上无法从比赛中获得自己想要的东西——胜利——他开始对队友冷嘲热讽，贬低他们的努力。那一年，我们输掉了近90%的比赛。之后，他又开始诋毁助理教练、老板、工作人员，最终甚至连我也未能幸免。因为他的天赋，我忍耐了他很久，尽管他当时的精神状态远低于他应有的水平。
Under more favorable circumstances, Cedrick might have been a positive force. However, given the situation as he viewed it, he became a negative and disruptive force—howling at everything, wounded and frustrated. While he was capable of being a leader under positive circumstances, he was not capable of doing it under losing circumstances. It takes extraordinary fortitude to stay with it when times are bad. Cedrick didn’t have it.
在更有利的情况下，塞德里克或许能成为一股积极的力量。然而，在他所处的境况下，他却变成了一股消极且具有破坏性的力量——对一切都咆哮，伤痕累累，沮丧不已。尽管在顺境中他有能力成为一名领导者，但在逆境中他却无能为力。在逆境中坚持下去需要非凡的毅力，而塞德里克恰恰缺乏这种毅力。
I determined that it was impossible to resurrect his enthusiasm for being a 49er and knew that every minute he continued to be with us he did damage to those who hadn’t given up. I called Al Davis across the Bay in Oakland and arranged a trade with the Raiders for our disgruntled defensive end.
我断定他再也无法重燃对49人队的热情，而且我知道他每多待一分钟，都会对那些尚未放弃的球迷造成伤害。于是我给身在湾对岸奥克兰的阿尔·戴维斯打了电话，安排他和突袭者队交易，换走了我们这位心怀不满的防守端锋。
Hardman had given up on the San Francisco 49ers too soon. Twenty-four months after the trade, we won Super Bowl XVI. In some small way, the championship came about because I had been willing to remove players—even those with great talent—whose actions or attitude didn’t conform to the Standard of Performance, who didn’t get with the program.
哈德曼过早地放弃了旧金山49人队。交易24个月后，我们赢得了第十六届超级碗。从某种程度上说，这场胜利的到来，是因为我愿意清除那些行为或态度不符合球队标准、不融入球队体系的球员——即使是那些天赋异禀的球员。
It’s worth remembering that some individuals have “situational character”—their attitude (and subsequent performance) are linked to results. Good results? Great attitude. Bad results? Bad attitude. Cedric was like that by the time I took over at San Francisco. He was a negative presence in our midst—a malignant force within the organization.
值得注意的是，有些人具有“情境型人格”——他们的态度（以及随后的表现）与结果息息相关。结果好？态度好。结果差？态度差。我接手旧金山分部时，塞德里克就是这样。他给我们带来了负面影响——是组织内部的一股毒瘤。
A leader must be able to identify these types of situations and not shy away from removing malcontents from the organization. It takes true character to stay with an organization when things seem to be at their bleakest.
领导者必须能够识别这类情况，并且毫不犹豫地将心怀不满者清除出组织。在组织处于最艰难的时刻，能够坚守岗位，这需要真正的品格。
It is also my opinion that lack of the “stick-with-it” attitude is accompanied by a certain lack of intelligence; not always, not with Cedrick, but often. The thick-witted person can’t deal with the hard knocks after a while, and that’s when the complaining begins.
我也认为，缺乏“坚持到底”的态度往往伴随着某种程度的智力不足；虽然并非总是如此，比如塞德里克就不是这样，但这种情况很常见。头脑简单的人过不了多久就无法承受打击，抱怨也就随之而来。
Some define character as simply aspiring to high ideals and standards. I disagree. Many people have lofty aspirations. Unfortunately, aspiring isn’t enough. You must also have the strength of commitment and sacrifice to adhere to those standards and ideals in both good times and bad.
有些人把品格定义为追求崇高的理想和标准。我不同意这种说法。许多人的确拥有远大的抱负。然而，仅仅有抱负是不够的。你还必须具备坚韧不拔的毅力和牺牲精神，才能在顺境和逆境中都恪守这些标准和理想。
Ronnie Lott, a 49er defensive back who had been an All-American at USC, was a model player who had no trouble adhering to high standards, regardless of the circumstances. In doing so, he brought others on our team up to his level. This quality of character was equal in its own way and importance to us to his Hall of Fame talent. (Lott was one of the hardest-hitting defensive backs in the history of the NFL. An opposing player described being tackled by Ronnie as equivalent to having someone hit you on the head with a baseball bat.)
罗尼·洛特，这位曾效力于旧金山49人队的防守后卫，在南加州大学时就入选了全美最佳阵容，是一位堪称楷模的球员，无论在何种情况下，他都始终坚持高标准。正因如此，他激励着我们队里的其他队友也达到他的水平。这种品格对我们来说，与他名人堂级别的天赋同样重要。（洛特是NFL历史上最强悍的防守后卫之一。一位对手球员曾形容被罗尼擒抱的感觉，就像被人用棒球棍狠狠地砸了一下脑袋。）
Commitment and sacrifice are among the personal characteristics I value most highly in people. Ronnie had both. One example may shock you.
责任感和奉献精神是我最看重的人格品质之一。罗尼两者兼备。一个例子或许会让你震惊。
During the final game of the ’85 regular season, against Dallas, he crushed the tip of his little finger—the pinky—tackling the Cowboys’ running back Tim Newsome. The finger failed to heal properly during the off-season, and bone-graft surgery was scheduled. However, because of the long recovery time necessary for the graft to “take,” Ronnie wouldn’t be ready to play at the start of the season, including our season opener against Tampa Bay.
在1985赛季常规赛最后一场对阵达拉斯牛仔队的比赛中，罗尼在擒抱牛仔队跑卫蒂姆·纽瑟姆时，小指指尖（小拇指）被压伤。休赛期期间，手指未能完全愈合，医生安排了植骨手术。然而，由于植骨需要较长的恢复期，罗尼无法赶上赛季初的比赛，包括我们与坦帕湾海盗队的揭幕战。
During a consultation with his doctor, Ronnie asked if there were any alternatives to the bone-graft operation that might speed things along. His surgeon replied, “I don’t recommend it, but we could amputate your finger, put the whole hand in a cast, and you’d be okay to play that first game.”
在咨询医生时，罗尼问他是否有除了植骨手术之外的其他方法可以加快康复进程。他的外科医生回答说：“我不建议这样做，但我们可以截掉你的手指，把整只手打上石膏，这样你就能参加第一场比赛了。”
I wish I could have seen the look on his surgeon’s face when Ronnie said, “Well, that’s what we’ll do. Take it off, doctor.” Ronnie Lott was in the starting lineup a few weeks later against Tampa Bay, wearing a big cast and minus part of the pinky on his left hand.
我真想看看罗尼对外科医生说“好吧，我们就这么做。医生，把它取下来吧”时，他医生的表情。几周后，罗尼·洛特就出现在了对阵坦帕湾的首发阵容中，他左手打着厚厚的石膏，小指也缺了一块。
While he was highly volatile—very overt—he had no grand plan to bring people along, but did it with his own drive, personality, and determination. He provides a good example of how good character is contagious.
他虽然性格极易冲动——而且非常外露——但他并没有什么宏大的计划来拉拢人心，而是凭借自己的干劲、个性和决心做到了。他很好地诠释了优秀品格的感染力。
Ronnie drove others to sacrifice at his level by setting extreme personal standards of physical intensity and concentration for himself in practice ( especially in practice, where it can be tempting to coast) and games that exceeded even my own expectations.
罗尼通过在训练中（尤其是在训练中，因为很容易懈怠）和比赛中为自己设定极高的身体强度和专注度标准，激励其他人以他为榜样做出牺牲，甚至超出了我的预期。
He simply demanded maximum effort and effective execution from himself at all times and refused to quit until it was achieved. Since he never felt it was totally and completely achieved, he never quit.
他始终要求自己付出最大的努力，高效完成任务，并且绝不放弃，直到达成目标。因为他从不觉得目标已经完全实现，所以他从未放弃。
His will to improve created a very real sense that if you wanted to associate with him professionally—to be on a “Ronnie Lott” team—you were expected to sacrifice to the same extreme degree he did. When a grueling set of push-ups was concluded by the coaching staff, Ronnie would often call for more; he would be the one setting the standard higher and higher. This was true during the season he joined us and San Francisco won a Super Bowl; it was equally true the following season when our won-lost record went in the tank: 3-6. He never quit.
他追求卓越的决心让人深信，如果你想在职业生涯中与他共事——成为“罗尼·洛特”团队的一员——你就必须像他一样付出极大的努力。当教练组结束一组艰苦的俯卧撑后，罗尼常常会要求队员们再做几组；他总是不断地提高标准。在他加入我们球队的那个赛季，旧金山队赢得了超级碗，他就是这么做的；而在接下来的赛季，我们的战绩跌至3胜6负，他依然如此。他从未放弃。
“Ronnie Lott” character reveals itself most starkly in two completely different circumstances: when victory or success is almost a given, and conversely, when there is little or no likelihood of victory. The former tempts an individual to become complacent, to ease up; the latter tempts an individual to start bellyaching and quit. Ronnie never gave up or let down. Consistent commitment and sacrifice in all situations was his trademark.
罗尼·洛特的性格在两种截然不同的情况下展现得最为淋漓尽致：一种是胜利或成功几乎已成定局之时，另一种则是胜利渺茫之时。前者容易使人变得自满懈怠；后者则容易使人开始抱怨连连，最终放弃。但罗尼从未放弃，也从未让人失望。始终如一的投入和奉献是他为人处世的标志。
He did what individuals with this kind of character do when facing either circumstance: Lott was constant in his drive to excel. This is very hard for an individual to do, but imagine how it transforms those within the organization. And imagine the pleasure it brings to the life of a leader.
无论面对何种境况，拥有这种性格的人都会做出同样的选择：洛特始终坚持追求卓越。这对个人而言实属不易，但试想一下，这会给组织内部带来怎样的改变。再想想，这会给领导者的生活带来怎样的乐趣。
Human nature is such that we are drawn to those with fortitude—whether it’s in the military (General Dwight Eisenhower), exploration (Sir Edmund Hillary), religion (Martin Luther King Jr.), or anywhere else. Ronnie Lott had that same stuff. His character transformed those around him in a positive, even profound way.
人性使然，我们会不由自主地被那些意志坚定的人所吸引——无论是在军队（如德怀特·艾森豪威尔将军）、探险家（如埃德蒙·希拉里爵士）、宗教界（如马丁·路德·金），还是其他任何领域。罗尼·洛特也具备这种品质。他的品格以一种积极甚至深刻的方式影响着周围的人。
In his own personal example, he became a de facto coach, one whose specialty was teaching others what it meant to give it everything you’ve got. When evaluating our people, this was a key characteristic that I valued highly. I understood the impact it has on others in the organization; I recognized that it made my job much easier.
他以身作则，实际上成为了一位教练，他的专长在于教导他人如何全力以赴。在评估员工时，这是我非常看重的一项关键特质。我明白这会对组织中的其他人产生怎样的影响；我也意识到，这让我的工作轻松了很多。
In building and maintaining your organization, place a premium on those who exhibit great desire to keep pushing themselves to higher and higher performance and production levels, who seek to go beyond the highest standards that you, the leader, set. The employee who gets to work early, stays late, fights through illness and personal problems is the one to keep your eye on for greater responsibilities.
在构建和维护团队的过程中，要重视那些渴望不断提升自身绩效和生产力水平、力求超越你（领导者）设定的最高标准的员工。那些早到晚归、克服病痛和个人困难的员工，才是你应该重点关注并委以重任的人选。
When you bring a “Ronnie Lott” into your organization, you are actually bringing several “Ronnie Lotts” aboard, because they create others in their own image. His teammate and fellow Hall of Fame player, running back Roger Craig, shared that same work ethic, intensity, and enthusiasm. Here’s an example: Roger would often race all the way to the goal line when he carried the ball—in practice . I didn’t ask him to do that; he had that drive within. Push. Push. Push. Lott and Craig were two different personalities that exuded their formidable character in different but equally effective ways.
当你把一个“罗尼·洛特”招入麾下时，实际上你引进了好几个“罗尼·洛特”，因为他们会培养出更多像他们一样的人。他的队友，同样入选名人堂的跑卫罗杰·克雷格，也拥有同样的职业精神、拼劲和热情。举个例子：罗杰在训练中经常持球冲向达阵区。我并没有要求他这么做；他内心就有这种动力。不断冲刺，不断冲刺，不断冲刺。洛特和克雷格是两种截然不同的性格，但他们以各自独特的方式展现了他们令人敬畏的品质，而且同样卓有成效。
I’ve seen athletes have great performances right after a personal tragedy occurred in their life. I’ve also seen the opposite—individuals who are unable to compete because of something that happened in their life that they allowed to cripple them.
我见过一些运动员在遭遇人生悲剧后能迅速恢复到巅峰状态，也见过一些运动员因为生活中某些不幸的遭遇而一蹶不振，最终无法继续比赛。
Otto Graham, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, demonstrated tremendous strength of character when he forced himself to compete in the NFL Pro Bowl Game just weeks after the tragic death of his son. Somehow he was able to summon the fortitude not only to perform, but to perform at a level that resulted in being selected as MVP. Otto just felt he had to continue with his life, to go on. Ultimately, he simply would not allow himself to opt out, even after such a catastrophic personal tragedy.
奥托·格雷厄姆是职业橄榄球名人堂成员，在儿子不幸去世几周后，他依然坚持参加NFL职业碗比赛，展现了惊人的毅力。他不仅鼓起勇气上场比赛，而且发挥出色，最终荣膺MVP。奥托觉得他必须继续生活下去，继续前行。最终，即使经历了如此巨大的个人悲剧，他也绝不让自己放弃。
On the other hand, I’ve known people who played poorly or not at all because some distant relative they hardly knew had died months earlier and it was still on their mind; they couldn’t get over it, couldn’t perform. They allowed themselves an excuse for poor performance. Character was at the core of both kinds of responses.
另一方面，我也认识一些人，他们因为几个月前一位素未谋面的远房亲戚去世而情绪低落，无法释怀，导致发挥失常甚至缺席比赛。他们以此为借口，为自己糟糕的表现开脱。这两种反应的核心都在于性格。
My point is that the Otto Grahams of this world are hard to find. The other kind are all over the place. Guys like Ronnie and Roger aren’t found all over the place. Both exemplify the message of UCLA’s coach John Wooden: “I wanted players who had character, not players who were characters.”
我的意思是，像奥托·格雷厄姆这样的人世间难寻。其他类型的人却随处可见。像罗尼和罗杰这样的人可不是随处可见的。他们两人都体现了加州大学洛杉矶分校教练约翰·伍登的理念：“我想要的是有品格的球员，而不是只会耍嘴皮子的球员。”
Of course, sometimes you get both. Jack “Hacksaw” Reynolds, who played such an important role in our first Super Bowl year, was a tremendous competitor with character. He also was a character. On many occasions, before games, he would put on his San Francisco 49ers uniform at his house, smear the eye black under his eyes, and call a cab to take him to the game. He would arrive at Candlestick Park ready to go, in full uniform, including cleats! And then Jack Reynolds would deliver the goods out on the field.
当然，有时候两者兼备。杰克·“电锯”·雷诺兹在我们首次夺得超级碗的那一年发挥了至关重要的作用，他是一位极具竞争力的球员，也是一位个性鲜明的球员。很多时候，赛前他会在家里穿上旧金山49人队的队服，在眼下抹上眼黑，然后叫辆出租车去球场。他会全副武装地抵达烛台公园，包括球鞋在内，做好上场的准备！然后，杰克·雷诺兹就会在球场上大显身手。
You go nowhere without character. Character is essential to individuals, and their cumulative character is the backbone of your winning team.
没有品格，你将一事无成。品格对个人至关重要，而团队品格的积累则是制胜团队的基石。

A Big Cheer for a Big Ego 为自大狂欢呼
Don’t let anybody tell you that a big ego is a bad thing. Tiger Woods, Bill Gates, Warren Buffett, and Cal Ripken Jr. have lots of ego, and so does anyone anywhere who is dedicated to taking his or her talent as far as it will go. I’ve got a big ego too.
别听人说自负是坏事。泰格·伍兹、比尔·盖茨、沃伦·巴菲特和卡尔·瑞普肯都很自负，任何致力于将自身天赋发挥到极致的人都一样。我也很自负。
Here’s what a big ego is: pride, self-confidence, self-esteem, self-assurance . Ego is a powerful and productive engine. In fact, without a healthy ego you’ve got a big problem.
这就是所谓“自负”：骄傲、自信、自尊、自我肯定。自负是一种强大而高效的动力。事实上，如果没有健康的自负，你就会有大麻烦。
Egotism is something else entirely. It’s an ego that’s been inflated like a hot-air balloon—arrogance that results from your own perceived skill, power, or position. You become increasingly self-important, self-centered, and selfish, just as a hot-air balloon gets pumped with lots of hot air until it turns into some big, ponderous entity that’s slow, vulnerable, and easily destroyed.
自负则完全是另一回事。它就像一个被吹胀的热气球——一种源于你对自身能力、权力或地位的自负。你会变得越来越自以为是、以自我为中心、自私自利，就像一个热气球被充入大量热气，最终变成一个庞大笨重、行动迟缓、脆弱不堪、极易被摧毁的物体一样。
Unfortunately, a strong, healthy ego often becomes egotism. When Jerry Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys, fired his head coach Jimmy Johnson immediately following the team’s second consecutive Super Bowl victory, ego may have been replaced by egotism in one or both men. The consequences were ultimately devastating for the Cowboys and took years to repair.
不幸的是，强大而健康的自尊心往往会演变成自大。达拉斯牛仔队老板杰里·琼斯在球队连续第二次赢得超级碗冠军后立即解雇了主教练吉米·约翰逊，这或许表明，两人中的一人或两人都已从自尊心转变为自大。最终，这一举动给牛仔队带来了毁灭性的后果，并耗费了数年时间才得以恢复。
In evaluating people, I prize ego. It often translates into a fierce desire to do their best and an inner confidence that stands them in good stead when things really get rough. Psychologists suggest that there is a strong link between ego and competitiveness. All the great performers I’ve ever coached had ego to spare.
在评价一个人时，我非常看重他们的自尊心。这往往意味着他们渴望做到最好，以及在逆境中能够助他们渡过难关的内在自信。心理学家认为，自尊心和竞争意识之间存在着密切的联系。我指导过的所有优秀运动员都拥有过人的自尊心。
However, when I sense ego turning into egotism, I sit down and talk with the individual to help him understand his problem, to recognize why he’s on the team, to see if we can’t get his perspective back in balance and minimize his inflated sense of value to the organization. Either the egotism goes away or the individual flaunting it does, because the damage a swaggering egotist can do to the organization always outweighs the good.
然而，当我察觉到自负正在演变成自大时，我会坐下来与他交谈，帮助他理解自身的问题，让他明白自己为何身处团队之中，看看能否让他重新调整视角，降低他过高的自我价值感。要么自大消失，要么炫耀自大的人离开，因为一个趾高气扬的自大狂对组织造成的损害总是远远大于其带来的益处。
Have there been times when your own ego has turned unhealthy, been pumped up for various reasons into egotism? Have there been instances where you hurt yourself because you got caught up in your self-importance? Be careful. People can sense it, they can see it. When they do, your effectiveness is dramatically reduced. At times it can even be fatal. That’s why it’s worth monitoring in yourself and your staff.
你是否曾有过自负膨胀到不健康的状态，因为各种原因而变得自大？你是否曾因为过于自负而伤害过自己？务必小心。人们能够察觉到这一点，也能看出来。一旦被察觉，你的工作效率就会大幅下降。有时甚至会造成致命的后果。因此，密切关注自己和员工的自负至关重要。
While the dynamics within a professional football team are unique in many ways, the element of dealing with egotism, arrogance, and the self-styled big shots is perhaps similar profession to profession.
虽然职业足球队内部的动态在很多方面都是独一无二的，但处理自负、傲慢和自封大人物等问题，或许是各个职业之间都存在的相似之处。
In football, if your team’s any good, what you have in the locker room is a superstar or two, along with a few people who have immense egos but aren’t superstars, perhaps are not even very good, just adequate. Peer pressure is one way for dealing with the egotists—maybe the best way—but the leader ultimately is the one who has to control the situation. If I talked enough about “professionalism,” how we carried ourselves and performed, how we interacted and respected one another, the huge egos were sometimes embarrassed out of their behavior because they understood that they were out of whack with the rest of the team.
在足球界，如果你的球队实力不错，更衣室里通常会有一两个超级巨星，外加几个自负却并非超级巨星，甚至可能水平一般，只能算得上合格的球员。同侪压力是应对这些自负球员的一种方法——或许是最好的方法——但最终掌控局面的还是球队的领导者。如果我反复强调“职业精神”，强调我们的言行举止、比赛表现、互动方式以及彼此间的尊重，那些自负的球员有时也会因为意识到自己与球队其他成员格格不入而感到羞愧。
Most of those who strutted around were the less intelligent players. And being less intelligent, they couldn’t understand my message and ended up being isolated by their teammates—ostracized to one degree or another. That’s the single best way, the most effective corrective method, because almost everyone seeks some peer approval or acceptance. One way or another, however you do it, you as a leader must recognize and remedy the egotists within your organization before they can damage what you’ve built.
那些趾高气扬的人大多是智力较低的球员。正因为智力较低，他们无法理解我的信息，最终被队友孤立——或多或少地遭到排挤。这是最好的方法，也是最有效的纠正手段，因为几乎每个人都渴望得到同伴的认可或接纳。无论如何，作为领导者，你必须识别并纠正组织内部的自负者，以免他们破坏你所建立的一切。

The Bottom 20 Percent May Determine Your Success 最终决定你成败的，可能是那20%的人群。
At the beginning of each year’s training camp, I made the following promise to our team: “Every single one of you guys will have at least one chance to win a game for us. I ask you to prepare for that opportunity with the attitude that it’s a certainty, not a possibility. Prepare and be ready when your time comes, because it will come. Can you do that for me?”
每年训练营开始时，我都会向全队做出这样的承诺：“你们每个人都至少有一次机会为我们赢得一场比赛。我希望你们做好准备，把这个机会当作必然，而不是一种可能性。做好准备，在机会来临时做好准备，因为机会一定会来。你们能做到吗？”
When Joe Montana first heard me say this, he may have thought, “Is Bill crazy? That’s what I’m here for, to win games.” But of course, my statement wasn’t directed at Joe.
乔·蒙塔纳第一次听到我说这话时，他可能心想：“比尔疯了吗？我来这里就是为了赢球。” 当然，我的话并不是针对乔的。
Those comments were aimed specifically at the so-called bottom 20 percent of our team—the backups, “benchwarmers,” and special role players, those who didn’t see much action during the regular season. In a sports organization this is the group that often determines your fate—they make the difference between whether you win or lose. In business it may be a customer-service representative or another less prominent “player” who fails to address a problem due to lack of readiness or a feeling that his or her particular job doesn’t really mean that much in the big picture.
这些评论专门针对我们团队中所谓的“后20%”——替补球员、“板凳球员”和特殊角色球员，也就是那些在常规赛中鲜有上场机会的人。在体育组织中，这部分人往往决定着球队的命运——他们决定着球队的胜负。在商业领域，这可能是客服代表或其他不太引人注目的“员工”，他们因为准备不足或觉得自己的工作在大局中无关紧要而未能解决问题。
Future Hall of Fame players such as Steve Young, Jerry Rice, Roger Craig, and others with plenty of playing time didn’t need me to remind them to get physically, mentally, and emotionally ready for action. Rather, it was the bottom 20 percent who were more likely to feel overlooked, unimportant, and unattached to our organization.
像史蒂夫·杨、杰里·赖斯、罗杰·克雷格等未来名人堂成员，以及其他拥有充足上场时间的球员，无需我提醒他们做好身体、心理和情感上的准备。相反，反而是排名后20%的球员更容易感到被忽视、不重要，并且与球队缺乏归属感。
Additionally, when they did play it was often in a physically dangerous situation such as a kickoff return, the football version of being a kamikaze pilot, where your career can end suddenly with an injury. They risk life and limb and yet can often feel unappreciated.
此外，他们上场比赛时往往身处危险境地，例如开球回攻，这就像橄榄球界的“神风特攻队”飞行员，职业生涯可能因伤病而戛然而止。他们冒着生命危险，却常常感觉不到应有的认可。
While these employees may have a limited role, in just one play they can destroy the efforts of everyone else; their impact, though limited, can be calamitous. Or they can save the game.
虽然这些员工的作用可能有限，但他们只需一次失误就能毁掉其他人的努力；他们的影响虽然有限，却可能造成灾难性的后果。当然，他们也可能力挽狂澜，拯救比赛。
Members of this group can become a serious distraction and liability, because as their attitude worsens, their commitment wavers and their carping increases. When the bottom 20 percent is dissatisfied—doesn’t feel they’re a real part of your team, that is, appreciated—their comments, perspective, and reactions—their “bitching”—is seen, heard, and absorbed by those who are positive and productive.
这个群体成员可能会成为严重的干扰因素和隐患，因为随着他们态度的恶化，他们的投入度会下降，抱怨也会增多。当那20%的底层员工感到不满——觉得自己没有真正融入团队，没有得到认可——他们的评论、观点和反应——也就是他们的“抱怨”——会被那些积极向上、富有成效的员工看到、听到并吸收。
For reasons I’ve never quite figured out, the bitching of the bottom 20 percent often overshadows the positive enthusiasm of the other 80 percent. I always thought it should be the other way around, but it isn’t. The whiners seem to have a disproportionate impact. Thus the need for my “be ready to win a game for us” speech at the start of each training camp, which attempted to give those who might come to feel disenfranchised a reason to stay plugged in, positive, and ready to perform. And this was only the start.
出于我始终未能完全理解的原因，那20%的抱怨声常常掩盖了其余80%的积极热情。我一直以为情况应该正好相反，但事实并非如此。抱怨者的影响似乎不成比例地大。因此，我需要在每次训练营开始时发表“准备好为我们赢得比赛”的演讲，试图让那些可能感到被边缘化的人找到理由继续保持积极向上、全力以赴。而这仅仅是个开始。
I was conscientious in repeating that message privately through the season and acknowledging them publicly; talking about their roles and their potential impact in the future; working to keep them feeling that their contribution to the team was important (because it was very important); working hard to ensure that they were integrated and assimilated into everything we did so they didn’t feel left out or part of a second tier on the team. If I noticed the same groups always sitting together at lunch or dinner, I would have the assistant coaches start mixing them around so that people got more familiar with one another. This also meant there was less likelihood of the same little group of complainers sitting together and adding members.
整个赛季，我都在私下里反复强调这一点，并在公开场合表扬他们；谈论他们的角色以及他们未来可能产生的影响；努力让他们感受到自己对团队的贡献至关重要（因为这确实非常重要）；努力确保他们融入到我们所做的每一件事中，让他们不会感到被冷落或被边缘化。如果我注意到午餐或晚餐时总是同样的几拨人坐在一起，我会让助理教练安排他们换位，让大家彼此更加熟悉。这也意味着，同一小撮抱怨的人聚在一起并不断增加新成员的可能性会大大降低。
During team meetings I would often give a one-hundred-dollar bill as a reward to a role player who had made a big contribution in the previous game. It was another chance for them to be recognized by me in front of the whole squad, for me to give them ownership in the organization’s results. While coaching at Stanford University, I instituted a “12th Man Award,” which, of course, didn’t involve money, but did acknowledge publicly the effort being made by those who were less visible. I wanted them to know they were an essential part of the success of the team and, as such, should focus and train for the moment they would have a chance to make a big play. I strove to avoid having a “second tier” of lower-class players or staff members.
在球队会议上，我经常会给上一场比赛表现突出的角色球员一百美元作为奖励。这让他们有机会在全队面前得到我的认可，让他们感受到自己对球队成绩的贡献。在斯坦福大学执教期间，我设立了“第十二人奖”，当然，这个奖项不涉及金钱，但它公开表彰了那些默默付出、不为人知的球员。我希望他们明白，他们是球队成功不可或缺的一部分，因此，他们应该专注于训练，为有机会发挥关键作用的那一刻做好准备。我努力避免球队出现“二流”球员或工作人员。
A leader who ignores this element of the organization—the “bottom 20 percent,” those who play subsidiary or special roles—is asking for trouble. When these individuals begin to feel extraneous, their discontent can spread through your entire organization just like a cancer spreads through a body.
如果领导者忽视组织中的这一部分——即“底层20%”的员工，那些扮演辅助或特殊角色的人——那无异于自找麻烦。当这些人开始感到自己被边缘化时，他们的不满情绪就会像癌症扩散一样，蔓延到整个组织。
Be conscientious in evaluating the effectiveness of the steps you take in connecting the role players on your team to the team itself. Helping them understand that they make a difference can be the difference in making it to the top.
认真评估你为将团队中的角色成员与团队本身联系起来而采取的措施的有效性。帮助他们理解自身作用的重要性，可能是最终走向成功的关键。

Avoid the Dance of the Doomed 避免跳那注定失败的舞蹈
On the steppes of Africa, a “dance of death” occurs when a wildebeest is run into exhaustion by a lion. Waiting to be killed as the lion circles, the wildebeest meekly submits to its fate—head drooping, shoulders slumped, eyes glazed over. It is the posture of the doomed, the same look you often see in competitors in sports and business who have given up after deciding that failure is inevitable, their competitor unbeatable.
在非洲草原上，当角马被狮子追赶至精疲力竭时，就会出现一种“死亡之舞”。角马在狮子的围攻下等待着被猎杀，它低垂着头，耸着肩，眼神空洞，默默地接受着命运的安排。这是注定失败者的姿态，与你在体育和商业领域经常看到的那些已经放弃、认定失败无可避免、认为对手不可战胜的竞争者脸上的神情如出一辙。
During my ten years as head coach of the 49ers, we won more than our share of division, conference, and Super Bowl games; we also lost sixty-three games. During some of those defeats, the dance of the doomed could be clearly seen on the faces of some 49er players, even by fans in the upper decks of a stadium. And certainly by our opponent right across from us on the field.
在我执教旧金山49人队的十年间，我们赢得了远超预期的分区赛、联盟赛和超级碗冠军；但我们也输掉了63场比赛。在一些失利中，即使是坐在球场上层的球迷，也能清晰地看到一些49人队球员脸上那种绝望的神情。当然，我们的对手在场上也能看到。
On those occasions I would say to the team in various ways, “Fellas, I guess we’re gonna lose today. How do you want to do it?” They knew what I meant. I was asking them to stand up and fight and if they lost, at least to lose with dignity.
每当这时，我都会用各种方式跟队员们说：“伙计们，看来我们今天要输了。你们想怎么输？”他们明白我的意思。我是在鼓励他们振作起来，奋力拼搏，即使输了，也要输得有尊严。
The impact this can have was demonstrated in an amazing comeback against New Orleans when we trailed at the half, 35-7. It came during that stretch in our second season when we had just lost seven out of nine games and were trying to pull out of the death spiral our season had become. As we ran off the field at the half, 49er fans let us know how disgusted they were with us, booing disdainfully and hurling paper cups and debris down on our heads.
这种战术的威力在对阵新奥尔良的比赛中得到了充分体现。当时我们半场以7比35落后，最终却上演了惊天逆转。那是在我们第二个赛季的低谷期，我们刚刚在九场比赛中输掉了七场，正努力摆脱赛季的死亡漩涡。中场休息时，当我们跑下球场时，49人队的球迷们用嘘声和投掷纸杯、杂物等方式表达了他们对我们的厌恶之情。
In the locker room my comments were honest in describing what was at stake, and it wasn’t the final score: “Some of you may think we have already lost this game,” I began. “You might be right. We may lose this afternoon, and if we do, I can live with it. This is only a football game. However, if we go down, you must decide how you want it to happen. How do you want to go down? Nobody would blame you for coasting the rest of this game, for throwing in the towel. And in fact, when you come back here in sixty minutes, only you will know if you did; only you will know if you let New Orleans continue this assault or if you stood your ground and fought back. Frankly, I care a lot more about how we lose than if we lose. Gentlemen, in the second half you’re going to find out something important; you’re about to find out who you are. And you may not like what you find.”
在更衣室里，我坦诚地描述了这场比赛的利害关系，而这并非最终比分：“你们有些人可能觉得我们已经输了，”我开口说道，“你们或许是对的。我们今天下午可能会输，如果输了，我也能接受。这只是一场橄榄球比赛。但是，如果我们输了，你们必须决定你们希望以怎样的方式输掉比赛。你们想以怎样的方式输掉比赛？如果你们选择在剩下的比赛时间里放松警惕，放弃抵抗，没有人会责怪你们。事实上，当你们六十分钟后回到这里时，只有你们自己才能知道你们是否做到了；只有你们自己才能知道你们是让新奥尔良队继续进攻，还是坚守阵地奋起反击。坦白说，我更在意的是我们输得如何，而不是输不输。先生们，下半场你们将会发现一些重要的东西；你们即将发现你们自己是谁。而你们或许并不喜欢你们发现的东西。”
That’s all I said. No rah-rah speech along the lines of “It’s never over ’til it’s over!” No angry shouting about lack of effort or stupid mistakes; no threats. I simply pointed out that we had arrived at an important threshold of discovery—that moment when you find out what you’re made of.
我说的就这些。没有像“不到最后一刻，一切皆有可能！”那样慷慨激昂的演讲，也没有因为对方不够努力或犯了愚蠢的错误而愤怒咆哮，更没有威胁。我只是指出，我们已经到达了一个重要的发现阶段——在那一刻，你会发现自己究竟能做到什么。
When I finished my brief comments, there was complete silence. We looked at one another—Dwight Clark, Freddie Solomon, Lenvil Elliott, Earl Cooper, Randy Cross, Keena Turner, Joe Montana, Dan Bunz, and all the others—in a way that probably happens in the military before the battle; you’re looking into one another’s competitive souls.
我简短发言结束后，现场一片寂静。我们彼此对视——德怀特·克拉克、弗雷迪·所罗门、伦维尔·埃利奥特、厄尔·库珀、兰迪·克罗斯、基纳·特纳、乔·蒙塔纳、丹·邦兹以及其他所有人——那种感觉就像战前军队里常见的场景；你仿佛在窥视彼此竞争的灵魂。
I turned and left the room while our assistant coaches gathered with their own units to go over changes to be made in the second half. Those tactical changes were not significant. The big change had to be in their attitude.
我转身离开了房间，我们的助理教练们则带着各自的队员聚在一起，商讨下半场需要做出的调整。这些战术上的改变并不重要，真正的改变在于他们的态度。
What I had attempted to do was remind our guys of the Standard of Performance that I had been teaching from the day I arrived. Among the multitude of rules, concepts, and prescribed attitudes it embraced was the matter of poise: Even in the worst circumstance (and this was pretty close to being the worst), do not unravel mentally or emotionally; continue to fight and execute well, even if the cause appears to be lost; act like professionals.
我当时试图提醒队员们我从到任那天起就一直强调的绩效标准。这套标准包含众多规则、理念和应有的态度，其中就包括保持冷静：即使在最糟糕的情况下（而当时的情况几乎就是最糟糕的），也不要精神崩溃或情绪失控；即使看似败局已定，也要继续战斗并出色地完成任务；要像专业人士那样行事。
“Who are you?” I asked them. I wanted to know; in the second half I found out. The 49ers outscored the Saints 28-0 and won the game in overtime on Ray Wersching’s field goal, 38-35. At the time, it was considered the greatest comeback in the history of NFL football. And it was not a fluke. Our team had resisted the temptation to perform the dance of the doomed.
“你们是谁？”我问他们。我想知道；下半场我终于知道了。49人队以28比0的比分击败圣徒队，并在加时赛中凭借雷·沃辛的任意球以38比35赢得了比赛。当时，这被认为是NFL历史上最伟大的逆转。而这并非侥幸。我们的球队抵制住了失败的诱惑。
The second half of the game demonstrated to me that the values, rules, and ideals I had been inculcating for the previous eighteen months—the Standard of Performance—were beginning to sink into the consciousness of the team, defining us to the core.
比赛的下半场向我证明，我在过去十八个月里灌输的价值观、规则和理想——绩效标准——开始深入团队的意识，从根本上定义了我们。
Among other things, I had taught players—those who needed to be taught—to comport themselves in a manner that demonstrated pride, poise, and a determination to never, ever quit, even if we trailed by a hundred points.
除此之外，我还教导球员——那些需要被教导的球员——要举止得体，展现出自豪、沉着和永不放弃的决心，即使我们落后一百分。
Your competitor must never look at you across the field, conference table, or anywhere else and conclude, “I not only beat you, I broke your spirit.” The dance of the doomed tells them they’ve broken your spirit. That message can hurt you the next time around.
你的竞争对手绝不应该在赛场上、会议桌旁，或其他任何地方看着你，然后得出这样的结论：“我不仅打败了你，还摧毁了你的意志。” 失败者的姿态会让他们觉得他们已经摧毁了你的意志。这种信息会在下次交锋中对你造成伤害。
And almost always there is a next time around.
而且几乎总会有下一次机会。

Use the Four Most Powerful Words 运用四个最有力量的词语
You need to stretch people to help them achieve their full potential. Joe Montana and Steve Young are quarterbacks who came to the 49ers with the highest personal expectations of themselves; neither lacked in confidence, and both believed they could do just about anything. I let them know I thought they could do even more than anything. You can do the same with your own talented staff and personnel.
你需要帮助员工突破极限，才能让他们充分发挥潜力。乔·蒙塔纳和史蒂夫·杨这两位四分卫当初加盟49人队时，都对自己抱有极高的期望；他们自信满满，都相信自己几乎无所不能。我让他们知道，我认为他们能做到的远不止这些。你也可以用同样的方式去培养你团队中才华横溢的员工。
The most powerful way to do this is by having the courage to say, “I believe in you,” in whatever words and way are comfortable for you. These four words—or their equivalents—constitute the most inspirational message a leader can convey. There are many different ways to do it, but the fundamental and underlying message must always be the same: “I believe in you. I know you can do the job.”
最有力的方法是鼓起勇气，用你觉得最舒服的方式，用任何你觉得合适的措辞，说出“我相信你”。这四个字——或者类似的表达——构成了领导者能够传递的最具鼓舞人心的信息。表达方式有很多种，但其根本信息必须始终如一：“我相信你。我知道你能胜任这份工作。”
Few things embolden and create self-confidence in a person like hearing those words from an individual whose judgment he or she respects, especially if that person is you, his or her boss.
没有什么比听到自己尊重的人说这些话更能鼓舞人心、增强自信了，尤其当这个人是你，是他或她的老板时。
Joe Montana—perhaps the greatest quarterback in the history of professional football—was not highly sought after by NFL teams when he graduated from Notre Dame. While he personally had a strong assessment of his own talents, most scouts didn’t share his opinion. When they saw him play, they did not see a future NFL superstar.
乔·蒙塔纳——或许是职业橄榄球历史上最伟大的四分卫——从圣母大学毕业时并没有受到NFL球队的青睐。虽然他本人对自己天赋充满信心，但大多数球探并不认同他的看法。当他们看到他比赛时，并没有看出他未来会成为NFL的超级巨星。
His performance in college, while brilliant at times, was inconsistent. He did not have a strong arm and was rather slight by NFL quarterback standards (at 6 feet 2 inches and 185 pounds, he looked like a Swedish placekicker). Additionally, Joe didn’t exude the “presence” usually associated with dominating team leaders; he was almost shy.
他在大学时期的表现虽然时有亮眼，但并不稳定。他的臂力并不强，而且以NFL四分卫的标准来看，身材也比较瘦弱（身高6英尺2英寸，体重185磅，看起来像个瑞典踢球手）。此外，乔并没有通常与球队领袖联系在一起的那种“气场”；他甚至有些腼腆。
Consequently, when it came to quarterbacks that year, Phil Simms was the guy everybody wanted, and Joe was still available in the third round of the draft when the 49ers picked him up. (Prior to my drafting Joe, my friend and fellow coach Sam Wyche tracked him down in southern California for a workout. We flew to Los Angeles International Airport and took a cab to a little public playground nearby. When Joe started throwing the ball, I knew immediately that he was very special—poise, nimble feet that reminded me of Joe Namath’s exquisite footwork, and a “look” I liked when he threw the football, even though his strength was not the long pass.)
因此，那一年四分卫位置上，菲尔·西姆斯是人人都想要的，而乔在选秀第三轮才被49人队选中。（在我选中乔之前，我的朋友兼教练同事萨姆·怀奇在南加州找到了他，让他试训。我们飞到洛杉矶国际机场，然后打车去了附近的一个小型公共游乐场。乔开始投球的那一刻，我立刻意识到他非常特别——沉着冷静，脚步灵活，让我想起了乔·纳马斯精湛的步法，而且他投球时的那种“神态”我也很喜欢，尽管他的强项并非长传。）
While he came to us with great confidence and competitive instincts, Joe Montana didn’t envision four Super Bowl rings in his future, nor that he would become a shoo-in for the NFL Hall of Fame. Regardless of the opinion Joe Montana had about his future when it came to Super Bowl rings, I let him know in word and deed that I believed in him, his potential, and his value to our team. Our relationship focused relentlessly on improving and perfecting his physical and mental skills, pushing to a higher level and nourishing his self-confidence so he could realize his optimum potential. I want to be clear that Joe believed in himself—very much. My role was to reinforce and expand that confidence and teach him how to translate it into performance at the highest level.
尽管乔·蒙塔纳带着十足的自信和强烈的竞争意识来到我们这里，但他并没有预料到自己未来会赢得四枚超级碗戒指，更没有想到自己会毫无悬念地入选NFL名人堂。无论乔·蒙塔纳对自己能否获得超级碗戒指有何想法，我都用言语和行动让他明白，我相信他，相信他的潜力，相信他对我们球队的价值。我们始终致力于提升和完善他的身心技能，推动他达到更高的水平，并培养他的自信心，让他能够充分发挥自己的潜力。我想强调的是，乔对自己充满信心——非常自信。我的职责是巩固和增强他的这份自信，并教会他如何将这种自信转化为最高水平的竞技表现。
Joe absorbed this ongoing support and teaching and saw that I was ready and willing to work hard with him in bringing forth his best effort. For this same reason, most quarterbacks I’ve worked with have also done very well, often becoming ranked as some of the best performers in their league. My first QB was Greg Cook with the Cincinnati Bengals, who soon led the league in passing efficiency. Next came Virgil Carter and Ken Anderson, who became rated at or near the top of the league in this same important category. Later, Hall of Famer Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers made huge improvements in his skills as a passer under my direction. When I coached at Stanford University, Guy Benjamin and Steve Dils led the NCAA and Steve Stenstrom broke all Pac-10 Conference records for passing efficiency.
乔吸收了这种持续的支持和指导，他看到我已做好准备，愿意与他一起努力，帮助他发挥出最佳水平。正因如此，我指导过的大多数四分卫都取得了非常优异的成绩，往往跻身联盟顶尖行列。我的第一位四分卫是辛辛那提猛虎队的格雷格·库克，他很快就领跑联盟的传球效率榜。接下来是维吉尔·卡特和肯·安德森，他们在这一重要指标上也名列联盟前茅。后来，在我的指导下，圣地亚哥闪电队的四分卫名人堂成员丹·福茨的传球技巧有了显著提升。我在斯坦福大学执教期间，盖伊·本杰明和史蒂夫·迪尔斯领衔NCAA，史蒂夫·斯滕斯特罗姆打破了太平洋十校联盟的所有传球效率纪录。
Of course, the great Steve Young, who followed Joe Montana as the 49ers’ starting quarterback, went from languishing in Tampa Bay to setting NFL records that put him in the Hall of Fame.
当然，伟大的史蒂夫·杨接替乔·蒙塔纳成为旧金山49人队的首发四分卫，他从在坦帕湾默默无闻到创造了NFL纪录，最终入选名人堂。
This pattern of significant improvement in quarterbacks—and I could give multiple examples at other positions and among our staff—was not an accident. Even though each man had different strengths and weaknesses (and all of them had problems that needed fixing), even though each had a different mixture of confidence and uncertainty, they all got one fundamental message from me: “I believe in you.” I said it, meant it, and had the expertise to teach them how to get better and better.
四分卫水平的显著提升——我还可以举出其他位置和我们教练组其他成员的很多例子——绝非偶然。尽管每个人都有不同的长处和短处（而且他们都有需要改进的地方），尽管每个人的自信和不确定程度也不尽相同，但他们都从我这里得到了一个根本的信息：“我相信你。”我说了这句话，而且是真心实意的，并且我有能力指导他们如何不断进步。
It’s true with starting quarterbacks and backup quarterbacks; it’s true with salespeople, department heads, staff members, and virtually everyone else we work with. As a leader you must have the strength to let talented members of your organization know you believe in them—nurture their belief in themselves, teach them what they need to know, and then watch what happens. It’s amazing and one of the things I love most about leadership—teaching a person how to reach higher and higher, to achieve great things with his or her talent.
首发四分卫和替补四分卫都是如此；销售人员、部门主管、员工，以及我们几乎所有共事的人，都是如此。作为领导者，你必须有勇气让组织中才华横溢的成员知道你相信他们——培养他们的自信心，教会他们需要知道的一切，然后静观其变。这令人惊叹，也是我最热爱领导力的原因之一——引导一个人不断攀登高峰，用他们的才能成就伟业。
And always keep this in mind: Nobody will ever come back to you later and say “thank you” for expecting too little of them.
永远记住这一点：没有人会因为你对他们期望太低而事后对你表示“感谢”。

Extreme Effort Requires Extreme Prudence 极致的努力需要极致的谨慎
Aggressive leaders—effective ones—push individuals hard, and then we push harder, knowing that one of our responsibilities is to get that extra effort necessary for an organization to achieve top results. A good leader believes that he or she knows the secret (or secrets) for bringing a group up to maximum productivity, and in fact, if you don’t know how to do it you’ll soon be gone.
积极进取的领导者——也就是高效的领导者——会严格要求员工，而我们也会更加努力，因为我们深知，我们的职责之一就是激发员工的额外潜能，从而帮助组织取得最佳业绩。优秀的领导者相信自己掌握了提升团队生产力的秘诀（或多个秘诀），事实上，如果你不知道如何做到这一点，你很快就会被淘汰。
However, it’s just as important to understand that “extra effort,” in whatever form it takes (mental, physical, emotional), cannot be sustained without eventual damage and diminishing returns. There has to be a very acute awareness on your part as to the level of exertion and the toll it’s taking on those you lead. A head coach is no different from a CEO or department head in needing to know when it’s time to let up a bit, allow for recharging of the internal batteries of those on your team.
然而，同样重要的是要明白，“额外付出”无论以何种形式（精神、体力、情感）持续下去，最终都会造成损害并导致收益递减。你必须敏锐地意识到自己付出的代价以及这种付出对你所带领的团队成员造成的损耗。主教练与首席执行官或部门主管并无二致，都需要知道何时应该稍作休息，让团队成员恢复精力。
One of your great challenges is finding the middle ground between the well-being of the people who work with you and the achievement of your goals. My observation is that many leaders have risen to the top in part because we work “too hard.” That’s one of the reasons we got to the top in the first place. It’s only natural that we think everybody should follow our extreme example. Most, however, do not desire to become consumed by work, to let it virtually take over their lives. That’s just a fact.
你面临的一大挑战是如何在团队成员的福祉和自身目标的实现之间找到平衡点。我的观察是，许多领导者之所以能登上顶峰，部分原因在于他们“工作太拼命”。这恰恰是我们当初能够成功的原因之一。我们自然而然地会认为每个人都应该效仿我们这种极端做法。然而，大多数人并不想被工作吞噬，让工作几乎占据他们生活的全部。这是不争的事实。
The art of leadership requires knowing when it makes sense to take people over the top, to push them to their highest level of effort, and when to take your foot off the accelerator a little. If your team is constantly working on adrenaline, in a crisis mode, running as hard as they can, they become vulnerable. When an emergency arises, when the competition suddenly presents an unexpected threat, your team has no next level to step up to, no reserves to draw on. The best leaders are those who understand the levels of energy and focus available within their team. They also recognize which situations require extreme effort and which do not. Knowing the difference ensures that your organization is fresh and fully able to perform at its uppermost levels when it’s necessary.
