领导的艺术在于懂得何时应该激励团队成员全力以赴，发挥他们的最大潜能，以及何时应该适时放慢脚步。如果你的团队始终处于肾上腺素飙升的状态，处于危机模式，拼尽全力，他们就会变得脆弱。当紧急情况发生，当竞争对手突然发起意想不到的威胁时，你的团队将无力应对，也无储备力量可以依靠。优秀的领导者能够了解团队成员的能量和专注力水平。他们也能够分辨哪些情况需要付出极大的努力，哪些情况则不需要。了解其中的区别，才能确保你的组织在必要时保持最佳状态，并能发挥出最高水平的实力。
In my own estimation, I was extremely good in this area, adept at knowing when to push very hard and for how long and in what manner. The one time I really missed the boat on it probably cost us a Super Bowl and almost got me fired.
依我看来，我在这方面做得非常出色，很擅长把握时机，知道何时该全力以赴，以及全力以赴的时长和方式。有一次我在这方面失手，可能导致我们输掉超级碗，也差点让我丢掉工作。
During my ninth year as head coach of the 49ers, NFL players went on strike after the second game of the season. It was not unexpected by our organization, and we did an excellent job getting ready for the consequences of having the regulars walk out. However, when the strike ended and they returned, there was a lot of pent-up anger and emotion that came out; some were extremely upset with me for decisions I had made; others were angry at the NFL and/or their teammates. It was an emotionally bruising return to action, but somehow we came through it in great shape and won nine of the next ten regular-season games—overall the best record in the NFL at 13-2 (the strike caused the cancellation of one regular-season game) and designation by many as the odds-on choice to win Super Bowl XXII. And now it was time for me to prepare our team for the play-offs leading to the championship game.
在我执教旧金山49人队的第九个年头，NFL球员在赛季第二场比赛后就举行了罢工。这对于我们球队来说并不意外，我们也做好了充分的准备，应对主力球员罢工可能带来的后果。然而，当罢工结束，球员们回归赛场时，积压已久的愤怒和情绪爆发了出来；有些人对我做出的决定感到非常不满；另一些人则对NFL和/或他们的队友感到愤怒。重返赛场的过程令人情绪低落，但我们最终还是挺了过来，并在接下来的十场常规赛中赢下了九场——以13胜2负的战绩领跑NFL（罢工导致一场常规赛取消），并被许多人视为第22届超级碗的夺冠热门。现在，是时候让我带领球队备战季后赛，最终冲击总冠军了。
For the first time in my career, I did something I had never done before; namely, during practices I ran our team into the ground. I’m still not sure what I was thinking when I pushed the team to their limits in those days prior to our NFC play-off game against the Minnesota Vikings, but it was fatal.
那是我职业生涯中第一次做一件以前从未做过的事：在训练中，我把全队累得筋疲力尽。直到现在，我仍然不确定在与明尼苏达维京人队进行NFC季后赛之前的那几天，我究竟是怎么想的，才会把球队逼到极限，但这却是致命的。
We had lost in the first round the two previous years, and that had been very hard to take. Perhaps I decided subconsciously that this time around I was just going to have to push them harder in areas I felt needed improvement—deep passes, for example. But there were always components of our game that I felt could be improved. That was nothing new. In this instance, however, I began driving the team harder and harder, offensive players especially, until ultimately they were essentially exhausted at the worst possible time: They were about to face a very strong Minnesota Vikings team with a defensive line that had come into its own during the season; the Vikings meant business.
前两年我们都在第一轮就被淘汰了，这让我们非常难受。或许我潜意识里决定，这次我必须在我觉得需要改进的地方——比如长传——对他们进行更严格的训练。其实，我们比赛中总有一些环节我觉得可以提升，这对我来说并不陌生。但这一次，我开始对球队，尤其是进攻球员，进行越来越高强度的训练，直到他们最终筋疲力尽，而这恰恰是最糟糕的情况：他们即将面对一支实力强劲的明尼苏达维京人队，维京人队的防守锋线在本赛季已经完全融入球队；维京人队是来真的。
This game, obviously, was a situation that called for stepping it up, extra effort, extreme exertion. Unfortunately, our guys, Jerry Rice, for example, were still physically and mentally worn down because of the grueling nature of my ongoing pre-play-off workouts. We got beat because we were beat. There was very little left in the tank by the opening kickoff. Minnesota won 36-24, but the game may not have been as close as that score suggests.
显然，这场比赛需要我们全力以赴，付出额外的努力。不幸的是，我们的队员，比如杰里·赖斯，由于我之前进行的季后赛前高强度训练，身心都已疲惫不堪。我们输球是因为我们真的筋疲力尽了。开球时，我们几乎已经精疲力竭。明尼苏达最终以36比24获胜，但比赛的实际比分可能并没有比分显示的那么接近。
Eddie DeBartolo was furious and seriously considered firing me. He was correct in the sense that it was my poor leadership judgment that had been responsible for our bad performance. It was my fault. I had strayed from my instincts and understanding that when it comes to demanding extreme effort, a good leader must exercise extreme prudence.
埃迪·德巴托洛非常生气，甚至认真考虑过解雇我。从某种意义上说，他的想法是对的，我们糟糕的业绩确实是我领导判断失误造成的。这都是我的错。我违背了自己的直觉和判断，没有意识到，在要求员工付出巨大努力时，一个优秀的领导者必须极其谨慎。
This is one of the most difficult areas of leadership. By instinct we—leaders—want to run hard all the time; by intellect we know this is not possible. Reconciling those two positions in the context of leadership is an ongoing challenge. I believe the one time in my career when I didn’t successfully reconcile the two, it cost us a championship.
这是领导力中最难的领域之一。出于本能，我们——领导者——总是想全力以赴；但理智告诉我们这是不可能的。如何在领导力的语境下调和这两种想法，始终是一个挑战。我相信，在我职业生涯中，唯一一次没能成功调和这两种想法，就让我们错失了冠军。
It’s an easy trap to fall into—pushing your team to the brink and then over—because there is comfort in knowing that if we are defeated, at least we worked—and worked our team—as hard as possible. For a hardwork ing leader that’s easy to do. What’s difficult to do is recognize when extra effort, extreme exertion, working “as hard as possible” starts to produce diminishing returns.
很容易陷入这样的陷阱——把团队逼到极限，然后推下去——因为即使失败，至少我们尽了全力，也让团队竭尽所能，这会带来一丝安慰。对于勤奋的领导者来说，这很容易做到。难的是，要意识到额外的努力、过度的付出、“竭尽全力”何时开始产生递减效应。

The Bubba Diet: You Can’t Transplant Willpower 布巴减肥法：意志力无法移植
Bubba Paris is a man whose outstanding talent and potential for greatness were exceeded only by his big heart and large appetite. While he had a great college career at Michigan and was a valuable member of the 49ers, I tend to think his craving for food eventually cost him his job in the National Football League.
巴布·帕里斯天赋异禀，潜力无限，但他的贪婪和食量却更胜一筹。他在密歇根大学时期表现出色，也曾是旧金山49人队的重要成员，但我认为，正是他对美食的渴望最终让他失去了在国家橄榄球联盟的工作。
Ideally, Bubba’s best weight was at something less than 300 pounds, but his voracious eating habits skyrocketed him into the vicinity of 350 pounds and beyond, dramatically reducing his quickness and stamina. Adding to the urgency of the issue was the fact that doctors were telling him, “Mr. Paris, you won’t live past the age of fifty if you don’t lose weight.” With 49er training camp workouts being conducted in hundred-degree heat at Sierra College in Rocklin, California, I worried that Bubba might not even reach forty if he didn’t get his weight under control.
理想情况下，巴布的最佳体重应该在300磅以下，但他暴饮暴食的习惯让他体重飙升至350磅甚至更高，这极大地降低了他的速度和耐力。更紧迫的是，医生告诉他：“帕里斯先生，如果你不减肥，活不过五十岁。” 49人队的训练营在加州罗克林市的塞拉学院进行，气温高达100华氏度（约38摄氏度），我担心如果巴布不控制体重，他可能连四十岁都活不到。
Consequently, our nutritionist and team trainers worked conscientiously with him during camp and encouraged Bubba to eat fewer fries and more fish, less pie and more pasta, Diet Coke instead of double-thick chocolate shakes.
因此，我们的营养师和团队教练在训练营期间尽心尽力地帮助他，鼓励巴布少吃薯条多吃鱼，少吃馅饼多吃意大利面，喝健怡可乐而不是双倍浓稠的巧克力奶昔。
Bubba was trying to get with the program, but it just didn’t seem to be working—the weight wasn’t coming off, in spite of the obvious fact that he was also giving it his best effort during practice and at the training table. This became very frustrating for us, and I came to recognize that a metabolic issue was the probable explanation for all the extra weight and his failure to lose any of it by the end of training camp. I was convinced of it. What more could Bubba Paris possibly have done to lose weight? Well, I found out.
巴布一直努力配合训练计划，但似乎并不奏效——尽管他在训练和饮食方面都尽了全力，体重却丝毫没有减轻。这让我们非常沮丧，我逐渐意识到，代谢问题很可能是导致他体重增加以及训练营结束时体重丝毫未减的原因。我对此深信不疑。巴布·帕里斯究竟还能做些什么来减肥呢？嗯，我后来找到了答案。
On the Saturday morning when we broke camp to head back to San Francisco, the maid’s supervisor in charge of the dormitories—a stern woman who reminded me of the head nurse in One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest —came to my office. “Mr. Walsh, I think you should take a look at how some of your athletes live,” she announced. Uh-oh.
周六早上，我们收拾营地返回旧金山时，负责宿舍的女佣主管——一个严厉的女人，让我想起了《飞越疯人院》里的护士长——来到我的办公室。“沃尔什先生，我觉得您应该看看你们的一些运动员的生活状况，”她宣布道。糟糕。
Dutifully I followed her to Bubba’s room in the dorm—empty now. When I entered, there was a pleasant surprise. “What’s the problem here?” I thought to myself. “Nothing’s broken. Very clean. No holes in the wall. Looks good.” I smiled and nodded politely in her direction. Maybe I’d misunderstood. Perhaps the problem was with some other player’s room, one of those who occasionally got overly rambunctious. I was wrong.
我乖乖地跟着她来到宿舍里巴布的房间——现在空无一人。进去之后，我惊喜地发现一切都很正常。“这是怎么回事？”我心想。“东西都没坏，很干净，墙上也没有洞，看起来不错。”我朝她笑了笑，礼貌地点了点头。也许是我误会了。或许问题出在其他球员的房间里，比如某个偶尔会过于喧闹的球员。我错了。
Solemnly I watched as she marched over to Bubba’s closet and opened the door. She reached inside, flipped the switch, and turned on the light. I took a look.
我神情肃穆地看着她走到巴布的衣橱前，打开了衣橱门。她伸手进去，拨动开关，打开了灯。我看了一眼。
There, stacked one on top of another in the back of the closet, were scores of grease-stained, extra large, red-striped Kentucky Fried Chicken boxes—the empty remnants of all the terrific meals Bubba had smuggled in during the past few weeks. Crumpled up and scattered around the closet floor were KFC napkins, empty soda cups, straws, even a couple of dried chicken bones that had also been left behind—final evidence of an appetite out of control.
在衣橱深处，一摞摞堆满了油渍斑斑的超大号肯德基红条纹外卖盒——那是巴布过去几周偷偷带进来的美味佳肴的空空残骸。衣橱地板上散落着揉成一团的肯德基餐巾纸、空汽水杯、吸管，甚至还有几根干巴巴的鸡骨头——这些都是他食欲失控的最终证据。
Bubba was eating like a bird at the training table, but the dinner bell didn’t really ring until he got back to his dorm room.
巴布在训练台上吃得像只小鸟，但直到他回到宿舍，晚餐铃声才真正响起。
All of this was a good lesson for me: Willpower was not a commodity I could simply hand out like a couple of aspirin tablets.
这一切对我来说都是一个很好的教训：意志力不是我可以像分发几片阿司匹林一样随意发放的东西。
Whether it’s a 350-pound tackle, an employee, or a child, we must try our best to encourage, support, and inspire, but eventually—ultimately—people must do it for themselves. No one else can do it for them, including you, regardless of whether you’re a head coach, CEO, manager, nutritionist, or doctor. A closet floor covered with KFC boxes reminded me of that.
无论是350磅重的橄榄球运动员、员工还是孩子，我们都必须尽力去鼓励、支持和启发他们，但最终——归根结底——人们必须靠自己。没有人能替他们做到，包括你，无论你是主教练、首席执行官、经理、营养师还是医生。堆满肯德基盒子的壁橱地板让我意识到了这一点。
Nevertheless, I’m happy to report that Bubba Paris has gotten a certain amount of control over his weight problem and is leading a much healthier lifestyle—too late to extend his successful football career, but hopefully in time to extend his life.
不过，我很高兴地告诉大家，布巴·帕里斯已经在一定程度上控制住了他的体重问题，并且正在过着更加健康的生活方式——虽然为时已晚，无法延长他成功的足球生涯，但希望能够延长他的寿命。

“Conventional Wisdom” Is an Oxymoron “传统智慧”本身就是一个自相矛盾的说法。
Coaches and scouts in the National Football League view the raw speed demonstrated in the forty-yard sprint as a litmus test of a receiver’s potential, a tried-and-true tool in deciding whether to draft him. Do a good time in the forty and you’ve probably got a job; less than that and you may have to look for another line of work.
美国国家橄榄球联盟（NFL）的教练和球探将40码冲刺的速度视为衡量接球手潜力的试金石，这是决定是否选秀的行之有效的工具。40码冲刺成绩好，你很可能就找到了工作；成绩差，你可能就得另谋出路了。
I took a somewhat different view. I valued blazing speed but also prized what I call “functional” speed—how fast a player can move with a ball in his hands after he’s in stride. To my thinking, that’s how it’s usually done in a game. Because of my unconventional philosophy, I was able to see the potential in a young man who became the greatest receiver in NFL history.
我的观点略有不同。我重视惊人的速度，但也同样重视我所谓的“实用速度”——球员持球跑动后的速度。在我看来，这才是比赛中通常应有的速度。正是因为我这种非传统的理念，我才能看到一位年轻人身上蕴藏的潜力，而他最终成为了NFL历史上最伟大的接球手。
The night before a 49ers game in Houston during my sixth season as head coach, I was watching a local television station’s sports highlights in my hotel room. One of the games it covered involved a tiny college in Itta Bena, Mississippi, called Mississippi Valley State.
在我担任主教练的第六个赛季，在休斯顿有一场49人队的比赛前夜，我在酒店房间里观看当地电视台的体育集锦。其中一场比赛的对手是位于密西西比州伊塔贝纳的一所小型学院，名叫密西西比河谷州立大学。
The school’s top receiver was a kid named Jerry Rice who seemed to find a way to get open, catch the ball, and gain yardage with ease. I think he scored four or five touchdowns in the game, in spite of the fact that he would not have won a medal in the Olympic hundred-yard dash. Once he hit full stride, however, Rice was something truly remarkable. He had functional speed, fantastic moves, and hands that were as sure as a surgeon’s. Plus, Jerry Rice had the heart of a warrior.
学校里最厉害的接球手名叫杰里·赖斯，他似乎总能找到空位，轻松接住球，推进码数。我记得他那场比赛拿了四五个达阵，尽管他就算在奥运会百米短跑比赛中也拿不到奖牌。但一旦他全力冲刺，赖斯就展现出了惊人的天赋。他速度很快，动作灵活，接球手感更是精准无比。此外，杰里·赖斯还拥有一颗战士般的心。
And I knew I could design plays that got him open and put the ball in his hands. I can still remember the excitement I felt thinking about it as I watched him during that sports highlights show in Texas. Believe it or not, I was in the minority when it came to recognizing Jerry’s potential.
我知道我可以设计一些战术，让他获得空位，把球交到他手里。我至今还记得，在德克萨斯州的体育集锦节目里看到他时，想到这一点，我感到多么兴奋。信不信由你，在当时，意识到杰里潜力的人并不多。
He was not considered a top-flight prospect by some prominent scouts around the league, and even in the 49er organization, because he had a “mediocre” forty-yard time—not much better than 4.6 seconds. They considered him a possible fifth- or sixth-round draft pick because he lacked so-called blazing speed off the blocks. I was strongly advised not to waste our number one draft choice to pick him. That was the conventional wisdom.
联盟中一些知名球探，甚至包括49人队内部的球探，都不认为他是一位顶尖新秀，因为他的40码冲刺成绩“平庸”——仅仅4.6秒左右。他们认为他可能在第五轮或第六轮才会被选中，因为他缺乏所谓的“闪电般”的起跑速度。我被强烈建议不要浪费我们的首轮选秀权去选他。这在当时是普遍的看法。
I knew better, looked beyond his so-so time in the forty, ignored the advice I had been given, and focused on his outstanding speed and moves from fifteen to fifty yards. I was one of only a few who felt this way about the promising receiver, because a trade with New England moved us up enough in the draft to acquire the still-available Jerry Rice with our number one pick. Two other wide receivers were chosen ahead of Jerry by teams that didn’t see what I saw in him. And that’s how the San Francisco 49ers acquired the services of the greatest receiver, perhaps the greatest player, in NFL history.
我当时看准了他的底细，没有理会他40码冲刺成绩平平，也没有听取别人的建议，而是专注于他惊人的速度和15到50码之间的移动能力。当时只有少数人像我一样看好这位前途无量的接球手，因为与新英格兰爱国者队的一笔交易让我们在选秀中顺位提升，最终用状元签选中了当时仍然待选的杰里·赖斯。在杰里之前，还有两名接球手被其他球队选中，因为他们没有看到我眼中的杰里。就这样，旧金山49人队得到了NFL历史上最伟大的接球手，或许也是最伟大的球员。
Here’s my point. Occasionally, when striving to go beyond conventional results, you must go beyond the conventional and against popular opinion. This means trusting your own judgment enough to be resourceful, innovative, and imaginative. It means resisting the herd mentality.
我的观点是这样的：有时候，为了超越常规，你必须打破常规，甚至违背大众观点。这意味着你要足够相信自己的判断，并发挥创造力、创新精神和想象力。这意味着你要抵制从众心理。
To put it another way: Conventional wisdom often produces conventional results. Conventional thinking didn’t produce Jerry Rice.
换句话说：传统观念往往产生传统结果。但杰里·赖斯并非出自传统思维。

Make Friends, Not Enemies: Al Davis, Howard Cosell, and Monday Night Football 广交朋友，而非树敌：艾尔·戴维斯、霍华德·科塞尔和周一晚间橄榄球赛
Enemies take up your time, energy, and attention—commodities too valuable to squander frivolously. This is especially true in a profession as public as professional football, because everybody takes potshots at you all the time; it’s easy to acquire a long list of individuals with whom you want to even the score.
敌人会消耗你的时间、精力和注意力——这些都是极其宝贵的资源，不容随意浪费。在职业足球这样备受瞩目的行业中，这一点尤为重要，因为每个人都会时不时地对你冷嘲热讽；你很容易就会积累一长串想要报复的人。
That’s why I instructed everyone in our organization—players, staff, and all others—to do everything possible to get along with people who interacted with us, even when it might appear they were treating us unfairly. We simply couldn’t afford to waste resources fighting needless fights, whether with fans, media, vendors, sponsors, other teams, or anyone else, including squabbles among ourselves. You can quickly find yourself doing nothing but chasing so-called enemies.
这就是为什么我指示我们组织里的所有人——球员、工作人员以及所有其他人员——尽一切可能与所有和我们接触的人和睦相处，即使他们看起来对我们不公平。我们实在无法承受把资源浪费在无谓的争斗上，无论是与球迷、媒体、供应商、赞助商、其他球队还是其他人，包括我们内部的争吵。否则，你很快就会发现自己除了追逐所谓的敌人之外，什么也没做。
“Hostile relationships are toxic. Cultivate good relationships,” I cautioned. “Be available; avoid making enemies; don’t close off communications.” I taught those in the organization that it was necessary to initiate communication after a conflict, even if the other person had misunderstood you or wrongfully ridiculed you. And to understand that regardless of the cause of the animosity, negative relationships have ongoing negative consequences.
“敌对的关系是有害的。要培养良好的关系，”我告诫道。“保持沟通渠道畅通；避免树敌；不要切断沟通。”我教导组织里的每个人，即使对方误解了你或无端嘲笑了你，冲突过后也必须主动沟通。并且要明白，无论敌意的起因是什么，负面的关系都会带来持续的负面影响。
I felt that positive or at least nonadversarial relationships were a tangible and significant organizational asset. I worked hard at following my own advice about having “no enemies,” and it paid handsome dividends.
我认为积极的、至少是非对抗性的人际关系是组织中一项切实而重要的资产。我努力践行自己“不树敌”的原则，并获得了丰厚的回报。
For example, Al Davis, owner of the Oakland Raiders, was a pivotal figure in the evolution of the NFL. He is a man of tremendous ability from whom I learned a great deal when I was one of his assistant coaches. Early in his career he was an outstanding and innovative coach (later general manager); his knowledge, creativity, and charisma made him one of the best. Additionally, Al had tremendous expectations of himself and everyone around him.
例如，奥克兰突袭者队的老板阿尔·戴维斯是NFL发展历程中的关键人物。他是一位才华横溢的人，我曾担任他的助理教练，从他身上学到了很多。在他职业生涯早期，他是一位杰出且富有创新精神的教练（后来担任总经理）；他的知识、创造力和个人魅力使他成为最优秀的教练之一。此外，阿尔对自己和周围的每个人都抱有极高的期望。
Similarly, as an owner he had great results—Oakland Raiders championships in Super Bowl XI, Super Bowl XV, and Super Bowl XVIII.
同样，作为球队老板，他也取得了巨大的成功——带领奥克兰突袭者队赢得了第十一届、第十五届和第十八届超级碗冠军。
But Al Davis could be the devil personified if you crossed him or got on his bad side. I did not want his wrath and made very sure that our relationship was very workable. I simply didn’t look for a fight, even when Al might test my patience, and he was pretty good at doing that. Among other things, my approach meant that we had a positive and productive connection. I could call Al on the phone and make a deal in a second (as I did in the Cedrick Hardman trade). We got along fine over many years and through a variety of challenges.
但如果你得罪了阿尔·戴维斯，或者惹恼了他，他简直就是魔鬼的化身。我不想惹他生气，所以非常注意我们之间的关系，确保我们合作愉快。我尽量避免与他发生冲突，即使阿尔有时会挑战我的耐心——而他在这方面确实很擅长。正因如此，我们之间建立了积极有效的联系。我可以随时给阿尔打电话，瞬间达成协议（就像我之前在塞德里克·哈德曼的交易中那样）。多年来，我们一直相处融洽，共同经历了各种挑战。
Howard Cosell, one of Monday Night Football ’s biggest stars, was a different story and tested my “no enemies” policy when I met him for the first time.
霍华德·科塞尔是周一晚间橄榄球赛最耀眼的明星之一，但他的情况却截然不同。当我第一次见到他时，他考验了我“不树敌”的原则。
Months before a chance meeting in New York, I had announced with great irritation during a Tuesday press conference that San Francisco had not been mentioned once on the previous evening’s Monday Night Football halftime highlights show. The reason? The network, and Howard, didn’t want to remind viewers that we had crushed Dallas, 45-14, the day before. And Dallas was playing the Los Angeles Rams in an unusual Sunday-night game on ABC-TV in just six days.
几个月前，在纽约那次偶然的会面之前，我曾在周二的新闻发布会上非常恼火地宣布，前一天晚上的周一橄榄球之夜中场集锦节目中，旧金山竟然一次都没被提及。原因何在？电视台和霍华德都不想让观众想起，就在前一天，我们以45比14的比分大胜达拉斯。而仅仅六天后，达拉斯就要在ABC电视台的周日晚间节目中，与洛杉矶公羊队进行一场不同寻常的比赛。
I was offended and told reporters, “The football elitists, jockstrap elitists don’t consider us in the comfort zone. There are power sources, influence sources in the National Football League, forty-five-year-old men who are football groupies who prefer that we not exist so they can hold on to their football contracts and associations or power groups. It’s a business, and they [ABC] need the Los Angeles-Dallas game to be a big [ratings] game. It’s obvious; it’s blatant. It’s a disservice to the public.” I was letting off steam because I viewed the omission as intentional and part of the NFL’s view that San Francisco was a backwater of professional football, a team that didn’t matter. Nevertheless, once I made my statement, I moved on and thought it was over. But it wasn’t over.
我当时很生气，就对记者说：“那些足球精英，那些穿着运动护裆的精英，根本不把我们当回事。NFL里有那些有权有势的人，那些四十五岁左右的足球狂热分子，他们巴不得我们不存在，这样他们才能保住自己的合同和关系网。这是生意，他们（ABC）需要洛杉矶对达拉斯的比赛能成为收视率大战。这很明显，明目张胆。这是对公众的不尊重。” 我当时是在发泄怒火，因为我觉得NFL故意忽略旧金山队，认为他们是在说旧金山队是职业橄榄球的边缘球队，无关紧要。不过，说完之后，我就觉得事情到此为止了。但事情并没有结束。
Many months later, I was at a cocktail reception in Manhattan and spotted Cosell across the room. I went over to him, assuming he’d want to say hello to me as much as I was looking forward to saying hello to him. I was wrong.
几个月后，我在曼哈顿参加一个鸡尾酒会，在房间另一头看到了科塞尔。我走过去和他打招呼，心想他应该也想和我打招呼，就像我期待着和他打招呼一样。但我错了。
Cosell had not forgotten my “jockstrap elitist” remarks from months earlier and was still incensed: “Who are you, sir , to confront someone like me or the people I represent?” he barked in my face as his cigar smoke curled around us. “You are nobody! You are nothing!”
科塞尔显然没忘记几个月前我那些关于“精英主义”的言论，依然怒不可遏：“你算老几，竟敢跟我这样的人，或者我所代表的人民对峙？”他冲着我的脸咆哮道，雪茄的烟雾在我们周围缭绕。“你算什么东西！你什么都不是！”
Scores of people witnessed his public browbeating of me. I retreated and disappeared into the crowd (which was buzzing about what it had just witnessed), too astonished and embarrassed by what he had done to utter any defense or apology or mount an attack. Obviously, I was very angry.
许多人目睹了他当众对我进行羞辱。我退缩着消失在人群中（人群正窃窃私语地议论着刚才发生的一切），我震惊又尴尬，根本说不出任何辩解、道歉或反击的话。显然，我非常生气。
But later, after considerable thought, I decided it was appropriate to follow my own “no enemies” policy and write Howard a conciliatory letter explaining that my comments had not been aimed at him, but rather at those at the network who were in management and production. Further, I explained that if he had taken the comments personally I sincerely apologized for any discomfort they might have caused him. Believe me, this was not an easy letter to write.
但后来，经过深思熟虑，我决定遵循自己“不树敌”的原则，给霍华德写了一封和解信，解释说我的评论并非针对他，而是针对电视台的管理层和制作人员。此外，我还解释说，如果他觉得这些评论冒犯了他，我真诚地为给他带来的任何不适道歉。相信我，这封信写起来并不容易。
Howard was appeased. He sent me a friendly note and the following season joined me for dinner in San Francisco before the 49ers’ upcoming appearance on Monday Night Football while I was head coach. Howard and I cemented our new friendship over martinis at a steak house in downtown San Francisco.
霍华德的心情缓和了下来。他给我发了一封友好的信，并在接下来的赛季中，在我担任主教练期间，49人队即将参加周一晚间橄榄球赛之前，和我一起在旧金山共进晚餐。我和霍华德在旧金山市中心一家牛排馆里一边喝着马提尼，一边巩固了我们的友谊。
From that point forward, Howard Cosell was a Bill Walsh booster, supporting my cause in all areas, even at times when I was being held up to great public criticism. He had been transformed from an adversary into an advocate.
从那时起，霍华德·科塞尔就成了比尔·沃尔什的支持者，在各个方面都支持我，即便在我遭受公众猛烈抨击的时候也是如此。他从对手变成了拥护者。
It was made possible because I was committed to a personal and organizational “no enemies” policy. Everyone on the 49ers payroll knew I expected them to do the same. Over the years, the benefits to us were significant. We simply didn’t get bogged down, distracted, or consumed with firefights that amounted to nothing. Or at least we minimized that number.
这一切之所以能够实现，是因为我始终坚持个人和组织层面的“不树敌”政策。49人队的每一位员工都知道，我希望他们也这样做。多年来，我们因此受益匪浅。我们根本不会陷入无谓的争斗，也不会被这些琐事分散注意力或消耗精力。或者至少，我们把这类事情的发生频率降到了最低。
It’s a maxim that one enemy can do more damage than the good of a hundred friends. I believe it’s true and worth remembering the next time you get upset with someone and mutter, “I’ll fix that so-and-so.” While you’re getting even, they’re getting ahead.
俗话说，一个敌人造成的破坏比一百个朋友加起来都大。我相信这句话的真谛，下次当你因为某人生气，嘟囔着“我一定要好好教训他”的时候，不妨想想这句话。在你报复的时候，他们却在趁虚而入。
You must be astute enough to avoid becoming the loser in such situations. By being sensitive to the inherent hazards of a hostile relationship, you can give yourself a chance to win the person over to having at least a neutral association with you.
你必须足够机敏，才能避免在这种情况下成为输家。通过敏锐地意识到敌对关系中固有的风险，你就能有机会赢得对方的信任，至少与对方保持一种中立的关系。
The reality of the situation is that regardless of the reason behind an extremely adversarial relationship, such a relationship can have negative consequences. Conversely, by minimizing the forces working against you, you do away with resultant distractions and free your mind and conserve your energy to focus on your work.
现实情况是，无论敌对关系背后的原因是什么，这种关系都会带来负面后果。反之，通过尽量减少不利因素，你可以消除由此产生的干扰，解放思想，节省精力，从而专注于工作。

Hold on Until Help Arrives: Keep Your Boss in the Loop 坚持到救援到来：随时向你的老板汇报情况
I was thrust into an organization that was a loser in need of a turnaround. In that situation and under the best conditions—and what I faced was far from the best—you need time to install your ideas and make them work. In one sense, you’re trying to keep your superiors from doing anything rash because they want results now , while simultaneously working with those under your supervision so they don’t give up or mutiny. Here’s how I tried to deal with the former, namely, ownership.
我被推入一个亟待扭转颓势的失败组织。在这种情况下，即便在最好的情况下——而我当时面临的远非最佳——你也需要时间来贯彻你的想法并使其奏效。一方面，你试图阻止你的上级做出任何鲁莽的举动，因为他们想要立竿见影的效果；另一方面，你又要与你的下属合作，防止他们放弃或哗变。以下是我尝试处理前者的方法，即培养责任感。
Two years before I was hired, Eddie DeBartolo paid $17 million for the San Francisco 49ers. He then turned the organization over to his son, Eddie DeBartolo Jr. Obviously, both men wanted a winner, but it wasn’t happening. Over their first two seasons, the team’s record was the worst in the league: 7-23.
在我受聘的两年前，埃迪·德巴托罗斥资1700万美元收购了旧金山49人队。之后，他将球队交给了他的儿子小埃迪·德巴托罗。显然，父子俩都渴望打造一支冠军球队，但事与愿违。在他们接手的头两个赛季里，球队的战绩是联盟最差的：7胜23负。
I came aboard in year three of their ownership and immediately added fourteen additional losses to the books, which meant after three years in the NFL the DeBartolos’ football team had a cumulative record of 9-37. The 49ers were bad and appeared to the uninformed to be getting worse. I honestly believe that in those days if we’d given away free tickets to games, we still wouldn’t have been able to fill the sixty thousand seats in Candlestick Park.
我加入球队时，他们已经拥有这支球队三年了，我立刻又给球队的账面记录增加了14场败绩，这意味着在NFL征战三年后，德巴托洛家族的球队总战绩为9胜37负。49人队当时战绩糟糕，而且在不明真相的人看来，似乎还在不断恶化。说实话，我当时觉得，就算我们免费赠送球票，也填不满烛台公园那六万个座位。
Obviously, I felt I could turn things around, but I needed to buy time. I did it, in part, by keeping Eddie Jr. in the loop; fully informed—perhaps overly informed—on every single phase of the operation.
显然，我觉得我可以扭转局面，但我需要争取时间。我争取时间的方式之一，就是让小埃迪全程参与，让他对行动的每一个阶段都了如指掌——或许是了解得太多了。
This included providing him with a budget manual (thick), an operations manual (thick), a personnel manual (thick), an overall set of job descriptions that included the specific job of each player and my evaluation of that individual (thick), and a detailed listing of my performance goals and expectations (even thicker). On and on and on. Paper. Paper. Paper. The information was not frivolous “filler,” but substantive and sizable.
这包括给他提供一份预算手册（很厚）、一份运营手册（很厚）、一份人事手册（很厚）、一套包含每位员工具体职责和我对该员工评估的综合职位描述（很厚），以及一份详细的绩效目标和期望清单（更厚）。诸如此类，不胜枚举。全是纸。这些信息并非无关紧要的“填充物”，而是内容丰富且数量庞大。
I wanted the owner (and his advisers) to understand that I was applying maximum effort and paying attention to every single solitary detail of the family’s massive financial investment. I believe the voluminous detailing of my efforts and plans bought me precious time. The hands-off patience Eddie Jr. afforded me in the beginning contributed greatly to winning our first Super Bowl championship. He was a terrific boss to work for during my early years as head coach and general manager of his team. I believe this was due in some measure to the fact that my ongoing effort to keep him totally informed gave him comfort.
我希望老板（以及他的顾问们）明白，我正在竭尽全力，并且对家族这笔巨额投资的每一个细节都一丝不苟。我相信，我详尽地阐述我的努力和计划，为我赢得了宝贵的时间。小埃迪在初期给予我的放手和耐心，对我们最终赢得首个超级碗冠军起到了至关重要的作用。在我担任球队主教练兼总经理的早期，他是一位非常棒的老板。我相信，这在一定程度上要归功于我始终如一地让他全面了解情况，这让他感到安心。
Positive results—winning—count most. But until those results come through your door, a heavy dose of documentation relating to what you’ve done and what you’re doing, planning to do, and hoping to do may buy you just enough extra time to actually do it.
积极的结果——胜利——才是最重要的。但在这些结果到来之前，大量记录你已经做过的事情、正在做的事情、计划要做的事情以及希望做的事情，或许能为你争取到足够的时间去真正地去做这些事情。
Whether they read it or not, flood your superiors with information that is documented—projections, evaluations, reports on progress, status updates. Then ask for periodic meetings. In a very professional way, force them to understand that you’re doing everything you possibly can and that it’s documented; in fact, they’re holding it in that large folder in their hands. Open and honest communication with your superiors, both written and verbal, is a valuable tool in keeping them from coming to the wrong conclusions.
无论他们是否阅读，都要让你的上级充分了解所有有据可查的信息——预测、评估、进度报告、状态更新等等。然后要求定期召开会议。以非常专业的态度，让他们明白你已经竭尽所能，而且所有工作都有记录；事实上，他们手里就拿着那厚厚的文件夹。与上级进行公开透明的沟通，无论是书面还是口头，都是避免他们得出错误结论的有效工具。
It can be the difference between being stabbed in the back or patted on the back.
这可能意味着你是被背后捅刀还是被拍拍肩膀。

Keep Your Eye on the Ball 盯紧球
While mollifying those who may decide your fate during a losing streak or turnaround effort—the boss, board of directors, or shareholders—you also need to be absolutely disciplined in focusing your own attention on what really matters. Here are a dozen daily reminders that will help keep you on the right track:
1. Concentrate on what will produce results rather than on the results, the process rather than the prize.
2. Exhibit an inner toughness emanating from four of the most effective survival tools a leader can possess: expertise, composure, patience, and common sense.
3. Maintain your level of professional ethics and all details of your own Standard of Performance.
4. Don’t isolate yourself. Keep in mind that as troubles mount, your relationships with personnel become even more critical. They are the key to holding the staff together. (Don’t get too friendly, however. Familiarity can be deadly.)
5. Don’t let the magnitude of the challenge take you away from the incremental steps necessary to effect change. Continue to be detail oriented.
6. Exude an upbeat and determined attitude. Never, ever express doubt, but avoid an inappropriate sunny optimism in dark times.
7. Hold meetings with staff educating them on what to expect; teach them that the immediate future may be a rough ride but that things will change under your leadership and with their support.
8. Don’t label some concept or new plan the thing that will “get us back on track.” Keep in mind that simple remedies seldom solve a complex problem.
9. Ensure that an appropriate level of courtesy and respect is extended to all members of the organization. When things are tough, civility is a great asset.
10. Don’t plead with employees to “do better.”
11. Avoid continual threatening or chastising.
12. Deal with your immediate superior(s) on a one-to-one, ongoing basis. Expect betrayal if results are not immediate. (You extend the time before betrayal occurs by keeping your superiors in the loop.)
在应对公司连败或扭转颓势时，你需要安抚那些可能决定你命运的人——老板、董事会或股东——同时，你也必须绝对自律，将注意力集中在真正重要的事情上。以下十二条每日提醒将帮助你保持正确的方向：1. 专注于能够产生结果的事情，而不是结果本身；专注于过程，而不是奖赏。2. 展现内在的坚韧，这源于领导者应具备的四项最有效的生存技能：专业知识、沉着冷静、耐心和常识。3. 保持你的职业道德水平，并严格遵守你自身的绩效标准。4. 不要孤立自己。记住，随着问题的增多，你与员工的关系变得更加重要。他们是维系团队的关键。（但是，不要过于亲近。熟悉可能会带来致命的后果。）5. 不要让挑战的艰巨性使你忽略了实现变革所需的循序渐进的步骤。继续保持对细节的关注。展现积极乐观、坚定不移的态度。永远不要流露出任何怀疑，但也避免在困境中表现得过于乐观。7. 与员工召开会议，让他们了解预期情况；让他们明白，短期内可能会比较艰难，但在你的领导和他们的支持下，情况终将好转。8. 不要把某个概念或新计划标榜为“让我们重回正轨”的灵丹妙药。记住，简单的解决办法很少能解决复杂的问题。9. 确保对组织中的所有成员都给予适当的礼貌和尊重。在困难时期，文明礼貌至关重要。10. 不要恳求员工“做得更好”。11. 避免持续的威胁或责骂。12. 与你的直接上级保持一对一的持续沟通。如果结果没有立即显现，就要做好被背叛的准备。（通过让你的上级了解情况，你可以延长被背叛的时间。）

Make Your Own Mentors: A PhD from the University of Paul Brown, et al. 打造你自己的导师：保罗·布朗等人的博士论文
We learn in many ways from many sources. One of the most powerful is a mentor, usually thought of as an older, wiser person who takes you under his wing—provides ongoing teaching, counsel, direction, experience, and moral support. But being mentored can also be simply a matter of keen observation, analysis, and learning by the “student,” whether there is any intent by a “mentor” or not.
我们通过多种途径从多种渠道学习。其中最有效的途径之一是导师，通常被认为是一位年长、睿智的人，他会悉心指导你，提供持续的教导、建议、方向、经验和精神支持。但接受指导也可能仅仅是“学生”敏锐的观察、分析和学习，无论“导师”是否有此意图。
I don’t think that when I was an assistant in the NFL—first at Oakland, then Cincinnati, then San Diego—any head coach or general manager I worked for thought of himself as my mentor. Nevertheless, they served as such because I consciously assimilated as much of their great know-how as I could—asking questions about the logic supporting their decisions; analyzing their behavior in managing others; drawing my own conclusions about how to incorporate it into my own approach to coaching and leadership.
我不认为我在NFL担任助理教练期间——先是在奥克兰，然后是辛辛那提，最后是圣地亚哥——我共事过的任何一位主教练或总经理会把自己视为我的导师。然而，他们确实起到了导师的作用，因为我自觉地尽可能多地吸收他们的丰富经验——我会询问他们决策背后的逻辑；分析他们管理他人的方式；并总结出如何将这些经验融入到我自己的执教和领导方法中。
In this way I cultivated and benefitted from their expertise nearly as much as if they’d taken me “under their wing” as a special friend they were mentoring.
这样一来，我从他们的专业知识中获益匪浅，就好像他们把我当成特别的朋友，像对待家人一样悉心指导我一样。
At Oakland, Al Davis introduced me (and anyone else on his staff who cared to pay attention) to an approach to preparation and execution unlike anything I’d ever seen. He was obsessed with achieving superior organizational performance and professionalism. His devotion to quality became Oakland’s official team motto: “Commitment to Excellence.” And it wasn’t just a marketing slogan. Al Davis was deeply dedicated to achieving it; he didn’t just mouth the motto, he personified it.
在奥克兰，阿尔·戴维斯向我（以及他手下所有愿意倾听的人）展示了一种我前所未见的准备和执行方法。他痴迷于追求卓越的组织绩效和专业精神。他对品质的执着也成为了奥克兰队的官方座右铭：“追求卓越”。这不仅仅是一句营销口号。阿尔·戴维斯全身心地投入其中；他不仅口头上说说这句座右铭，更是身体力行地践行着它。
“Ohhhhh, this is how you do it,” probably summed up my early reaction to seeing him run things.
“哦，原来是这样啊！”这大概就是我看到他掌控一切时的第一反应。
He loved the pass—the long pass especially—and expanded on the creativity of Sid Gillman’s breakthrough approach, which included all sorts of pass patterns to multiple receivers. Consequently, at Oakland I was in a milieu where passes—especially deep passes—were “in the air,” the coin of the realm, and I loved it.
他热爱传球——尤其是长传——并在西德·吉尔曼突破性战术的基础上，进一步拓展了传球的创造性，其中包括向多名接球手传出各种各样的球路。因此，在奥克兰，我身处一个传球——尤其是长传——无处不在的环境中，传球成了制胜法宝，我非常喜欢这种氛围。
Al had a tremendous football background, including being a player personnel assistant, an assistant coach, a head coach, and much more. I saw it manifested in his decisiveness, boldness, and advanced thinking. While he never put his arm around my shoulder and offered tutoring and career counseling as a mentor might, it didn’t matter. I was paying close attention; I did lots of learning—the high standards of organization, the embrace of modern passing concepts, and the dedication and loyalty to his players. I learned like a studious apprentice serving a master craftsman.
阿尔拥有极其丰富的足球经验，曾担任过球员人事助理、助理教练、主教练等等。我从他的果断、大胆和前瞻性思维中看到了这些经验的体现。虽然他从未像导师那样对我指手画脚，提供辅导和职业建议，但这并不重要。我一直在认真观察，从中学习了很多——他严谨的组织能力、对现代传球理念的运用，以及他对球员的奉献和忠诚。我像一个勤奋的学徒，跟随一位技艺精湛的师傅学习。
In a sense, my eight years as Paul Brown’s assistant in Cincinnati were like attending a graduate school in leadership and modern football. He taught me so many things, most of them good.
从某种意义上说，我在辛辛那提担任保罗·布朗助理教练的八年，就像是在读领导力和现代橄榄球的研究生院。他教了我很多东西，其中大部分都很有用。
He was by nature extremely meticulous and organized, a severe man whose mind constantly probed for better ways of doing things, whose teams at the high school, college (Ohio State University before Woody Hayes), and NFL (Cleveland Browns and Cincinnati Bengals) levels were all known for their precise execution. In fact, at Ohio State he was dubbed “Precision Paul.” It was an apt nickname; he was precise—punctilious—in every aspect of his leadership.
他生性严谨细致，做事一丝不苟，是一位严谨认真、不断追求精益求精的领导者。他执教的高中、大学（伍迪·海耶斯执教前的俄亥俄州立大学）以及NFL（克利夫兰布朗队和辛辛那提猛虎队）的球队都以精准的执行力著称。事实上，在俄亥俄州立大学，他就被誉为“精准保罗”。这个绰号非常贴切，因为他在领导工作的方方面面都展现出了精准无误的品质。
Here’s his own description of what he did and how he did it: “We were painstaking in our preparations and even practiced how to practice. I took one complete session to show our players exactly when and where they should go on the practice field and those routines remained the same whether it was a practice day or a game day.”
以下是他对自己所做工作和方法的描述：“我们做了非常细致的准备，甚至连如何训练都进行了练习。我专门安排了一节完整的训练课，向队员们详细讲解他们在训练场上应该何时何地出现，无论是训练日还是比赛日，这些流程都保持不变。”
I know this is true because I was there. Brown felt his teaching would be so ingrained that he didn’t need to resort to pep talks or phony slogans: “You can’t prepare a player that way [i.e., push them to high performance with a pep talk]. The only way to do it is to be so thorough in your work beforehand as to make him totally confident of himself and those around him.” I adopted that attitude in my own head coaching at Stanford and San Francisco.
我知道这是真的，因为我亲身经历过。布朗认为他的教学方式会深入人心，无需再靠激励演讲或空洞的口号来激励球员：“你不能用那种方式（即通过激励演讲来激发球员的潜能）来训练他们。唯一的方法就是事先做好充分的准备工作，让他们对自己和周围的人都充满信心。”我在斯坦福和旧金山担任主教练时也秉持了这种态度。
One of the game’s great innovators, Paul Brown was the first (or among the first in some cases) to use IQ tests to evaluate players, establish a game film “library” and studiously analyze the footage, teach players in a formal classroom setting, send in plays from the sideline with “messenger” linemen, fit helmets with face masks, expand the network for player recruitment beyond anything that had been seen before, emphasize a wide-open and profuse passing game (especially with the great Otto Graham), and take organizing practice schedules to an almost scientific level, including assigning assistant coaching detailed duties—defined areas of responsibility for which they were held accountable. You could say he was one of the men who brought modern management techniques to coaching football.
作为橄榄球运动的伟大创新者之一，保罗·布朗是第一个（或者在某些情况下是最早一批）使用智商测试评估球员的人，他建立了比赛录像“库”并认真分析录像，在正规课堂上指导球员，让边线球员“传话”传递战术，为头盔配备面罩，将球员招募网络扩展到前所未有的规模，强调开放且丰富的传球进攻（尤其是在伟大的奥托·格雷厄姆的带领下），并将训练计划的制定提升到近乎科学的水平，包括为助理教练分配详细的职责——明确他们的责任范围并对其负责。可以说，他是将现代管理技巧引入橄榄球教练领域的先驱之一。
His approach to quality control, or more accurately, controlling what creates quality, was evident even in his early years. As a high school coach in Ohio (at Massillon’s Washington High School), Brown had his football system used by all of Massillon’s junior high schools so that the youngsters would be familiar with it if they made his high school team—the Tigers.
他对质量控制，或者更准确地说，是对质量产生因素的控制，早在早年就已显露无疑。在俄亥俄州马西隆市华盛顿高中担任橄榄球教练期间，布朗将他的橄榄球训练体系推广到马西隆市所有初中，以便那些有机会进入他执教的高中球队——老虎队——的孩子们能够提前熟悉这套体系。
Paul Brown was one of those pioneers who advanced the way coaches approached doing their job—not as a serious sideline, but as a profession, almost a science. That’s the environment—classroom—I was in for eight years. I didn’t think of Paul as my mentor, nor did he, but the sheer volume of coaching and leadership expertise I harvested, both consciously and unconsciously, qualified him as such.
保罗·布朗是那些革新教练工作方式的先驱之一——他把教练工作视为一项职业，近乎科学，而非仅仅是一份兼职。我正是在这种环境下——在这样的课堂里——待了八年。我并不认为保罗是我的导师，他自己也不这么认为，但我从他身上汲取的海量教练和领导经验，无论是有意识的还是无意识的，都足以让他成为我的导师。
San Diego’s Tommy Prothro, a fine coach whose greatest achievements were at the college level, where his ability to connect with his players was made into an art form (resulting in a Rose Bowl championship at UCLA and two other Rose Bowl appearances as head coach at Oregon State), demonstrated what it means to truly care about your people.
圣地亚哥的汤米·普罗索是一位优秀的教练，他最大的成就是在大学层面取得的，他与球员建立联系的能力堪称艺术（在加州大学洛杉矶分校带领球队获得玫瑰碗冠军，并在俄勒冈州立大学担任主教练期间两次带领球队进入玫瑰碗），他展现了真正关心自己人的意义。
I believe Tommy’s advice when I received an offer from Stanford University—“Take the job, Bill, because a head coaching position in the Pac-10 is significant. For the good of your family and career and peace of mind, go to Stanford.”—was perhaps as close to the kind of input a mentor gives as any I’ve gotten. As noted, this lesson stood me in good stead at San Francisco.
我相信汤米在我收到斯坦福大学的聘用通知时给我的建议——“比尔，接受这份工作吧，因为在太平洋十校联盟担任主教练意义重大。为了你的家庭、事业和内心的平静，去斯坦福吧。”——这或许是我所得到过的最接近导师建议的指导了。正如我之前提到的，这条建议在旧金山大学对我帮助很大。
Additionally, I had the good fortune to be a player and assistant for Bob Bronzan, head coach at San Jose State—an astute teacher of football who organized each practice almost to the minute. There was also some traditional mentoring in Bob’s relationship with me. I was young, he believed in me, and he told me so in no uncertain terms.
此外，我有幸成为圣何塞州立大学主教练鲍勃·布朗赞的球员和助理教练。他是一位精明的橄榄球教练，几乎把每次训练都安排得井井有条。鲍勃和我之间也存在着一些传统的师徒关系。我当时很年轻，他信任我，并且毫不含糊地表达了这一点。
I was also lucky to work as an assistant coach at Stanford for John Ralston—a man with a keen mind for football.
我很幸运能在斯坦福大学担任约翰·拉尔斯顿的助理教练——他是一位对足球有着敏锐洞察力的人。
All along the way, I was paying attention to my teachers—unofficial mentors. While I was an assistant coach teaching others how to play football, others were teaching me how to coach football. By the time I was named head coach at Stanford University, I had a virtual PhD in coaching and leadership. Stanford football—head coach for two years—was my postdoctorate.
一路走来，我一直很重视我的老师们——那些非正式的导师们。当我担任助理教练教别人踢球的时候，他们也在教我如何执教。等到我被任命为斯坦福大学橄榄球队的主教练时，我已经积累了丰富的执教和领导力经验，几乎达到了博士学位水平。斯坦福大学橄榄球队的两年主教练经历，就是我的博士后研究。
In a sense, the day I arrived at 49ers headquarters as head coach (and soon thereafter, general manager) I could have been wearing a cap and gown and holding a parchment paper that said, “William Ernest Walsh, Doctor of Philosophy, Modern Football, Coaching, and Leadership.”
从某种意义上说，当我作为主教练（不久之后又担任总经理）抵达 49 人队总部的那天，我本可以戴着学士帽，穿着学士服，手里拿着一张羊皮纸，上面写着：“威廉·欧内斯特·沃尔什，哲学博士，现代足球、教练和领导力”。
I certainly wasn’t the only head coach who had that kind of “academic” credentialing, but I was lucky to be among those who did. My expertise accumulated because I made it my job to study others, to learn along the way.
当然，我并非唯一拥有那种“学术”资历的主教练，但我很幸运能成为其中之一。我的专业知识积累源于我把研究他人作为我的工作，并在实践中不断学习。
Some are lucky and find themselves blessed with a mentor who truly makes a difference throughout their life. But you can make the biggest difference of all by yourself. There are mentors in our professions teaching lessons (good and bad) that are free for your inquiring mind. You must be aggressive in acquiring what they teach and adapting it to your own leadership philosophy and playbook.
有些人很幸运，能遇到一位真正影响他们一生的良师益友。但其实，你完全可以靠自己做出最大的改变。在我们的职业领域，有很多导师会传授经验教训（无论好坏），这些经验教训都免费提供给求知欲强的人。你必须积极主动地学习他们所传授的知识，并将其融入到你自己的领导理念和行动指南中。
In my experience, there has never been a leader who arrived fully formed, who figured it out all by him- or herself. Ralph Waldo Emerson described a great and creative person as one who “finds himself in the river of the thoughts and events, forced onward by the ideas and necessities of his contemporaries. Thus all originality is relative. Every thinker is retrospective.” We learn from others.
依我之见，从来没有哪个领导者是天生具备所有特质，完全靠自己摸索出来的。拉尔夫·沃尔多·爱默生曾这样描述一位伟大而富有创造力的人：“他/她身处思想和事件的洪流之中，被同时代人的思想和需求所裹挟。因此，一切原创性都是相对的。每个思想家都是回顾过去的。”我们从他人身上学习。
Always there are mentors—some official, some unofficial. We apprentice when we are young, and it should continue even when we are old. A good leader is always learning. The great leaders start learning young and continue until their last breath.
人生总会有导师——有些是正式的，有些是非正式的。我们年轻时学习，即使年老时也应该继续学习。优秀的领导者永远都在学习。伟大的领导者从年轻时就开始学习，并一直学习到生命的最后一刻。

THE WALSH WAY 沃尔什路
The Fog Cutter 雾气切割者
Randy Cross, San Francisco 49er, 1976-88
兰迪·克罗斯，旧金山49人队，1976-88年







I witnessed the destruction of a venerable NFL franchise—the San Francisco 49ers—during my first three years with the team before Bill Walsh arrived. This included seeing the headquarters gutted of longtime personnel and the removal of all vestiges of former 49er teams—even pictures of San Francisco legends like John Brodie and Frankie Albert were tossed in the Dumpster by a general manager, Joe Thomas, who wanted to get rid of 49er history.
在比尔·沃尔什到来之前的三年里，我亲眼目睹了这支历史悠久的NFL球队——旧金山49人队——的衰落。这包括看到球队总部被彻底清空，老员工全部离职，所有49人队昔日的痕迹都被清除——甚至连约翰·布罗迪和弗兰基·阿尔伯特等旧金山传奇人物的照片都被总经理乔·托马斯扔进了垃圾箱，他一心想要抹去49人队的历史。
It culminated in a 2-14 season my third year, when we legitimately could lay claim to being perhaps the worst NFL team in history. It’s hard to convey how miserable our situation was as morale plummeted about as low as it could possibly go.
在我效力球队的第三年，球队最终以2胜14负的战绩收官，我们或许真的可以称得上是NFL历史上最差的球队。当时球队士气跌至谷底，处境极其糟糕，难以言表。
Then we heard this coach from Stanford University was coming in to take over—Bill Walsh. No big deal. He’d be my fifth head coach in four years at San Francisco, so I figured he’d last as long as the others; that is, not long. In fact, the whole team was skeptical about his chances. But from day one I could see things were going to be different.
后来我们听说斯坦福大学的比尔·沃尔什要来接手。这没什么大不了的。他将是我在旧金山四年来的第五位主教练，所以我估计他也会像其他人一样待不了多久。事实上，全队都对他能否执教持怀疑态度。但从第一天起，我就知道情况会不一样。
We arrived at training camp and Bill came in and gave a short speech to all of us. He said, “I know what some of you guys sitting there are thinking. You’re thinking, ‘I was here before Walsh arrived, and I’ll be here when Walsh is gone.’ Well, you better think about this too: If you can’t play for me, and this is the worst team in the National Football League, where else are you going to go; who in the hell is gonna hire you?” And many of us sitting there thought to ourselves, “Hmmmm, maybe he’s got a point there.”
我们抵达训练营后，比尔进来给我们所有人做了个简短的讲话。他说：“我知道你们有些人心里在想什么。你们肯定在想，‘沃尔什来之前我就在这里了，沃尔什走了之后我也会在这里。’好吧，你们最好也想想：如果你们不能为我效力，而这又是国家橄榄球联盟最差的球队，那你们还能去哪儿？谁会雇用你们？”我们很多人当时都心想：“嗯，也许他说的有道理。”
That was my first taste of his ability to kind of twist your mind a little bit. No rah-rah speech, no threats, no promises. Instead Bill came in through the side door. But that’s just a tiny example of his comprehensive leadership arsenal.
那是我第一次领略到他那种能稍微扭转人心的能力。没有慷慨激昂的演讲，没有威胁，也没有承诺。比尔采取了一种迂回的方式。但这只是他全面领导手段中的一小部分。
Of all the coaches and businesspeople I’ve been around in fifty-four years, I’ve never known a person who could get a message across, focus that message, and get people ready to perform better than Bill Walsh. He was able to do this, in part, because he was the smartest person I have ever known and the best-organized person I have ever known. And it didn’t take weeks to figure that out; it took maybe an hour. Probably less.
在我过去五十四年接触过的所有教练和商界人士中，我从未见过像比尔·沃尔什那样能够清晰传达信息、聚焦重点并激励人们发挥最佳水平的人。他之所以能做到这一点，部分原因在于他是我认识的最聪明的人，也是我认识的最有条理的人。而我领悟到这一点并不需要几周的时间；也许只需要一个小时，甚至更短。
I saw immediately that he had a singular focus: on being first class, on being the best, on being the greatest. But lots of guys have that—the desire to be the best. Here’s the difference: Bill knew exactly how to do it, the specifics , not just for his quarterback but for a receptionist answering the phones; not just for a backup left tackle but for groundskeepers. Somehow he knew what it was, what constituted greatness for every single job in his organization. He had that in his head.
我立刻发现他只有一个目标：做到一流，做到最好，做到最伟大。但很多人都有这种渴望——想要做到最好。区别在于：比尔非常清楚该怎么做，他不仅对四分卫如此，对接电话的前台接待员也如此；不仅对替补左截锋如此，对场地管理员也如此。不知何故，他知道组织里每个岗位的卓越标准是什么。他把这些都牢记在心。
He knew what a spreadsheet looks like, what a marketing presentation should look like, and all the rest. Detailed concepts. And he hired the very best people to do the jobs that he needed them to do. And in most cases he had the good sense to get out of the way and let them do their job—a very undervalued management skill.
他熟知电子表格的格式、营销演示文稿的样式等等。他对细节了如指掌。他聘请了最优秀的人才来完成他需要的工作。而且在大多数情况下，他明智地选择放手让他们各司其职——这是一种被严重低估的管理技能。
Bill had a plan for everything, a Standard of Performance for each one of us that was so clear he could spell it out exactly. And he did. If you were a San Francisco 49er, you were not foggy on what his goal was for you specifically—what he wanted you to do—and for the organization too.
比尔对所有事情都有计划，他为我们每个人都制定了清晰明确的绩效标准，甚至可以详细阐述。而且他也确实这么做了。如果你是旧金山49人队的球员，你肯定很清楚他为你设定的目标——他希望你做什么——以及他对整个球队的目标。
Right from the start, he really got out there and coached—rolled up his sleeves and got totally into teaching what he was aiming for. And he did that every day of every year for a decade. Of course, the offense was his baby, his first love, and he was totally involved in coaching the smallest details of its execution. He was not aloof, but right in there with the troops. Sometimes he’d take a break for a few minutes and be over on the side shadowboxing and the next minute be back in the thick of things. (Shadowboxing! That got noticed.)
从一开始，他就全身心投入到执教中——卷起袖子，全身心地投入到教学中，贯彻他的目标。十年如一日，年复一年。当然，进攻是他的心血之作，他的挚爱，他事无巨细地参与到战术执行的每一个细节中。他并非高高在上，而是与队员们并肩作战。有时他会休息几分钟，到场边练练空击，下一秒又回到训练场上。（空击！这可真够引人注目的。）
The year before Bill arrived, we were 2-14 and maybe the worst team in the history of the NFL. The next year, under Bill, we had exactly the same record, 2-14, but we were the best 2-14 team in the history of the NFL. We had the germinating seeds of a good offense, and we sensed it. Players are very hard to fool, and we could see things happening because of Bill.
比尔到来前一年，我们的战绩是2胜14负，或许是NFL历史上最差的球队。第二年，在比尔的带领下，我们的战绩依然是2胜14负，但我们却是NFL历史上战绩最好的2胜14负的球队。我们拥有了打造优秀进攻体系的雏形，而且我们自己也意识到了这一点。球员们很难被蒙蔽，而正是因为比尔，我们才能预见到一些事情的发生。
For the first three years, when he was doing this almost miraculous turnaround of the San Francisco 49ers, from the worst in the NFL to champions, we were all like coworkers, so we could really see what he was suffering through; only two wins his first year, followed by a horrible eight-game losing streak in the middle of our second season. That streak just ate his stomach up. It was his team, his deal, and he could not figure out a way to pull us out of it. You saw how it really killed him, because he was in so close with us. We could feel it, what he was going through.
头三年，他几乎奇迹般地扭转了旧金山49人队的颓势，从NFL垫底一路逆袭成为冠军。我们就像同事一样，所以能真切地感受到他当时的痛苦：第一年只赢了两场，第二年赛季中期又遭遇了可怕的八连败。那场连败让他备受煎熬。那是他的球队，他的心血，但他却束手无策，无法带领我们走出困境。你看，那场连败对他来说是多么沉重的打击，因为他和我们关系太密切了。我们都能感受到他当时的痛苦。
When we’d watch film and see a guard go the wrong way pulling, or a running back hit the wrong hole, or a quarterback ignore the first read, we knew we were screwing up his offense. It was ours too, but it was his first. He had created perfection on paper, and we couldn’t execute it. But he kept pushing us to get better.
当我们观看比赛录像，看到后卫拉边跑错方向，跑卫跑错了空档，或者四分卫忽略了第一选择时，我们就知道我们搞砸了他的进攻战术。这套战术也是我们的，但这是他的第一套。他在纸面上设计出了完美的战术，而我们却无法执行。但他仍然不断督促我们进步。
He’d tell us that perfection usually wasn’t possible, but that was what he wanted us to aspire to. And the offensive plays he dreamed up needed perfection in order to work. Bill had the same high standard not just for the offense and for the defense and for the special teams, but for everything: the way the office was run, the personnel department, everything and everybody. He had his hands on everything in the organization.
他常说完美通常是不可能的，但这正是他希望我们追求的目标。他设计的进攻战术也需要完美才能奏效。比尔对一切都有着同样的严格标准，不仅对进攻、防守和特勤组，而是对所有事情都是如此：办公室的运作方式、人事部门，所有的一切，每个人。他对组织里的方方面面都了如指掌。
After three or four years, Bill started giving each of us individually the Talk. He called you into his little office in that rat hole of a building we were in on Nevada Street in Redwood City, California, and gave you a synopsis of how he saw your future. You could tell when a guy came down from his office and he’d heard a version of reality from Bill that he didn’t like.
三四年后，比尔开始单独和我们每个人谈话。他会把我们叫到他在加州红木城内华达街那栋破旧大楼里的小办公室，然后简要地告诉我们他对我们未来的设想。如果有人从他办公室下来，发现比尔说的现实版本让他很不满意，你一眼就能看出来。
He called me in one time after I’d had the best season of my career and said, “Randy, you probably have five to six years left in the NFL. But my guess is that here, with us, you’ve got three or four years.” I gulped: “What?”
有一次，在我职业生涯中表现最好的一个赛季之后，他把我叫到办公室，说：“兰迪，你可能还能在NFL打五六年。但我估计，在这里，在我们这里，你还能待三四年。”我倒吸一口凉气：“什么？”
I came down from his office with one of those looks on my face I’d seen on others. But he was doing everybody a service, because he was absolutely right. And that’s a little piece of why he was ahead of his time. He was looking out for the welfare of organization, but also the players, by helping us deal with that harsh little reality; namely, we weren’t playing football forever, and we certainly weren’t playing for him forever. He didn’t lead us down a rosy path. He gave us the truth.
我从他办公室下来时，脸上带着那种我曾在其他人脸上见过的表情。但他其实是在帮大家，因为他说的完全正确。这也是他超越时代的原因之一。他不仅关心俱乐部的利益，也关心球员，帮助我们面对那个残酷的现实：我们不可能永远踢球，当然也不可能永远为他效力。他没有给我们描绘美好的蓝图，而是坦诚相告。
We won a Super Bowl in Bill’s third year and the following season basically tanked. After that, he pulled back from us in some ways. Not only did he feel we had forfeited his trust, but also there were veterans on the team and he was going to have to start making some hard decisions about them. So he began separating himself somewhat. From then on, he had a more arm’s-length connection emotionally, a more professional relationship than in the early days. He was still hands-on with his coaching, but he pulled back from the personal part of it. It’s hard to explain, but there was a change.
我们在比尔执教的第三年赢得了超级碗，但接下来的一个赛季却一落千丈。之后，他在某些方面开始疏远我们。他不仅觉得我们辜负了他的信任，而且队里还有一些老将，他不得不开始对他们做出一些艰难的决定。所以他开始与我们保持一定的距离。从那时起，他在情感上与我们保持了更疏远的距离，关系也比早期更加专业。他仍然亲力亲为地参与执教，但减少了个人层面的参与。这很难解释，但确实发生了变化。
Two years later we won another championship, Super Bowl XIX—just tore through people during an 18-1 year, one of the best teams that anybody had ever seen. Once that happened, from that moment on, we had sort of set our own high-water mark. Good luck meeting that one every year. Nevertheless, the pressure on Bill got ratcheted way up by the owner, Eddie DeBartolo. A Super Bowl was the norm; anything less was not acceptable, and the pressure became crushing.
两年后，我们又赢得了一个冠军，第十九届超级碗——那一年我们以18胜1负的战绩横扫对手，是史上最强球队之一。从那以后，我们就仿佛给自己设定了一个巅峰。想要每年都达到那个高度，恐怕很难。然而，老板埃迪·德巴托罗却给比尔施加了越来越大的压力。超级碗冠军成了标配；任何低于这个成绩的成绩都是不可接受的，这种压力最终让他喘不过气来。
In Bill’s final season, his tenth, he really got put through the wringer. We were 6-5 at one point and being written off by everybody. After a one-point loss at Phoenix to the Cardinals, Eddie stormed into our locker room immediately after the game and was livid. He dressed down everybody verbally, I mean really hard. Threatening us. That wasn’t such a big deal; we’d been screamed at as a team before, nothing new there. But this time Bill himself was targeted in the threats and dressing-down. He got screamed at along with the rest of us. That was an eye opener right there—a first for us. It had to really hurt him—to be humiliated like that. Looking back, I don’t think Eddie would consider it one of his sterling moments.
比尔的最后一个赛季，也是他的第十个赛季，真是让他吃尽了苦头。我们一度战绩只有6胜5负，所有人都觉得我们完了。在菲尼克斯以一分之差输给红雀队之后，埃迪一比赛结束后就冲进了更衣室，怒不可遏。他狠狠地训斥了我们所有人，我是说真的，非常严厉。他还威胁我们。这倒没什么大不了的；我们全队以前也挨过骂，没什么新鲜的。但这一次，比尔自己成了被威胁和训斥的目标。他和我们其他人一样，都被吼了一顿。这真是让我们大开眼界——对我们来说还是第一次。那样的羞辱肯定让他很受伤。现在回想起来，我想埃迪也不会把那段经历视为他人生中的高光时刻。
But that’s what that place was about as the years went on. We weren’t there to be good, we weren’t there to win a lot of games, we were there to win Super Bowls. Otherwise, get out. And personally, I think that level of expectation is productive. It’s the only way to go about doing it, even though it cost Bill a couple of years on his career and maybe some more Super Bowls.
但随着时间的推移，那支球队的意义就变成了这样。我们来这里不是为了取得好成绩，也不是为了赢得很多比赛，我们是为了赢得超级碗。否则，就离开。就我个人而言，我认为这种高期望值是有益的。这是唯一的方法，尽管这让比尔的职业生涯缩短了几年，也可能让他错失了更多超级碗冠军。
Under the pressure he had on him during the last few years, there was no way he could keep going. At the end he would have needed a six-month vacation all by himself on a desert island—making him sleep all the time, making him relax, making him chill out—if he wanted to continue under that load and that pressure.
在过去几年里他承受的巨大压力下，他根本无法继续坚持下去。如果他想继续承受那样的重担和压力，到最后他需要独自一人在荒岛上待上六个月，让他整天睡觉，彻底放松，彻底舒缓身心。
Throughout the years, Bill’s passion was so evident. It became the passion of his team and the staff and everybody in the organization. We stepped up to his level of dedication, his standard, his vision, and his ability to get the job done. And brother, if he detected anything less than an equal kind of passion from any one of us, we’d get the sharp end of the stick.
多年来，比尔的热情显而易见。这份热情感染了他的团队、员工以及整个组织的每一个人。我们都努力达到他的奉献精神、标准、远见和完成工作的能力。兄弟，如果他发现我们当中有人缺乏同样的热情，那我们可就惨了。
That’s why I chuckle when I see all these pictures of Bill, that image of him being a professor, pensive, the “thinker” with his hand on his chin, contemplating the exact words of his next lecture. Nobody on the outside ever saw the other side that he could summon up. Bill Walsh could burn a hole right through you with his eyes. Right through your bones and everything. His eyes could knock you out.
所以每次看到比尔的照片，我都会忍不住笑出声来。他总是摆出一副教授的姿态，若有所思，手托着下巴，仿佛在斟酌下一堂课的措辞。外人永远看不到他那不为人知的另一面。比尔·沃尔什的眼神能把你彻底看穿，直击你的灵魂深处。他的眼神能让你昏厥。
We saw a whole different guy from the professor. He could present a whole different vocabulary when he wanted to—like a longshoreman. But it was part of his passion for greatness.
我们看到的是一个和教授截然不同的人。他想用什么词汇就用什么词汇——就像码头工人那样。但这正是他追求卓越的动力所在。
Bill Walsh had the ability to change the way people thought—not just how we performed a task, but how we thought and felt about who we were. In the beginning, when we were as bad as we were, nobody was thinking about a Super Bowl. Our goal in life was just to be pretty good. Bill’s goal in life was to convince us that we could be great. And he did; and we were. That’s why he was such a great leader.
比尔·沃尔什有能力改变人们的思维方式——不仅仅是改变我们完成任务的方式，更是改变我们对自身身份的认知和感受。起初，当我们成绩糟糕透顶时，没人想过要赢得超级碗。我们的人生目标仅仅是做到还不错。而比尔的人生目标就是让我们相信，我们能够变得伟大。他做到了；我们也确实做到了。这就是他成为如此伟大领袖的原因。

PART V 第五部分
Thin Skin, Baloney, and “The Star-Spangled Banner”: Looking for Lessons in My Mirror 薄皮、胡说八道和《星条旗永不落》：从我的镜子中寻找教训

How You Get Good: No Mystery to Mastery 如何变得优秀：精通之道并不神秘
If you’re Jerry Rice, the greatest receiver in NFL history and, according to some, the greatest player, you’re practicing a slant pass pattern at 6 A.M. over and over with nobody within a mile of you—no football, no quarterback, nobody but Jerry working to improve, to master his profession.
如果你是杰里·赖斯，NFL历史上最伟大的接球手，而且在某些人看来，他也是史上最伟大的球员，那么你早上6点就会一遍又一遍地练习斜线传球，方圆一英里内都没有人——没有橄榄球，没有四分卫，只有杰里在努力提高自己，精通自己的职业。
Why is the NFL’s greatest-ever receiver doing this? Jerry Rice understands the connection between preparation and performance; between intelligently applied hard work and results; between mediocrity and mastery of your job. And Jerry has the skill coupled with the will to do it.
为什么NFL史上最伟大的接球手会这样做？杰里·赖斯深谙准备与表现之间的联系；明白勤奋努力与成果之间的联系；明白平庸与精通之间的区别。而且，杰里不仅拥有这样的天赋，更具备实现这一切的决心。
Joe Montana, perhaps the greatest quarterback in NFL history, in his last season as a professional, when he was playing for Kansas City, would spend two hours a day every day at the same little practice field at Menlo College near San Francisco. I would work with him on basic fundamentals that would bore a high schooler to death. Joe had four Super Bowl rings. How did he get them? Why was he on that little practice field? Joe Montana understands what mastery means.
乔·蒙塔纳，或许是NFL历史上最伟大的四分卫，在他职业生涯的最后一个赛季，效力于堪萨斯城酋长队时，每天都会在旧金山附近门洛学院那块小小的训练场上花费两个小时。我会和他一起练习一些基本功，这些基本功足以让一个高中生都感到枯燥乏味。乔拥有四枚超级碗戒指。他是如何赢得这些戒指的？他为什么会在那块小小的训练场上？乔·蒙塔纳深谙精通的真谛。
You never stop learning, perfecting, refining—molding your skills. You never stop depending on the fundamentals—sustaining, maintaining, and improving. Jerry and Joe, maybe the best ever at their positions, at the last stages of their careers were still working very hard on the fundamental things that high school kids won’t do because it’s too damn dull.
你永远不能停止学习、完善和精进——不断塑造你的技能。你永远不能停止依靠基本功——保持、巩固和提升。杰里和乔，或许是各自位置上最优秀的球员，在他们职业生涯的最后阶段，仍然在努力钻研那些高中生因为觉得太枯燥而不愿去做的基本功。
It wasn’t dull to Jerry and Joe, because they understood the absolute and direct connection between intelligently directed hard work and achieving your potential. We all do; you do; I do. Everybody who’s a serious player knows what it takes. The difference is how much you’re willing to give to get there.
对杰瑞和乔来说，这并不枯燥，因为他们明白，有条不紊地努力工作与充分发挥自身潜力之间有着绝对而直接的联系。我们都明白这一点；你明白；我也明白。每个认真对待比赛的人都知道需要付出什么。区别在于你愿意为之付出多少。
For us, there is no mystery to mastery. And it applies to football players and coaches, general managers and executives in sports or business. It applies to anyone anywhere who wants to get really good—who wants to master his or her profession. It applies to you.
对我们而言，精通之道并无神秘之处。这适用于足球运动员和教练，适用于体育或商业领域的总经理和高管。它适用于任何想要精益求精、想要在自己专业领域达到巅峰的人。它也适用于你。

Sine Qua Non: Your Work Ethic—What William Archibald Walsh Taught His Son 必要条件：你的职业道德——威廉·阿奇博尔德·沃尔什教给他的儿子
For me, the starting point for everything—before strategy, tactics, theories, managing, organizing, philosophy, methodology, talent, or experience—is the work ethic. Without one of significant magnitude you’re dead in the water, finished.
对我而言，一切的起点——先于战略、战术、理论、管理、组织、理念、方法论、才能和经验——是职业道德。缺乏高度的职业道德，你就寸步难行，彻底失败。
Among other things, I knew the example I set as head coach would be what others in the organization would recognize as the standard they needed to match (at least, most of them would recognize it). If there is such a thing as a trickle-down effect, that’s it. Your staff sees your devotion to work, their people see them, and on through the organization.
除此之外，我知道我作为主教练树立的榜样，会成为组织内其他人需要效仿的标准（至少大多数人会这么认为）。如果说存在涓滴效应，那就是这个了。你的员工会看到你对工作的投入，他们的员工会看到，然后这种影响会传递到整个组织。
Obviously, it’s not enough for you alone to work hard; there must be a similar organizational work ethic for anything of significance to occur. You—the one in charge—are the reference point for what that means.
显然，光靠你一个人努力是不够的；要想取得任何有意义的成果，团队中必须具备类似的组织协作精神。而你——作为负责人——正是衡量这一切的标准。
What does total effort and 100 percent commitment and sacrifice look like? The leader—head coach in my case—is the one who answers that question by example for the entire team; you demonstrate in your behavior what it looks like. Just talking about it, exhorting those in your organization to “give it all you’ve got” is close to meaningless. It’s like telling someone what constitutes a great movie. They’ve got to see it to know it. Same thing with a voracious appetite for work. Most people don’t have it; many people can achieve it; one person is charged with setting the standard and demonstrating what it means: you.
全力以赴、百分百投入和牺牲精神究竟是什么样的？领导者——就我而言是主教练——要以身作则，为整个团队解答这个问题；你的行为本身就能说明一切。仅仅空谈，或者激励团队成员“竭尽全力”，几乎毫无意义。这就像告诉别人一部好电影的标准是什么一样。他们必须亲眼观看才能明白。对工作的热情也是如此。大多数人没有这种热情；很多人可以做到；但有一个人肩负着树立标准、展现其意义的重任：那就是你。
During my years as head coach both at Stanford University and with the San Francisco 49ers, I believe it is safe to say there was no single individual in the organization—player, assistant coach, trainer, staff member, groundskeeper, or anyone else—who could accurately say he or she out-worked me. Not one. I can state that with no fear of contradiction. Some worked as hard—nobody worked harder.
在我担任斯坦福大学和旧金山49人队主教练的那些年里，我可以毫不夸张地说，队里没有任何一个人——无论是球员、助理教练、训练员、工作人员、场地管理员，还是其他任何人——能够说自己比我更努力。绝对没有。我可以毫不夸张地说出这句话。有些人和我一样努力，但没有人比我更努力。
I never asked anyone to do more than I was willing to do, nor what I wasn’t willing to do. Nobody could ever—not once—point at me and say, “Walsh sits on his ass in his office all day while we do the work.” When that sentiment spreads through an organization, you have signaled that “sitting on your ass all day” is an accepted standard of performance.
我从不要求任何人做我不愿意做的事，也从不要求任何人做我不愿意做的事。从来没有人——一次也没有——能指着我说：“沃尔什整天坐在办公室里无所事事，而我们却在辛勤工作。”一旦这种观念在组织内部蔓延开来，就等于向外界传递了一个信息：‘整天无所事事’竟然成了公认的绩效标准。
I was fortunate in this regard, because when I was growing up my role model was a good one. The guy who set the standard for me was my father. Dad knew what it meant to really work hard. And he did. William Archibald Walsh never went past eighth grade, scrambled around as a young man to make money, and came through tough times, including the Great Depression. He struggled to make a living for his family but showed me what a man does when he has a job to do: He goes out and does it.
在这方面我很幸运，因为我成长过程中有一位很好的榜样。为我树立榜样的人是我的父亲。父亲深知努力工作的意义，而且他确实做到了。威廉·阿奇博尔德·沃尔什只读到八年级，年轻时就四处奔波赚钱，经历了包括大萧条在内的艰难岁月。他努力养家糊口，但也让我明白，一个男人在有工作要做的时候应该做什么：那就是全力以赴。
During the Depression, my father was paid thirty-one cents an hour to work ten hours or more a day on the assembly line at the huge Chrysler plant near our small house in south central Los Angeles. That didn’t pay the bills, so he set up a little auto body repair shop in our garage, where he worked after he got done working at the plant, late at night and on weekends.
大萧条时期，我父亲在我们位于洛杉矶市中心南部的小房子附近的克莱斯勒大型工厂的装配线上工作，每小时工资只有31美分，每天工作10个小时甚至更久。这点钱根本不够支付账单，所以他在我们家的车库里开了一家小型汽车修理店，下班后，他会在深夜和周末在那里工作。
When I was a teenager, I had to work with him on many of those evenings and weekends, long hours into the night helping him out. I hated it, but he taught me the connection between hard work and survival, between survival and success. Dad taught me that. His work ethic became my work ethic.
我十几岁的时候，经常要在晚上和周末帮他干活，常常忙到深夜。我讨厌这样，但他教会了我努力工作与生存、生存与成功之间的联系。爸爸教会了我这一点。他的职业道德也成了我的职业道德。
He paid a tremendous price for his willingness to work. It may have shortened his life—a life that offered little in the way of fun or material reward—and kept him from connecting in any meaningful way with his son. I never really got to know my father; he didn’t have time. It was all work for Dad, or his family wouldn’t survive.
他为自己的勤奋付出了沉重的代价。这或许缩短了他的寿命——他的一生几乎没有任何乐趣或物质回报——也让他无法与儿子建立任何有意义的联系。我从未真正了解过我的父亲；他没有时间。父亲的生活只有工作，否则他的家庭就无法生存。
Over the years, I’ve heard many theories, often complex or convoluted, on what it takes to be an outstanding leader. Most of the theories seem to take a monumental work ethic for granted, as if it is assumed or something, as if people automatically know what it is and do it. I didn’t assume it. The majority of people out there don’t know what it is. They need to be shown, and you’re the one who must show it.
多年来，我听过许多关于如何成为杰出领导者的理论，这些理论往往复杂晦涩。大多数理论似乎都把卓越的职业道德视为理所当然，仿佛这是不言而喻的，仿佛人们天生就知道它是什么并能做到。但我并没有这样想。事实上，大多数人并不了解它是什么。他们需要有人指引，而你必须成为指引者。
Some of our great leaders come from the military, not just America’s, but those we fought against. General Erwin Rommel, the Desert Fox, as he was known commanding Germany’s tank brigades in North Africa during World Ward II, understood the power of example in the area of effort. Here’s what he said: “A commander must accustom his staff to a high tempo from the outset, and continuously keep them up to it. If he once allows himself to be satisfied with norms, or anything less than an all-out effort, he gives up the race from the starting post, and will sooner or later be taught a bitter lesson.”
我们的一些伟大领袖来自军队，不仅是美国的军队，也包括我们曾经的敌人的军队。绰号“沙漠之狐”的埃尔温·隆美尔将军，在二战期间指挥德国坦克旅在北非作战，他深谙以身作则的力量。他曾说过：“指挥官必须从一开始就让他的参谋人员适应高强度的工作节奏，并持续保持这种节奏。如果他一旦满足于现状，或者没有全力以赴，他就等于从一开始就放弃了比赛，迟早会付出惨痛的代价。”
A high tempo from the outset and continuously throughout; dissatisfaction with the usual norms; insistence on all-out effort? Rommel understood hard work and the importance of demonstrating it to his troops. The same applies to your troops. You’re the one who shows them what all-out effort really means, what hard work looks like.
从一开始就保持高节奏，并且贯穿始终；对常规做法不满；坚持全力以赴？隆美尔深谙努力的意义，也明白向部下展现努力的重要性。这同样适用于你的部队。你要让他们明白全力以赴的真正含义，以及努力工作的真正模样。
You cannot do that if you’re invisible, cooped up in your office instead of being out there with your team. A leader’s great work ethic must been seen to be perceived, must be perceived if it is to be the organization’s norm .
如果你隐形人，把自己关在办公室里而不是和团队一起工作，你就无法做到这一点。领导者的卓越职业道德必须被看到才能被感知，必须被感知才能成为组织的规范。

The Perfection of the Puzzle 拼图的完美之处
I hate to see bad football. I hate to see a team play bad football, even on a single play—in practice, in a game, anywhere. Bad football makes me ill in the same way, I suppose, a symphony conductor hates to hear an orchestra mangle Bach or Beethoven. There’s a reverence for the art. For me, it can be described as a reverence for football as it could be played—the exquisite beauty of what can occur at its uppermost level. I think top performers in all professions have that same deep respect—even reverence—for their work.
我痛恨看到糟糕的足球比赛。我痛恨看到一支球队踢得糟糕，哪怕只是一回合——无论是在训练中、比赛中，还是任何场合。糟糕的足球比赛让我感到恶心，我想，就像交响乐指挥痛恨听到乐团糟蹋巴赫或贝多芬的作品一样。这是一种对艺术的敬畏。对我而言，这种敬畏可以被描述为对足球这项运动应有水平的敬畏——对这项运动最高水平所能展现的精妙绝伦的美的敬畏。我认为各行各业的顶尖人士都对自己的工作怀有同样的深深敬意——甚至是崇敬。
One player, a guard, for example, making every small move perfectly on a play is a little work of art that I can watch on tape over and over again with satisfaction. Imagine then, when on a single play each one of our players does his job exactly, perfectly, totally right . It can be breathtaking. If it scores a touchdown, the points are almost incidental, frosting on the cake (unless the frosting wins a game).
举个例子，一个球员，比如后卫，如果在一次进攻中每个小动作都做得完美无瑕，那简直就是一件艺术品，我可以一遍又一遍地在录像中欣赏，百看不厌。试想一下，如果我们的每个球员在一次进攻中都能精准、完美、无可挑剔地完成自己的任务，那该是多么精彩绝伦！如果最终达阵得分，那得分反而成了锦上添花，就像蛋糕上的糖霜（除非这糖霜最终赢得了比赛）。
When it’s done perfectly at its highest level, football is art and gives me such great fulfillment. Anything less, the botched play, casual effort, sloppy execution, inept play calling, even if it gains ground or scores points, was very disturbing—painful—to me on an aesthetic level. I was never able to take refuge in a winning score if it was produced by shoddy performance—bad football.
当足球比赛达到最高水准，完美呈现时，它就是一门艺术，能带给我极大的满足感。但如果达不到这个水平，那些糟糕的配合、漫不经心的态度、马虎的执行、拙劣的战术安排，即便最终能取得一些进展或得分，也会让我感到非常不适，甚至在审美层面上感到痛苦。如果胜利是建立在糟糕的表现之上——糟糕的足球——我永远无法从中获得慰藉。
Thus, if we won, I cared about how we won; if we lost, I cared about how we lost. I didn’t want to lose by forty points; I’d prefer to lose by thirty-nine. If we won by twenty, I’d wake up in the middle of the night and try hard to figure out how we could have scored twenty-one points. It wasn’t increasing or decreasing the point differential that was so intriguing to me, but rather increasing the quality of our execution and decision making—the quality of the football we played.
因此，如果我们赢了，我会在意我们是如何赢的；如果我们输了，我会在意我们是如何输的。我不想输40分，我宁愿输39分。如果我们赢了20分，我会在半夜醒来，努力思考我们是如何再得21分的。真正让我着迷的不是分差的大小，而是我们执行和决策的质量——也就是我们踢球的质量。
Had I miscalculated or ignored information that was there for me to see and evaluate? Why and where did our execution break down? Where were our decisions—my decisions—flawed or dead wrong? On and on and on. It was, I think, perfection that I was pursuing.
我是否误判了形势，或者忽略了摆在眼前、显而易见的信息？我们的执行为何在何处出了差错？我们的决策——我的决策——在哪些方面存在缺陷，甚至完全错误？诸如此类的问题不胜枚举。我想，我当时追求的或许就是完美。
Whatever it was, beyond the score I had a passion for figuring out how we could have performed at a higher and higher level of excellence. Good or bad, win or lose, “What caused what, and how can it be improved?” was my recurrent question, an obsession.
无论结果如何，除了比分之外，我始终热衷于探究我们如何才能发挥得更加出色。无论好坏，无论输赢，“是什么原因导致了什么，以及如何才能改进？”是我反复思考的问题，近乎痴迷。
At 2 A.M. I’d be staring up at the ceiling or tossing around in bed. Eventually, I’d get up, pace around, sit down in the next room to write some notes. Then back to pacing, slowly analyzing before writing down additional observations or ideas.
凌晨两点，我会盯着天花板发呆，或者在床上辗转反侧。最后，我会起床，来回踱步，然后坐到隔壁房间写些笔记。之后又继续踱步，慢慢分析，再把其他的观察或想法记录下来。
Finally, as the sun was getting ready to come up, I’d go back to bed and try to get a few minutes of sleep. It was like this after every single game I coached at San Francisco for ten years, close to it on many other nights. By the end of the season, I was a mess physically and emotionally.
最后，当太阳即将升起时，我会回到床上，试图再睡一会儿。在旧金山执教的十年里，每场比赛结束后都是如此，其他很多夜晚也差不多如此。到了赛季末，我的身心都已疲惫不堪。
All of this had less to do with running up the score or trying to lose by fewer points than with how I perceived the entire process of leadership and striving for success. To me it was a puzzle to be solved, pieces to be found and put in place, solutions to be figured out. I had a passion for trying to determine how we could have performed at a higher level, how we could achieve perfection, or at least get closer and closer and closer.
这一切与其说是为了尽可能多地得分或尽量少输，不如说是为了更好地理解领导力以及追求成功的整个过程。对我而言，这就像一个待解的谜题，需要找到并拼凑出各个环节，最终找到解决方案。我热衷于探究我们如何才能表现得更好，如何才能达到完美，或者至少如何才能越来越接近完美。
Of course, losing is monumentally—traumatically—different from winning, but in both cases I was extremely and, at times, perhaps overly analytical of our efforts in searching for a means of closing in on perfection.
当然，失败与胜利有着巨大的、甚至是创伤性的差异，但在这两种情况下，我都非常认真地，有时甚至可能过于认真地分析我们为寻找接近完美的方法所做的努力。
In Super Bowl XIX—the closest I’ve ever come to coaching a perfect game—two events occurred that marred it for me to this very day. Although they may seem trivial or illogical to you, they illustrate my all-consuming desire to set every single piece of the puzzle perfectly in place.
在第十九届超级碗——我执教生涯中最接近完美比赛的一场——发生了两件事，至今仍让我耿耿于怀。虽然在你看来它们或许微不足道或不合逻辑，但它们恰恰体现了我那种力求完美、事事尽善尽美的执着。
The game was played in front of 84,059 fans at Stanford Stadium, thirty minutes south of San Francisco in Palo Alto, California. Our opponents, the Miami Dolphins, were led by Dan Marino, a quarterback whose arm was so strong he could supposedly throw a football sixty yards behind his back. Additionally, he had an uncanny ability to read defenses, a trigger-fast release, and two of the greatest receivers of the time, Mark Clayton and Mark Duper.
这场比赛在加州帕洛阿尔托的斯坦福体育场举行，现场有84059名球迷，斯坦福体育场位于旧金山以南30分钟车程处。我们的对手是迈阿密海豚队，他们的四分卫是丹·马里诺，据说他的臂力惊人，能把橄榄球从背后扔出60码远。此外，他还拥有不可思议的防守洞察力、极快的出手速度，以及当时最伟大的两位外接手——马克·克莱顿和马克·杜珀。
Some viewed Miami and Marino as unstoppable, and the results supported it: a regular-season record of 14-2. While our regular season record was even better, 15-1, there was a troubling fact within those numbers; namely, in the AFC championship game to advance to the Super Bowl, Marino had thrown twenty-one completions for 421 yards against the Pittsburgh Steelers. It was an easy win for the Dolphins: 45-28. This was relevant and very troubling because Pittsburgh had been the only team to beat San Francisco during our 15-1 regular season.
有些人认为迈阿密和马里诺势不可挡，而战绩也印证了这一点：常规赛14胜2负。虽然我们的常规赛战绩更佳，达到了15胜1负，但这些数字背后却隐藏着一个令人担忧的事实：在晋级超级碗的AFC冠军赛中，马里诺面对匹兹堡钢人队完成了21次传球，推进421码。海豚队轻松取胜，比分45-28。这一点尤其令人担忧，因为在15胜1负的常规赛期间，匹兹堡是唯一一支击败过旧金山的球队。
That’s why it concerned me so much—the only team to beat us had, in turn, been beaten easily by our upcoming Super Bowl opponents, the Miami Dolphins, and their young superstar quarterback, Marino. While the oddsmakers had us favored by three points, lots of bettors thought it should have been the other way around and placed their bets accordingly.
这就是我如此担忧的原因——唯一击败过我们的球队，却被我们即将到来的超级碗对手迈阿密海豚队及其年轻的超级巨星四分卫马里诺轻松击败。虽然博彩公司认为我们被看好赢三分，但许多投注者认为结果应该相反，并据此下了注。
Nevertheless, after trailing 10-7 at the end of the first quarter, we began to gradually take over on both offense and defense. With less than a minute remaining in the first half, San Francisco seemed to be in control of the game and held a big lead: 28-10.
然而，在第一节结束时以7比10落后之后，我们开始在攻防两端逐渐掌控比赛。上半场还剩不到一分钟时，旧金山队似乎已经控制了比赛，并取得了28比10的大比分领先。
With time running out on the half, the Dolphins’ kicker, Uwe von Schamann, nailed a field goal from thirty-seven yards to bring the score to 28-13. As Miami prepared to kick off, I instructed our kickoff return team to simply fall on the ball to remove all risk of a fumble: “No runback! No runback! Fall on the ball! No runback!” I would be very happy to let the first half run down and head into the locker room with a fifteen-point lead.
上半场即将结束时，海豚队的踢球手乌韦·冯·沙曼命中了一记37码的任意球，将比分改写为28比13。迈阿密准备开球时，我指示我们的开球回攻组队员直接扑向球，以避免任何掉球的风险：“不许回攻！不许回攻！扑向球！不许回攻！”我非常希望上半场能够顺利结束，带着15分的领先优势进入更衣室。
The Dolphins’ kick went to Guy McIntyre, a blocker, who grabbed the ball and immediately fell to the ground, exactly as I had instructed just seconds earlier. The clock would now run out on the first half in a very orderly manner and send us into the locker room to prepare for the second half with a solid advantage.
海豚队的开球落到了阻挡队员盖伊·麦金泰尔手中，他接住球后立刻倒地，正如我几秒钟前指示的那样。上半场比赛就这样井然有序地结束了，我们带着稳固的优势回到更衣室，准备下半场的比赛。
But suddenly 49er rookie Derrick Harmon ran over to McIntyre and began screaming, “Get up! Run! Run, run, run!” Guy got up and ran. Or tried to. He immediately got hit by a Miami defender who’d been building up a full-speed head of steam for twenty yards. In the resulting collision, Guy fumbled; Miami recovered and quickly kicked another field goal. The first half— suddenly —was over.
但突然间，49人队新秀德里克·哈蒙冲到麦金泰尔身边，开始大喊：“起来！跑！跑，跑，跑！”盖伊起身跑了起来。或者说，他试图跑。他立刻被一名迈阿密防守队员撞倒，那名防守队员已经全速冲刺了20码。在随后的碰撞中，盖伊掉球了；迈阿密队抢回球权，并迅速踢进另一个任意球。上半场比赛——突然——结束了。
It happened in a flash, and it was stunning to me. I felt like I’d been hit hard on the head with a metal baseball bat. Even though we still had a comfortable lead, in a space of ten seconds the Dolphins had scored twice on field goals, narrowed the margin, and completely turned things around psychologically . But in retrospect there was something else that was equally upsetting.
一切发生得太快了，我简直不敢相信。感觉就像被人用金属棒球棍狠狠地击中了脑袋。尽管我们当时还保持着相当大的领先优势，但海豚队在短短十秒钟内两次射门得分，缩小了分差，彻底扭转了比赛的局势。不过，事后回想起来，还有另一件事同样令人沮丧。
I felt that if our coaching— my teaching—had been better, the breakdown in discipline and execution would not have occurred. I didn’t blame Guy, nor did I really blame Derrick. I blamed myself for that high school level of execution and still do. It was bad football.
我觉得如果我们的执教——或者说我的教学——做得更好，纪律和执行力的崩溃就不会发生。我没有责怪盖伊，也没有真正责怪德里克。我责怪的是自己，因为那水平的执行力只有高中水平，现在依然如此。那是一场糟糕的橄榄球比赛。
The second blemish on this otherwise near-perfect game occurred as the clock was winding down very late in the fourth quarter, with the 49ers leading 38-16. At that point, I made a decision that still gnaws at me.
这场近乎完美的比赛中出现的第二个瑕疵发生在第四节比赛即将结束时，当时49人队以38比16领先。就在那时，我做出了一个至今仍让我耿耿于怀的决定。
With second down and less than a yard to go for a touchdown, I called off the hunt, ran the same play three consecutive times, knowing it probably wouldn’t score—variations of Roger Craig going over the top—because I didn’t want to create the impression we were pouring it on, running up the score.
第二次进攻，距离达阵区不到一码时，我放弃了追分，连续三次执行同样的战术，我知道这可能不会得分——罗杰·克雷格的长传战术的各种变体——因为我不想给人留下我们正在猛攻、试图拉开比分的印象。
As intended, we didn’t make a touchdown. Miami took possession as the clock ran out, and the 49ers won our second Super Bowl in four years: 38-16.
正如预期的那样，我们没能达阵。比赛时间耗尽时，迈阿密队获得了球权，49人队以38比16的比分赢得了四年内的第二个超级碗冠军。
My decision obviously didn’t affect the final outcome of the game, but I believe it was wrong to do what I decided to do; namely, force a team dedicated to competing to stop competing. It was wrong to do that, to take the bullet out of the chamber. It was bad football, and it was my fault.
我的决定显然没有影响比赛的最终结果，但我认为我当时的做法是错误的；我当时强迫一支全力以赴的球队停止比赛。这样做是错误的，就像是扼杀了机会之火。这是糟糕的足球，而这一切都是我的错。
Now, those two incidents might cause you to say, “Why in the world would you worry about it, Bill? Guy McIntyre’s response to Derrick Harmon’s yelling to get up and run was just good aggressive instinct, and your calling off the hunt at the end of the game was just good sportsmanship.”
现在，这两件事可能会让你说：“比尔，你到底为什么要担心呢？盖伊·麦金泰尔对德里克·哈蒙让他起来跑的喊声的回应，只是良好的进攻本能，而你在比赛结束时叫停追捕，只是良好的体育精神。”
But as the years have passed, both situations have come back to me in a negative way that I don’t feel good about. Neither should have occurred; both marred an otherwise perfect game. And that’s the point: Our game was very close to perfect.
但随着时间的流逝，这两件事都以一种令我感到不快的负面方式重新浮现出来。它们本不该发生；它们都破坏了一场原本近乎完美的比赛。而这正是关键所在：我们的比赛原本非常接近完美。
Those two incidents will live with me forever because otherwise it was as flawless a football game as I’ve ever coached, as close to putting all the pieces in place for the full four quarters of a game.
这两件事将永远铭刻在我的记忆中，因为除此之外，这场比赛是我执教过的最完美的一场足球比赛，几乎完美地完成了四节比赛的所有环节。
Achieving success in a competitive environment requires solving a very complicated puzzle. This is true in all big-time competition. The winners know how to get more pieces of the puzzle in place than the losers. I still regret that those two final pieces of the puzzle prevented it from being solved perfectly.
在竞争激烈的环境中取得成功需要解决一个极其复杂的难题。所有大型比赛都是如此。赢家比输家更懂得如何拼凑出更多拼图碎片。我至今仍感到遗憾，正是最后那两块拼图碎片阻碍了整个难题的完美解决。
I also know that the degree of drive an individual has to solve the puzzle perfectly, no matter how complex or difficult, is directly related to attaining higher and higher levels of success. It’s that desire that wakes you up in the middle of the night reaching for a pen and paper next to your bed—an insatiable hunger to capture inspiration and answers that all highly driven people share.
我也知道，一个人解决难题的动力，无论难题多么复杂或困难，都与他取得越来越高的成功直接相关。正是这种渴望，让你在半夜惊醒，伸手去拿床边的纸笔——一种所有积极进取的人都拥有的、永不满足的灵感和答案的渴望。
Where that drive comes from is often a mystery. Here’s what Arthur Ashe, one of the greatest tennis players in history, had to say about it: “Who knows what force gnaws at us, telling us that our accomplishments, no matter how sensational, are not enough; that we need to do more?” (Arthur Ashe, Days of Grace .)
这种动力究竟源自何处，往往是个谜。历史上最伟大的网球运动员之一阿瑟·阿什曾这样描述它：“谁知道是什么力量在啃噬着我们，告诉我们，无论我们的成就多么辉煌，都还不够；我们需要做得更多？”（阿瑟·阿什，《恩典岁月》）
I sought perfection, and 99 percent isn’t perfection. Why “almost perfect” wasn’t enough for me is something I can’t explain.
我追求完美，但99%并非完美。至于为什么“接近完美”对我来说还不够，我自己也无法解释。

The Gladiator Mentality: Get Your Mind Right 角斗士心态：调整好你的心态
The gladiator mentality is common in sports, especially football at all levels. Although it’s played out differently in business, I think there is a similar phenomenon—that is, the effort to “get your mind right ,” totally focused—before a significant event, whether it’s a major sales presentation or something else.
