Among other things, it involves the preparation, the “ceremony” before the main event. Top performers utilize this opportunity to get ready for battle.
角斗士心态在体育运动中很常见，尤其是在各级别的足球比赛中。虽然在商业领域表现形式有所不同，但我认为也存在类似的现象——即在重要事件（无论是大型销售演示还是其他活动）之前，努力“调整心态”，全神贯注。这其中就包括准备工作，也就是正式活动前的“仪式”。顶尖人才会利用这个机会为即将到来的挑战做好准备。
There is a ritual, sort of a crescendo, that takes you to the very peak of preparation and readiness. The gladiator is thinking, mentally narrowing his focus, as he goes through the ritual before the game. It draws him upward smoothly into the increasing intensity and pressure of the event like a high-performance car going from zero to sixty, the gears shifting seamlessly and without notice.
有一种仪式，一种渐强的过程，能将你推向准备和就绪的巅峰。角斗士在赛前进行仪式时，会思考，集中精神。这仪式如同高性能跑车从零加速到六十，档位切换流畅自然，毫不突兀，让他平稳地进入比赛日益激烈和紧张的状态。
In addition to our pregame discussions, I had my own ritual as a coach before each kickoff and did it almost unconsciously. I always went to my locker first and then walked through the locker room, taking exactly the same route each time. I would sit in my office and watch another NFL game on television for five minutes or so—not really paying much attention to it, just distracting myself. Then I would leave my office, and just before going out to the field I would shake hands with every single player on our team. If I got done and had missed one of them, I somehow knew it and would search him out and shake hands.
除了赛前讨论之外，我作为教练，在每次开球前都有自己的一套仪式，几乎是下意识的。我总是先去我的更衣柜，然后穿过更衣室，每次都走同样的路线。我会坐在办公室里，看五分钟左右的NFL比赛——其实我并没有太认真看，只是为了分散注意力。然后我会离开办公室，在去球场之前，和我们队里的每一位球员握手。如果握手完毕后漏掉了一位，我总能感觉到，然后会找到他，和他握手。
It was that ritual that helped me to create the mind-set I wanted before each game. It helped me to focus on what I was about to do, allowed me to methodically narrow my concentration to the point where I could block out everything but the game plan and its execution. The routine was part of the grounding process in which I sought to eradicate worry, excitement, stress, distractions, hopes, fears, and all personal issues. It was like walking into a completely different room mentally, like being on a different planet. And it didn’t end when I left the locker room.
正是这个仪式帮助我在每场比赛前建立起想要的心态。它让我专注于即将要做的事情，让我有条不紊地集中注意力，直到屏蔽掉除比赛计划及其执行之外的一切干扰。这套流程是我赛前准备的一部分，旨在消除焦虑、兴奋、压力、干扰、希望、恐惧以及所有个人问题。感觉就像走进了一个完全不同的房间，仿佛置身于另一个星球。而且，这种体验并没有在我离开更衣室后就结束。

I Never Sang “The Star-Spangled Banner” 我从未唱过《星条旗永不落》
During “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the opening kickoff, I would stand at attention with my hand over my heart, but I wasn’t singing. It was during this brief moment that I would remove myself mentally from the activities and considerable energy around me on the sidelines—compose and focus myself, extend what I had begun in the locker room.
在开球前奏响美国国歌《星条旗永不落》时，我会立正，手放在胸前，但我不会唱歌。就在这短暂的时刻，我会让自己从场边的各种活动和喧嚣中抽离出来——调整心态，集中注意力，延续我在更衣室里开始的练习。
I visualized that I was looking at the football field through a big plate-glass window, removed, in a sense, so I wouldn’t get overly involved emotionally and could stay with what I had prepared prior to game. Clear thinking and overly charged emotions are usually antithetical.
我设想自己透过一块巨大的落地玻璃窗看着足球场，某种程度上与比赛保持距离，这样我就不会过度投入情绪，可以专注于赛前准备的内容。清晰的思维和过度激动的情绪通常是相互矛盾的。
I actually think my heart rate may have gone down as the opening kickoff approached. Rather than getting more and more excited, pumped up and emotional, a sense of calm came over me. If a person can be extremely intense, extraordinarily focused, and completely composed all at the same time, I guess that’s the state I was in by the time I was through not singing the national anthem.
事实上，我觉得随着开球时间的临近，我的心跳可能反而下降了。我没有越来越兴奋、激动和情绪激动，反而感到一阵平静。如果一个人可以同时做到极度专注、无比冷静，我想，当我唱完国歌后没有唱国歌时，我的状态大概就是这样。
By the opening kickoff, I had blocked out crowd noise (and the crowd) and all the crazy energy and activity on the sidelines, which are disruptive to good decision making. It may have been as pleasing a sensation as any I ever got as a coach. Winning a Super Bowl championship was great, but the emotion I felt in victory was often more relief than anything else, especially as the years went on.
比赛开球时，我已经屏蔽了人群的喧闹声（以及人群本身），还有场边那些疯狂的活力和活动——这些都会干扰我的决策。这或许是我作为教练经历过的最令人愉悦的感觉之一。赢得超级碗冠军固然很棒，但胜利带给我的更多是如释重负，尤其随着时间的流逝更是如此。
The state of mind I could achieve as a game was about to begin was pure, so free of dissonance—it was just the best. The ritual created it. It was the gladiator mind-set, free of stress, distractions, and emotionalism, that got me ready for the competition and allowed me to work at my highest level.
比赛即将开始时，我能达到的那种心境纯粹无瑕，没有任何杂念——简直完美。仪式感造就了这种状态。正是这种角斗士般的心态，摒除压力、干扰和情绪波动，让我为比赛做好准备，并发挥出最佳水平。
“Getting your mind right” has application beyond a football game. Those events where you’re putting it all on the line—a big sales presentation, an important conference with your team (or your boss), and many other occasions—all require that your thinking be at its best. The prep erformance “ritual” that you develop can help make it happen just as it helped me to do my job to the best of my ability.
“调整好心态”的道理不仅适用于足球比赛。那些需要你全力以赴的场合——比如重要的销售演示、与团队（或老板）的重要会议等等——都要求你保持最佳的思维状态。你培养的准备“仪式”可以助你一臂之力，就像它帮助我尽最大努力完成工作一样。

My Strengths? 我的优势？
I have a passion for what I do. Also, if I’m honest about it, I’d say that I have an ability to communicate and relate to others in the context of work, to express myself clearly, and to do that in all circumstances, especially under extreme pressure.
我热爱我的工作。坦白地说，我具备良好的沟通能力，能够在工作中与他人建立联系，清晰地表达自己的想法，并且在任何情况下都能做到这一点，尤其是在压力极大的情况下。
If I have a gift, it is the imaginative strain in my system, my makeup. I’m excellent at coming up with concepts and then finding a way to make them a reality. If I have a vision, a concept, I know how to find a way to implement it and not back away from it, a determination to see it through and, if necessary, take risks to make it happen.
如果说我有什么天赋，那就是我与生俱来的想象力。我擅长构思，并能找到方法将它们变为现实。一旦有了愿景或想法，我知道如何实现它，绝不会退缩，而是会坚定不移地坚持到底，必要时甚至会承担风险去实现它。
If I had an idea for a certain new formation or play, or a way of using a particular player, I would find a way to make it work. (This is what I did when I utilized John Ayers to take on the task of neutralizing the great threat presented by New York Giants outside linebacker Lawrence “L.T.” Taylor.) And if my idea failed, I knew whether to drop it and move on to something else or to continue to develop it. You could call me a good problem solver. Of course, before you solve a problem, you’ve got to spot the problem. I was good at that too.
如果我构思出某种新的阵型或战术，或者想到如何运用某个特定的球员，我总会想办法让它奏效。（比如，我让约翰·艾尔斯去应对纽约巨人队外线卫劳伦斯·“L.T.”·泰勒的巨大威胁，就是这么做的。）如果我的想法失败了，我知道是该放弃它，转而尝试其他方案，还是继续完善它。你可以说我善于解决问题。当然，在解决问题之前，你首先得发现问题所在。而我在这方面也很出色。
I had this ability even when I was coaching high school football in Fremont, California. I just couldn’t stop trying to figure out new ways of doing things, coming up with novel solutions to problems, different plays. It fascinated me. That part of it never stopped—looking for innovative ways of doing things. I was always looking to build a better mousetrap.
早在我在加州弗里蒙特执教高中橄榄球时，我就拥有这种能力。我总是忍不住去探索新的做事方法，想出解决问题的新颖方案，设计不同的战术。这让我着迷。这种对创新方法的追求从未停止。我总是想着如何打造更好的捕鼠器。

Unleash Mentors: Tell Your Team to Teach 释放导师潜能：让你的团队去教导
One of the reasons the 49ers won five Super Bowls in fourteen years is that we expected veterans to do everything possible to bring along rookies. In effect, they were expected to train their own replacements, and it was one of the reasons I prohibited hazing. I wanted new players, new staff members, new scouts, and everyone else who joined us to sense immediately they had joined an organization with a unique environment.
49人队在14年内赢得5次超级碗冠军的原因之一，是我们要求老将竭尽所能地帮助新秀成长。实际上，我们希望他们能够培养自己的接班人，这也是我禁止欺凌新人的原因之一。我希望新球员、新工作人员、新球探以及所有加入我们的人都能立刻感受到，他们加入了一个拥有独特氛围的团队。
I stressed to veterans that we should take pride in welcoming the new arrivals who could help the team win and create and carry on the 49ers tradition. To help us accomplish this goal, the veterans were instructed to help others learn the ropes, do the job better (even if it was their own job they were training someone else to do). Thus, the body of knowledge a veteran player had accumulated—especially as it pertained to my Standard of Performance—was being assimilated by new employees, rookies, and first- and second-year players in a very effective manner. In a sense, I made teachers out of my students. The players became coaches. This built-in crew of teachers exists in your own organization. Tap into it.
我向老队员们强调，我们应该为新队员的到来感到自豪，他们能够帮助球队赢得比赛，并创造和传承49人队的辉煌传统。为了实现这一目标，我指示老队员们帮助其他人熟悉工作流程，把工作做得更好（即使他们培训的是自己的工作）。因此，老队员们积累的知识——尤其是在我制定的绩效标准方面——被新员工、新秀以及一二年级球员以非常有效的方式吸收利用。从某种意义上说，我让我的学生成为了老师。球员们变成了教练。你们的组织中也存在着这样一支现成的“老师队伍”。好好利用它吧。
I applied the same expectations—teaching and training others to do one’s own job—to myself. When I retired as head coach after Super Bowl XXIII, my replacement and longtime assistant coach, George Seifert, had been well schooled in the Standard of Performance that had become the 49er way. Seifert’s San Francisco 49ers won Super Bowl XXIV the year immediately following my departure. It was his team, but I felt ownership and pride in it.
我对自己也抱有同样的期望——教导和训练他人做好自己的工作。在我于第23届超级碗后卸任主教练一职时，我的继任者、长期担任助理教练的乔治·塞弗特已经熟练掌握了49人队奉行的“绩效标准”。塞弗特执教的旧金山49人队在我离开后的第二年就赢得了第24届超级碗。虽然这是他的球队，但我对它充满归属感和自豪感。
There was, however, great ambivalence in my pride. At the moment of San Francisco’s fourth Super Bowl title, as I watched the commissioner of NFL football, Paul Tagliabue, hand the Lombardi Trophy to George Seifert and Eddie DeBartolo, I was filled with deep remorse and great sadness.
然而，我的自豪感中却夹杂着巨大的矛盾。当旧金山队第四次赢得超级碗冠军，当我看到NFL总裁保罗·塔利亚布将隆巴迪奖杯颁给乔治·塞弗特和埃迪·德巴托洛时，我心中充满了深深的懊悔和悲伤。
By retiring at the end of the previous season I had denied myself the opportunity to equal the all-time record for a head coach of winning four Super Bowls, as Chuck Noll’s Pittsburgh Steelers had done under his leadership. It is perhaps the most illustrious of all NFL records. I quit at three, “voluntarily” walked away from my chance to make history. I never got over that one.
上赛季结束后我选择退休，错失了追平查克·诺尔执教匹兹堡钢人队时创下的四次超级碗夺冠纪录的机会。这或许是NFL历史上最辉煌的纪录。我只赢了三次就离开了，算是“自愿”放弃了创造历史的机会。我至今仍为此耿耿于怀。
My philosophy of team members teaching new arrivals the organization’s system, not just X ’s and O ’s but the attitudes and actions of performance, is essential to a self-sustaining winning organization. It is accomplished through mentoring within your organization. And for mentoring to exist, members of your team must truly believe that their first loyalty is to furthering the good of the group: “What is good for us is good for me.” That’s tough to teach, but it’s part of the connection and extension principle that was built into my Standard of Performance.
我的理念是，团队成员应该向新成员传授组织的运作体系，不仅仅是操作流程，更重要的是培养他们的态度和行动力，这对于一个能够自我维持并取得成功的组织至关重要。而这可以通过组织内部的导师制来实现。导师制的前提是，团队成员必须真正相信，他们的首要忠诚是促进团队的利益：“对我们有利的，对我也有好处。” 这一点很难做到，但它是我绩效标准中“联系与延伸”原则的核心组成部分。
I am not naive. Intense rivalries existed between players fighting for the same position, and they did not want to train their own replacements. The best example in my experience is perhaps Steve Young and Joe Montana—two of the greatest quarterbacks in NFL history, who are both in the NFL Hall of Fame. When Steve was acquired from Tampa after Joe had led San Francisco to two Super Bowl championships, Montana didn’t like it one bit. He felt threatened, perhaps insulted and embarrassed. Nevertheless, my goal was to help both of them put aside personal ambition and accept my decisions regarding what was best for the team as I looked into the future. Good luck with that.
我并非天真。球员之间为了争夺同一位置而展开激烈竞争，他们并不想培养自己的接班人。就我的经验而言，最好的例子或许就是史蒂夫·杨和乔·蒙塔纳——两位NFL历史上最伟大的四分卫，他们都已入选NFL名人堂。当乔带领旧金山49人队两次夺得超级碗冠军后，球队从坦帕湾海盗队交易来了史蒂夫，蒙塔纳对此非常不满。他感到威胁，或许还觉得受到了侮辱和羞辱。然而，我的目标是帮助他们放下个人野心，接受我为球队未来利益所做的决定。祝我好运吧。
Obviously, it was impossible for them to literally do this, to forget about their rivalry. After all, they were both thoroughbreds by nature and nurturing, born leaders who felt diminished standing on the sidelines watching the other guy do a job each felt he could do better. Nevertheless, I wanted to get close to a situation where they were able to coexist and not be disruptive to the overall environment of the organization.
显然，他们不可能真的做到这一点，彻底忘却彼此的竞争。毕竟，他们都是天生的佼佼者，都是善于培养人才的领导者，如果只能站在一旁看着对方做着自己认为更擅长的工作，就会感到自卑。尽管如此，我还是想尽可能地让他们能够共存，并且不扰乱组织的整体环境。
An overall workable “truce,” which was uneasy at times, was held together, and each player made some efforts to help the other. They were never buddies, and in fact to this day view each other with a wary eye. But it held together. We— they —kept the peace. In my opinion, overall they did help each other. Perhaps it’s wishful thinking, but that’s how I would like to think it was. It certainly was that way for other players throughout most of the organization.
总体而言，双方维持着一种勉强可行的“休战”关系，尽管有时并不稳固，但每个球员都尽力帮助对方。他们从来就不是朋友，事实上，直到今天，他们仍然对彼此抱有戒心。但这种关系勉强维持了下来。我们——他们——维持了和平。在我看来，总的来说，他们确实互相帮助了。也许这只是我的一厢情愿，但我愿意这样认为。对于俱乐部里的其他球员来说，情况也确实如此。
Everyone must have an attitude of helping one another. Are you teaching that to those you lead? Do you teach that being on your team includes sharing their knowledge? That an employee strengthens himself or herself when he or she strengthens another member of the organization?
每个人都应该有互相帮助的态度。你是否在教导你的团队成员这一点？你是否教导他们，团队合作意味着分享知识？员工帮助其他成员提升自身能力时，自身也会得到提升？
It’s a powerful force when you unleash it. I unleashed it during my years as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers. It was one of our great assets—unseen by those outside the 49er organization.
一旦释放出来，它就是一股强大的力量。在我担任旧金山49人队主教练的那些年里，我就释放了它。这是我们的一大优势——只是49人队以外的人看不到而已。

Don’t Do unto Others (What Paul Brown Did unto Me) 不要以牙还牙（就像保罗·布朗对我做的那样）
Paul Brown, the only man in history to have an NFL team named after him—the Cleveland Browns—was also one of professional football’s most powerful and creative forces, a football genius whose absolute commitment to his team’s welfare was an obsession. He was willing to do virtually anything for the good of the team. This caused him to deal severely and, at times, unscrupulously with anyone acting in a manner he viewed as contrary to the best interests of the Browns (and later the Cincinnati Bengals).
保罗·布朗是历史上唯一一位拥有以他名字命名的NFL球队——克利夫兰布朗队——的人，他也是职业橄榄球界最具影响力和创造力的人物之一，一位对球队利益无比执着的橄榄球天才。他愿意为了球队的利益付出一切。因此，对于任何他认为有损布朗队（以及后来的辛辛那提猛虎队）利益的人，他都会采取严厉甚至不择手段的手段。
I know because at a very important point in my career I was subjected to this dark side of Paul Brown’s character. Ultimately, it became one half of a crucial lesson I learned about dealing with people.
我知道，因为在我职业生涯的一个非常关键的时刻，我亲身经历了保罗·布朗性格中阴暗的一面。最终，这成为我学习如何与人相处的重要一课。
When Paul Brown decided to retire, I had been his assistant offensive coach at Cincinnati for eight years. During that time, he’d led me to believe I would replace him as head coach when the time came for him to step down. But when the time came, he chose Bill “Tiger” Johnson, a talented offensive coordinator I had worked with during my years on the Bengals’ staff. I was devastated and felt it was time to look elsewhere if I was going to advance my career in the direction of eventually becoming a head coach.
保罗·布朗决定退休时，我已经在辛辛那提猛虎队担任了八年的进攻助理教练。在那段时间里，他一直让我相信，等他卸任时，我会接替他成为主教练。但到了那一天，他却选择了比尔·“老虎”·约翰逊，一位才华横溢的进攻协调员，我曾在猛虎队共事过。我感到非常失望，觉得如果想要在职业生涯中继续发展，最终成为一名主教练，就必须另谋出路。
Very soon I discussed job openings with the Seattle Seahawks and the New York Jets, neither of whom showed any interest at all. This struck me as unusual, since both teams needed to make improvements in an area where I had proven expertise and a good track record; namely, figuring out how to score more touchdowns.
很快，我就联系了西雅图海鹰队和纽约喷气机队，询问是否有合适的职位空缺，但他们都毫无兴趣。这让我感到很意外，因为这两支球队都需要在我擅长且成绩斐然的领域进行补强：那就是如何提高得分效率。
Later, during an interview with the San Diego Chargers about the job as their offensive coordinator, I began to understand why I had received such a cool reception in those earlier job interviews: My efforts to find employment outside the Bengals football organization were being aggressively sabotaged by someone from inside the Bengals organization: my boss, Paul Brown.
后来，在接受圣地亚哥闪电队进攻协调员一职的面试时，我开始明白为什么我在之前的面试中受到了如此冷遇：我在辛辛那提猛虎队之外寻找工作的努力，遭到了猛虎队内部某人的恶意破坏：那就是我的老板保罗·布朗。
Tommy Prothro, head coach of the Chargers, casually mentioned during my job interview that Paul had called him two days earlier and made very critical remarks about my work at Cincinnati, including the observation that I was too passive to really motivate and lead a large group of players. He strongly urged Tommy not to hire me. (Simultaneously, I was being offered the job as offensive coordinator of the Bengals, the same position the Chargers had been told by Brown that I couldn’t handle.)
在我的面试中，闪电队主教练汤米·普罗索漫不经心地提到，保罗两天前给他打过电话，对我在辛辛那提的工作提出了非常严厉的批评，包括认为我过于被动，无法真正激励和领导一大群球员。他强烈要求汤米不要聘用我。（与此同时，我收到了猛虎队进攻协调员的职位邀请，而布朗曾告诉闪电队，我无法胜任这个职位。）
This backstabbing was confirmed shortly afterward by Al Davis, the crafty owner of the Oakland Raiders, who told me that other owners and executives around the NFL were also getting negative critiques about me out of Cincinnati. “The word going out on you isn’t so good, Bill. People are hearing that you’re great with X ’s and O ’s but not really a leader. Maybe that’s why you’re not getting offers,” he suggested.
不久之后，奥克兰突袭者队老谋深算的老板阿尔·戴维斯证实了这番背后捅刀之事。他告诉我，NFL其他球队的老板和高管也从辛辛那提那边听到了关于我的负面评价。“比尔，你的名声不太好。大家都说你战术很厉害，但领导能力不行。也许这就是你没收到报价的原因吧。”他暗示道。
Al was correct. In spite of my loyal and very productive years as an assistant coach with the Cincinnati Bengals, Paul Brown wouldn’t recommend me to other teams and was, in fact, aggressively reaching out to prevent me from getting a job elsewhere. (It also explained why during my eight years at Cincinnati I had received no serious job offers. Brown had turned aside inquiries about my availability and downplayed my leadership abilities. In all those years, he never mentioned that others were expressing interest in hiring me, that other teams wanted to talk to me about a job.)
艾尔说得没错。尽管我在辛辛那提猛虎队担任助理教练期间忠诚尽责，贡献卓著，保罗·布朗却从未向其他球队推荐过我，事实上，他还积极地阻止我去其他地方工作。（这也解释了为什么我在辛辛那提的八年间没有收到任何正式的聘用邀请。布朗拒绝了所有关于我是否适合执教的询问，并且贬低了我的领导能力。这么多年来，他从未提及其他球队有意聘用我，也从未提及其他球队想和我谈谈工作机会。）
In one way, it was understandable. Brown had a fanatical desire to protect the Cincinnati franchise at all costs, even if it meant dishonestly denigrating my ability to other NFL owners and coaches. Obviously, this was a personal betrayal, even if he believed it was somehow in my own best interests to remain with the Bengals.
从某种程度上来说，这可以理解。布朗狂热地想要不惜一切代价保护辛辛那提猛虎队，即便这意味着他要不择手段地在其他NFL老板和教练面前诋毁我的能力。显然，这是一种背叛，即便他认为我留在猛虎队对我自身最有利。
Added to everything else, this made it imperative that I leave Cincinnati as soon as possible. Subsequently, I joined Tommy Prothro’s staff in San Diego and soon learned the other half of an important lesson in how to treat people if you want a productive organization filled with true team spirit and vitality.
除此之外，其他种种因素也让我不得不尽快离开辛辛那提。随后，我加入了汤米·普罗索在圣地亚哥的团队，并很快领悟到如何待人接物才能打造一个高效、充满活力和团队精神的组织。
One year after I was hired by the Chargers, Stanford University called and inquired about my availability to take over as its head coach. When Tommy heard about the offer, he immediately came to me with the following advice: “Take the job, Bill, because a head coaching position in the Pac-10 is significant. For the good of your family and career and peace of mind, go to Stanford.”
在我被圣迭戈闪电队聘用一年后，斯坦福大学打电话来询问我是否有意愿担任他们的主教练。汤米听到这个消息后，立刻来找我，给了我这样的建议：“比尔，接受这份工作吧，因为在太平洋十校联盟担任主教练意义重大。为了你的家庭、事业和内心的平静，去斯坦福吧。”
Tommy felt that I had done outstanding work for him during the previous season—my efforts with future Hall of Fame quarterback Dan Fouts and the subsequent improved offensive attack had produced excellent results, and there was every reason to expect more of the same. Nevertheless, Tommy put my best interests ahead of his own and his team’s. He was a man of the highest ethical standards.
汤米认为我在上个赛季为他做出了杰出的贡献——我与未来名人堂四分卫丹·福茨的合作以及随后进攻端的提升都取得了显著成效，完全有理由期待我继续保持这样的表现。然而，汤米始终将我的利益置于他自身和球队的利益之上。他是一位拥有极高道德标准的人。
My subsequent work as head coach at Stanford University led directly to being hired by the San Francisco 49ers, and it was due in great measure to his encouragement and selflessness.
我后来在斯坦福大学担任主教练，这直接促成了我被旧金山 49 人队聘用，这很大程度上要归功于他的鼓励和无私奉献。
However, the following question should be addressed: If the bottom line, winning, is all that counts, didn’t Paul Brown make the smart choice—doing everything possible to keep a valued employee on staff, even if it meant hurting that individual’s chance for advancement elsewhere? No, and ethical considerations aside, here’s a very practical reason why.
然而，以下问题值得探讨：如果最终结果（即胜利）才是最重要的，那么保罗·布朗的做法难道不是明智之举吗？他竭尽所能留住一位优秀的员工，即使这意味着损害该员工在其他地方的晋升机会。答案是否定的。抛开道德考量不谈，这里有一个非常实际的原因。
I believe that character-based leaders tend to seek and attract character-based employees in sports, in business, or anywhere else. As my own career progressed, I tried hard to emulate the example of Tommy Prothro, who believed in treating people right, whose leadership was founded on ethics. Here’s just one example of how it played out for me.
我相信，无论在体育界、商界还是其他任何领域，品格高尚的领导者往往都能找到并吸引同样品格高尚的员工。随着我职业生涯的发展，我努力效仿汤米·普罗索的榜样，他坚信要善待他人，他的领导力建立在道德准则之上。以下是我亲身实践的一个例子。
When I was head coach of the 49ers, one of our defensive coaches, Ray Rhodes, began attracting attention from other teams because of his uncommon abilities—highly informed, enthusiastic, straightforward, a good teacher and communicator who got exceptional results. He was a very important factor in the early years when we were trying to turn things around and then later in winning Super Bowls.
我担任旧金山49人队主教练时，我们的一位防守教练雷·罗兹（Ray Rhodes）因其非凡的能力而开始吸引其他球队的关注——他知识渊博、热情洋溢、直言不讳，是一位优秀的教练和沟通者，并取得了卓越的成绩。在我们早期努力扭转颓势的时期，以及后来赢得超级碗的过程中，他都发挥了至关重要的作用。
The New York Giants, already familiar with Ray’s outstanding qualities because he was one of their former players, requested permission to talk to him about a coaching position (he still had a one-year obligation left on his San Francisco contract).
纽约巨人队对雷的出色能力早已有所了解，因为他曾是巨人队的球员，所以他们请求允许与他谈谈教练职位的事（他与旧金山巨人队的合同还有一年才到期）。
In spite of the fact that we greatly valued his ability, character, and importance to our team, I recognized what Tommy Prothro had done for me. I gave New York permission to talk to Ray with the understanding that if he ultimately wanted to break his contract with the 49ers and join the Giants, he would be free to do so. Additionally, I told New York the truth about Ray Rhodes; namely, that he was a terrific coach and solid citizen. The Giants soon offered him a job.
尽管我们非常重视他的能力、品格以及他对球队的重要性，但我同样明白汤米·普罗索对我的帮助。我允许纽约方面与雷·罗兹接触，前提是如果他最终想解除与49人队的合同并加盟巨人队，他完全可以自由选择。此外，我还向纽约方面如实介绍了雷·罗兹的情况：他是一位杰出的教练，也是一位品行端正的公民。巨人队很快就向他提供了一份工作。
Now it was our turn. To keep Ray in the organization, we prepared a very strong counteroffer, including a three-year contract for a lot more money. It was not an easy decision for Ray, because he had received two outstanding offers, but after giving it careful consideration over a period of several days, he decided he would benefit most by staying with the 49ers. Ray remained with us and continued to do great work. A few years later, he became head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.
现在轮到我们了。为了留住雷，我们准备了一份极具竞争力的反报价，包括一份三年高薪合同。这对雷来说并非易事，因为他已经收到了两份非常不错的报价，但经过几天的深思熟虑，他最终决定留在49人队对他最有利。雷留了下来，并继续为我们做出卓越贡献。几年后，他成为了费城老鹰队的主教练。
There’s a phrase that sums it up fairly well: “What goes around comes around.” I believe that word of what Paul Brown had done to me (and probably others) when I was attempting to leave Cincinnati got around the league and ultimately hurt the Bengals in a variety of predictable ways. After all, how eager would you be to join an organization that might not look after your interests, that might betray your loyalty?
有一句谚语很贴切地概括了这件事：“善恶终有报”。我相信，保罗·布朗在我试图离开辛辛那提时对我（可能还有其他人）所做的一切，最终在联盟中传开，并以各种意料之中的方式损害了猛虎队的利益。毕竟，你会多么渴望加入一个可能不会维护你利益、可能会背叛你忠诚的组织呢？
Conversely, I know for a fact that many talented players and coaches—individuals who eventually helped us win NFC conference championships and Super Bowls, such as quarterback Steve Young, Wendell Tyler, Jack “Hacksaw” Reynolds, Paul Hackett (later head coach of USC), and others— sought to join San Francisco in large measure because they knew their career aspirations would be addressed and respected.
相反，我确切地知道，许多才华横溢的球员和教练——最终帮助我们赢得 NFC 联盟冠军和超级碗冠军的球员和教练，例如四分卫史蒂夫·杨、温德尔·泰勒、杰克“电锯”雷诺兹、保罗·哈克特（后来的南加州大学主教练）等等——之所以寻求加入旧金山，很大程度上是因为他们知道他们的职业抱负会得到关注和尊重。
While they were with us, we expected them to give us everything they had, but in turn, we gave them our recognition that they had the right to advance their own careers. Word got around that the 49ers treated people right.
在他们与我们共事期间，我们希望他们竭尽全力，但作为回报，我们也承认他们有权发展自己的职业生涯。49人队善待员工的名声也随之传开。
In your own professional activities, remember that a reputation for fair play—treating people right—can be a big part of a potential employee’s decision to join you or a current and valued employee’s desire to remain. It can infuse your team with strength in creating a self-image that transcends a sense of being in a band of mercenaries. It can matter more than money.
在你的职业生涯中，请记住，公平待人——也就是善待他人——的声誉，对于潜在员工是否愿意加入你的团队，以及现有优秀员工是否愿意继续留任，都至关重要。它能增强团队凝聚力，塑造一种超越雇佣兵式的自我形象。它的重要性甚至超过金钱。
When it comes to deciding how you treat people, exploitation, expedience, and self-interest are a formula for creating a team of individuals who will soon be looking to join another team. I learned many great lessons from Paul Brown, but “treating people right” was not among them. That lesson was one I learned from Tommy Prothro.
在决定如何待人接物时，剥削、权宜和自私自利只会让你打造出一支很快就会另谋出路的团队。我从保罗·布朗身上学到了很多，但“善待他人”并不在其中。这个道理我从汤米·普罗索那里学到了。

Nine Steps for a Healthy Heart 九个步骤，助您拥有健康的心脏
People matter most—more than equipment, investors, inventions, momentum, or X ’s and O ’s. People are at the heart of achieving organizational greatness. Too often aggressive leaders forget the human part of the equation—the most important part. Let me suggest nine steps you can take that involve treating people right, for having a healthy heart in your organization:
1. Afford each person the same respect, support, and fair treatment you would expect if your roles were reversed. Deal with people individually, not as objects who are part of a herd—that’s the critical factor.
2. Leadership involves many people, each with their own need for role identity within the organization. Find what a person does best, utilize and emphasize it, and steer clear of his or her weaknesses.
3. Demonstrate a pronounced commitment to employees by providing a work environment that enables them to achieve their maximum potential and productivity.
4. Acknowledge the uniqueness of each employee and the need he or she has for a reasonable degree of job security and self-actualization. You don’t own him or her.
5. The most talented personnel often are very independent minded. This requires that you carefully consider how you relate to and communicate with this type of individual. Creative people usually bring a passion to seeing their ideas put into play as quickly as possible. They must be helped to understand that not every idea is appropriate and that coming up with a new concept is just the start of a process that includes evaluation, comparisons, practicability, and more. But be careful not to quash an idea-friendly environment in your organization.
6. While at times a divergence may exist between the good of the group and the good of the individual , in a best-case scenario the group’s and the individual’s “good” should be the same. When this is not the case, you are well served to explain the reasons behind the divergence to the person who feels badly treated—for example, when he or she is passed over for promotion. (For me, occasionally a player wanted to play one position when, in fact, he was better suited to another. I attempted to explain this to the individual whose goal was being denied. You may have an individual who similarly needs direction to play to his or her strength within your organization. And you may have to explain how this benefits the goal of the team.)
7. People are most comfortable with how they are being treated when their duties are laid out in specific detail and their performance can be gauged by specific metrics. The key is to document—clarify—those expectations. In my initial year at San Francisco, our starting quarterback, Steve DeBerg, was outstanding in many areas. The category that he came up short in, however, was critical—throwing interceptions at important junctures. It cost him his job because it was right there on paper, a quantifiable statistic that verified what I already knew. In a very easily seen way, he could be shown where he was underperforming.
8. It is critical that employee expectation levels be reasonable, attainable, and high. While you should exhibit flexibility in the work environment to accommodate the needs of employees, you should be inflexible with regard to your expectations of their performance.
9. Establish a protocol for how members of the organization interact with one another. This is essential to preventing compartmentalization and “turf protection.” Let them know their first priority is to do their job; their second priority is to facilitate others in doing their jobs.
人是最重要的——比设备、投资者、发明、势头或技术细节都重要。人才是组织走向卓越的核心。很多时候，咄咄逼人的领导者会忽略等式中最重要的人性因素。以下九个步骤可以帮助您善待员工，让您的组织充满活力：1. 给予每个人同样的尊重、支持和公平对待，就像您自己角色互换时所期望的那样。要将每个人都视为独立的个体，而不是群体中的一员——这是关键所在。2. 领导力涉及众多成员，每个人都需要在组织中获得身份认同。找到每个人的优势，加以利用和强调，并避开他们的弱点。3. 通过提供一个能够让员工充分发挥潜能和提高生产力的工作环境，来展现您对员工的坚定承诺。4. 承认每位员工的独特性，以及他们对合理程度的工作保障和自我实现的需要。您并不拥有他们。5.最有才华的人往往非常独立思考。这就要求你认真考虑如何与这类人相处和沟通。富有创造力的人通常渴望尽快将自己的想法付诸实践。必须帮助他们理解，并非每个想法都合适，提出新概念仅仅是一个过程的开始，这个过程还包括评估、比较、可行性分析等等。但要注意不要扼杀组织中鼓励创新的氛围。6. 虽然有时集体利益和个人利益之间可能存在分歧，但在理想情况下，集体利益和个人利益应该是一致的。如果并非如此，你应该向感到不公平对待的人解释造成分歧的原因——例如，当他们晋升受阻时。 （对我来说，偶尔会有球员想打某个位置，但实际上他更适合另一个位置。我会尝试向这位目标受阻的球员解释这一点。你的团队中可能也有类似的球员需要指导才能发挥自身优势。你也可能需要解释这如何有利于团队目标的实现。）7. 当员工的职责被详细列出，并且他们的绩效可以通过具体的指标来衡量时，他们会感到最自在。关键在于记录——明确——这些期望。在我执教旧金山的第一年，我们的首发四分卫史蒂夫·德伯格在很多方面都表现出色。然而，他在关键时刻的失误却至关重要——在关键时刻传球被拦截。这让他丢掉了工作，因为这一点就写在纸上，一个可量化的统计数据证实了我早已知晓的事实。他可以非常清楚地看到自己在哪些方面表现不佳。8. 员工的期望值必须合理、可实现且高，这一点至关重要。虽然你应该在工作环境中展现灵活性以满足员工的需求，但你对他们的绩效期望应该毫不妥协。9. 建立一套组织成员之间互动的规范。这对于防止部门壁垒和“地盘争夺”至关重要。让他们明白，他们的首要任务是做好自己的工作；其次是协助他人完成工作。

Seriously, Don’t Be Too Serious 说真的，别太严肃
There’s not a lot of room for joking around in the midst of competitive challenges, whether on the football field or in the marketplace. Humor is often a sign of being removed from the focus and commitment necessary to do the job well—a casual attitude about a serious endeavor.
在充满竞争挑战的环境中，无论是在足球场上还是在市场中，都没有太多开玩笑的空间。幽默往往意味着缺乏专注和投入，而专注和投入是做好工作所必需的——是对严肃事业的一种漫不经心的态度。
But a leader also runs the risk of pushing so hard, with deadly solemnity and grim-faced determination, that he or she creates an oppressive and performance-limiting workplace. You need to recognize when it’s time to lighten up and let some of the steam—pressure—vent. This requires the ability to gauge when and how it is appropriate to utilize humor.
但领导者也可能面临这样的风险：用力过猛，摆出一副死板严肃、表情严肃的姿态，反而营造出一种压抑压抑、限制员工绩效的工作环境。你需要懂得何时放松下来，释放一些压力。这就要求你能够判断何时以及如何恰当地运用幽默。
We encountered that kind of situation in the week prior to playing in our first Super Bowl. The incredible experience was brand new to all of us, but I was especially concerned that our young players would be adversely affected by the media gauntlet and fan frenzy, not to mention the requirement that they perform at their absolute best. It could be crushing, and in fact, oddsmakers generally give an edge in the Super Bowl to a team that has been there before—experienced the near-trauma of the week’s media circus and ultimate-game pressure. (In this instance, neither team had appeared in a Super Bowl before.)
我们在首次参加超级碗的前一周就遇到了这种情况。对我们所有人来说，这都是一次全新的体验，但我尤其担心我们的年轻球员会受到媒体的狂轰滥炸和球迷的狂热追捧的影响，更不用说他们必须拿出最佳状态才能赢得比赛了。这可能会让他们崩溃，事实上，博彩公司通常会更看好那些参加过超级碗的球队——他们经历过一周媒体的狂轰滥炸和决赛的压力，那种压力几乎让他们崩溃。（而这次，两支球队之前都没有参加过超级碗。）
I arrived in Detroit several days before the rest of the team to do interviews and participate in league meetings. My plan was to meet the players when they arrived at our hotel after their bus trip in from the Detroit airport. Consequently, I was looking for something for our guys that would crack the tension, something where they could just enjoy one another in the incredible hype they would encounter immediately after stepping off the buses in front of the hotel.
我比其他队员早几天抵达底特律，目的是进行采访并参加联盟会议。我的计划是等球员们从底特律机场乘大巴抵达酒店后再和他们见面。因此，我一直在寻找一些能缓解他们紧张情绪的活动，让他们在一下车后，面对酒店门口那令人难以置信的兴奋氛围时，能够放松下来，享受彼此陪伴的时光。
I had about thirty minutes before they arrived and came up with this idea: I would put on a bellhop’s uniform and cap—disguise myself—and help the players with their bags as they got off the bus. I paid a bellhop thirty bucks to let me wear his outfit and stood on the curb as the first San Francisco 49ers bus pulled up right in front of me. My disguise was effective because crowding behind me on the sidewalk were hundreds of fans, friends, reporters, and photographers who distracted the players as they got off the bus.
他们到达前我还有大约三十分钟，于是我想到了一个主意：我穿上行李员的制服和帽子——伪装一下——然后帮球员们搬行李。我花了三十美元请一位行李员借给我这身行头，然后站在路边，等第一辆旧金山49人队的巴士停在我面前。我的伪装很奏效，因为人行道上挤满了数百名球迷、朋友、记者和摄影师，他们分散了球员们的注意力，让他们无法专心下车。
As team members stepped to the sidewalk I kept my head kind of looking down at their luggage so they couldn’t see who it was—their head coach handling their bags. The whole point, of course, was to break the heat of the experience and remind them, “Hey, we’re still us .” I wanted to let them know that it was okay to be comfortable and even enjoy what was going on, that they didn’t have to go into some hyper level of tension and stress because it was the Super Bowl.
当队员们走到人行道上时，我一直低着头看着他们的行李，不让他们看到是谁——他们的主教练在帮他们拿行李。当然，我这么做的目的是为了缓解紧张气氛，提醒他们：“嘿，我们还是我们。”我想让他们知道，放松下来，享受当下的一切是完全可以的，不必因为这是超级碗就过度紧张焦虑。
My disguise worked so well that Joe Montana actually got into a tug-of-war with me over his duffel bag. He was trying to keep me from taking it when suddenly he saw who the “bellhop” was—his head coach. The whole team started breaking up and joking with one another—a big shift for the positive in team attitude. They saw the guy in charge—me—having a little fun. It gave them an important message: Don’t get all worked up and stressed out by everything. Stay loose.
我的伪装太成功了，乔·蒙塔纳竟然为了抢他的行李袋跟我打了起来。他拼命想阻止我拿走，结果突然发现“行李员”是谁——他的主教练。全队顿时笑了起来，互相打趣——这极大地鼓舞了士气。他们看到负责人——也就是我——也玩得很开心。这给他们传递了一个重要的信息：别什么事都那么紧张焦虑，放松点。
The little stunt went to my understanding that in a crucible of pressure a safety valve is valuable, something that will release tension. And I could see that the pressure immediately reduced in the 49ers as they got off the buses.
这个小插曲让我明白，在压力巨大的情况下，安全阀是多么重要，它能释放压力。我看到，当49人队队员们下车时，他们身上的压力立刻减轻了。
The same kind of opportunities exist for you if you’re alert and recognize that puncturing pressure with appropriate humor can be beneficial under the weight of deadlines and other stress producers.
如果你保持警觉，并意识到在截止日期和其他压力源的重压下，用适当的幽默来缓解压力是有益的，那么你也会有同样的机会。
A more outlandish situation occurred a week later on the way to the Silverdome in Pontiac, Michigan, where we would play in Super Bowl XVI. We traveled in two buses, and I was on the second one with Montana and half of the team. The first bus made it to the Silverdome without a problem. Our bus got caught in a massive traffic jam caused by a motorcade for Vice President George Bush. It was made worse by a snowstorm that had hit a few hours earlier. At one point, it looked like we might be thirty minutes late for our own Super Bowl game.
一周后，在前往密歇根州庞蒂亚克银穹体育馆参加第十六届超级碗的途中，发生了一件更加离奇的事情。我们乘坐两辆大巴，我和蒙塔纳以及半数队友在第二辆车上。第一辆大巴顺利抵达银穹体育馆，而我们的大巴却被困在了由副总统乔治·布什的车队造成的严重交通堵塞中。几个小时前突如其来的暴风雪更是雪上加霜。一度，我们眼看就要错过自己的超级碗比赛，迟到了三十分钟。
It would have been easy to sit in silence and stew, to let the extreme pressure go even higher. Instead, I intentionally made some lighter comments and a few jokes, including my announcement over the bus’s loudspeaker that the game had started without us using just the players of the first bus: “May I have your attention, please. This just in from the Silverdome: ‘Early in the first quarter, San Francisco is trailing Cincinnati 7-0. 49ers trainer Chico Norton is calling the plays.” This loosened people up, and the energy returned to something approaching a “normal” level of enthusiasm and eagerness to go into battle. We arrived at the Silverdome just ninety minutes before the kickoff.
如果就此沉默不语，任由压力倍增，那该有多轻松。但我没有这么做，而是刻意说了些轻松的话，开了几个玩笑，包括用大巴上的广播宣布比赛已经开始，而我们并没有只用第一辆大巴上的球员：“请大家注意。这是银穹体育馆传来的消息：‘第一节刚开始，旧金山49人队0比7落后辛辛那提猛虎队。49人队的训练师奇科·诺顿正在指挥比赛。’” 这番话让大家放松下来，气氛也恢复到接近“正常”的热情和斗志。我们赶在开球前90分钟到达了银穹体育馆。
I certainly am not suggesting that a joke or lighter comment is why we won that game. But I know for certain that tightening of nerves in an atmosphere of increasing uncertainty and anxiety is counterproductive. I defused or changed it to something more productive because I knew that humor, used in the right way at the right time, could provide that valuable safety valve. (By the way, after nearly being late for the Super Bowl because he was on the second bus, Joe started taking a taxi to the stadium for all future road games. That way he could leave much earlier and guarantee that he wouldn’t miss the opening snap.)
我当然不是说我们赢球是因为开了个玩笑或者说了句轻松的话。但我确信，在日益加剧的不确定性和焦虑气氛中，紧张的情绪只会适得其反。我之所以能化解紧张情绪，或者把它转化成更有益的事情，是因为我知道，在合适的时机以合适的方式运用幽默，可以起到重要的安全阀作用。（顺便一提，乔因为坐第二班大巴差点错过超级碗，之后他每次客场比赛都打车去体育场。这样他就能早点出发，确保不会错过开球。）
Does pressure improve performance? Yes, up to a point, but let me suggest the following: Regardless of context, those who are able to perform best are those who are best able to remove tension, anxiety, and fear from their minds. There’s a phrase for it: “being in the zone.” And, there is no tension, anxiety, or fear in the zone, whether on the football field, in the conference room, or in a multitude of situations where you are called on to really produce.
压力能提升表现吗？在一定程度上可以，但我想指出的是：无论在何种情况下，那些能够发挥最佳水平的人，往往也是那些最能消除内心紧张、焦虑和恐惧的人。有一种说法可以形容这种状态：“进入状态”。在这种状态下，无论是在足球场上、会议室里，还是在其他任何需要你全力以赴的场合，都不会感到紧张、焦虑或恐惧。
You want your team to push hard, to feel as if they will come up short without total effort. But total effort doesn’t mean total anxiety. I believe optimum creativity and high performance—a sales presentation, for example, or a complex pass play from Joe Montana to Jerry Rice—are most likely to succeed when the individual or group has an attitude that is seemingly a paradox; specifically, both relaxed and intense. That’s when things really happen. Here’s an example that many people still don’t believe is true.
你希望你的团队全力以赴，让他们觉得如果不竭尽全力就会失败。但全力以赴并不意味着焦虑不安。我相信，最佳的创造力和卓越的绩效——例如，一场精彩的销售演示，或者乔·蒙塔纳传给杰里·赖斯的复杂传球——最有可能在个人或团队拥有看似矛盾的态度时取得成功；具体来说，就是既放松又专注。那时，奇迹才会真正发生。下面这个例子，很多人至今仍不相信。
In Super Bowl XXIII the 49ers took possession of the ball late in the fourth quarter—with less than three minutes left—on our own eight-yard line. We needed to drive the length of the field and score a touchdown to win the ballgame. A single mistake along the way could cost us the Super Bowl. This is about as much situational pressure as exists in NFL football.
在第23届超级碗中，49人队在第四节末段——距离比赛结束不到三分钟——在己方8码线处获得球权。我们需要推进到对方半场并达阵得分才能赢得比赛。过程中任何一个失误都可能让我们与超级碗失之交臂。这几乎是NFL橄榄球比赛中最紧张的局面了。
As our offense huddled in the end zone to hear Joe Montana call the first play, they noticed his head turn; something had caught his eye. “Hey,” he said to his teammates huddled with him, “isn’t that John Candy, the comedian, standing over there by the exit in the stands?” Everybody looked up, and sure enough, it was Candy. Then they turned back into the huddle and got back to business.
当我们的进攻队员围在端区，准备听乔·蒙塔纳喊出第一个战术时，他们注意到他转过头来；有什么东西吸引了他的目光。“嘿，”他对围在他身边的队友们说，“那边看台出口旁边站着的，是不是喜剧演员约翰·坎迪？”所有人都抬头望去，果然是坎迪。然后他们转回围成的圈，继续投入到战术中。
How was it possible for Joe (and his teammates) to be comfortable—relaxed but intense and focused—in the middle of that cauldron? With all due respect to Joe and his teammates, that’s what a leader tries to teach—how to be in the zone.
乔（和他的队友们）是如何在那种紧张激烈的环境中保持放松、专注和沉着的呢？恕我直言，这正是领导者努力教导队员的——如何进入最佳状态。
Wisely applied humor—even something as silly as putting on a bellhop’s uniform—can be a useful device in allowing your team, staff, or organization to get past anxiety and into the zone. Don’t overdo it, but don’t underestimate its effectiveness.
巧妙运用幽默——哪怕是像穿上门童制服这样看似傻气的做法——也能有效地帮助你的团队、员工或组织克服焦虑，进入最佳状态。切勿过度使用，但也不要低估它的效果。

The Last Word on Getting in the Last Word 关于如何发表最后发言的最后意见
I have been accused of being overly sensitive to criticism—thin-skinned. Maybe it’s because I’ve seen too many examples of so-called experts and critics who didn’t have much of a clue. Unfortunately, what they say or write becomes part of the public record and is subsequently perceived as fact. This can really hurt when it’s hogwash.
我曾被指责对批评过于敏感——玻璃心。或许是因为我见过太多所谓的专家和评论家，他们其实一窍不通。不幸的是，他们所说或所写的内容会成为公开记录的一部分，并被人们视为事实。当这些话纯属胡说八道时，真的会让人很受伤。
Here’s an example. A Seattle sports writer published a book that singled me out as “a most stupid coach.” He gave as evidence a game against the Seahawks in which the 49ers had executed a series of well-crafted running plays to get inside Seattle’s ten-yard line. I then called three passing plays in an attempt to score. We failed. The writer suggested this was the work of a coaching moron.
举个例子。一位西雅图的体育记者出版了一本书，书中把我贬为“最愚蠢的教练”。他举了一场对阵海鹰队的比赛作为证据：49人队精心策划了一系列跑动进攻，推进到了海鹰队十码线以内。然后我连续三次传球试图得分，结果失败了。这位记者认为这是个白痴教练的杰作。
What this “expert” didn’t recognize was that while Seattle had a much weaker team, they did have one outstanding asset: the NFL’s best goal-line defense against the run. You just couldn’t expect to score on the ground against the Seahawks inside the ten-yard line. So we went to the air. Again and again and again.
这位“专家”没意识到的是，虽然西雅图海鹰队的实力远逊于我们，但他们却拥有一项无可匹敌的优势：NFL最强的防跑能力。你根本不可能在10码线内通过地面进攻击败海鹰队。所以我们只能选择空中进攻。一次又一次，没完没了。
When I read this critic’s analysis of me, it hurt. Not because he was right, but because tens of thousands of his readers would accept his misguided evidence as proof and his opinion as fact: “Bill Walsh is a most stupid coach.”
当我读到这位评论家对我的分析时，我感到很受伤。不是因为他说得对，而是因为他的成千上万的读者会把他的错误证据当作证据，把他的观点当作事实：“比尔·沃尔什是个极其愚蠢的教练。”
If you care about how you’re perceived by others, including the public, it’s good to remember the following: Criticism—both deserved and undeserved—is part of the territory when you’re the one calling the shots. Ignore the undeserved; learn from the deserved; lick your wounds and move on.
如果你在意别人（包括公众）对你的看法，那么最好记住以下几点：当你身居要职时，批评——无论是否合理——都是不可避免的。忽略不合理的批评；从合理的批评中吸取教训；舔舐伤口，继续前行。
Sometimes you can’t have the last word.
有时候，你没必要非得说最后一句话。

Thinly Sliced Baloney (Can Make a Good Sandwich) 薄切博洛尼亚香肠（可以做成美味的三明治）
There’s a certain amount of “larceny” that goes on with competition—gamesmanship both intentional and unintentional. Whether you’re pro-active or reactive, how you deal with it can affect the outcome in sports or elsewhere.
竞争中总会存在一定程度的“欺骗”——有意或无意的博弈手段。无论你是主动出击还是被动应对，你的处理方式都会影响体育或其他领域的结果。
For example, the week prior to each of our first three Super Bowl appearances, a key 49er receiver came down with an unexpected injury—a legitimate but not debilitating one. I understood the media frenzy that goes along with a world championship Super Bowl game and the desperate need of the media to supply all kinds of “news,” including gossip, conjecture, and rumor. Of course, an injury to a primary receiver in a pass-oriented offense like ours becomes very big news.
例如，在我们前三次打进超级碗的前一周，49人队的一名关键外接手都遭遇了意外伤病——虽然伤势严重但并不致命。我理解超级碗世界冠军赛带来的媒体狂潮，以及媒体迫切需要提供各种“新闻”，包括八卦、猜测和谣言。当然，对于像我们这样以传球为主的进攻体系来说，主力外接手的受伤无疑是重大新闻。
One year it was Freddie Solomon, who twisted his knee in practice. I said publicly he could miss the game because of it. Could he miss the game? Yes, it was a possibility, but an unlikely possibility.
有一年是弗雷迪·所罗门，他在训练中扭伤了膝盖。我公开表示他可能会因此缺席比赛。他会缺席吗？是的，这有可能，但可能性不大。
All I cared about was the Bengals reading the injury report about Freddie and wondering whether or not he was going to play. I was hoping it might upset their preparation slightly, make them prepare for what we might do without our star receiver, perhaps get overly confident that they had an advantage going into the game. I was using a little gamesmanship.
我当时只关心猛虎队会不会看到弗雷迪的伤情报告，琢磨他能不能上场。我希望这能稍微打乱他们的备战计划，让他们不得不考虑我们缺少明星外接手时的应对策略，或许还会让他们过于自信，以为自己在比赛中占了上风。我这是在耍点小手段。
In Super Bowl XIX the same sort of thing happened with Dwight Clark—a sprained ligament. Then in Super Bowl XXIII it was Jerry Rice, who came to me after a practice at Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami and said, “Bill, my hamstring is really tight. I hope it doesn’t get any worse.” That’s all I needed to put him on the questionable list and express my concern publicly about his being fully recovered in time for the kickoff.
在第十九届超级碗上，德怀特·克拉克也遭遇了类似的情况——韧带扭伤。到了第二十三届超级碗，杰里·赖斯在迈阿密乔·罗比体育场训练结束后找到我说：“比尔，我的腿筋很紧。希望情况不会恶化。” 仅此一点就足以让我把他列入出战成疑名单，并公开表达我对他在比赛开始前能否完全康复的担忧。
In duly reporting the status of these top receivers to the media—always with the look of a graveside preacher—I knew the story would get blown out of proportion as it worked its way through the news process: “Will San Francisco’s offense sputter if Solomon (or Dwight Clark) can’t play?” “Can the 49ers win with a hobbled Jerry Rice?” These and scores of variations would dominate the sports news for at least twenty-four hours, because this kind of story is like catnip to the media.
当我面带肃穆的神情，像个在墓前布道的牧师一样，郑重地向媒体报告这些顶级外接手的伤情时，我知道这条新闻在媒体传播的过程中肯定会被无限放大：“如果所罗门（或德怀特·克拉克）不能上场，旧金山49人队的进攻会不会受到影响？”“杰里·赖斯带伤上阵，49人队还能赢球吗？”诸如此类的问题以及无数类似的衍生问题，至少会在24小时内占据体育新闻的头条，因为这类新闻对媒体来说简直就是猫薄荷。
I was taking the “rules” right to the edge, flirting, going as far as I could legitimately go. And of course, other than those who were somewhat naive, I think all of us did it. You use the resources and remedies that are available within the boundaries of the law.
我当时完全是在挑战“规则”的边缘，到处调情，尽可能地越过法律允许的界限。当然，除了那些比较天真的人之外，我想我们所有人都这么做过。你要做的就是利用法律允许的资源和补救措施。
Seeing the story evolve from an update on a player’s condition to the center of a media storm was predictable and somewhat amusing. I also recognized that opposing players and coaches would perhaps read or hear the “news” and tend to be distracted as they evaluated any potential advantage to be gained. It takes tremendous discipline to avoid this kind of speculation.
看着这件事从球员伤情更新演变成媒体风暴的中心，既在意料之中，又有点滑稽。我也意识到，对方球员和教练或许会看到或听到这些“新闻”，在评估任何潜在的优势时，他们往往会分心。要避免这种猜测，需要极强的自律性。
As a result, I constantly warned our own players to ignore any and all media “updates” coming out of an opponent’s camp or anywhere else. If the papers reported that the entire opposing team had gotten the flu and been rushed to a local hospital in a Mayflower van, I didn’t want us to be distracted by it; I didn’t want us to speculate on anything other than the assumption that the Dolphins, Bengals, or anyone else would be 100 percent ready to go at game time. All else is usually thinly sliced baloney, which can take away from the intense concentration needed to achieve maximum results.
因此，我不断告诫队员们，不要理会任何来自对手阵营或其他任何地方的媒体“最新消息”。即便报纸报道说对方全队都得了流感，被紧急送往当地医院，我也不希望我们因此分心；我不希望我们去猜测任何事情，除了假设海豚队、猛虎队或其他任何球队都能在比赛开始时做好百分之百的准备。其他的一切通常都是些无关紧要的胡说八道，会分散我们集中精力、发挥最佳水平的注意力。
A similar kind of distraction crops up in business. A sales representative will learn that a competitor has just reduced the price on a competing product or introduced a new feature that may offer a significant benefit; an individual will hear that someone is being groomed to replace him or her or that a much desired promotion is going to someone else (exactly the same situation many players and coaches face every day of their professional lives).
类似的干扰也会出现在商业领域。销售代表会得知竞争对手刚刚降低了竞品的价格，或者推出了一项可能带来显著好处的新功能；个人会听说有人正在被培养来取代自己，或者梦寐以求的晋升机会将落到别人手中（这种情况与许多运动员和教练在职业生涯中每天都会面临的情况完全相同）。
True or false, these rumors can cause great uncertainty and create a distraction that can grow into anxiety and fear. In a worst-case scenario in sports, it can be crushing to a player and even lead to his professional demise because his self-distraction leads to plummeting performance. Even superstars—franchise players—such as Steve Young and Joe Montana heard occasional rumors and undercurrents that they were going to be traded. Both were subject to uncertainty and the embarrassment a trade would bring to them when, in fact, neither one was seriously being offered for trade during his peak years with the 49ers.
无论真假，这些谣言都会造成极大的不确定性，分散球员的注意力，进而引发焦虑和恐惧。在体育界，最糟糕的情况是，这些谣言会对球员造成毁灭性的打击，甚至导致其职业生涯的终结，因为自我干扰会导致球员表现直线下降。即使是像史蒂夫·杨和乔·蒙塔纳这样的超级巨星——球队的基石球员——也偶尔会听到关于他们将被交易的传闻。他们都曾受到这种不确定性的影响，并担心交易会给他们带来尴尬，而事实上，在他们效力于旧金山49人队的巅峰时期，球队并没有真正考虑过将他们交易出去。
The fact is that I was in a continuous dialogue with other teams about trades, or, at times, exploring trades without even being serious—throwing out the name of one player in hopes that the other side would express interest in a player I wasn’t offering. I was just throwing the bait out, hoping the other side would come back and express interest in someone else: “We don’t want this one, but we will take that guy.” This gave us information as to the level of interest the opposing partner in the trade talks had.
事实上，我一直在和其他球队就交易进行对话，有时甚至只是漫不经心地探讨交易——抛出一个球员的名字，希望对方能对我没提到的球员表现出兴趣。我只是抛出诱饵，希望对方会回应，表达对其他球员的兴趣：“我们不要这个，但我们会要那个。”这样我们就能了解交易谈判对方的兴趣程度。
In fact, I offered to trade Joe and Steve at various times knowing it would get the attention of the team I was talking to—hoping I could move them to another player off that opener. During all of this, I was careful to reassure those players whose names were offered that nothing was in the works. I suspect that my comforting words provided little comfort—football is a game that induces paranoia.
事实上，我曾多次提出用乔和史蒂夫交换，我知道这会引起我洽谈球队的注意——我希望能在揭幕战后用他们换来另一名球员。在此期间，我一直小心翼翼地向那些被提及的球员保证，没有任何交易计划。我怀疑我的安慰之词并没有起到多大作用——橄榄球这项运动本身就容易让人疑神疑鬼。
In all cases, I emphasized to the people in our organization that their response to rumors, gossip, and hearsay should be the same: Focus only on doing your best to maintain and improve your level of performance; concern yourself only with that which you can control, and you can’t control rumors. Ignore thinly sliced baloney.
在任何情况下，我都向组织中的每个人强调，他们对待谣言、闲话和传闻的态度应该相同：只专注于尽自己最大的努力保持和提高工作绩效；只关注你能控制的事情，而谣言是你无法控制的。对那些不实之言置之不理。

Surprising News Re: The Element of Surprise 关于“出其不意”元素的惊人消息
The surprise tactic has its place—very limited—in any competitive endeavor. However, I believe surprise for the sake of surprise is often a trap. There’s a mistaken mentality, a kind of thinking that leads you to a faulty conclusion: “They won’t expect us to do this .” It’s very dramatic but often reveals recklessness—“Let’s try it. No one will ever anticipate it.”
在任何竞争中，出其不意的策略都有其存在的价值——尽管这种价值非常有限。然而，我认为为了出其不意而出其不意往往是一个陷阱。这是一种错误的思维模式，一种会让你得出错误结论的思维方式：“他们不会想到我们会这么做。”这种想法虽然很戏剧化，但往往暴露出鲁莽——“我们试试吧。没人会预料到。”
The media glorified this attitude in movies such as The Great Escape : “They’ll never expect us to do it in broad daylight,” or something to that effect. That idea—“nobody will expect it”—is grossly overrated and often the manifestation of poor strategic planning. Surprise is often simply a default device, something in lieu of strong thinking. Innovation is something else.
媒体在《大逃亡》等电影中美化了这种态度：“他们绝不会想到我们会在光天化日之下行动”，或者类似的话。这种“没人会想到”的想法被严重高估了，而且往往是糟糕的战略规划的体现。出其不意通常只是一种默认的手段，用来代替深思熟虑。而创新则截然不同。
Innovation—according to the dictionary, “to advance or improve”—is an intrinsic part of achieving dominance in a given profession. In my own work, it was innovation regarding the use of the forward pass that led directly to a breakthrough in performance results. What our team did, though innovative, was usually not based on surprise tactics, although opposing teams were often surprised by the complexity of what they faced.
创新——根据字典的解释，意为“进步或改进”——是任何行业取得主导地位的内在组成部分。就我个人而言，正是对前传球战术的创新运用，直接带来了成绩的突破。我们团队的做法虽然具有创新性，但通常并非基于出其不意的战术，尽管对手常常会因我们战术的复杂性而感到措手不及。
Innovation that works is based on solid integral logic and applied performance. Calculated risks are part of what you do, but the idea that something completely crazy will work just because it’s completely crazy is completely crazy. It fails dramatically more often than it succeeds, but when it does succeed you’re tempted to do it again, and that’s when you get caught. By taking a reckless approach you think you’ll fool people. You hear commentators talking about it: “They really caught ’em with that one,” or “They never expected that.” It’s glorified, just like in the movies.
真正有效的创新建立在扎实的整体逻辑和切实有效的实践之上。权衡风险固然重要，但认为仅仅因为某个想法疯狂就能成功，这种想法本身就是疯狂的。它失败的次数远多于成功的次数，但一旦成功，你就会忍不住想再来一次，而这正是你被抓住把柄的时候。你以为采取鲁莽的做法就能蒙混过关。你经常听到评论员们这样说：“他们这次真的被抓住了把柄”，或者“他们绝对没想到会这样”。这种做法被过度美化了，就像电影里演的那样。
The principle of assuming the other person is unprepared, believing the competition will not adjust or is inflexible, or being convinced you can just outsmart the opposition with the element of surprise, is bad. In football terms, it’s comparable to running a reverse on third-and-goal, thinking, “They’ll never expect it.” That’s poor logic.
假设对方毫无准备、认为对手不会调整策略或僵化不变，或者坚信自己可以凭借出其不意战胜对手，这种想法是错误的。用足球术语来说，这就好比在三档进攻时选择反向跑动，心想“他们绝对想不到”。这种逻辑很差劲。
If it works, that might be the worst thing that can happen, because you’ll be tempted to make other equally ill-advised and risky decisions. High-risk decisions are very necessary at times but should not be an ongoing course of action. Finding yourself in a position where you believe your only option is to pull off a big surprise often means you haven’t prepared, haven’t done your homework. The “big surprise” option eases the internal pressure to come up with solid planning and preparation that can force your opponent to resort to high-risk options.
如果这招奏效，那或许是最糟糕的结果，因为你会忍不住做出其他同样不明智且冒险的决定。高风险决策有时固然必要，但不应成为常态。当你发现自己唯一的选择就是出其不意地发动突袭时，往往意味着你准备不足，没有做好充分的准备工作。“出其不意”的策略会减轻你制定周密计划和准备的内在压力，从而迫使对手也采取高风险的策略。
I preferred the position of being able to take lower-risk actions with higher reward potential. That sounds like a situation that rarely exists—low risk, high reward—but it’s exactly what my pass-oriented, ball-control system offered on the majority of our plays. In order to make it work, I applied great energy and expertise to a methodical process of anticipating, planning, and practicing for every conceivable situation.
我更喜欢那种风险低、回报高的策略。低风险高回报听起来似乎很少见，但这正是我那套以传球为主、控球至上的体系在大多数战术中所能提供的。为了实现这一点，我投入了大量精力和专业知识，系统地预测、计划并演练每一种可能出现的情况。
This sounds rather easy, but we both know that “walking the walk” is harder than “talking the talk.” Just “talking about it” will too often put you in the position where your only option is the element of surprise.
这听起来很容易，但我们都知道“言行一致”比“空谈”难得多。光说不练往往会让你陷入只能依靠出其不意的境地。

Don’t Delay Delegating (Famous Last Words: “I’ll Do It Myself”) 不要拖延授权（临终遗言：“我自己来做”）
My stated philosophy as head coach was that the person in our organization best suited for a specific job should be the person heading it up or doing it. The best play caller should be calling plays, the best offensive coordinator should be coordinating the offense, and so on. That was my theory, but not my practice.
我作为主教练时提出的理念是，我们团队中最适合特定工作的人就应该负责这项工作或亲自执行。最好的战术指挥应该负责战术指挥，最好的进攻协调员应该负责进攻协调，以此类推。这是我的理论，但我的实践并非如此。
Somehow in my mind I believed that I was the best qualified to do almost every job, especially when it came to the offensive part of our game. In one sense, it stemmed from confidence; I was absolutely sure that if I did the job it would not get screwed up. Well, that can only take you so far. Pretty soon you’re on overload while very talented people in the organization are being underutilized.
不知怎的，我一直觉得自己最适合胜任几乎所有工作，尤其是在进攻方面。某种程度上，这源于我的自信；我坚信只要我来做，就绝对不会出错。然而，这种自信终究有限。很快，你就会发现自己工作量过大，而队里其他才华横溢的人却被埋没了。
For example, Mike Holmgren, a superb assistant coach who eventually won a Super Bowl while head coach of the Green Bay Packers, was on my staff and could have taken on much more responsibility than I gave him. (The year immediately following my retirement, the 49ers won Super Bowl XXIV against the Denver Broncos 55-10, an all-time scoring record. Mike was calling the plays.)
例如，迈克·霍尔姆格伦，一位杰出的助理教练，后来成为绿湾包装工队的主教练并带领球队赢得超级碗，他曾是我的团队成员，完全可以承担比我赋予他的更多责任。（在我退休后的第二年，旧金山49人队以55比10战胜丹佛野马队，赢得了第24届超级碗，创造了历史最高得分纪录。当时迈克负责战术指挥。）
There were others, too, on my staff who were able and willing to take on more responsibilities. They were willing; I was reluctant, even unwilling—unable is perhaps more accurate. Of the various failures I cite myself for, one of the most problematic may have been my inability to delegate to the extent I could, and should, have. Increasingly, I continued to take on massive responsibilities. I appeared to be in full control—and I think I was—but the exhaustion I experienced, the track I was on, offered no escape. I couldn’t take a real vacation because there was always more and more to do, and I felt, rightly or wrongly, that Bill Walsh was the one best able to handle too many of the various responsibilities. Well, that kind of thinking can only take you so far. Eventually, you’re working seven days a week, sixteen hours a day with little good sleep, eating poorly, and dealing with all kinds of forces. You burn your energy like an acetylene torch until your nerves are completely stretched and then virtually destroyed. It took me years to figure this out, to learn it, to understand it. By then I was no longer head coach of the San Francisco 49ers.
我的团队里还有其他人有能力也愿意承担更多责任。他们愿意，而我却犹豫不决，甚至可以说是不情愿——或许用“不能”来形容更为贴切。在我反思的诸多失误中，最棘手的问题之一或许就是我无法像我应该做的那样，有效地授权。我不断地承担着繁重的责任。表面上看，我似乎一切尽在掌握——而且我也确实这么认为——但我所经历的精疲力竭，以及我所处的困境，让我无处可逃。我无法真正休假，因为总有做不完的事情，而且我感觉，不管对错，比尔·沃尔什才是最能胜任这些繁杂工作的人。然而，这种想法终究是行不通的。最终，你会发现自己每周工作七天，每天工作十六个小时，睡眠严重不足，饮食不规律，还要应对各种各样的压力。你的精力就像乙炔焊枪一样被燃烧殆尽，直到神经完全绷紧，最终崩溃。我花了数年时间才弄明白、学习和理解这一点。那时我已经不再是旧金山49人队的主教练了。
You may suspect you need to be delegating more, but you can’t bring yourself to do it; you can’t summon in yourself a trust in others whose talent you respected enough to hire them. I should have had more of a plan or commitment to move other people into different roles and to let them emerge, to loosen my grip on control, but I couldn’t, and the exhaustion I experienced, the track I was on, was partially the direct result of not being able to delegate more intelligently.
你或许意识到自己需要更多地授权，但却无法做到；你无法信任那些你曾足够尊重其才能并聘用他们的人。我本应制定更完善的计划或做出更多承诺，让其他人担任不同的角色，让他们有机会展现自己的能力，从而放松我的控制欲，但我却做不到。我所经历的疲惫，以及我当时所处的困境，部分原因正是由于我无法更明智地授权。
There was always something to do, and I was the one most capable of doing it—or so I thought.
总是有事情要做，而我是最有能力去做这些事的人——至少我是这么认为的。

Cut Your Losses Before They Cut You 趁他们还没把你甩掉，赶紧止损。
Thomas Henderson was not only one of the best linebackers in NFL history, but a very intelligent man—one of the great athletes to play the game. He was also one of the most flamboyant during his years with the Dallas Cowboys. His nickname was appropriate: “Hollywood.”
托马斯·亨德森不仅是NFL历史上最优秀的线卫之一，而且是一位非常聪明的人——也是这项运动中最伟大的运动员之一。在效力达拉斯牛仔队期间，他也是最具个性魅力的球员之一。他的绰号“好莱坞”非常贴切。
Unfortunately, by the time he joined the 49ers during my first year as head coach, a more apt moniker would have been “Cocaine” Henderson, because he was a serious addict whose life was coming apart.
不幸的是，当他在我担任主教练的第一年加入 49 人队时，更贴切的绰号应该是“可卡因”亨德森，因为他是一个严重的瘾君子，生活一团糟。
In fact, when my wife, Geri, and I had Thomas and his wife, Wyetta, over for dinner at our home in Menlo Park, California, shortly before he officially joined San Francisco, he excused himself briefly while the apple pie and ice cream were being served. Later, I discovered he had gone into our bathroom to snort cocaine.
事实上，就在托马斯正式加入旧金山队前不久，我和妻子格里邀请他和妻子怀塔来我们位于加州门洛帕克的家中吃晚饭。当时我们正在上苹果派和冰淇淋，他却突然找了个借口离开了一会儿。后来我发现，他竟然去了我们的浴室吸食可卡因。
I was aware that Thomas had become somewhat difficult during his final years with Tom Landry’s Cowboys—violating curfews, breaking dress code rules, increasingly contentious and criticizing the coaching staff, even mugging on the sidelines for the television cameras—but I thought that with my supposed ability to work with problem players, I could get him back on track. Plus, in that first year as head coach, I was desperate for talent—especially on our defensive team.
我知道托马斯在汤姆·兰德里执教达拉斯牛仔队的最后几年里变得有些难搞——违反宵禁、违反着装规定、越来越爱争辩，还批评教练组，甚至在场边对着电视镜头做鬼脸——但我认为凭借我所谓的处理问题球员的能力，我可以让他重回正轨。此外，在我担任主教练的第一年，我急需人才——尤其是在防守组。
However, it soon became evident that my abilities were no match for the destructive power of Henderson’s addiction. (In fact, in those days most coaches were ignorant when it came to hard drug use among players. The most common drug being abused was alcohol. When a player had a problem with it, the symptoms were evident the next day—a big hangover. The cure was simple: Work him hard and make him suffer. Throwing up over on the sidelines in ninety-degree heat usually solved the problem for a while. Cocaine was much more insidious.)
然而，很快我就发现，我的能力根本无法与亨德森的毒瘾相抗衡。（事实上，在那个年代，大多数教练对球员吸食毒品一无所知。当时最常见的滥用药物是酒精。一旦球员酗酒，第二天症状就会很明显——宿醉难受。解决方法很简单：让他拼命训练，让他受苦。在90华氏度（约32摄氏度）的高温下，让他跑到场边呕吐通常能暂时解决问题。可卡因则要阴险得多。）
When it soon became apparent that things weren’t going to work out between “Hollywood” and the 49ers, he began talking about injuries—most of all a neck problem that kept him out of practice. Keep in mind that neck injuries are often difficult to diagnose and consequently easy to feign.
当“好莱坞”和49人队之间的合作显然无法继续下去时，他开始谈论伤病——尤其是让他无法参加训练的颈部问题。需要注意的是，颈部伤病通常难以诊断，因此也很容易伪装。
In truth, and in light of “Hollywood’s” recent behavior, we had no idea whether or not he was injured or faking it. Thus, it appeared the 49ers might not only be unable to trade him, but have to pay for an “injury” that was imaginary or had happened when he was with Dallas.
事实上，鉴于“好莱坞”近期的行为，我们根本不知道他究竟是受伤了还是装病。因此，49人队不仅可能无法交易他，还可能要为一场他捏造的“伤病”或他效力达拉斯牛仔队时发生的“伤病”买单。
It all came to a boiling point during practice one afternoon, with “Hollywood” stretched out and moaning on our locker room floor—spread-eagled while players gingerly stepped over him to get out to the practice field. It was completely disordered and a serious distraction. I realized we needed to remove him from the environment—that is, get him off the roster—quickly, while at the same time avoiding a lawsuit related to his neck issues.
一天下午的训练中，事情终于爆发了。“好莱坞”四肢大张地躺在更衣室的地板上呻吟，球员们小心翼翼地跨过他，走向训练场。场面一片混乱，严重影响了训练。我意识到我们必须尽快把他从球队名单中移除——也就是说，把他除名——同时还要避免因他的颈椎问题而引发诉讼。
I used his ego to solve the problem. “Hollywood,” I said, leaning over him, “this next game of ours is televised nationally. The whole country is going to be watching, and you’re one of the guys the cameras are going to be zooming in on. We absolutely need you out on the field to run through some plays today. Otherwise, you won’t be ready to go into the game and your family and friends are going to be very disappointed when they don’t see you on network television.”
我利用他的自尊心解决了这个问题。“好莱坞，”我俯身靠近他说道，“我们下一场比赛是全国直播的。全国人民都会看，而你就是镜头会聚焦的人物之一。我们今天绝对需要你到场上演练几套战术。否则，你就无法上场比赛，你的家人和朋友在电视上看不到你，他们会非常失望的。”
“Hollywood” loved attention. With the prospect of national television exposure in the balance, he “struggled” to his feet and ran out to the practice field.
“好莱坞”喜欢引人注目。眼看就要获得全国电视曝光，他“挣扎”着站起身，跑向训练场。
Meanwhile, my assistants were ready. Three cameras had been set up in the stands to tape “Hollywood” slamming into people with great zest and without the slightest discomfort. We had our evidence and released him immediately. I don’t know if “Hollywood” ever found out that our upcoming game was not scheduled for network television.
与此同时，我的助手们早已准备就绪。看台上架设了三台摄像机，用来拍摄“好莱坞”兴致勃勃、毫发无损地撞向人群的画面。我们掌握了证据，立即释放了他。我不知道“好莱坞”是否知道我们接下来的比赛并没有安排在电视上播出。
The lesson is simple: When you make a mistake, admit it and fix it. Don’t let pride, stubbornness, or possible embarrassment about your bad decision prevent you from correcting what you have done. Fix it, or the little problem becomes a big one.
道理很简单：犯了错，就要承认并改正。不要让骄傲、固执，或者对错误决定的尴尬阻碍你纠正错误。改正吧，否则小问题会变成大问题。
The ending to this story about Thomas Henderson is positive, although it took a while. Soon after his release from San Francisco, he was out of football and in trouble, including serving time in jail. Eventually, however, he overcame his addiction to drugs and alcohol and got his life back on track. That’s the biggest game Thomas Henderson ever won. I’m only sorry he couldn’t have achieved that victory while a member of the San Francisco 49ers.
托马斯·亨德森的故事结局是积极的，尽管过程有些曲折。离开旧金山49人队后不久，他就离开了橄榄球界，并且惹上了麻烦，甚至锒铛入狱。然而，最终他克服了毒瘾和酒瘾，重回正轨。这是托马斯·亨德森职业生涯中最重要的一场胜利。我唯一感到遗憾的是，他没能在效力旧金山49人队期间赢得这场胜利。

Look Below the Surface: There’s More Than Meets the Eye 透过表象看本质：远不止表面所见
You must be willing to account for a person’s emotions and state of mind when you judge his or her actions. Frequently we misinterpret behavior because we don’t allow for explanations other than what is most obvious; we don’t look below the surface. Here’s an example from my own experience.
在评判一个人的行为时，你必须考虑到他或她的情绪和心理状态。我们常常误解他人的行为，是因为我们只看到表面现象，而忽略了更深层次的原因。以下是我亲身经历的一个例子。
During my last season as head coach, I began suffering from emotional and mental exhaustion brought on by the demands and pressures of my job that had been building up in my mind for several years. The inner toll this took is indescribable. It became almost torturous and manifested itself during the last months in my becoming increasingly sentimental about things and, at times, maudlin. All of it was, of course, related to exhaustion.
在我担任主教练的最后一个赛季，我开始出现情绪和精神上的双重疲惫，这是由于多年来工作中的各种要求和压力在我心中不断累积造成的。这种内心的煎熬难以言表，几乎到了折磨人的程度。在最后几个月里，这种疲惫表现为我变得越来越感性，有时甚至有些伤感。当然，这一切都与疲惫有关。
I would frequently be on the edge of breaking down in tears and started to protect myself to keep it from happening. Consequently, and without telling anyone, I decided I had to retire at the end of the season.
我经常濒临崩溃，眼泪夺眶而出，于是开始保护自己，避免这种情况发生。因此，我没跟任何人说，就决定在赛季结束后退役。
A week before we played in Super Bowl XXIII, I did a television interview in which the topic eventually turned to my feelings about the team. Well, this really got to me because of my fragile emotional state. The woman interviewing me had no ulterior motive; she was simply interested in knowing if I felt any different about these players compared with earlier 49er teams and had no idea her question would evoke overwhelming emotion in me.
在第23届超级碗比赛前一周，我接受了一次电视采访，话题最终转到了我对球队的感受上。当时我的情绪很脆弱，这个问题真的触动了我。采访我的女士并无其他目的，她只是想知道我对这支球队的球员和以往的49人队相比，感觉是否有所不同，她完全没想到她的问题会让我如此情绪激动。
I could feel myself starting to come apart as I considered her question and realized if I said even one word I was going to break down and start crying in front of a camera. Since I had no interest in sobbing on television, I abruptly stood up and walked off the set. The studio personnel were stunned, and the story subsequently went out that Bill Walsh, in becoming a successful coach, had also become arrogant and uncivil, a person who would truncate a conversation by standing and storming out of the room. This, of course, was incorrect.
想到她的问题，我感觉自己快要崩溃了。我意识到，如果我说一个字，就会在镜头前嚎啕大哭。我不想在电视上哭，于是猛地站起来，离开了拍摄现场。演播室的工作人员都惊呆了，随后有传言说，比尔·沃尔什在成为一名成功的教练后，也变得傲慢无礼，动不动就站起来怒气冲冲地离开房间，打断谈话。这当然是无稽之谈。
It’s important to understand a person’s response in the context of his or her state of mind, where he or she might be emotionally; this often connects directly to his or her answers and actions. This reporter decided I was an arrogant, strutting personality who would simply walk out when I had had enough. In reality, she missed the point. Something big was going on, and she didn’t get it, didn’t go beneath the surface of what she saw.
理解一个人的反应，要结合他/她的心理状态和情绪状态；这往往直接影响着他/她的回答和行为。这位记者认定我是一个傲慢自大、趾高气扬的人，觉得我一旦受够了就会径直走开。但实际上，她完全没理解我的意思。事情远比表面看起来复杂得多，而她却一无所知，没有深入探究。
She didn’t even consider any other explanation. She missed the larger story in settling for the obvious answer.
她甚至没有考虑过其他解释。她满足于显而易见的答案，而忽略了更深层次的问题。

A Pretty Package Can’t Sell a Poor Product 精美的包装卖不出去劣质产品。
Even before I joined the 49ers, it was apparent that their public image was deeply damaged, almost as bad as their won-lost record. In a sense, I had a front-row seat, because I was coaching at Stanford University, which is right in the middle of the San Francisco 49ers’ fan base.
甚至在我加入旧金山49人队之前，他们的公众形象就已经明显受损，几乎和他们的胜负记录一样糟糕。从某种意义上说，我亲眼目睹了这一切，因为我当时在斯坦福大学执教，而斯坦福大学正好位于旧金山49人队球迷的大本营之中。
Subsequently, when I came aboard as head coach and general manager of the 49ers, I was concerned not only with the specifics of what happened on the field, but also with crucial off-field matters such as selling tickets, in particular season tickets. Our season ticket sales were awful, the worst in the league—7,012 in a stadium that held over 60,000 people. I immediately set to work beefing up those sales so that our 2-14 team would have bigger crowds to play in front of and the owner would have larger gate receipts.
后来，当我接任旧金山49人队的主教练兼总经理时，我不仅关注场上的具体情况，也关注一些至关重要的场外事务，例如售票，尤其是季票销售。我们的季票销售情况惨不忍睹，是联盟垫底——在一个能容纳超过6万人的体育场里，只卖出了7012张。我立即着手提升季票销售，这样我们这支2胜14负的球队就能在更多球迷面前比赛，老板也能获得更多的门票收入。
In an attempt to do this, I tried to reach out to the community, to repair the damaged image the public had of us. I made sure the players and staff lent their support and presence to good causes, were available for interviews, and responded to correspondence.
为了做到这一点，我努力与社区沟通，试图修复公众对我们受损的形象。我确保球员和工作人员积极参与公益活动，接受采访，并回复邮件。
To promote sales of season tickets, I came up with an ambitious (and time-consuming) plan called “Pick-a-Seat Day” in which we put bright red ribbons on all available season ticket seats and invited the public to buy their favorites. And that’s not all.
为了促进季票销售，我制定了一项雄心勃勃（且耗时）的计划，名为“选座日”。在这一天，我们给所有可用的季票座位系上鲜红的丝带，邀请公众购买他们心仪的座位。但这还不是全部。
On the big promotion day we offered balloons, free donkey rides, ethnic foods, and clowns for the kiddies. Also, free popcorn, soft drinks and hot dogs, jugglers, a Dixieland band, and magicians. It was really a great family event for the thousands of folks who came out to Candlestick Park.
在大型推广日当天，我们为孩子们准备了气球、免费骑驴、特色美食和滑稽小丑表演。此外，还有免费爆米花、软饮料和热狗，以及杂耍表演、迪克西兰爵士乐队和魔术师的演出。对于成千上万前来烛台公园的游客来说，这真是一场精彩纷呈的家庭盛会。
The next morning I arrived at the office early to see what the results of my “Pick-a-Seat Day” promotion were. Or, more accurately, weren’t. Total season tickets sold: seven. (I bought three more myself on the fifty-yard line, just so I could report that we’d hit double digits. In fact, our family still has those seats.)
第二天早上我早早来到办公室，想看看我的“选座日”促销活动效果如何。或者更准确地说，是毫无效果。季票总共只卖出了七张。（我自己又在球场中线附近买了三张，就为了能汇报说我们卖出了两位数的季票。事实上，我们家现在还保留着那三张座位。）
“Pick-a-Seat Day” was a total flop, but it was a flop that taught me something very important: A pretty package can’t sell a poor product. Results—in my profession, winning football games—are the ultimate promotional tool. I was trying to sell a bad product, a team that was the worst franchise in sports, that had lost twenty-seven straight road games, and whose record at home wasn’t much better.
“选座日”彻底失败了，但这次失败让我明白了一个非常重要的道理：再精美的包装也卖不出去劣质产品。成绩——在我的职业领域，就是赢得足球比赛——才是最终的宣传利器。我当时试图推销的是一个糟糕的产品，一支体育界最差的球队，他们已经连续27场客场比赛失利，主场战绩也好不到哪里去。
From that point on, I focused my energies exclusively on creating a quality product, a team that was worth spending money to see. When that was achieved, we also achieved a ten-year waiting list to buy a 49ers’ season ticket.
从那时起，我便全身心投入到打造高质量的产品，打造一支值得球迷花钱观看的球队。当这一目标实现后，我们也迎来了49人队赛季套票长达十年的候补名单。
In your efforts to create interest in your own product, don’t get carried away with premature promotion—creating a pretty package with hype, spin, and all the rest. First, make sure you’ve got something of quality to promote. Then worry about how you’re going to wrap it in an attractive package. The world’s best promotional tool is a good product.
为了提升产品知名度，切勿过早进行过度宣传——不要用花哨的包装、夸张的宣传等手段来包装产品。首先，确保你的产品本身具备足够的质量。然后再考虑如何用吸引人的包装来呈现它。世界上最好的宣传工具就是好的产品。

Zero Points for Winning (Means You’re Losing) 赢了得零分（意味着你输了）
Part of the makeup of many people with a very strong competitive instinct, whether in sports or business—especially those who are more intelligent—is that they know just how much losing hurts and don’t like that feeling; they just can’t accept it.
许多人，无论是在体育界还是商界，都具有非常强烈的竞争本能——尤其是那些比较聪明的人——他们的一部分性格特点是，他们深知失败的痛苦，并且不喜欢这种感觉；他们就是无法接受失败。
Losing is so devastating to them that it’s just thorough ; there isn’t anything that can stop the pain except winning. For those people, I think probably in the majority at the top end of the competitive scale, it’s almost impossible to accept defeat and the feelings of desolation that go with it. Consequently, we’ll do almost anything to avoid it.
对他们来说，失败的打击是如此巨大，以至于痛苦彻底爆发；除了胜利，没有任何东西能够止住这种痛苦。我认为，对于这些人来说——尤其是在竞争最激烈的群体中——几乎不可能接受失败以及随之而来的绝望感。因此，我们会不惜一切代价去避免失败。
That anxiety about failure, that disgust with failure, that fear of failure is really a distinct part of competition and must be absolutely under your control. Unfortunately, this is often very hard to do—at least it was for me and took four or five years off of my coaching career at San Francisco.
对失败的焦虑、厌恶和恐惧，的确是竞争中不可或缺的一部分，必须完全掌控。不幸的是，这往往很难做到——至少对我来说是这样，它让我在旧金山的执教生涯中断了四五年。
Losing, however you define it, even the thought of losing, can become so psychologically crippling that winning offers little solace and no cause for celebration because you’ve imposed an internal accounting system on yourself that awards zero points for winning and minus points for losing. You can never get ahead on points. That’s exactly what happened to me.
无论你如何定义失败，甚至仅仅是想到失败，都可能造成严重的心理创伤，以至于胜利无法带来丝毫安慰，也无法庆祝，因为你已经给自己设定了一套内部的计分系统：赢了得零分，输了得负分。你永远无法在积分上取得进步。我就是这样过来的。
I see the symptom all the time in business. Study the faces of some executives or salespeople when they achieve a big “win.” The best description of their demeanor is “grim-faced,” and grim-faced they trudge cheerlessly on to fight without comment. They have allotted themselves zero points for victory.
我在商界经常看到这种现象。仔细观察一些高管或销售人员取得重大“胜利”时的表情。他们神情最贴切的形容就是“板着脸”，然后板着脸，毫无兴致地继续战斗，一句话也不说。他们给自己的胜利打了零分。
This can occur as your expectations and the expectations of others get higher and higher—they keep raising the bar on you, and you keep raising it on yourself.
当你的期望和他人的期望越来越高时，这种情况就会发生——他们不断提高对你的要求，而你也不断提高对自己的要求。
In my early years as an assistant coach, and then later in the beginning with the 49ers, simply teaching our personnel how to execute and perform at higher levels provided satisfaction and gratification. Seeing areas of our game reflect that improvement—increased yards per carry, fewer turnovers, higher pass completion percentages, and fewer penalties—allowed me to take pride in various elements of a loss. We hadn’t yet reached the point of being expected to win every game, every Super Bowl.
在我担任助理教练的早期，以及后来在49人队执教初期，仅仅是教导队员们如何执行战术并提升比赛水平，就能让我感到满足和欣慰。看到比赛中的某些方面有所改进——每次持球推进码数增加、失误减少、传球成功率提高、犯规减少——即使输球，我也能从中找到值得骄傲的地方。那时，我们还没有达到那种被期待每场比赛、每场超级碗都赢的地步。
Later, good play and execution were still able to produce satisfaction, but only if accompanied by a win. Eventually, good play and execution, even when accompanied by victory, produced virtually no ongoing satisfaction or pleasure, just momentary relief. I got zero points for winning.
后来，即使发挥出色、执行到位，仍然能带来满足感，但前提是必须赢得比赛。最终，即便赢得了比赛，出色的发挥和执行也几乎无法带来任何持续的满足感或愉悦感，只有短暂的解脱。我赢了，却一分也没拿到。
Victory meant little more than delaying the pain of loss, as I quickly turned to the next game and the next one and the next one, each offering no more than the opportunity to postpone the awful feelings that accompany defeat while doing nothing to remove the fear of it.
胜利的意义仅仅在于延缓失败的痛苦，因为我很快就投入到下一场比赛、再下一场比赛、再下一场比赛中，每一场比赛都只是让我有机会推迟失败带来的糟糕感觉，而并没有消除对失败的恐惧。
When this happens, any kind of loss, mistake, or setback becomes very disturbing, even devastating, because you’ve attached your self-image to the results of the competition. Winning can become insidious for the same reason, that is, you allow the victory to begin determining your self-worth, how you feel about yourself.
当这种情况发生时，任何损失、错误或挫折都会变得非常令人不安，甚至具有毁灭性，因为你已经将自我形象与比赛结果挂钩。同样，胜利也会变得具有隐蔽性，也就是说，你允许胜利开始决定你的自我价值，决定你如何看待自己。
Either way, you are putting yourself on a slippery slope when you start believing that the outcome of your effort represents or embodies who you really are as a person—what your value as a person is. I speak from personal experience.
无论如何，当你开始相信自己努力的成果代表或体现了你作为一个人真正的价值时，你就走上了一条危险的道路。这是我的亲身经历。
For me, the San Francisco 49ers increasingly became who “Bill Walsh” was on the inside. Any mistake or loss became me . Any setback—big or small—reflected back on me, and I personalized it. If Jerry Rice dropped a pass, I dropped it; if a play didn’t work, it was my fault, instead of the fault of the assistant coach who called it or the opposing defensive player who made an outstanding stop; if Steve Young or Joe Montana threw an interception, it was my poor pass. This is a dangerous way to run your professional life because it seeps into and contaminates your private life. Eventually, it led me to make some horrible choices in my personal behavior that I deeply regret and am embarrassed by—even ashamed of.
对我而言，旧金山49人队逐渐变成了“比尔·沃尔什”的化身。任何失误或失利都成了我的责任。任何挫折——无论大小——都会影响到我，而我却将其归咎于自己。如果杰里·赖斯接球脱手，那就是我的错；如果战术失败，那就是我的错，而不是负责布置战术的助理教练或做出精彩防守的对方防守球员的错；如果史蒂夫·杨或乔·蒙塔纳被拦截，那就是我的传球失误。这种对待职业生涯的方式非常危险，因为它会渗透并污染你的私人生活。最终，它导致我在个人行为上做出了一些糟糕的选择，我对此深感后悔和羞愧——甚至感到耻辱。
Ultimately, because failure had been personalized to such a degree, I was tormented by the very thought of errors of execution, mistakes, or loss. Winning, winning, winning—perfection—was the only solution. Except it was no solution—even winning a Super Bowl couldn’t remove the knowledge that failure was in the future, because nobody wins all the time.
最终，因为失败被过度个人化，我甚至一想到执行上的失误、错误或失败就备受煎熬。胜利、胜利、再胜利——完美——成了唯一的出路。然而，这根本行不通——即便赢得超级碗也无法抹去失败终将到来的认知，因为没有人能永远获胜。
In part, I brought the situation on myself, because our team was so bad in the beginning that all of us, including the owner, Eddie DeBartolo Jr., were grateful for the slightest signs of improvement. Eddie did not come from a football background, so he left me totally alone, free to fail or succeed without interference. This changed when I achieved results.
部分原因是我自己造成的，因为我们球队一开始实在太糟糕了，以至于包括老板小埃迪·德巴托罗在内的所有人都对哪怕一丝进步都感激不尽。埃迪并非足球出身，所以他完全放任我，让我自由地去尝试，无论成功还是失败。但当我取得成绩后，情况就发生了变化。
When San Francisco won a Super Bowl championship, the owner’s involvement began to show itself in various ways, including a willingness to pay top money for talent. Eddie Jr. opened his pocketbook, and the 49ers went from the bottom of the spending charts to among those at the top.
旧金山49人队赢得超级碗冠军后，老板的影响力开始以各种方式展现出来，包括愿意为优秀球员支付高薪。小埃迪·斯皮尔斯慷慨解囊，49人队的支出也从联盟垫底跃升至联盟前列。
Salaries were high, and the players (and their families) were given first-class treatment in travel and accommodations, including being flown to luxurious resorts for our Super Bowl ring ceremonies. When we needed him to write a check to acquire top talent from another team, Eddie didn’t bat an eye. He was the best in the NFL in that regard and was known to occasionally hand an envelope stuffed with cash to a player who had done well during a game.
薪水很高，球员（及其家人）在旅行和住宿方面都享受着一流的待遇，包括被安排飞往豪华度假村参加我们的超级碗戒指颁奖仪式。当我们想从其他球队引进顶尖人才时，埃迪毫不犹豫地就开出了支票。在这方面，他是NFL中最优秀的，而且众所周知，他偶尔会给比赛中表现出色的球员一个装满现金的信封。
That part of it was great. Unfortunately, it was accompanied by something else that became destructive. Increasingly, Eddie kept raising the bar. Soon enough, if his team didn’t win that year’s Super Bowl, he was distraught, enraged. Just getting to the play-offs each year was insufficient; in fact, it drove him crazy—it was unacceptable to him, perhaps because his pride was involved.
那一部分确实很棒。可惜的是，随之而来的却是另一件极具破坏性的事。埃迪不断提高标准。很快，如果他的球队当年没能赢得超级碗，他就会心烦意乱，怒不可遏。每年仅仅打进季后赛对他来说远远不够；事实上，这让他抓狂——对他来说，这是无法接受的，或许是因为牵涉到他的自尊心。
When we lost, he felt helpless, since I was the coach, the one in charge who was running the show, not him. At the same time he was loosening the purse strings, he was beginning his heavy-handed approach to micro-management, occasionally offering ideas to me, which was certainly his right. But then he began questioning my decisions, occasionally belittling them, wondering out loud to anyone who cared to listen whether there wasn’t a better way than what I did—whether he, perhaps, knew more about it than I did.
当我们输球时，他感到很无助，因为我是教练，是负责人，是他掌控一切。与此同时，他开始削减预算，并逐渐采取他那专横跋扈的微观管理方式，偶尔会给我提些建议，这当然是他的权利。但后来，他开始质疑我的决定，有时甚至贬低它们，逢人便问，是不是有比我更好的办法——或许，他比我更懂行。
This was embarrassing because, among other reasons, when it came to technical football, Eddie knew about as much as the average fan, which is to say, not too much. It reached a point, after one loss in a season during which we struggled, that he called me into my office for a ranting critique of the game and my coaching of it.
