The team knew what was going on because they could see and hear it; it was embarrassing—more than that, humiliating.
这很尴尬，原因之一是，埃迪对足球技术方面的了解和普通球迷差不多，也就是说，他懂得不多。在一个赛季我们表现挣扎，输掉一场比赛后，他把我叫到办公室，对我执教的比赛和表现进行了一番激烈的批评。队员们都明白发生了什么，因为他们亲眼所见，亲耳所闻；这很尴尬——不，应该说是耻辱。
Eddie’s background in football, his knowledge of football, was limited, but he felt peer pressure from his friends when we lost, and he occasionally reacted in an uncontrolled manner, usually after overindulging.
埃迪的足球背景和足球知识有限，但当我们输球时，他感到来自朋友的同辈压力，他偶尔会做出不受控制的反应，通常是在过度放纵之后。
When people are frustrated, they look outside themselves for someone to blame; it was someone else causing his problem, others are making bad decisions, not him. “I’m being criticized unfairly,” Eddie may have thought. It’s human nature when your deep emotions are involved in something that you lash out at anything or try to reach in and fix it even if you don’t know what’s going on.
人们感到沮丧时，往往会向外寻找替罪羊；是别人造成了他的问题，是别人做了错误的决定，而不是他自己。“我受到了不公平的批评，”埃迪或许会这样想。当内心深处的情绪被卷入某件事时，人们往往会迁怒于任何事物，或者试图介入并解决问题，即使他们并不了解事情的真相，这也是人之常情。
Looking back, it was something I should not have allowed. I let him haul me over the coals in regard to my effort or performance when he had no basis for doing it. His only basis was that he owned the team, a pretty good basis, but not enough for me to let him excoriate me without significant cause in front of the team even once.
现在回想起来，我真不该允许他那样做。他毫无理由地对我大加指责，批评我的努力和表现，我却任由他这么做。他唯一的理由就是他是球队老板，这当然是个不错的理由，但不足以让我允许他在全队面前无缘无故地训斥我，哪怕一次也不行。
I regret that I didn’t back him down. Or leave. Ironically, it was part of the reason I left, for good. By then I had lost my taste for the job. I’m not sure I ever got it back, and in some way Eddie was part of the reason. I let him set a preposterous standard and then humiliate me when I couldn’t reach it.
我后悔当初没让他退让，也没离开。讽刺的是，这反而成了我最终彻底离开的原因之一。那时我已经对这份工作失去了兴趣。我不确定自己是否还找回了这份兴趣，而埃迪在某种程度上也是原因之一。我让他设定了一个荒谬的标准，然后在我达不到的时候羞辱我。
Looking back on it, I concluded that there are times when you must stand up for yourself even if the consequences include being fired. That’s easier said than done, as evidenced by the fact that I didn’t do it.
回想起来，我得出的结论是，有些时候你必须维护自己的权益，即使这意味着被解雇。说起来容易做起来难，我最终没能做到就证明了这一点。
For Eddie—and I admit, for me too—eventually only a Super Bowl championship was acceptable; anything less was failure and cause for disgust and dismissal. (George Seifert, my immediate and able successor as 49er head coach, won two Super Bowls in eight years and was fired two seasons after the second championship in spite of having the highest winning percentage of any coach in NFL history: .766 with a 98-30-1 record. Eddie wanted a Super Bowl. Every year.)
对埃迪来说——我承认，对我来说也是如此——最终只有超级碗冠军才能让他满意；任何低于这个目标的成绩都被视为失败，都会让他感到厌恶并最终被解雇。（我的直接继任者，49人队主教练乔治·塞弗特，他能力出众，在八年内赢得了两次超级碗冠军，但在第二次夺冠两个赛季后就被解雇了，尽管他的胜率是NFL历史上最高的：76.6%，战绩为98胜30负1平。埃迪想要的是超级碗冠军。年年如此。）
All of the above, in a nutshell, contributed to why I had to retire. The pursuit of the prize had become an exercise in avoiding pain; the expectations had become unattainable; the behavior of our owner had become—on occasion—unacceptable; and the responsibilities I took on, coupled with the pressure I put on myself, were unmanageable. Or so it seemed.
以上种种，总而言之，导致了我不得不退役。追求奖项变成了逃避痛苦；期望值变得遥不可及；老板的行为有时令人无法接受；我承担的责任，加上我给自己施加的压力，让我不堪重负。至少当时看来是这样。
A profession I loved and had worked for all my life had gone from being joyful to unenjoyable to unendurable. I couldn’t win when I won; there were no points in winning and thus no point in continuing.
我热爱并为之奋斗终生的职业，从最初的快乐变成了痛苦，最终变得难以忍受。即使赢了，我也得不到任何满足感；赢了毫无意义，因此继续下去也毫无意义。
Later, when I became a commentator for NBC after I got out of NFL coaching, I would see similar pain when I’d interview some coaches at the beginning of the regular season. They were hanging on for dear life after a bad year and had just been through eight weeks of training camp working eighteen-hour days with no sleep, bad food, and all kinds of forces pounding them, including decisions on which players stay, which players go, and how to deal with the press, injuries, holdouts, agents, owners, media, and everything else.
后来，我离开NFL教练岗位，成为NBC的评论员后，在常规赛开始前采访一些教练时，也看到了类似的困境。他们刚刚经历了一个糟糕的赛季，正苦苦支撑，刚刚结束了为期八周的训练营，每天工作18个小时，睡眠不足，伙食很差，还要应对各种各样的压力，包括决定哪些球员留队，哪些球员离开，以及如何应对媒体、伤病、球员罢训、经纪人、老板、媒体等等。
On some of those occasions, a coach would see me and just break down. Marty Schottenheimer broke down one time when I opened the door to his hotel room after he had lost two consecutive games early in the season. He came to me and put his arms around me and quietly cried. Why? He looked at me, a former coach, and saw relief, someone who had been there, who understood and sympathized.
有些时候，教练看到我就会崩溃大哭。有一次，赛季初马蒂·肖滕海默连输两场后，我去他酒店房间开门，他顿时崩溃了。他走到我身边，拥抱住我，默默地哭泣。为什么？他看着我——一个前教练——看到了如释重负的神情，看到了一个曾经经历过这一切、理解他、感同身受的人。
Football coaches, just like executives who push themselves to the brink and beyond, often have no support system and become isolated from family, friends, and normal interactions. I’ve described it as being in a submarine, submerged and cut off from the human race.
就像那些把自己逼到极限甚至超越极限的高管一样，足球教练往往缺乏支持系统，与家人、朋友和正常的社交活动隔绝开来。我曾把这种感觉比作身处潜艇之中，沉入水下，与世隔绝。
My good friend Dick Vermeil did it as head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles. In his quest for a Super Bowl title, he ultimately began living full time in his cramped little office deep inside Veterans Stadium, working to the exclusion of everything else. His team reached Super Bowl XV only to lose to the Oakland Raiders (led by Jim Plunkett). Dick then pushed himself even harder.
我的好友迪克·维梅尔曾担任费城老鹰队的主教练。为了赢得超级碗冠军，他最终选择全职住在退伍军人体育场深处那间狭小的办公室里，全身心投入工作，无暇顾及其他。他的球队打进了第十五届超级碗，却最终输给了由吉姆·普伦克特率领的奥克兰突袭者队。之后，迪克更加努力地鞭策自己。
Not long after, he was finished—“burnout,” as he described it to reporters at a very emotional press conference when he announced he was quitting. Dick retired for fourteen years before returning in triumph by leading the St. Louis Rams to victory against the Tennessee Titans in Super Bowl XXXIV. Later he told the story of having a sign on the wall while he was the Eagles head coach. It said, “The best way to kill time is to work it to death.” He told people, “I worked time to death until it killed me.”
不久之后，他就筋疲力尽了——正如他在一场情绪激动的记者招待会上宣布辞职时向记者们所描述的那样，是“职业倦怠”。迪克退休了十四年，之后又凯旋回归，带领圣路易斯公羊队在第34届超级碗中战胜田纳西泰坦队。后来，他讲述了自己担任费城老鹰队主教练时，墙上挂着一块牌子的故事。牌子上写着：“消磨时间的最好方法就是拼命工作。”他告诉别人：“我拼命工作，直到精疲力竭。”
Can you imagine how burned out you must be to wait fourteen years to return to doing something you love? I don’t have to imagine it. I never returned to the NFL as a head coach, in spite of offers where I was given a blank contract and told to fill it in with whatever I wanted and then sign it.
你能想象等待十四年才能重返自己热爱的事业，该是多么疲惫不堪吗？我不用想象。尽管有人给我提供空白合同，让我随意填写，然后签字，但我从未以主教练的身份重返NFL。
In professional football, just as in corporate life, as you press harder and harder the ownership (shareholders or the board of directors) may or may not support you. At midnight, while an exhausted coach is staring at a screen watching game video inch by inch by inch, back and forth, over and over, eating stale, cold pizza in the dim light, they’re deciding over martinis and a steak dinner by candlelight whether he’s worth keeping around: “Does he measure up?” they’re asking over dessert while you’re killing yourself with work. “Poor bastard looked pretty beat up last time I saw him,” somebody says with a chuckle. Everybody nods. I didn’t want to be that “poor bastard” again.
在职业足球界，就像在企业界一样，你越是努力拼搏，老板（股东或董事会）是否支持你，就未必了然。午夜时分，当一位疲惫不堪的教练盯着屏幕，一遍又一遍地回放比赛录像，昏暗的灯光下吃着干巴巴的冷披萨时，他们却在烛光下，一边喝着马提尼，一边享用着牛排晚餐，讨论着他是否值得留下：“他够格吗？”当你还在拼命工作时，他们会一边吃甜点一边问。“上次见到他的时候，那可怜的家伙看起来伤痕累累，”有人笑着说。大家都点头表示赞同。我可不想再当那个“可怜的家伙”了。
Nevertheless, that’s part of their duty—to plan ahead, to be ready for whatever the future brings, to decide when their “poor bastard” should be gotten rid of. But the volatility and emotional exhaustion of the environment can just drain you totally, and you’re living with it continuously. It can make you very vulnerable, fragile.
然而，未雨绸缪，做好应对未来一切的准备，决定何时摆脱他们“可怜的家伙”，也是他们职责的一部分。但这种环境的动荡和令人精疲力竭的情绪会彻底耗尽你的精力，而且你还要持续生活在其中。这会让你变得非常脆弱，不堪一击。
I was in Columbus, Ohio, to receive an NFL award just after the 49ers had won a Super Bowl. I got up, started talking, and lost it because I was still emotionally exhausted from the season. Most of the folks in the crowd didn’t really care. Some did, some didn’t.
我当时在俄亥俄州哥伦布市，去领取一个NFL奖项，当时旧金山49人队刚刚赢得了超级碗。我站起来开始讲话，结果因为赛季带来的情绪冲击，我失控了。台下大多数人似乎并不在意。有些人在意，有些人不在意。
I sat down afterward, and it occurred to me, “Most of these people don’t give a damn about me. Why am I exposing my emotions to them? For what?” In that situation you can become a walking basket case for people to gawk at. When this happens, you must have the extreme discipline to alter your perspective. You must change things, but, oh, boy, is that tough to do.
事后我坐了下来，突然意识到：“这些人大多数根本不在乎我。我为什么要向他们袒露心扉？为了什么？” 在这种情况下，你很容易变成一个供人围观的“行走的疯子”。一旦发生这种情况，你必须拥有极强的自律性来改变你的看法。你必须做出改变，但是，哎，这可真难啊。
Aggressively looking for the positive elements, however small, can dilute the toxic pressure of personalizing the results by allowing you to take pride in your strategies, tactics, effort, and execution even when they don’t produce victory every time. It can provide comfort and ease the severity of an ever-growing loathing of failure, which, uncontrolled, can eventually take over to a point of making you almost dysfunctional.
积极寻找哪怕再微小的积极因素，也能减轻将结果个人化所带来的有害压力，让你为自己的策略、战术、努力和执行感到自豪，即便它们并非每次都能带来胜利。这可以带来安慰，缓解日益增长的对失败的厌恶感，而这种厌恶感若不加以控制，最终会占据你的全部身心，甚至让你几乎丧失行动能力。
And, of course, you must derive satisfaction and gratification from winning without letting it define your self-worth, just as you cannot allow defeat to define you as a person. There has to be a balance. You can’t put yourself in a smaller and smaller box where there’s only the infliction or avoidance of pain—a personal torture chamber.
当然，你必须从胜利中获得满足感和成就感，但不能让胜利定义你的自我价值，正如你不能让失败定义你的人格一样。两者之间必须保持平衡。你不能把自己困在一个越来越小的牢笼里，那里只有施加痛苦或逃避痛苦的选择——那简直就是一个个人的酷刑室。
I was increasingly unable to do this. Consequently, during my tenth season with the 49ers, I knew I had to get out. We had achieved great success, gone beyond anything we or anyone else could have imagined early on. In the eyes of many, a San Francisco 49ers dynasty had been created in which a Super Bowl championship was now a given. Imagine that. Winning a Super Bowl was a given. But I bought into it and thought anything less was utter and contemptible failure. I believed it, but I didn’t really believe it.
我越来越无法做到这一点。因此，在为旧金山49人队效力的第十个赛季，我知道我必须离开。我们取得了巨大的成功，远远超出了我们自己以及任何人当初的想象。在许多人眼中，旧金山49人队的王朝已经建立，超级碗冠军似乎已成定局。想想看，赢得超级碗竟然成了理所当然。但我却深信不疑，认为任何低于这个目标的成绩都是彻头彻尾、令人不齿的失败。我表面上相信这一点，但实际上并非如此。
I was suffering from the emotional and mental exhaustion of having been at various times head coach, president, general manager, offensive coordinator, and play caller, in addition to having other unofficial titles and responsibilities for various parts of a decade. But much of it had to do with our ultimately unattainable expectations and my inability to deal with the prospect of failure. All of it put together became too much.
我当时身心俱疲，因为我曾先后担任过主教练、总裁、总经理、进攻协调员和战术指挥，此外在过去十年间还承担过其他一些非正式的头衔和职责。但更主要的原因是我们最终无法实现的期望，以及我无法面对失败的可能。所有这些加在一起，让我不堪重负。
Had I been able to avoid the dead-end calculation of “zero points for winning,” I would have continued to coach the 49ers and, I believe, won additional Super Bowl championships. That is something that has never stopped eating at me. But by the end I wasn’t thinking straight. When CBS announcer Brent Musburger interviewed me in the locker room in the middle of the wild celebration immediately after our third Super Bowl victory, he asked me, “Will this be the final game on the sidelines for Bill Walsh?”
如果我当初能避免“赢球不得分”这种死胡同式的计算方式，我本可以继续执教49人队，而且我相信，我还能赢得更多超级碗冠军。这件事一直让我耿耿于怀。但到了最后，我的思维已经混乱不堪。在我们第三次赢得超级碗冠军后，CBS解说员布伦特·穆斯伯格在更衣室里采访我时，正值我们疯狂庆祝之际，他问我：“这将是比尔·沃尔什在场边执教的最后一场比赛吗？”
Before he could even finish the sentence, I dropped my head and began weeping. I looked for my son Craig in the crowd and put my arm around him for support; we walked away. Somebody took a picture of us at that moment. I saw it the other day. I looked like an old man—frail, weak, almost bewildered.
他话还没说完，我就低下头，开始哭泣。我在人群中寻找儿子克雷格，搂住他的肩膀支撑着他；我们一起离开了。有人拍下了我们当时的合影。前几天我看到了那张照片。照片上的我看起来像个老人——虚弱、憔悴，几乎有些茫然。
Like my dear friend Dick Vermeil when he left Philadelphia, I had nothing left in the tank. In retrospect, it seems so simple; that is, the steps I could have taken to remain the productive and enthusiastic head coach of the San Francisco 49ers.
就像我亲爱的朋友迪克·维梅尔离开费城时一样，我已经精疲力竭。现在回想起来，事情似乎很简单：我本可以采取一些措施，继续担任旧金山49人队的主教练，保持高效和热情。
Let me share some thoughts on avoiding the trap I fell into, some ideas on how to deal with escalating expectations that become preposterous, personalization of results, and “zero points for winning.” I must admit that I’m not sure any of this would have benefitted me by the time I reached the end of my rope. The time to do it is before your tank is empty.
让我分享一些避免重蹈覆辙的想法，一些应对不断膨胀、最终变得荒谬的期望、个性化结果以及“赢了不得分”的技巧。我必须承认，当我精疲力竭的时候，我并不确定这些方法是否真的对我有帮助。所以，行动的时机必须在你精疲力竭之前。
1. Do not isolate yourself. While your spouse and family can be extremely important for support, they may not be equipped to deal with the magnitude of your professional issues in this area. Thus, develop a small , trusted network of people whose opinions you respect and are willing to honestly evaluate. My own make-up resisted this. As I marched forward as head coach, I became isolated, increasingly separated, even lonely. Keep your lines of communication open with mentors and professionals in your business whom you trust, even a professional counselor. (I had one for a while.) They can help you restore perspective and help clarify and prioritize situations and responsibilities. Be very discreet about whom you confide in. Crying on somebody’s shoulder, if it’s the wrong “somebody,” can have negative repercussions.
1. 不要孤立自己。虽然你的配偶和家人可以提供极大的支持，但他们可能没有能力应对你在这一领域遇到的如此巨大的职业问题。因此，你需要建立一个小型且值得信赖的人际网络，这些人是你尊重并愿意诚实评估其意见的人。我自身就很难做到这一点。随着我作为主教练不断前进，我变得越来越孤立，与外界的联系也越来越少，甚至感到孤独。要与你信任的导师和业内专业人士保持沟通，甚至可以咨询专业心理咨询师。（我曾经咨询过一段时间。）他们可以帮助你重新审视问题，理清思路，明确轻重缓急。务必谨慎选择倾诉对象。如果找错了倾诉对象，向别人倾诉可能会带来负面影响。
2. Delegate abundantly. If you’ve done your job in leadership, you’ve brought on board individuals who are very talented. Allow them to use their talent in ways that serve the team and lighten your load. If you’ve hired and taught them well, they will do their job. I confess it was hard for me to amply delegate, even though I was surrounded by exceptionally talented people. I hired them, added to their expertise, and then had trouble turning some of them—especially on the offensive side of the game—fully loose to do their jobs. I was like a man dying of thirst who was sitting on the edge of a mountain stream. I denied myself what was available.
2. 充分授权。如果你尽职尽责地做好领导工作，你就会招揽到才华横溢的人才。让他们发挥才能，为团队做出贡献，减轻你的负担。如果你招聘和培养得当，他们自然会做好自己的工作。我承认，即便身边都是才华横溢的人，我也很难充分授权。我招聘了他们，提升了他们的专业技能，却很难放手让他们中的一些人——尤其是在进攻端——完全放手去做。我就像一个渴死的人坐在山涧边，却拒绝了唾手可得的机会。
3. Avoid the destructive temptation to define yourself as a person by the won-lost record, the “score,” however you define it. Don’t equate your team’s “won-lost record” with your self-worth.
3. 避免陷入以胜负记录、“比分”（无论你如何定义）来定义自己的陷阱。不要将球队的“胜负记录”与你的自我价值划等号。
4. Shake it off. Marv Levy lost four straight Super Bowls as head coach of the Buffalo Bills and was able to keep it in perspective: “It hurts like the devil for ten days or two weeks and then you bury it and go back to work and look ahead.” Bud Grant lost four Super Bowls as head coach of the Minnesota Vikings and was able to keep it in perspective: “I’ve got a 24-hour rule. You only let it bother you for 24 hours and then it’s over.”
4. 放下执念。马夫·利维作为布法罗比尔队的主教练，曾连续四次输掉超级碗，但他能够保持清醒的头脑：“这种痛苦会持续十天到两周，但之后你必须把它埋在心底，重新投入工作，展望未来。” 巴德·格兰特作为明尼苏达维京人队的主教练，也曾四次输掉超级碗，但他同样能够保持清醒的头脑：“我有个‘24小时法则’。你只会让它困扰你24小时，然后一切就都过去了。”
As you may have noted, I was unable or unwilling to utilize any of the prescriptions that I’ve just suggested. It would be facile to say it was because I didn’t know about these options while I was head coach. In honesty, I did know—at least I think I did—but I didn’t have the strength or intelligence to use them, to protect myself. Like many who wear blinders and focus on victory to the exclusion of everything else, I barreled down the highway until the engine burned up.
正如你可能已经注意到的，我当时无法或不愿采用我刚才提出的任何建议。如果说是因为我担任主教练时对这些方法一无所知，那就太简单了。说实话，我当时确实知道——至少我认为我知道——但我没有足够的精力和智慧去运用它们，去保护自己。就像许多戴着眼罩、一心只想赢球而忽略其他一切的人一样，我一路狂奔，直到引擎彻底报废。
One of the common traits of outstanding performers—coaches, athletes, managers, sales representatives, executives, and others who face a daily up/down, win/lose accounting system—is that a rejection, that is, defeat, is quickly forgotten, replaced eagerly by pursuit of a new order, client, or opponent. They know that a defeat, whether a lost account or a loss on the field, can’t be taken personally. Like Bud Grant, they shake it off and go forward. And so must you.
杰出人士——教练、运动员、经理、销售代表、高管以及其他每天都要面对成败得失的人——都有一个共同的特质：他们能迅速忘记失败，转而积极追求新的订单、客户或对手。他们明白，无论是失去客户还是赛场失利，都不能把失败看得太重。就像巴德·格兰特一样，他们会迅速调整心态，继续前进。你也应该如此。
In my early days, I did this too. I firmly believed that if I took care of my job the score would take care of itself. When it didn’t, I worked even harder to improve my coaching and elevate the Standard of Performance of our team. This was one of the reasons I drove myself so relentlessly. But gradually I found it harder and harder to accept my concept that the “score will take care of itself.” I became consumed with how the score would take care of itself, whether it would be in a manner that resulted in victory for me. I became overwhelmed with worry about that score and lost sight of the fact that in a fight you go as hard as you can, do all you’re capable of doing, knowing that ultimately, while you can influence the result to a greater or lesser degree, you do not control the result.
早年间，我也曾如此。我坚信，只要做好自己的工作，比分自然会水到渠成。但事与愿违，我便更加努力地提升执教水平，提高团队的整体表现。这也是我如此鞭策自己的原因之一。然而，渐渐地，我发现自己越来越难以接受“比分自然会水到渠成”这种想法。我开始执着于比分最终会如何变化，是否能以我获胜的方式收场。我对比分的焦虑让我喘不过气，却忘记了在战斗中，你必须全力以赴，竭尽所能，因为你知道，最终，尽管你能在一定程度上影响结果，但你无法掌控结果。
If your hard work is coupled with intelligence and talent, you may win. If not, you go back to work and get ready for the next fight without feeling that somehow, having given it everything you’ve got (as I did for ten years), you are somehow inadequate as a person, that you didn’t measure up. You can’t let that happen to yourself.
如果你勤奋努力，又兼具智慧和天赋，你或许就能成功。即便失败，你也要继续努力，为下一场战斗做好准备，而不必因为自己已经竭尽全力（就像我一样，奋斗了十年）而感到自己不够优秀，觉得自己没有达到标准。你不能让这种想法发生在自己身上。

What Do I Miss Least? 我最不怀念的是什么？
The cruelty of the sport, both mental and physical, was almost repellent to me—not what occurs during a game so much, but the brutal attitudes and practices I saw when I was coming up: treating players in an almost thuglike manner, working them to death in practice, pitting one against another, disrespecting their intelligence, dehumanizing them, and all the rest of it. It just seemed to be a crude model of leadership, an ineffective way of bringing out great performance for an organization filled with highly competitive and usually intelligent individuals who just happened to be fantastic athletes. I changed that completely when I became a head coach in charge of everything.
这项运动的残酷，无论是精神上的还是肉体上的，都令我几乎作呕——倒不是比赛本身，而是我成长过程中目睹的那些粗暴的态度和做法：对待球员近乎流氓，让他们在训练中拼命，挑拨离间，轻视他们的智商，剥夺他们的人性，等等等等。这在我看来是一种粗劣的领导模式，对于一个由极具竞争力且通常都很聪明的运动员组成的团队来说，这种领导方式根本无法激发他们的潜能。当我成为主教练，负责一切事务后，我彻底改变了这一切。
Even more, it was disgusting to see how people under stress can turn on one another and how those satellite and peripheral people will try to take credit for what you’ve done. I’ve got a list of people—albeit short—who claim they discovered Joe Montana and had to talk me into drafting him because I didn’t think he had what it takes. One of the lessons I learned was how people change with success or failure. People’s behavior and attitudes can be transformed in the most positive or most disturbing ways.
更令人作呕的是，压力之下人们会如何互相攻击，那些边缘人物又会如何试图窃取你的功劳。我有一小撮人——虽然不多——他们声称自己发现了乔·蒙塔纳，还得说服我选他，因为我当时觉得他没那个本事。我从中得到的教训之一是，成功或失败都会改变人。人们的行为和态度可能会发生最积极的转变，也可能朝着最令人不安的方向发展。
Also, it was unpleasant to know that doing a good job in the NFL wasn’t much different from doing a bad job. Both will get you fired; the latter just gets you fired sooner. You know you’re there as a coach temporarily, only while you’re very successful, only when you do a fantastic job. Then you learn that even a fantastic job is inadequate. The norm becomes the impossible, and when you don’t achieve the impossible, your head’s on the chopping block.
此外，更令人不快的是，在NFL里，做得好和做得差其实没什么区别。两者都会让你丢掉饭碗，只不过后者让你走得更快而已。你知道自己只是个临时教练，只有在你非常成功、做得非常出色的时候才能待在那里。然后你会发现，即便做得非常出色也远远不够。“正常”变成了“不可能”，而当你达不到“不可能”的标准时，你的饭碗就岌岌可危了。
Good and bad are about the same in the NFL, perhaps in corporate America too. You’re gone if good is the best you can do. Good just buys you time; great buys you a little more time. And then you’re gone. In the NFL, a head coach is on a very short string.
在NFL，好和坏几乎没什么区别，或许在企业界也是如此。如果你只能做到“好”，那就注定要被淘汰。“好”只能为你争取时间；“优秀”也只能为你争取更多时间。然后，你还是会被淘汰。在NFL，主教练的任期非常短暂。

What Do I Miss Most? 我最怀念的是什么？
I will start a list like this with the athletes and the relationships I had with others in the organization, especially assistant coaches and staff such as John McVay, Bill White, Bobb McKittrick, George Seifert, Norb Hecker, Denny Green, Ray Rhodes, Bill McPherson, and so many others—sharing a common goal, sacrificing, interacting, navigating the dynamics of dealing with other people in moving toward our goal. In fact, even though my relationship with Eddie DeBartolo became almost toxic at the end, during the early years it was wonderful. (And by the way, we repaired things in the years after my retirement and became very good friends. Eddie DeBartolo did what nobody else was willing to do; namely, he gave me a chance. I will always be indebted to him for seeing in me the potential that others did not. Eddie and I were partners in one of the great success stories in the history of sports.)
我会先列出这份清单，从运动员以及我与组织内其他成员的关系开始，特别是助理教练和工作人员，比如约翰·麦克维、比尔·怀特、鲍勃·麦基特里克、乔治·塞弗特、诺布·赫克尔、丹尼·格林、雷·罗兹、比尔·麦克弗森等等——我们拥有共同的目标，彼此付出牺牲，互相交流，共同应对与他人相处的种种挑战，朝着共同的目标前进。事实上，尽管我和埃迪·德巴托罗的关系在后期几乎恶化，但在最初几年里，我们的关系非常美好。（顺便说一句，在我退役后的几年里，我们修复了关系，成为了非常好的朋友。埃迪·德巴托罗做了别人都不愿意做的事：他给了我一个机会。我将永远感激他，因为他看到了我身上别人看不到的潜力。埃迪和我共同创造了体育史上最伟大的成功故事之一。）
I also really miss the strategy and tactics of the game—designing plays and seeing them work. Nothing is more gratifying than creating something that you’re sure no one else has ever seen or thought of and having it succeed. Then later to see it become a commonly used device throughout football is really something that is satisfying.
我也很怀念比赛的策略和战术——设计战术并看到它们奏效。没有什么比创造出你确信别人从未见过或想过的东西，并且它成功了更令人满足的了。之后看到它成为足球界普遍使用的战术，真的非常令人欣慰。
The offensive system I came up with was like that, what they called the West Coast Offense. As variations of it spread throughout the NFL and college football, it was very nice to see. I felt good about it, perhaps because it was the ultimate compliment, something along the lines of, “If you can’t beat ’em, join ’em.” Many started “joining” my approach to offensive football. It was in some sense a validation of what I’d created at Cincinnati and then been mocked for at San Francisco even after we won a Super Bowl. (I’ve never forgotten the dismissive comments, even ridicule, by many who thought that the kind of football I was teaching wasn’t “real” football, that it was a gimmick. For reasons that I’ve never totally figured out, there was a reluctance to acknowledge the legitimacy of what I was doing.)
我设计的进攻体系就是这样，他们称之为西海岸进攻。随着这种体系的各种变体在NFL和大学橄榄球界传播开来，我感到非常欣慰。我为此感到自豪，或许是因为这是对我最高的赞誉，类似于“打不过就加入他们”的道理。许多人开始“加入”我的进攻体系。从某种意义上说，这证明了我在辛辛那提大学所创造的体系是值得肯定的，尽管后来我们在旧金山赢得了超级碗，却仍然遭到嘲笑。（我永远不会忘记那些轻蔑的评论，甚至是嘲讽，许多人认为我所教授的橄榄球不是“真正的”橄榄球，只是噱头。出于我至今仍未完全弄明白的原因，他们不愿意承认我所做的事情是合理的。）
I also got a kick out of seeing opposing coaches start using the situational advance planning of plays, written out on a clipboard (usually covered in clear plastic to protect against rain and snow). I started it in response to Paul Brown’s question at Cincinnati, “What’ve you got for openers, Bill?” and then developed and greatly expanded it as the benefits became more obvious.
看到对方教练开始使用情景预判战术，并把战术写在写字板上（通常会用透明塑料膜盖住以防雨雪），我感到非常兴奋。我最初是在辛辛那提大学时，保罗·布朗问我：“比尔，你有什么开场战术？”之后，随着战术优势的日益显现，我不断完善和扩展了它。
And of course there was the deep fulfillment of climbing the mountain, of going where few in my profession were able to go. Our first Super Bowl championship was profoundly meaningful and satisfying—thrilling beyond my ability to fully articulate. Thrilling .
当然，攀登高峰带来的那种深深的满足感也令人难以忘怀，我们到达了同行中鲜有人能企及的高度。我们第一次赢得超级碗冠军意义非凡，令人无比欣慰——那种激动人心的感觉，我简直无法用语言来形容。真是太激动人心了。
I miss all of that.
我怀念这一切。

Quick Results Come Slowly: The Score Takes Care of Itself 快速见效需要时间：分数会慢慢提升。
The Fujian Province of China is known as the Venice of Asia because of the superb stone sculptures created there over the centuries. Hundreds, perhaps thousands of years ago, near the city of Sichuan, artists—stone sculptors—worked in a time-honored and time-consuming way. Legend has it that when their sculpture was completed, the artist immersed it in the shallows of a nearby stream, where it remained for many years as the waters constantly flowed over it.
中国福建省因其数百年来创作的精美石雕而被誉为“亚洲威尼斯”。数百年前，或许数千年前，在四川附近，石雕艺术家们以一种古老而耗时的方式进行创作。传说，当他们完成雕塑后，艺术家会将其浸入附近溪流的浅水中，让它在溪水的冲刷下静静地保存多年。
During this period, the finishing touch was applied by Mother Nature (or perhaps Father Time). The gentle but constant flow of water over the stone changed it in subtle but profound ways. Only after this occurred would the sculptor consider it complete—only when time had done its work was the sculpture perfect.
在此期间，大自然（或许是时间之父）为这件作品完成了最后的润色。潺潺流水轻柔而持续地流淌在石头上，以微妙而深刻的方式改变了它。只有当这一切发生之后，雕塑家才会认为作品完成——只有当时间完成它的使命，雕塑才臻于完美。
I believe it’s much the same in one’s profession; at least it was in mine. Superb, reliable results take time. The little improvements that lead to impressive achievements come not from a week’s work or a month’s practice, but from a series of months and years until your organization knows what you are teaching inside and out and everyone is able to execute their responsibilities in all ways at the highest level.
我相信在专业领域也是如此；至少在我的专业领域是如此。卓越可靠的成果需要时间。那些最终带来显著成就的微小进步，并非源于一周的工作或一个月的练习，而是需要数月甚至数年的积累，直到你的组织对你所教授的内容了如指掌，每个人都能以最高水平履行各自的职责。
Your team has absorbed and assimilated not just the mechanics of your own Standard of Performance, but the attitudes and beliefs that are central to it. I believe that every organization has a cultural conscience that it carries forward year after year. That ethos may be good or bad, productive or unproductive. Some leaders are able to create the former, others the latter. But productive or unproductive, it exists, and it is guiding ongoing personnel and informing new arrivals as they come on board.
您的团队不仅吸收并理解了您自身绩效标准的具体运作方式，更理解了其核心态度和信念。我相信每个组织都有其文化意识，并年复一年地传承下去。这种文化意识或许是好的，或许是坏的；或许是高效的，或许是低效的。有些领导者能够营造前者，有些则不然。但无论高效与否，它都真实存在，它指导着现有员工，也影响着新加入的成员。
The attitudes and actions I installed, including the inventory of San Francisco’s football plays—offensive and defensive—were the result of the same guys (or their similarly trained replacements) doing the same thing for years and years. Subsequently, it became almost routine to execute at the highest level when the heat was on. Excellence in every single area of our organization had been taught and expected from the day I arrived as head coach.
我所建立的态度和行动，包括旧金山橄榄球队的进攻和防守战术体系，都是同一批球员（或训练有素的替补）多年来反复实践的结果。因此，在关键时刻保持最高水准的执行力几乎成了惯例。自从我担任主教练以来，我们球队的每个环节都力求卓越，这也是我们对球员的期望。
The “big plays” in business—or professional football—don’t just suddenly occur out of thin air. They result from very hard work and painstaking attention over the years to all of the details related to your leadership.
商业或职业足球中的“重大胜利”并非凭空而来，而是多年来对领导力相关细节的辛勤工作和一丝不苟关注的结果。
Talent, functional intelligence, experience, maturity, effort, dedication, and practice may not be perfect, but they will get you so close to perfection that most people will think you achieved it. And the results will show it.
天赋、功能性智力、经验、成熟度、努力、奉献和练习或许并非完美无缺，但它们能让你无限接近完美，以至于大多数人都会认为你已经达到了完美。而结果也会证明这一点。
It takes time to develop this Standard of Performance; it is not just a seminar or a practice or a season’s worth of seminars and practices, but thoughtful and intense attention over years and years. Then, when you’ve got to score on the last play of the game to win, you know it can happen. This is a powerful force to have within you.
培养这种高水平的竞技状态需要时间；它并非仅仅是一次研讨会、一次训练，或者一个赛季的研讨会和训练就能完成的，而是需要多年来深思熟虑、全神贯注的投入。这样，当比赛最后时刻需要你得分才能赢得胜利时，你就知道一切皆有可能。这是一种强大的内在力量。
In Super Bowl XXIII, the final game I ever coached in the NFL, the Cincinnati Bengals led San Francisco 16-13 when we took possession of the ball on our own eight-yard line with 3:08 remaining to play. Most smart observers assumed a Cincinnati victory was now almost a given. What followed has become legendary in the NFL: the Drive. It is a wonderful example of the principles demonstrated by the stone sculptors of China as applied to one’s profession.
在第23届超级碗，也是我执教生涯的最后一场比赛中，辛辛那提猛虎队以16比13领先旧金山49人队，比赛还剩3分08秒时，我们在己方8码线处拿到了球权。大多数明智的观察家都认为辛辛那提队获胜已成定局。接下来发生的一切，在NFL历史上已成为传奇：那次精彩的进攻。它完美地诠释了中国石雕大师的技艺如何应用于职业领域。
The 49ers methodically—and artistically—marched ninety-two yards in eleven plays, culminating with orderly precision in an eighteen-yard pass from Joe Montana to John Taylor (“20 halfback curl X up”) for a touchdown and a Super Bowl championship. There was hardly a hiccup as Joe and the team looked up from our own eight-yard line and saw the mountain’s summit ninety-two yards away, then calmly—almost nonchalantly—climbed to the top.
49人队有条不紊地——而且极具艺术性地——推进了92码，历经11次进攻，最终由乔·蒙塔纳精准地将球传给约翰·泰勒（“20号半卫卷腹X形跑动”），完成18码达阵，赢得了超级碗冠军。从己方8码线抬头望向92码外的山顶，乔和他的队友们几乎没有遇到任何阻碍，他们平静地——几乎是漫不经心地——攀登到了顶峰。
As the Drive unfolded—those eleven plays—I had a deep sense that what I was witnessing was the manifestation, the expression, of everything we had done along the way in the previous decade, culminating with this final opportunity for a grand victory. Everything that was happening in front of me went back to the beginning, the first day of practice at training camp ten years earlier, and was linked by all the years of effort and intelligence by all the people in our organization during the decade since then.
随着那十一次进攻的展开，我深深地感受到，我所见证的，正是过去十年我们所有努力的最终体现，是这最后一次赢得伟大胜利的机会。眼前发生的一切，都追溯到十年前训练营的第一天，又与此后十年间我们团队所有人的辛勤付出和智慧紧密相连。
From my first day at 49er headquarters, I had begun imbuing individuals with a sense that a higher standard was being taught and learned, executed and expected in all of our actions and attitudes. My Standard of Performance and the hard work all of us put into achieving it had created a deep sense of organizational character, commitment, and ability—a sense that every individual was connected to the entire team, and that this group fighting its way to the summit against Cincinnati was a natural extension of those that had preceded it—culminating now in a work of near perfection.
从我来到49人队总部的第一天起，我就开始向队员们灌输一种理念：我们要学习、学习、执行并期望在所有行动和态度中都达到更高的标准。我的绩效标准以及我们所有人为之付出的辛勤努力，塑造了我们深厚的组织精神、责任感和能力——一种每个人都与整个团队紧密相连的意识，一种我们这支一路披荆斩棘、力克辛辛那提的队伍，是前人努力的自然延续——最终成就了近乎完美的辉煌。
There was almost a sense of inevitability. We seemed certain, almost destined, to drive the length of the field against a ferocious Cincinnati Bengals defense. At least, that’s how I remember feeling—no panic, no anxiety, no uncertainty. All we had to do was exactly what we had been doing for years and years: adhere to the Standard of Performance we had been sculpting for a decade.
当时几乎有一种命中注定的感觉。我们似乎笃定，仿佛命中注定，要一路推进，突破辛辛那提猛虎队凶猛的防守。至少，我记得当时就是这种感觉——没有恐慌，没有焦虑，没有不确定。我们所要做的，就是像多年来那样：坚持我们十年来不断完善的竞技标准。
The Drive became the final offensive series of plays in my career as a head coach in the National Football League. As it unfolded on the field in front of 75,129 fans in Miami’s Joe Robbie Stadium, I was filled with an appreciation that what these players and the members of our organization who were not on the field were doing was a work of art, one that had been created over many years—similar, in a way, to the sculptures in China. It was a thing of beauty.
“那次进攻”成了我作为NFL主教练生涯中最后一次进攻。当这套战术在迈阿密乔·罗比体育场75129名球迷面前展开时，我由衷地赞叹这些球员以及我们团队中那些不在场上的成员们所做的一切，简直就是一件艺术品，一件历经多年精心雕琢的艺术品——某种程度上，它与中国的雕塑作品有异曲同工之妙。那真是一件美的艺术品。
I believe it’s true in your profession. Your effort in the beginning is part of a continuum of effort; your Standard of Performance is part of a continuum of standards. Today’s effort becomes tomorrow’s result. The quality of those efforts becomes the quality of your work. One day is connected to the following day and the following month to the succeeding years.
我相信这在你的职业中同样适用。你最初的努力只是持续努力的一部分；你的绩效标准也是一系列标准的一部分。今天的努力会成为明天的成果。这些努力的质量最终会体现在你工作的质量上。每一天都与第二天息息相关，下个月又与未来的几年紧密相连。
Your own Standard of Performance becomes who and what you are. You and your organization achieve greatness.
你自身的绩效标准将塑造你，成就你。你和你的组织都将因此而辉煌。
For me, the road had been rocky at times, triumphant too, but along the way I had never wavered in my dedication to installing—teaching—those actions and attitudes I believed would create a great team, a superior organization. I knew that if I achieved that, the score would take care of itself.
对我而言，这条路有时崎岖坎坷，有时也充满胜利的喜悦，但我始终坚定不移地致力于灌输——或者说教授——那些我认为能够打造一支卓越团队、一个杰出组织的行动和态度。我知道，只要我做到了这一点，最终的成绩自然会水到渠成。
As you’ve seen, there were stretches where I found it impossible to truly allow that to happen, when I became almost terrified of losing, of letting the score take care of itself. But ultimately, I got back to it. On that final San Francisco 49er drive, ninety-two yards to a championship, I was at peace knowing the score—one way or another—would take care of itself.
正如你所见，有好几次我都无法真正接受这一切，我几乎害怕失败，害怕比分尘埃落定。但最终，我还是调整好了心态。在旧金山49人队最后一次进攻，距离冠军仅差92码的时候，我内心很平静，因为我知道比分——无论结果如何——都会水到渠成。
And it did.
确实如此。

THE WALSH WAY 沃尔什路
A Complex Man. A Simple Goal. 一个复杂的人，一个简单的目标。
Craig Walsh
克雷格·沃尔什







I was with my father on that final day, experienced with tens of thousands of others the incredible conclusion not only to Super Bowl XXIII, but to the NFL coaching career of Bill Walsh. “The Drive,” ninety-two yards against Cincinnati for his third Super Bowl championship in eight years, has become legendary—a point of perfection when experts talk about how great teams perform under pressure.
在那最后一天，我和父亲一起，与成千上万的观众共同见证了超级碗 XXIII 以及比尔·沃尔什 NFL 教练生涯的辉煌落幕。“那次进攻”，对阵辛辛那提猛虎队时推进的 92 码，为他赢得了八年来的第三个超级碗冠军，已成为传奇——当专家们谈论伟大球队如何在压力下发挥时，这堪称完美典范。
Moments after the final gun sounded and victory was secured, my father found himself in the midst of total pandemonium. The San Francisco 49ers’ locker room was exploding with joy and manic energy—reporters, players, staff, and many others all jammed inside to celebrate. Amid the wild crowd, Bill Walsh was an anomaly—quiet, withdrawn, almost melancholy. As he stepped off the podium after receiving the Lombardi Trophy and trying to give a short speech—shortened because of his overwhelming emotion and fatigue—he found me in the crowd, put his arm around my shoulder, and wept. “Let’s go,” he said quietly. My father was stepping down at the top, like he had asked his players to do when it was their turn.
终场哨声响起，胜利尘埃落定的那一刻，我的父亲置身于一片狂热的庆祝之中。旧金山49人队的更衣室里洋溢着喜悦和疯狂的气氛——记者、球员、工作人员以及许多其他人都挤在里面庆祝。在这群疯狂的人群中，比尔·沃尔什显得格格不入——他安静、内敛，甚至有些忧郁。当他走下领奖台，接过隆巴迪奖杯，试图发表一段简短的讲话时——由于情绪激动和疲惫，讲话被大大缩短了——他在人群中找到了我，搂住我的肩膀，哽咽着说：“走吧。”他轻声说道。我的父亲正像他要求球员们在轮到他们时那样，从最高处走下来。
The Score Will Take Care of Itself is an appropriate title for his book on leadership. As head coach he was tireless—even obsessive—in his drive to intelligently prepare himself and his entire organization (players, assistant coaches, trainers, staff, and everybody else) so that they were in a position to prevail in one of the most fiercely contested professions—the National Football League. A man of great logic, he truly believed that in the end, your ultimate assignment as a leader is getting those on your team totally ready for the battle. After that, you have to let winning take care of itself. His ability to do that contributed to his success; his inability to do that, increasing as the years went by, forced him to leave the game as an NFL head coach.
《比分自会水到渠成》是他这本关于领导力著作的恰当书名。作为主教练，他孜孜不倦，甚至近乎痴迷地致力于让自己和整个团队（球员、助理教练、训练员、工作人员以及其他所有人）做好充分准备，以便在竞争最激烈的行业之一——美国国家橄榄球联盟（NFL）中脱颖而出。他逻辑思维极强，坚信领导者的最终任务是让团队成员做好充分的战斗准备。之后，胜利自然会水到渠成。他在这方面的能力成就了他的成功；然而，随着岁月的流逝，他在这方面的能力逐渐下降，最终迫使他离开了NFL主教练的岗位。
Having said that, I will share an interesting and revealing and little-known fact about my father: When he started his coaching career, the approval of and acceptance by fans meant very little to him. Football was in large part an intellectual activity in which he completely immersed himself—almost like a scientist searching for, and fascinated by, a mathematical solution in quantum physics. For Dad, “quantum physics” was about leadership, team building, and extraordinary performance in the context of football. (Of course, he also had a competitive streak a mile wide.)
话虽如此，我还是要分享一个关于我父亲鲜为人知却又颇具启发性的事实：在他执教生涯的初期，球迷的认可和接受对他来说并不重要。足球对他而言很大程度上是一种智力活动，他完全沉浸其中——就像一位科学家在量子物理学中寻找并着迷于某种数学解法一样。对父亲来说，“量子物理学”指的是在足球领域中展现领导力、团队建设和卓越表现。（当然，他也有着极其强烈的竞争意识。）
How football could create devotion, fan frenzy, and be America’s number one sport was something of a mystery to my father. When he did the impossible and won Super Bowl XVI in his third year as head coach, he quietly argued against a victory parade in San Francisco because he didn’t think many people would show up; he feared that it would be an embarrassment for his players to be riding down empty streets waving at nobody.
足球为何能激起球迷的狂热，成为美国第一运动，这对我来说一直是个谜。当他执教的第三年就带领球队创造了奇迹，赢得了第十六届超级碗冠军时，他却私下反对在旧金山举行庆祝游行，因为他觉得不会有多少人到场；他担心球员们在空荡荡的街道上游行，向空无一人的观众挥手致意，会让他感到难堪。
He was surprised, but delighted, when over five hundred thousand people lined Market Street in downtown San Francisco to wildly cheer their newly beloved 49ers. Nevertheless, he could never fully comprehend what all the excitement was about. His excitement was drawn from a completely different source than the average fan’s.
当超过五十万民众涌上旧金山市中心的市场街，为他们新近挚爱的49人队疯狂欢呼时，他既惊讶又欣喜。然而，他始终无法完全理解这股狂热究竟源于何处。他的兴奋之情与普通球迷截然不同。
However, after the rallying point of that first San Francisco 49er Super Bowl victory, my father realized what a dramatic role the team had played in bringing the city back together as one following the public trauma of the murders of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk, and the Jonestown massacre a few years earlier. The “Niners” had become the common ground for the entire city of San Francisco and much of the Bay Area—a wildly diverse group of people. Dad took immense pride in this.
然而，在旧金山49人队首次赢得超级碗冠军之后，我父亲意识到，这支球队在帮助这座城市从乔治·莫斯科尼市长和哈维·米尔克议员遇害以及几年前琼斯镇惨案带来的公众创伤中重新团结起来方面发挥了多么重要的作用。“49人队”成为了整个旧金山市乃至整个湾区——一个由形形色色的人们组成的群体——的共同纽带。父亲为此感到无比自豪。
In a sense, Bill Walsh introduced twenty-first-century playmaking and management in the NFL two decades before the new century arrived—starting in 1979 when he was appointed president, general manager, and head coach of a lowly franchise in San Francisco, a distant outpost in the eyes of many throughout the league.
从某种意义上说，比尔·沃尔什在21世纪到来之前的20年，就将21世纪的比赛策略和管理理念引入了NFL——这一切始于1979年，当时他被任命为旧金山一支低级别球队的总裁、总经理和主教练，在联盟许多人眼中，旧金山是一个遥远的边陲之地。
While most observers focus on his “genius” when it came to figuring out how a football team gains ground and scores touchdowns, few understand the complex psychological make-up of this remarkable man, whose need to prove himself, while almost self-destructive, was the fuel in the engine that helped catapult him to the top.
虽然大多数观察家都关注他在研究足球队如何推进和得分方面的“天才”，但很少有人了解这位杰出人物复杂的心理构成，他渴望证明自己的需求虽然近乎自我毁灭，但却是推动他登上巅峰的动力。
I’ve come to understand that, in some ways, my father’s life was almost Shakespearean, because what got him to the top professionally was his downfall personally; in spite of his incomparable achievements, he had trouble ever feeling fulfilled on a continuing basis. While he learned from each loss and every win, my dad increasingly took something away from a defeat that he couldn’t shake. Driven by a desire to gain the stamp of approval from his peers (but not necessarily the public), he was consumed by work and winning, increasingly haunted by losing. When you achieve what he achieved, the inability or unwillingness to grant yourself happiness and satisfaction is perhaps tragic.
我逐渐明白，在某种程度上，父亲的人生几乎堪比莎士比亚的戏剧，因为他事业上的巅峰成就却也导致了他个人生活的崩塌；尽管他取得了无与伦比的成就，却始终难以获得持续的满足感。虽然他从每一次失败和每一次胜利中汲取经验，但父亲却越来越难以摆脱失败带来的阴影。他渴望获得同行（而非公众）的认可，因此全身心投入工作和胜利，却也越来越被失败的阴影所困扰。当你达到他那样的成就之后，却无法或不愿给予自己幸福和满足，这或许是一种悲剧。
By the sixth and seventh year of his decade as head coach with the 49ers, he was showing the price being paid emotionally. After a home game I would sometimes stop by and join him for a Jacuzzi in the backyard of his house on Valparaiso Street in Menlo Park, California. Although by then he had won Super Bowl XVI and was on his way to more championships, his mind-set was not what you’d expect.
在他执教旧金山49人队的十年间，到了第六年和第七年，他开始显露出为此付出的精神代价。主场比赛结束后，我有时会去他位于加州门洛帕克瓦尔帕莱索街的家，和他一起在后院的按摩浴缸里泡澡。虽然那时他已经赢得了第十六届超级碗，并且正朝着更多的冠军迈进，但他的心态却与人们预想的截然不同。
Late at night, we would sit there in that hot tub, father and son. If the 49ers had won their game that afternoon at Candlestick Park, he would have a sort of blank look on his face; if they had lost the game that afternoon, he’d have the same blank look. I kidded him about it once. He said ruefully, “This is what happens to a man, Craig.” He wasn’t talking about fatigue from that day’s work. I felt bad for him.
深夜，我们父子俩会一起泡在热水浴缸里。如果49人队那天下午在烛台公园赢了比赛，他脸上就会露出茫然的表情；如果他们输了，他脸上的表情也一样茫然。我曾经拿这事儿跟他开玩笑。他无奈地说：“这就是男人的下场，克雷格。”他说的可不是一天工作的疲惫。我真替他感到难过。
It happened in part because one manifestation of his creative abilities—the West Coast Offense (a name he didn’t like)—was such a paradigm shift that most of the NFL elite, including other head coaches, were reluctant to acknowledge him as a true equal or admit that his system was a dramatic improvement, a giant step into the future. “Backyard football” Dallas rival and head coach Tom Landry called Dad’s radical but successful offense. Others were similarly dismissive and sometimes explained a loss to the 49ers with some version of the following: “We just had a bad day. We were off our game.” Rarely did they like to mention that the cause of their “bad day” was the great football team they had faced across the line of scrimmage. In fact, as the 49ers gained dominance in the NFL, he would sometimes motivate his players when, for example, Dallas was next on the schedule by telling them, “According to Landry, we’ve never beaten the ‘real’ Dallas Cowboys. They’ve always got some goddamn excuse: ‘We had an off day, somebody was injured, the sun was shining.’ Always some excuse for us beating the hell out of them.” His speech was meant to motivate but was based on his own perception of being discounted.
部分原因是，他创造力的体现之一——西海岸进攻体系（他并不喜欢这个名字）——带来了如此巨大的范式转变，以至于包括其他主教练在内的大多数NFL精英都不愿承认他是一位真正的对手，也不愿承认他的体系是一项巨大的进步，是迈向未来的一大步。“后院橄榄球”达拉斯牛仔队的对手兼主教练汤姆·兰德里称他父亲的进攻体系激进但成功。其他人也同样不屑一顾，有时甚至用类似这样的理由来解释输给49人队的比赛：“我们今天状态不好，不在状态。”他们很少愿意提及，导致他们“状态不好”的原因是他们在进攻线上遇到了一支强大的球队。事实上，随着49人队在NFL中逐渐占据统治地位，他有时会激励球员，比如在即将对阵达拉斯牛仔队的时候，他会说：“兰德里说，我们从来没赢过‘真正的’达拉斯牛仔队。他们总能找到一些该死的借口：‘我们状态不好，有人受伤了，阳光明媚。’总有理由让我们把他们打得落花流水。”他的这番话意在激励球员，但却源于他自己觉得自己被轻视的感觉。
For some, perhaps, dismissive comments and excuses for losing to their team would mean nothing. It was different for my father; it was personal.
对某些人来说，输球后那些轻蔑的评论和借口或许无关紧要。但对我父亲来说却不同；这关乎个人恩怨。
As a young athlete, my father moved around a lot. Going to three different high schools, he never felt as if he fit in with the teams he played on; his friends were always changing. With average grades, he fell to the wayside. He grew up tough and had a left hook to prove it. Dad was an outsider; he wanted to be an insider.
我父亲年轻时是一名运动员，经常搬家。他上过三所不同的高中，始终感觉与自己所在的球队格格不入；他的朋友也总是换来换去。由于成绩平平，他逐渐被边缘化。他从小就意志坚强，一记左勾拳就是最好的证明。父亲是个局外人，但他渴望融入其中。
What he found along the way professionally, starting in his days as an assistant coach, was an unwillingness by others to “let him in.” He didn’t have the pedigree—the athletic résumé from a big-name school or assistant coaching credentials from a big college program.
从他担任助理教练开始，他在职业生涯中就发现，其他人并不愿意“接纳他”。他没有那样的资历——既没有名校的体育履历，也没有知名大学项目的助理教练资格。
He told me this story about a dinner he attended with my mother while he was a quarterbacks coach for the Cincinnati Bengals way back when. Some of the other assistant coaches talked about where they had played football—Duke, Ohio State, Alabama, and other big-name schools were mentioned, as he recalled it. When it came his turn, he said, “I played at San Jose State.” A woman at the table asked, “Is that in Mexico?”
他给我讲过这样一个故事：很久以前，他还是辛辛那提猛虎队四分卫教练的时候，有一次和我母亲一起吃饭。其他一些助理教练聊起了他们以前打球的地方——他回忆说，杜克大学、俄亥俄州立大学、阿拉巴马大学和其他一些名校都被提到了。轮到他的时候，他说：“我在圣何塞州立大学打球。” 同桌的一位女士问：“那是在墨西哥吗？”
Most of the head coaches at the major colleges and all but a very few NFL coaches had had stellar playing careers; many were already household names. In their eyes, he felt, Bill Walsh was the runt of the litter.
大多数大学橄榄球队的主教练，以及除极少数例外的NFL教练，都曾拥有辉煌的球员生涯；许多人早已是家喻户晓的人物。在他看来，比尔·沃尔什简直是其中最不起眼的一个。
This is the reason that he hid from view—never included on his professional résumé—a brief but successful tenure as head coach of the San Jose Apaches, a semipro football team that he coached very early in his career. Dad feared that others would view it as a step down, “slumming” as a coach, furthering the image that he was not big-league material.
这就是他为何刻意隐瞒——从未将其写入职业履历——早年执教半职业橄榄球队圣何塞阿帕奇队那段短暂却成功的执教经历的原因。父亲担心别人会认为这是他职业上的降级，是“屈尊”当教练，加深人们对他“不具备大联盟执教能力”的印象。
He gradually recognized that the old boys’ network that defined the NFL management and ownership in those days considered him junior grade, not up to head coach potential, in part because of his lack of a pedigree, but also because his style was not traditional, not heavy-handed. It was more professorial or corporate in style than the shouting and screaming, intimidation and punishment that were the usual tools of old-school head coaches in the league.
他逐渐意识到，在当时主导NFL管理层和老板圈的“老男孩俱乐部”里，他只是个二流人物，不具备主教练的潜质，部分原因是缺乏资历，但更重要的是，他的执教风格并非传统强硬，而是更偏向于学者式的严谨和企业化的管理，而非联盟老派主教练惯用的吼叫、恐吓和惩罚手段。
Here’s a very small example: In those days, one method of “toughening up” players was to prohibit them from drinking any water while they were on the field during practice. Bill Walsh allowed it, because he saw no gain in the policy. In fact, he felt depriving players of water during practice was counterproductive; it lowered performance. The “toughening up” approach, however, was the one owners felt comfortable with because it had been around since the start. In this and many other ways big and small, nobody had ever done it like Bill Walsh did it. His unorthodoxy put off owners who subsequently held him at arm’s length.
举个小例子：在那个年代，一种“磨练”球员意志的方法是禁止他们在训练期间在场上饮水。比尔·沃尔什对此表示赞同，因为他认为这种做法毫无益处。事实上，他认为限制球员在训练期间饮水会适得其反，降低他们的表现。然而，这种“磨练意志”的方法却让老板们感到安心，因为它由来已久。在这一点以及其他许多大大小小的方面，从来没有人像比尔·沃尔什那样行事。他的这种非传统做法让老板们感到反感，他们后来都对他敬而远之。
My father found evidence of their bias at Cincinnati, where he consistently worked wonders with the Bengals’ offense but didn’t receive a single inquiry from any NFL owner in those many years about becoming a head coach. Even the Bengals’ Paul Brown, the man for whom he was working the wonders, didn’t hire him as his replacement when he retired. Brown chose another assistant, Bill “Tiger” Johnson, who fit the conventional mold of what a head coach should do.
我父亲在辛辛那提就发现了他们偏见的证据。他在那里一直带领猛虎队的进攻组取得显著进步，但多年来，没有一位NFL老板问过他是否愿意担任主教练。就连他曾经效力过的猛虎队老板保罗·布朗，在他退休时也没有聘请他接任。布朗选择了另一位助理教练比尔·“老虎”·约翰逊，约翰逊更符合人们对传统主教练的期待。
Dad felt snubbed by the NFL, and his feelings didn’t change much as he emerged as one of football’s greatest coaches.
父亲觉得自己被 NFL 冷落了，即使他后来成为橄榄球界最伟大的教练之一，这种感觉也没有太大改变。
As San Francisco became the dominant team in the NFL, he recognized another kind of prejudice on the part of critics elsewhere—not just against San Francisco but against other teams from “way out west.” The media, especially in the eastern media capitals, were loath to admit that the center of gravity for professional football had moved to the other coast; that “backyard football” had replaced brute force coupled with the occasional long bomb pass; that a guy who looked like he belonged in a board-room or lecture hall was the top dog in coaching.
随着旧金山队成为NFL的霸主，他意识到其他地方的评论家也存在另一种偏见——不仅是针对旧金山队，也针对其他来自“遥远西部”的球队。媒体，尤其是东部媒体中心的媒体，不愿承认职业橄榄球的重心已经转移到了西海岸；“街头橄榄球”已经取代了蛮力加偶尔长传的比赛；一个看起来像是应该待在会议室或讲堂里的人，竟然成了教练界的领军人物。
The other West Coast team that won Super Bowl championships during this era, Al Davis’s Raiders, was given short shrift because Al was viewed by the league as a troublemaker, a renegade. Even though the Raiders had a more traditionally NFL style of football, they, too, were considered interlopers because they were on the “wrong” coast.
另一支在同一时期赢得超级碗冠军的西海岸球队，阿尔·戴维斯执教的奥克兰突袭者队，却受到了冷遇，因为联盟将阿尔视为一个麻烦制造者，一个叛逆者。尽管突袭者队的球风更接近传统的NFL风格，但他们也被视为外来者，因为他们身处“错误的”海岸。
My father’s irritation continued when the radical offense he created was dubbed the “West Coast Offense” by the media. The slight may have been unintentional, but perhaps not. He had been the sole creator of the brand-new offense that turned football on its head, and he hadn’t created it on the West Coast but in Ohio with the Bengals. No writer, not one, felt it appropriate to call it the Bill Walsh Offense. Even now, after all these years, that seems either intentional or uninformed.
当媒体将他一手打造的激进进攻体系称为“西海岸进攻”时，我父亲的恼火更是有增无减。这种轻视或许并非有意，但也未必。他才是这套颠覆橄榄球运动的全新进攻体系的唯一缔造者，而且这套体系并非诞生于西海岸，而是在俄亥俄州的辛辛那提猛虎队时期。没有一位作家，真的没有一位，觉得称之为“比尔·沃尔什进攻”是合适的。即便时隔多年，时至今日，这种做法仍然显得要么是故意为之，要么是出于无知。
All of this bothered my father a great deal. Regardless of what he did, it seemed the powers that be would not accord him equal status, would not recognize the legitimacy of his approach and his leadership skills. Thus, he increasingly became driven by a simple but almost obsessive goal: to prove them all wrong. And he did.
这一切都令我父亲极为苦恼。无论他做什么，当权者似乎都不愿给予他平等的地位，不愿承认他的方法和领导才能的合理性。因此，他越来越被一个简单却近乎执着的目标所驱使：证明他们都错了。而他最终做到了。
This feeling of being discriminated against was part of the reason he created the Minority Coaches Fellowship Program while he was at San Francisco. He knew that smart, skilled black college coaches were not even being considered for head coaching jobs in the NFL because of race. He understood their plight because of his own experience of being kept at arm’s length when it came to a head coaching position. He hated it and was the first head coach in the NFL to establish a formal program to address the problem by inviting talented minority coaches to observe how he did things at San Francisco. He showed them what they needed to know to operate successfully at the top level. Later, the league followed his lead with a fellowship program that expanded on what he had done.
这种被歧视的感觉是他执教旧金山期间创立少数族裔教练奖学金项目的原因之一。他深知，由于种族原因，许多才华横溢、技艺精湛的黑人大学教练甚至连NFL主教练的职位都得不到考虑。他感同身受他们的困境，因为他自己也曾有过类似的经历，在争夺主教练职位时被拒之门外。他对此深恶痛绝，并成为NFL历史上第一位设立正式项目来解决这一问题的主教练。他邀请有才华的少数族裔教练到旧金山观摩他的执教方式，向他们传授如何在顶级联赛中取得成功所需的知识。后来，联盟效仿他的做法，推出了一个在他基础上扩展的奖学金项目。
In Super Bowl XLI, the Chicago Bears faced the Indianapolis Colts. Lovie Smith was head coach of the Bears; Tony Dungy was head coach of the Colts. Both are black. Dad enjoyed seeing those two great coaches running the show. (In fact, Tony had played briefly for Dad as a 49er.) In 2009, two years later, the Pittsburgh Steelers won Super Bowl XLIII. Their young coach was Mike Tomlin. By now, the fact that a black head coach was in the Super Bowl wasn’t even a big deal. Times had changed so much. My father didn’t live long enough to see that game, but somewhere, he had to be smiling.
在第41届超级碗中，芝加哥熊队对阵印第安纳波利斯小马队。熊队的主教练是洛维·史密斯，小马队的主教练是托尼·邓吉。他们都是黑人。爸爸很喜欢看这两位伟大的教练执教。（事实上，托尼曾经短暂地效力于旧金山49人队，当时他的父亲就是托尼的教练。）两年后的2009年，匹兹堡钢人队赢得了第43届超级碗。他们的年轻教练是迈克·汤姆林。到了那时，一位黑人主教练出现在超级碗赛场上已经不再是什么稀奇事了。时代已经发生了翻天覆地的变化。我的父亲没能活到亲眼看到那场比赛，但想必他在某个地方正微笑着。
You might think all assistant coaches in the NFL have the same level of desire to become a head coach that Bill Walsh had, but the magnitude of his aspiration is impossible to overstate. He was a perfectionist, and he saw perfection as being most likely achieved only if his ideas and decisions weren’t filtered through and inevitably—in his opinion—misconstrued and misapplied by others. He had to be the one in charge.
你或许会认为NFL所有助理教练都像比尔·沃尔什那样渴望成为主教练，但他的野心之大，怎么形容都不为过。他是个完美主义者，他认为只有当他的想法和决定不被他人曲解和误用时，才最有可能达到完美。他必须掌控一切。
Oddly enough, he came to this conclusion as head coach at a little high school near San Francisco in Fremont, California, during his first two years of coaching—the Washington High Huskies. In short order, he turned a perpetual loser into a big winner. My father saw what happened when he did everything himself (including driving the team bus to away games). As you’ve read in his own words, this desire to “do it all myself ” eventually became an Achilles’ heel for him.
说来也怪，他是在加州弗里蒙特市旧金山附近一所小型高中——华盛顿高中哈士奇队——担任主教练的头两年里得出这个结论的。他很快就把一支常年垫底的球队变成了常胜之师。我父亲亲眼目睹了他事事亲力亲为（包括亲自驾驶球队大巴前往客场比赛）的后果。正如你从他自己的话中读到的，这种“事事亲力亲为”的欲望最终成了他的致命弱点。
From high school coaching he moved up by moving down: “up” to the college and NFL level, “down” as an assistant coach (i.e., secondary) position.
他从高中教练做起，一步步往上爬：“往上”到大学和 NFL 级别，“往下”担任助理教练（即后卫）职位。
Subsequently, he often saw his well-thought-out and often unconventional ideas ignored, modified, or, on occasion, screwed up by others above him. This drove him to distraction and created a smoldering desire to be in charge of everything once again—just as he was at Washington High School. Now, however, he wanted to do it at the highest level of football, where the quality of talent offered him the possibility of achieving perfection: the NFL.
随后，他常常发现自己深思熟虑、甚至有些非传统的想法被上级忽视、修改，有时甚至被搞砸。这让他心烦意乱，心中燃起一股强烈的渴望，想要再次掌控一切——就像他在华盛顿高中时那样。然而，这一次，他想在橄榄球的最高殿堂——NFL——实现这一目标，那里汇聚了顶尖人才，让他有机会达到巅峰。
There were lots of guys in the motor pool of assistant coaches around the league, but not many developed Dad’s all-consuming passion to run the show. It finally paid off when, after many years of working for and learning from Paul Brown at Cincinnati, one of the NFL’s acknowledged great minds, Dad was put in charge of virtually everything by Eddie DeBartolo, San Francisco’s young owner, the man who must be given all the credit for seeing something special in Bill Walsh.
联盟里助理教练人才济济，但像我父亲那样对球队运营充满热情的人却寥寥无几。最终，这份热情得到了回报。在辛辛那提猛虎队为保罗·布朗（NFL公认的伟大教练之一）工作多年并向他学习之后，我父亲被旧金山49人队的年轻老板埃迪·德巴托罗委以重任，几乎全权负责球队的一切事务。正是德巴托罗慧眼识珠，发现了比尔·沃尔什的非凡之处，功不可没。
Eddie was too young—thirty years old—to be part of the NFL’s good-old-boy network (the DeBartolo family had only recently purchased the San Francisco 49ers) and thus wasn’t concerned about Dad’s lack of “pedigree” or put off by the intellectual disposition of his new head coach—he liked it, in fact. Eddie was rewarded for both his perspective and his perceptive choice: Three years later, his team achieved one of the greatest turnarounds in sports history when San Francisco went from worst to best and won a Super Bowl.
埃迪当时还太年轻——只有三十岁——还没能融入NFL的“老男孩俱乐部”（德巴托罗家族不久前才收购了旧金山49人队），因此他并不在意父亲缺乏“出身”，也不排斥新任主教练的理性气质——事实上，他很喜欢这位教练。埃迪的远见卓识和敏锐眼光都得到了回报：三年后，他的球队实现了体育史上最伟大的逆转之一，旧金山49人队从垫底跃升至巅峰，并最终赢得了超级碗冠军。
Bill Walsh loved military history, including the Civil War. He had read all of the books he could find about it, and when Dad took the family to Gettysburg one year, he conducted a tour of the battlefield for us that was detailed to such a degree a paid tour guide could have learned something. He used his knowledge of military history to motivate teams and often invoked battles when, against all odds, the troops—i.e., his team—had overcome the enemy.
比尔·沃尔什热爱军事史，尤其是美国内战史。他几乎读遍了所有能找到的相关书籍。有一年，父亲带全家去葛底斯堡，他亲自为我们讲解了战场，讲解之详尽，连专业导游都可能自愧不如。他运用自己的军事史知识激励团队，经常会讲述一些战役，讲述他的团队如何力挽狂澜，战胜敌人。
He was a PhD-level motivator with a powerful ability to get people’s attention and point them in the right direction. Military analogies were useful occasionally, but he had a full bag of other options. Some are amusing. As head coach of the San Jose Apaches, a group of cast-offs and wan nabes who all felt they deserved to be playing at a higher level (specifically, the NFL), Dad made the following statement in his first meeting with the team: “Fellas, I want you to think about something: There’s a reason you’re all in this room today.” He paused as his implied message—“Nobody out there thinks you’re any good”—sank in. Then he continued with a solemn warning: “This is your last chance to prove you don’t belong here.”
他是一位博士级别的激励大师，拥有强大的能力，能够吸引人们的注意力并引导他们走向正确的方向。军事类比偶尔会奏效，但他还有很多其他方法。有些例子颇为有趣。作为圣何塞阿帕奇队的主教练，这支队伍由一群被淘汰的球员和渴望成名的年轻人组成，他们都觉得自己应该在更高的水平（具体来说，就是NFL）打球。在与球队的第一次会议上，父亲说了这样一番话：“伙计们，我想让你们好好想想：你们今天聚集在这里是有原因的。”他停顿了一下，让大家消化他话里的弦外之音——“外面没人觉得你们有多厉害”。然后，他继续郑重地警告道：“这是你们证明自己不属于这里的最后一次机会。”
And regardless of the approach he used, Bill Walsh would not degrade individuals. While he was very careful in handing out compliments (that is, he was a master of withholding praise), he constantly focused attention on the next level of commitment and sacrifice and performance. One of his tactics occurred during the team meeting the night before a game. He didn’t give a big rah-rah speech but incited players with his own method: One by one, selectively, he called players out for commitment: “Keith Fahnhorst, if I call 90-O tomorrow, can we count on you to hold your block?” Fahnhorst was a tackle; 90-O was a play that needed him to block. “Can you promise you’ll knock somebody on his ass if I call 90-O, Keith?”
无论他采用何种方式，比尔·沃尔什都不会贬低任何人。他非常谨慎地给予赞扬（也就是说，他是一位吝于表扬的高手），但他始终将注意力集中在更高层次的投入、牺牲和表现上。他的一个策略发生在比赛前一晚的球队会议上。他没有发表慷慨激昂的演讲，而是用自己的方式激励球员：他有选择地逐一点名，要求球员们做出承诺：“基思·法恩霍斯特，如果我明天叫90-O战术，你能保证做好掩护吗？”法恩霍斯特是一名进攻截锋；90-O战术需要他进行掩护。“基思，你能保证如果我叫90-O战术，你一定能把对方球员撞倒在地吗？”
He’d go through the roster like that: “Ray [Wersching, 49ers field-goal specialist], how long can we count on you for tomorrow? Can you deliver forty-seven yards at the end of the game if we need it? Don’t say yes unless you’re sure. I need to know absolutely I can count on you, Ray. Can I?” On and on, commitments, publicly to their team, of high performance in the coming battle.
他会这样逐条询问队员：“雷（沃辛，49人队的任意球专家），明天我们能指望你多久？如果比赛最后需要，你能踢进那47码吗？除非你确定，否则别轻易答应。雷，我需要绝对信任你。真的可以吗？” 就这样，队员们不断向队友公开承诺，将在即将到来的比赛中发挥出色。
He was also frank about admitting his own mistakes. After a game, at the next meeting, he would review what had gone right and wrong with the whole team. While he didn’t pull any punches when reviewing their individual performances, he was also forthright when it came to his own work. He would tell them where he had made mistakes: “I should have done this instead of what I called,” he’d say. There was no culture of seeking scapegoats, no failure and finger pointing. It was very matter-of-fact: We did this wrong; here’s how we do it right. He would critique himself equally hard in winning and losing, always leaving room for improvement. Improvement was his obsession—always looking for ways to improve his coaching, his team, his organization.
他也很坦诚地承认自己的错误。每场比赛结束后，在下次会议上，他会回顾全队的比赛，分析哪些地方做得好，哪些地方做得不好。在评价队员的个人表现时，他毫不留情，对自己的工作也同样直言不讳。他会指出自己的错误：“我应该这样做，而不是那样指挥，”他会这样说。这里没有寻找替罪羊的风气，也没有失败后互相指责的现象。一切都非常务实：我们做错了；这是正确的做法。无论输赢，他都会同样严格地审视自己，始终留有改进的空间。改进是他的执念——他总是想方设法提升自己的执教水平、团队和组织。
Twelve O’Clock High , starring Gregory Peck, was one of his favorite movies and inspired him a great deal. Eventually, after his retirement, he described to me the similarity he felt between General Frank Savage (Peck’s character in the movie) and his own situation and trajectory at San Francisco.
由格里高利·派克主演的《正午十二点》是他最喜欢的电影之一，对他影响深远。最终，在他退休后，他向我描述了他感觉弗兰克·萨维奇将军（派克在电影中饰演的角色）与他在旧金山的处境和经历之间的相似之处。
The film is about an American bomber group in England during World War II that is suffering extreme problems. Leadership is poor; casualties are high; morale is low; their luck is bad. General Savage comes in and, against long odds, turns the bomber group around, installing discipline, high performance, and good morale while leading raid after successful raid over Germany. But the personal toll is high as he sees friends killed and good men destroyed in various ways in combat.
这部电影讲述的是二战期间驻扎在英国的一支美国轰炸机大队遭遇的困境。指挥混乱，伤亡惨重，士气低落，运气也极差。萨维奇将军临危受命，力挽狂澜，扭转了轰炸机大队的颓势。他建立了严明的纪律，提高了作战效率，鼓舞了士气，并率领部队对德国发动了一次又一次成功的空袭。然而，他个人也付出了沉重的代价，亲眼目睹战友阵亡，许多优秀的士兵在战斗中以各种方式牺牲。
The raids continue day after day, until one morning, as the crews of the bomber group—the 918th Flying Fortresses—are climbing into their planes for another attack, Savage finds that he is unable to lift himself into his B-17 bomber to lead them into battle. Having led his fliers to victory, he is emotionally gutted—a basket case who is taken to a hospital ward to recover.
空袭日复一日地持续着，直到一天早晨，当轰炸机大队——第918飞行堡垒轰炸机大队——的机组人员正准备登上飞机进行又一次攻击时，萨维奇却发现自己无法再爬进他的B-17轰炸机，带领他们投入战斗。尽管他带领飞行员取得了胜利，但他却精神崩溃，情绪极度低落，被送往医院病房休养。
Substitute the San Francisco 49ers for the 918th Bomber Group, football players for flight crews, Coach Bill Walsh for General Frank Savage, retirement for the hospital ward, and you get the idea. My father loved that movie because it told the story of what he did in football, and what happened to him as a result, in the context of something he loved—the military.
把旧金山49人队换成第918轰炸机大队，把橄榄球运动员换成飞行员，把比尔·沃尔什教练换成弗兰克·萨维奇将军，把退休换成医院病房，你就明白我的意思了。我父亲很喜欢这部电影，因为它讲述了他打橄榄球的经历，以及由此给他带来的后果，而这一切都发生在他所热爱的——军队——的背景之下。
It is in the framework of this dichotomy, extreme success as a leader in the NFL and extreme distress as a person, that makes Dad’s story so compelling, his lessons in leadership so valuable. His staggering drive to prevail—to “prove them all wrong”—his ferocious competitive instinct, and his singular brilliance as a strategist, organizer, and team builder produced historic results. The blueprint for his kind of leadership is revealed in this book.
正是这种矛盾的对比——作为NFL领袖的巨大成功与作为普通人的巨大痛苦——使得父亲的故事如此引人入胜，他传授的领导力经验如此宝贵。他惊人的求胜欲望——“证明所有人都错了”——他强烈的竞争本能，以及他作为战略家、组织者和团队建设者的卓越才能，共同创造了历史性的成就。本书揭示了他这种领导力的蓝图。
The lessons he shares in The Score Takes Care of Itself are both a beacon for leadership and a cautionary tale—what to do and what not to do. But isn’t that the subject all effective leaders dwell on? Isn’t it the perpetual puzzle of their leadership?
他在《分数自会水落石出》一书中分享的经验教训，既是领导力的灯塔，也是一个警示故事——告诉人们应该做什么，不应该做什么。但这难道不是所有高效领导者都在思考的问题吗？这难道不是他们领导力中永恒的谜题吗？
My father was a complex man, but he had a simple goal. Although the price was high, he achieved his goal, and as the years rolled by following his retirement, he gained peace and pride, great satisfaction and contentment, within himself. No longer an outsider in his mind, he saw that his philosophy and methodology were held in the highest esteem; his radical system the norm; his approach to team building commonplace. And that many considered him the greatest football coach of all time. At the end, he was lecturing about his ideas on leadership for graduate students at Stanford University.
我的父亲是个复杂的人，但他的目标却很简单。尽管代价高昂，他最终实现了目标。退休后，岁月流逝，他内心充满了平静、自豪、满足和喜悦。他不再觉得自己是个局外人，而是看到自己的理念和方法备受推崇；他那套激进的体系已成为常态；他打造团队的方式也广为人知。许多人甚至认为他是史上最伟大的橄榄球教练。晚年，他还在斯坦福大学为研究生们讲授他的领导力理念。
I’ve told people that my father didn’t need a traditional family; his real family was football. And it was almost true. His commitment to the team, his organization, and its goals was total. Bill Walsh may not have sold his soul to the company store, but he leased it to the game he loved for many years.
我曾跟人说过，我父亲不需要传统意义上的家庭；他真正的家人是橄榄球。这话几乎没错。他对球队、俱乐部以及球队目标的投入是百分之百的。比尔·沃尔什或许没有把灵魂出卖给俱乐部，但他确实把自己的灵魂奉献给了他所热爱的这项运动多年。
My sister and I were there with my father on his final day. He was so weak, but still so strong in spirit. I whispered in his ear that it was okay to go, that the time had come and we loved him. Dad closed his eyes and was gone. He was brave as hell. I put my arms around him and my sister, Elizabeth, and I wept. His triumphs had been recognized for many years. He knew he was no longer an outsider.
我和姐姐陪在父亲身边，走完了他生命的最后一程。他当时身体很虚弱，但精神依然无比坚强。我轻声在他耳边说，你可以走了，时候到了，我们都爱他。爸爸闭上眼睛，走了。他勇敢得令人难以置信。我拥抱了他和姐姐伊丽莎白，泪流满面。他的成就早已为人所知，他知道自己不再是局外人了。
My father is gone, but his hard-earned leadership lessons remain in place, perhaps more relevant now than ever before. I know he would hope that something in his own experience, as shared in this book, is of value in your own challenges as a leader. It would mean that once again he was able to do what he loved doing and did so well: teach others how to be as great as they can be.
我的父亲虽然离世，但他毕生积累的领导经验却依然历久弥新，或许在今天比以往任何时候都更具现实意义。我知道他会希望，本书中分享的他自身的经历，能够对您作为领导者所面临的挑战有所裨益。这意味着他能够再次做他热爱且擅长的事情：教导他人如何发挥自身最大潜能。

command skills
